HEADLINE: Study on H.M.O.'s Targets the State 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE 

 BODY:
WHILE health maintenance organization plans are starting to lose favor around the United States, they are booming in New Haven and Meriden, so much so that last year that region had a higher percentage of H.M.O. patients than any other metropolitan area in the country, according to a study released last week.
 Between July 1999 and July 2000, H.M.O. plans across the United States lost 700,000 people. But in the New Haven-Meriden area, H.M.O. plans gained 55,533 people during that period, continuing a four-year rise. 
 More than 73 percent of the population in New Haven and Meriden, or 397,651 enrollees out of 542,474 people who live there, were patients in 1 of 10 H.M.O. plans last year. 
The statistics were part of a new report by InterStudy Publications of St. Paul. The company analyzes health insurance data from surveys and state records and sells its reports to businesses that track industry changes, Caryn Mohr, a research specialist at InterStudy, said.
InterStudy did not analyze the reason for the H.M.O. boom in New Haven and Meriden. But the increase coincided with an economic boom there, especially in research and biotechnology companies.
From 1996 to 2000, the labor force grew by 8 percent after steady losses in the early 1990's. In 2000 alone, the labor force in the New Haven-Meriden area grew 4.2 percent compared with a national growth of 1.4 percent that year.
"That corridor from Meriden to New Haven has really become the biotech cradle in Connecticut," said Keith Stover, a lobbyist for the Connecticut Association of Health Plans. "They've experienced some extraordinary growth in employment."
Mr. Stover said H.M.O.'s are popular in Connecticut because health care here is expensive. Prescription drugs and hospital care are the costliest elements, he said.
Mr. Stover said another factor is that in 1997 the state passed a law allowing H.M.O. patients to take grievances to outside arbiters at the state government's expense. The arbiters can order an H.M.O. to pay even if the H.M.O. had initially refused.
In a survey about patients' attitudes, the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation found that people generally complain about H.M.O.'s although they like their own H.M.O. plans. Mr. Stover said his experience reinforced that conclusion.
"The rhetoric around managed care and H.M.O.'s is sort of like the rhetoric around Congress," Mr. Stover said. "Everybody hates Congress and loves their congressman. People generally like their H.M.O.'s, but think managed care, generally, really stinks."
The largest H.M.O. company in Connecticut is Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which had 58 percent of the H.M.O. patients in New Haven and Meriden as of last July, InterStudy said. In second place was Physicians Health Services of Connecticut with 22 percent, Ms. Mohr said.
Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield has grown tremendously in two years, from 90,079 H.M.O. enrollees in New Haven and Meriden on July 1, 1997 to 230,590 on July 1, 2000. Statewide, Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield has more than 444,000 H.M.O. customers and nearly 1.2 million customers for all of its plans, said Carol Pompano, public relations manager.
Ms. Pompano said there are several reasons for the growth, including that about 60,000 of the company's H.M.O. customers are state employees (some of whom work in Meriden and New Haven), and that small businesses like the company's plans.
The other companies providing H.M.O. plans for the New Haven-Meriden area are MedSpan Health Options, HealthChoice of Connecticut, Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, ConnectiCare Inc., CIGNA HealthCare of Connecticut, Aetna U.S. Healthcare of Connecticut, and Prudential HealthCare H.M.O., a member company of Aetna U.S. Healthcare.
Total H.M.O. enrollment in the northeast dropped by almost 2 percent last year while Meriden and New Haven's grew by about 8 percent. In 1997, H.M.O. patients in the New Haven-Meriden area made up 39 percent of the population. In 1998 the percentage rose to 58. Then in 1999 the percentage was more than 65. It is one of few urban regions in the northeast where H.M.O. enrollments are so high. Most H.M.O. strongholds are in California.
The next-highest concentration of H.M.O. patients is in Sacramento, Calif., where 1,169,129 people, nearly 72 percent of the population, use H.M.O.'s. Close behind are three more California urban areas: Oakland, San Francisco, and the Vallejo-Fairfield-Napa area. Between 70 and 71 percent of the population use H.M.O.'s in these areas.
Other areas where many people chose H.M.O. plans included Jackson, Tenn., and Rochester, both with just under 70 percent, the Buffalo-Niagara Falls area in New York with just under 65 percent. In ninth place was Madison, Wis., with over 64 percent, and 10th was the Stockton-Lodi area in California with nearly 62 percent.
The Worcester, Mass. area, which includes parts of north-central Connecticut, came in 14th with an H.M.O. concentration rate of nearly 59 percent. The Fitchburg-Leominster area in Massachusetts was 15th with 57 and a half percent.
Nationally, H.M.O. patients in urban areas accounted for just more than 32 percent of the general urban population, or nearly 73 million H.M.O. patients out of an urban population of 225 million. That rate decreased by 1.4 percent from what it was between 1998 and 1999, InterStudy said.
About 80 million people use H.M.O.'s nationwide.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Island's Economy Still Hums Along

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
LLOYD STAFFING of Melville is currently screening applicants to fill three openings for controllers at Long Island companies, at salaries ranging from $65,000 to $145,000. Merrill Banks, Lloyd's president, said his recruiters were being highly selective. 
 "If a company is looking for a vice president of finance, they want to see a vice president of finance at a company more or less the same size as theirs," Mr. Banks said. "They don't want to take a qualified assistant vice president. They're not thinking out of the box these days." 
 Spooked by the possibility that today's hire could become tomorrow's layoff, Long Island companies are more cautious in their hiring, Mr. Banks said. After spending most of the 90's complaining that labor shortages were impeding growth, many are now postponing hiring decisions. 
"Clients are saying they're doing well, but still they are both more cautious and less flexible in hiring," Mr. Banks said. "The talk in the marketplace is about being prepared should things get worse."
So Lloyd Staffing, which specializes in filling jobs in sales, information technology, biotechnology, office services, accounting and finance, has fewer positions to fill. "Last year, we did over 400 placements by the end of May," Mr. Banks said. "This year at the same time, we were at 350."
As the year's midway point approaches, the Long Island economy seems to be lagging behind last year's pace, although it is still outpacing the national economy. "If we see a slowing of the economy on Long Island, it is a moderate slowing," said Dr. Pearl Kamer, the chief economist at the Long Island Association, the regional chamber of commerce.
In May, the unemployment rate was 2.5 percent in Nassau County and 2.7 percent in Suffolk, about the same as last year. By comparison, the rate was 4.0 percent in New York State and 4.1 percent in the United States at large. 
"Unemployment currently is about as low as it can get," Dr. Kamer said, referring to the Long Island figures. "We haven't had major layoffs, and in fact we have had a net gain in jobs. My guess is that the national economy will start to recover in the first quarter of next year. The local economy may not get the chance to slow down before the national economy recovers."
In other words, the national economy will pick up before Long Island slows down, thus averting a regional slowdown. 
According to State Labor Department figures, Nassau and Suffolk added 21,500 jobs in the 12 months ending in May, a 1.8 percent increase. All but 200 of the new jobs were in the service sector. "We have diversified from a manufacturing economy to one based on a broad array of services," Dr. Kamer said. "The new jobs being produced are high-wage jobs. We have diversified very well, and this is the strength of today's economy."
Nevertheless, the biggest gains in the service sector came in retailing, traditionally a low-paying field. Here, 4,800 jobs were added, many of them at garden centers. The next-largest gains came in education, which added 3,900 jobs. Social-service jobs grew by 2,500; transportation and public utilities by 1,800. 
The biggest contraction came in the government sector. Federal jobs on Long Island shrank by 2,800, mostly census workers. State jobs grew by 400 and local government jobs by 3,300, mostly teachers.
Manufacturing lost 2,100 jobs, more than half of them in equipment manufacturing, continuing a trend that has been going on for decades. Printing and publishing lost about 600 jobs.
While the regional economy continues to hum along by most economic indicators, optimism is tempered by the realities of the flagging national economy, weakness in major capital markets and increased energy costs. "When energy prices go up, it affects us materially on Long Island," said Dr. Irwin L. Kellner, the chief economist at North Fork Bancorp in Melville.
Exactly how strong Long Island's economy is has become something of a political issue. State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, said in a report released June 13 that Governor Pataki was ignoring high energy and housing costs. But earlier this month when the governor visited Long Island, he introduced new mortgage and energy programs. Mr. Pataki, who will probably run for a third term, denied Mr. McCall's charges through a spokesman. 
Pointing to other areas of concern, Dr. Kellner cited Conference Board statistics for the New York metropolitan region that showed a drop in help-wanted advertising of 34.6 percent during the 12-month period ending in April.
"Businesses are under severe pressure to cut costs any way they can, because they cannot pass along energy-cost increases," he said. "We have to keep our fingers crossed that business doesn't push the panic button and start another round of layoffs." 
The Long Island Association, which contends that an expanding labor force is essential to ensuring long-term regional economic growth, is playing down the likelihood of layoffs. "Companies have spent a lot of money building their labor force during times when labor has been tight," Dr. Kamer said. "They made a huge investment in human capital, and they are looking for ways to maintain that investment."
In fact, there are signs hiring is rebounding. At Sigma Staffing in Melville, hiring is up by as much as 25 percent in the second quarter, said Thea Linker, the president. "Our clients are telling us we should recruit more because they say they are going to hire more," she said. 
Dr. Kamer said that steady employment, accumulated stock-market gains and widespread consumer confidence in the region were keeping the housing market strong. Prices remain stable or are rising slightly in most communities, she said, and she expects that the housing market will continue to be buoyed during the second half of the year by the sale of starter houses. 
Dorothy Herman, an owner of Prudential Long Island Realty in Huntington, said that sales had been brisk. Several weeks ago, she said, she put her father's house in Franklin Square on the market and received six offers within days.
"Last year, people were bidding above the asking price," Ms. Herman said. "Not this year. But except for the East End, the housing market is strong. We are getting more listings. Last month was the strongest month in terms of revenue since I opened the company," in 1989.
On the commercial side, the office vacancy rate is edging up, reflecting both the volume of new space coming onto the market -- more than 1.5 million square feet since the economic expansion began in 1992. In the first quarter of this year, the overall office vacancy rate on Long Island was 9.3 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield. A year ago during the same period, it was 8.8 percent.
While demand remains strong for large chunks of office space, beginning at 500,000 square feet, smaller configurations, the kind generally rented by small and midsize companies, are becoming harder for landlords to lease. 
Or as David Pennetta, a partner in Oxford & Simpson Realty in Jericho, put it, "I've had a little more time to improve my golf game." 
Having grown used to the idea that the region couldn't put up new office space fast enough to meet demand, some real estate brokers and leasing agents are troubled by the symbolism of empty space. For example, in Great River, nearly a third of the Long Island Technology Center, ostensibly ground zero in the region's information technology boom, is vacant. 
So caution prevails. Apart from Sigma, other staffing companies say that employers are cutting back on part-time and temporary workers. At Thisco in Woodbury, which finances the payrolls for more than 200 staffing companies across the country, Marty Orenstein, Thisco's director, said that on Long Island, staffing company payrolls were down by 15 to 40 percent. 
Medical office support is down the least, Mr. Orenstein said, and "information technology is down the most." 
Bill Heather, the vice president for Long Island at Right Management Consultants, a Philadelphia company that provides employer-financed outplacement services for people who have lost their jobs, said that searches were taking longer these days: two weeks longer for middle-management positions, three or four weeks for senior management.
"When companies reduce the number of their employees, our business improves," said Mr. Heather, who has an office in Melville. "And lately, business has been good."

HEADLINE: Impending Lease Reignites Talk of a Rte. 110 Hub at Airport 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
THE proposed site of a transportation hub that might be built around the old rail station at Republic Airport in East Farmingdale is about to be leased, and that has lighted a fire under those seeking to ease traffic congestion along Route 110 at the Nassau-Suffolk border.
 News of the planned lease was announced at a meeting June 15 of Action 110 Long Island. The chairman of the group, Sheldon R. Sackstein, said immediately that he would fight the move. Last week, officials from the Towns of Huntington and Babylon, together with the Long Island Association, joined the chorus. 
 "We have been talking about a number of issues for some time now, but the possibility that this site would be lost forever spurred the reaction we've seen in the last few days," said Steven Bellone, a Babylon councilman. He and another Babylon councilman, Wayne R. Horsley, said there was general agreement that the Long Island Rail Road station at Republic Airport -- a station closed in 1986 -- should be reopened and the site developed into a major transportation hub. 
Mr. Bellone said that until the director of Republic Airport, Hugh D. Jones, confirmed plans to lease the station property at the Action 110 meeting, he had "only heard rumblings" about it. 
"He created the impression that this deal was already wrapped up," Mr. Bellone said. "But we're now speaking with state leaders in Albany about this, and I suspect that someone at the Department of Transportation is going to put the brakes on this and say, 'We should take a look at it.' "
At the meeting, Mr. Jones noted that the train station, which is on Conklin Street just east of Route 110, was part of the 530-acre Republic Airport complex. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the L.I.R.R.'s parent, acquired it in 1969 from the Fairchild Engine Manufacturing Company after it closed its operations there. 
Ownership of the complex was transferred to the state Department of Transportation in April 1983, and Mr. Jones said there were now plans to lease the station property to a private developer, which plans to build stores there.
"It is irresponsible of D.O.T. to not have looked at the efficiencies that could have been made to traffic" had the station been used as a transportation hub, Mr. Sackstein told him. "Why shouldn't people who want to do inter-island commuting have a train station at one of the most populated sections of Long Island?"
Mr. Sackstein said he planned to enlist the support of Governor Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer to convince the Department of Transportation not to lease the property. Just a few minutes earlier, Mr. Schumer, the New York Democrat, had addressed the group and announced his conditional support for reopening the train station.
"The idea of an additional railroad station at Republic makes a great deal of sense," he said, but he added that such a project would need community support.
Mr. Schumer, who has a senatorial office at 145 Pinelawn Road, just off Route 110, said there was no chance of getting federal financing this year to relieve traffic congestion on Route 110. But he said federal transportation money would be available in 2003 and that he would like the group to have a budget proposal to him by January for a comprehensive plan for Route 110.
"If the community is truly behind it, I will go to bat for you," he said. 
But Mr. Jones said in an interview after the meeting that the lease was scheduled to be signed at the end of the month. He said Mairoll Inc., a part of the Fairchild Corporation, would lease 12.5 acres of the former train station property.
Mairoll, which owns a shopping center, Airport Plaza, on a 91-acre parcel across the street from the station, would like to put up two more buildings totaling 112,000 square feet on the station property, Mr. Jones said. The rest of the 12.5 acres would be set aside for parking.
A "conceptual agreement was reached" last May to lease the property, he said. He would not say how much Mairoll had agreed to pay. 
In a separate deal, Mairoll would sell the state 11.3 acres of its Airport Plaza property that is now used for a parking lot at the eastern end of the site, abutting Jillian's Entertainment Inc. Mr. Jones said the land was needed to provide a runway safety area.
In 1992, a USAir flight "went off the runway at La Guardia and into the bay," Mr. Jones said. "If there had been an adequate runway safety area," he added, "it would not have gone into the water. So the Federal Aviation Administration said airports need safety areas at the end of their runways. When we started doing a master plan for the airport in 1997, the F.A.A. asked where our runway safety area was."
He said that after the Fairchild Corporation straightened out Conklin Street in 1999, that made it possible for the airport to use a strip 1,000 feet long and 500 feet wide as a safety area. 
The federal government agreed to give the state a total of $14.3 million to buy the land and prepare the site. At the end of the last fiscal year, Congress appropriated $4.355 million for the transaction and added another $5 million on June 1. Mr. Jones said that when the next fiscal year begins Oct. 1, he hoped that Congress would appropriate the remainder of the money.
As part of the transaction, the Town of Babylon and the Farmingdale school district would get payments in lieu of taxes from Mairoll for the leased property. Those payments would total $300,000 to $350,000 annually, Mr. Jones said.
Mr. Bellone, the councilman, took issue with Mairoll's plans for more stores, arguing that they would only compound Route 110's traffic problems. He asked how many jobs might be lost if traffic congestion was not eased. 
"Companies would not want to move onto the Route 110 corridor," he said, and some already there might move out. 
"If we don't address the traffic problem quickly, we're going to lose a lot more revenue than that," Mr. Bellone said.
Gary Lewi, a spokesman for Republic Airport, said that ultimately it would be up to the Long Island Rail Road to decide if it wants to reopen the airport station. He pointed out that the railroad has another station in Farmingdale that is only a mile away and questioned whether it would be cost-effective to reopen the one at the airport. 
Nick LaRocco, a railroad spokesman, said the Republic Airport station was a small one that was created to serve the employees of Fairchild Republic. He said Ken Bauer, the railroad's president, was examining the feasibility of reopening it. "If it makes sense to have a station there, it will happen," he said.
The idea of placing a similar transportation hub at the Huntington railroad station at the north end of Route 110 was proposed last week by Huntington Town Councilman Mark A. Cuthbertson. 
"It is already a transportation hub, but we could offer more amenities to allow commuting into Melville," Mr. Cuthbertson said. "This comes at an opportune time for us because we are working on revitalization plans for Huntington Station, and as we do that, we want them to fit into the regional plans."
The Towns of Huntington and Babylon formed the Route 110 Redevelopment Corporation three years ago to deal with regional issues, particularly economic development, along the Route 110 corridor. 
"It quickly became apparent that transportation and traffic issues were the No. 1 challenge that needs to be met to sustain economic growth along the corridor," Mr. Cuthbertson said.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Haverstraw; 
A Village Intent on Reviving Past Renown

BYLINE:  By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
MICHELLE AND JOSEPH NATALE grew up in the hilly Rockland County village of Haverstraw. Mrs. Natale, an officer at M & T Bank in Tarrytown, said she had childhood memories of "a quaint little village for children and adults with a busy shopping district and main street." By the time she and her husband, a payment processor for Orange and Rockland Utilities, married and settled in their first home in 1971, things were different.
 Little more than remnants remained of the village's handsome, turn-of-the-century architecture. Haverstraw was once the brick-making capital of the world, but many of its residents had lost their jobs and homes when the local clay ran out in the early part of the century, and other construction materials, like steel, became more popular. 
 Mrs. Natale said she had always wanted to move away, "but our roots are here." So as her family grew, she moved up a house size, deliberately choosing not to leave. 
Then this winter, instead of making a move now that her children are grown, Mrs. Natale, 50, traded her ranch for a 150-year-old, four-bedroom mansard colonial on Hudson Avenue with the thought of turning it into a bed and breakfast. "With all the talk of revitalization here, with the idea of things turning around, I thought it would be a good investment opportunity as well as a way to fulfill a lifelong dream," she said. "I always hoped Haverstraw would turn around, and when it does, I want to be part of it."
Like the Natales, Melissa Salmon-Saravia, and her husband, Giovanni, who own IMF Services, a mortgage and insurance business in Stony Point, were seeking a good real estate investment in March when they found Haverstraw. They were looking to move out of their apartment in Tompkins Cove in Rockland to buy their first home.
"We were looking in surrounding areas," Ms. Salmon-Saravia said. "But mostly we tried to stick to Haverstraw because of its up and coming plans. We did lots of research on different homes and streets that we thought would be profitable in the future." The couple settled on a turn-of-the-century two-family Georgian Victorian on Hudson Street. "If all goes as planned, it's going to be a good investment in the future," Ms. Salmon-Saravia said.
For years investors, real estate developers and the village government have yearned to reinvent Haverstraw using its picturesque two miles of waterfront as a strong magnet. The mayor, Francis J. Wassmer, known as Bud, said the village is getting closer to its goal.
Last fall a ferry began operating, linking the village with Ossining in affluent Westchester County across the Hudson.
Abandoned industrial sites along Haverstraw's Hudson riverfront have been demolished to make way for 850 units of upscale housing and a public promenade. It is hoped that construction will begin within a year, Mayor Wassmer said.
Besides sprucing up its waterfront, Haverstraw has been fixing up its downtown with new facades and has lured several new businesses in the last few months, including cafes, antique dealers and boutiques. Over the last three years the number of crimes reported in the village has been cut in half.
"Haverstraw has not only more than two miles of Hudson River frontage, but also the background of High Tor Mountain," the tallest peak in the Palisades, which at 832 feet seems to tower over Haverstraw, Mayor Wassmer said. "It looks like a European village. Sure, it's been underutilized and gone through hard times, but there's no question that with the right impetus the beauty and charm of the village will come back to life in ways that will be nicer than Nyack, with a distinct Hispanic flavor."
Comparisons with neighboring Nyack are often heard in Haverstraw. Jo Baer, owner of Baer & McIntosh Real Estate in Nyack, said: "In the 1960's, Nyack was a fledgling Hudson River village, like Haverstraw, in need of restoration and rehabilitation of its housing stock. But over the years it's grown to be a thriving, diverse, cultural community that takes advantage of its riverfront." The market has soared in Nyack, she said, with not enough housing stock available for all the people who want to move there.
But Edna I. Rivera, the executive director of Housing Opportunities for Growth, Advancement and Rehabilitation, a community economic development agency, who ran against the mayor in the last election, said she was worried about how Haverstraw's revitalization plans would affect Hispanic residents, the majority in the village.
"We are hoping that the gatekeepers of this village will ensure that this development will benefit its residents first because we are faced with a very big dilemma," Ms. Rivera said. "Essentially, this proposed redevelopment will change the cultural life of this village and its demographic face."
Families are already being forced to flee Haverstraw because rents have gone up, she said. Of 137 businesses in the village, she said, 69 have Hispanic owners or managers."These businessmen," she said, "stand to lose their livelihood."
Rafael Gonzalez, 66, owns 50 Broadway Grocery, which opened in 1977, one of many bodegas in the village. Though he is treasurer of the Hispanic Merchants Association, formed six months ago, he said he did not know whether he would have time to attend classes that Rockland Community College is offering to help Hispanic business owners adapt to change. His day begins at 6 a.m. and ends at midnight. If his business ultimately fails, Mr. Gonzalez said, "I do not know how to start again; I don't know how to do anything else."
For her part, Dona Coene, who just opened the Soup Stone Cafe, said: "If I run out of stuff, I always go to the local bodega. They always have something I need. I think that's what's so special about Haverstraw. We're all working together to make the village work."
EMILY MARTIN, a broker at Prudential Rand Realty in Stony Point, said, "With all the excitement going on, everything on the market is very active, especially multifamily homes," which, according to the mayor, account for almost 70 percent of the village housing stock. "But single-family homes priced right sell in a day," Ms. Martin said.
This month, she said, a small three-bedroom, one-bath colonial on a tenth of an acre without a garage sold for $160,000, more than $5,000 above its asking price.
Susan Bova, owner of Country Sun Realty in Garnerville, said 1,200-square-foot, two- or three-bedroom handyman specials in the village range from $119,000 to $150,000. Larger colonials, or Cape Cods in better condition, bring $150,000 to $200,000. In the $200,000 to $300,000 range, buyers can choose from Victorian homes and smaller multifamily homes, which Ms. Bova called "a great investment." Larger multifamily homes range from $300,000 to $350,000.
Other housing options include 250 attached, three-bedroom town homes at Village on the Green that range from $160,000 to $189,000. There are also 90 condominium units at the Village Mill, the former site of the Long Life Webbing Company, which made suspenders that G.I.'s used to carry their packs during World War II. Ms. Bova said a two-bedroom, one-story unit there started at $130,000. A three-story, two-bedroom town house brings $180,000.
Ms. Martin said two-bedroom apartments in the village's several small buildings rent for $700 to $1,200 a month and could reach $1,700 in multifamily homes .
The houses of worship in the village are as diverse as its housing stock. There are Roman Catholic churches that celebrate Spanish and Polish masses as well as Methodist, Pentecostal and Presbyterian churches.
Haverstraw's cultural and economic diversity is an asset to the Haverstraw-Stony Point School District, generally known as the North Rockland School District, after the district's high school, said Dr. Dodge Watkins, the superintendent.
The 7,884 students of the district come not only from Haverstraw but also from Stony Point, Garnerville, West Haverstraw and parts of Pomona and Highland Falls. Of the total, almost a third are eligible for free or reduced-price lunches. Students get "a unique, real-life situation here," he said. "Their differences are our strength and lead the district to create many new and innovative programs."
The district, which has five elementary schools, including Gerald F. Neary in the village; three middle schools, of which Haverstraw Middle School is in the village; and one high school, offers everything from prekindergarten classes and a special education program to an ability to study the stars first hand in the planetarium.
"We're a full-service comprehensive school system," Dr. Watkins said. "One of our testimonials is that we're one of the fastest-growing districts in the region."
Of this year's 436 graduating seniors at North Rockland High School, 41 percent will go on to four-year colleges and 52 percent to two-year colleges. The latest College Board scores for the district, from the spring of 2000, were 497 in verbal and 493 in math, very close to the state averages.
The school is far above average, however, in its performance in sports, which are enthusiastically supported by the community. Since 1993, North Rockland has won state championships in football, baseball, girls soccer and girls volleyball.
There are several parks in the village. Mayor Wassmer said a $500,000 renovation would begin later this year at the five-acre, riverfront Emeline Park, where a children's section and lighted trails will be built.
Dutch farmers first settled in Haverstraw, a land of rich blue and yellow clay, in 1666. By 1771, the first brick-making operation opened. Other brickyards soon followed to keep up with orders from New York City. By 1883, Haverstraw was so renowned for making bricks that, in that year alone, 2,400 men worked in the brickyards, producing more than 302 million bricks.
The village was incorporated in 1854. With its clay deposits stripped, Haverstraw brickyards barely remained open during the 1920's. Its last brickyard closed in 1941.
Mrs. Natale, whose memories of Haverstraw go back to her childhood, is hopeful about the village's future, and her own. "I know right now it's hard to envision Haverstraw needing a bed and breakfast," she said. "But I'm beginning to get inquiries about people needing a place to stay for class reunions and weddings." She hopes to open her doors next year

HEADLINE: After 7 Years of Planning, Memorial to Irish Famine Is Ready 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS STAUDTER 

 BODY:
WHEN the Great Hunger Memorial of Westchester County is unveiled on Tuesday in V. E. Macy Park in Ardsley, it will be the culmination of an effort by community leaders and elected officials to commemorate the suffering and, ultimately, the courage of millions of Irish immigrants and others who arrived on our shores looking for a new life.
 The memorial, a multiform sculpture created by the Irish artist Eamonn O'Doherty, is also meant to call attention to the fact that "hunger shouldn't exist in a land of plenty," said James J. Houlihan, chairman of the Great Hunger Memorial Committee. Along with raising more than $600,000 for the memorial, a charitable foundation connected to the project has been helping support area soup kitchens, food banks and meal programs. 
 In the last four years more than 100 volunteers have worked to see the memorial become a reality, but Eleanor McDonald of White Plains initiated the idea. 
In 1994 Ms. McDonald, her sister Patricia, and Maureen Redmond, a friend from Ossining, attended a conference on world hunger at Glucksman Ireland House at New York University. Inspired to fight hunger at a local level, Ms. McDonald incorporated the Great Hunger Foundation and started organizing different events around the county to raise money and collect food for the poor. One such event, "Make a Difference Day" at Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains, featured an interfaith prayer service and collected more than 7,000 pounds of food for local organizations.
Enter Louis A. Mosiello, the county legislator who represents District 15 in Yonkers. After being elected to office in November 1995, Mr. Mosiello realized he needed "to reach out to the many Irish-Americans living in my district, to learn about their culture and find out what ways I could be of service to them." So he invited Hugh Fox Jr., a constituent, and Ms. McDonald, whose charitable work he was aware of, to a meeting.
There, Ms. McDonald and Mr. Fox presented an idea for a memorial to the Irish who died in the potato famine of the mid-19th century or were forced to leave their country. Similar memorials had already been erected in Ireland (and a few in the United States), and since roughly 25 percent of Westchester's population is of Irish ancestry, everyone agreed that it seemed fitting that the county have a similar memorial. 
An ad hoc committee advocating a Great Hunger Memorial was formed in 1996 and Mr. Mosiello presented the idea to Andrew O'Rourke, who was then the county executive. Mr. O'Rourke accepted it with the stipulation that the county would donate the land for the memorial if private funds were raised for its planning and construction.
The election of Andrew J. Spano as Mr. O'Rourke's successor in 1996 brought a moment of trepidation to the memorial's backers, who didn't know if he would shepherd the project along or not. In his first week in office, however, Mr. Spano endorsed the memorial and proposed V. E. Macy park as its site.
Having taught junior high and high school history entering politics, Mr. Spano said he was quite aware of the horrors suffered by the Irish people in 1845 when the potato crop failed and approximately 1.5 million people died of starvation. More than 2 million braved inhuman steerage conditions in "coffin ships" that crossed the Atlantic to find hope abroad, many of them landing in New York Harbor. Jobs available to these immigrants were among the hardest imaginable: digging canals and building dams and railroads. In Westchester, the Irish immigrants helped build the aqueducts that provided water to New York City residents.
"Hunger is often the result of government policy," Mr. Spano said, "and as a public servant it's my job to deal effectively with this problem."
He pointed out that Westchester soup kitchens served more than four million meals last year, and stressed the need for more awareness of and programs to fight hunger. "After all, we live in a area where there is tremendous affluence," he said, "but we still don't have our hands completely around the problems of feeding the hungry and housing the poor."
V. E. Macy Park, which envelops the Saw Mill River Parkway in Ardsley and part of Irvington and includes Woodlands Lake, was slated for major renovations that would turn it into a "family friendly" destination when the Great Hunger Memorial proposal came through. The park is named for Valentine Everett Macy, who was superintendent of the poor in Westchester during the 1930's.
The memorial sculpture will be the first public artwork erected in a county park in the last couple of years, said Mary Kaye Koch, a public information officer with the county parks department. 
Mr. Mosiello, who is an honorary chairman of the Great Hunger Memorial Committee along with Mr. Spano as well as executive chairman, said, "I'm hoping this will be the catalyst for more public art in our parks."
In July 1997 the Great Hunger Memorial Committee began in earnest to organize and make plans, agreeing, Mr. Houlihan said, that the memorial should appeal to and reflect a vast number of residents, "because what happened to the poor in Ireland 150 years ago, their hunger and homelessness, is still being experienced by people all over the world today."
The committee's intention, Mr. Houlihan said, was never "to just build a statue for people to look at -- we wanted it to be part of educational programs, too." To that end one such event the committee recently sponsored was an art and literary competition for students, from elementary to university levels, to interpret aspects of the great Hunger of Ireland, also known as "An Gorta Mor."
For the memorial itself a worldwide competition was held, and the committee received serious proposals from as far away as Australia and the Netherlands. A panel of judges that included curators from local museums, an art professor, an artist and an architect, among others, whittled the contestants down to four semifinalists, choosing a proposal in the end from Mr. O'Doherty, who is known in Ireland for his large-scale public sculptures.
Ms. McDonald, the comptroller for the village of Harrison, served as treasurer to the Great Hunger Memorial. She said that more than $635,000 has been raised to erect the memorial and to finance hunger and educational programs. While about $100,000 in public grants secured with the help of State Senator Nicholas A. Spano and his younger brother, State Assemblyman Michael J. Spano, have aided the effort substantially, individuals contributed much of the money raised. A gala dinner dance held last November at the Rye Town Hilton, which featured traditional Irish songs from Cathie Ryan of South Salem, raised $375,000.
Ms. McDonald said, "When a lot of Irish-Americans in the area began to learn more about the impact of what happened in 19th-century Ireland in terms of politics, economics and sociology, they became passionate about being a part of this and seeing the memorial come to fruition."
One couple eager to attend the unveiling are John and Eileen Carey, longtime Yonkers residents who came to the United States from Ireland more than 40 years ago and who spent the last four years volunteering their time to the memorial committee.
"I feel a lot of pride seeing the memorial," Mrs. Carey said. "It'll be a lasting monument to the Irish and other nationalities who came to this country. It's something that should have been done a long time ago."

Though the memorial honors the Irish who survived the potato famine, it is also intended as a reminder that hunger has no place in an affluent area. HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
A New Type of Project for Affluent Saddle River

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AFTER more than 20 years, changes in ownership and a legal debate, a 28-acre triangular-shaped site along Route 17 is midway through its transformation into a mixed-used development that is changing the face of Saddle River, an affluent community in northwestern Bergen County.
 Now along with the stately houses on manicured lawns that define Saddle River, where the former President Richard M. Nixon lived in retirement, there will be four real estate uses new to the borough: low- and moderate-income housing, assisted-living apartments for the elderly, a hotel and an office building. 
 "It's a good use of the property," said Conrad S. Caruso, the mayor of Saddle River, who described the project as "the largest single development" in the history of this borough of 3,120. 
A separate owner is developing each component. They are following an overall plan worked out by a different developer and local officials to ensure the project would complement the character of the five-square mile borough. The site is bordered by Boroline and East Allendale Roads and is on the west side of Route 17, while most of the rest of the borough is on the opposite side. 
The 153-unit assisted-living development has already been completed. It serves people 70 or older who need help with daily chores but who do not need constant medical care. 
The affordable housing is rising on 7.6 acres in the northern corner of the site and consists of 19 rentals for people age 62 or over and 57 condominium apartments. All of the units will be affordable to people earning no more than $53,465 a year for a family of four. 
Meanwhile, construction is under way on a three-story, 174-room Marriott Residence Inn. And work is expected to begin this summer on a 100,000-square-foot office building. 
The groundwork for the mixed-use development started in the mid-1980's, when borough officials rezoned a wooded parcel for offices and low- and moderate-income housing. The housing was intended to meet the borough's obligation under the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel doctrines, which require municipalities to provide through zoning the opportunity for affordable housing to be built; otherwise they could be sued by builders. Saddle River's obligation is for 152 such units.
"To make the affordable housing work needed a financial engine, and in this case it was the office buildings," Mayor Caruso said.
But the site defied development because it was not served by public water and sewer lines. During the real estate recession of the late 80's, the property was taken by its lender through foreclosure.
NOTHING happened until 1992, when Saddle River Properties of Englewood Cliffs acquired the site for $1.5 million on behalf of an investor, mainly because of its location. But with the office market in the doldrums the new owner revised the development plan to the current one.
"We felt this was the finest use of the land, and it made economic sense for us and was in scale and more compatible with the residential character of Saddle River and neighboring Allendale," said Constantine Karalis of Brooklyn, the project's architect and development and planning consultant. In addtion, 31 percent of the parcel will be left open, he said. 
Still, it took four years to gain all of the state and local approvals. To address the public water and sewer issue, Mr. Karalis said, Saddle River Properties and the borough negotiated agreements with Upper Saddle River for the water and with Allendale for the sewers. The cost of those improvements was $3 million. 
The owner then divided the site into four parcels to sell to developers. The seven-acre assisted-living component was developed first. Such residences are being constructed rapidly throughout New Jersey. Now there are 111 assisted-living communities in the state, up from 16 in 1994, according to the state's Department of Health and Senior Services.
Saddle River and Bergen County have sizable populations of old people and of children who make the decisions for their elderly parents, said Nanci Wechsler, a spokeswoman for Marriott Senior Living Services, the developer. The building houses 90 assisted-living suites and a 25-bed special-care wing for people with Alzheimer's disease and related memory disorders, she said.
Monthly rents, including all meals and services, start at $3,300. 
By 1997 while construction of the assisted-living community was under way, the other components of the project hit a roadblock. The owner of 23 acres on the opposite side of Saddle River sued the borough under the Mount Laurel doctrines, creating uncertainty that caused developers of the Route 17 project to delay until late 1999.
Because the borough did not yet have its affordable housing plan approved by the state, it was still vulnerable to builders' lawsuits. 
Stuart R. Koenig, the lawyer for the borough's planning board, said the suit was ultimately settled with the zoning for the mixed-use project remaining intact and the other property owner's site rezoned from single family homes to town houses.
Saddle River Realty L.L.C is developing the in-town affordable housing, which will be completed in January at a cost of $5 million, said Thomas Caleca, a principal of the Ramsey-based company. 
The 57 condominiums, called Saddle River Estates, will have one, two or three bedrooms and 550 to 1,100 square feet of space. Sale prices, depending on family size and income, range from $64,406 to $157,500. Monthly fees are expected to average $104. 
There are deed restrictions on the homes that dictate the resale prices, said Jack R. D'Ambrosio, executive director of the Housing Authority of Bergen County, which will manage the overall development. 
The authority will also acquire for $1.45 million the rental apartments, called Saddle River Senior Housing. The units will have one and two bedrooms and 507 to 815 square feet of space. Monthly rents will be based on 30 percent of a person's income, or a minimum of $350, whichever is greater, Mr. D'Ambrosio said. 
"Most towns are concerned that they have an opportunity to participate in the planning of a Mount Laurel development and what it will eventually look like," he said. "The Saddle River project will be an example of what other towns can plan for." 
The Marriott Residence Inn, an extended-stay hotel, will rise in the next 16 months. Robert S. Mannon, regional vice president for development at Marriott, said his company got involved in the project because "it offered an unique opportunity in a market where the barriers to entry are high." 
HOTELS in such markets typically achieve an above-average occupancy rate, he said, adding that the projection for the Saddle River hotel is 82 percent, compared with the national average of 67 percent.
Innkeepers U.S.A Trust of Palm Beach will own and manage the $15 million hotel, and Marriott will collect a franchise fee. Daily room rates will be $120 to $140. 
Despite the cooling economy, Mr. Mannon said the Route 17 business corridor is underserved by extended-stay hotels. The corridor encompasses 17 towns in northwest Bergen County.
There have not been any new Class A office buildings built along the corridor in nearly 15 years, said Thomas A. Reilly, senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis, the national commercial brokerage, in Paramus. Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage, put the corridor's vacancy rate at 10 percent, down from 13.3 percent last year.
Those are among the reasons Kwartler Associates of Waldwick plans to construct the 100,000-square-foot office building, now called Saddle River Executive Center, without a specific tenant in hand. Marty Kwartler, a principal at the company, added that the site is also one of the last parcels at a four-way interchange on the highway at East Allendale Road. His firm is developing the building for TA Associates Realty, an institutional real estate investment company in Boston.
The T-shaped building, two stories high in parts and three stories in others, will cost $120 a square foot to build. It will rise on 9.5 acres and is being designed by Poskanzer Skott Architects of Ridgewood with a facade of red brick, precast concrete and glass. Completion is expected by the third quarter of 2002, and by then whatever softness there is in the market will be gone, Mr. Reilly predicted. 
The bottom line, Mr. Kwartler added, is that "Saddle River, like Beverly Hills, is an address that is irreplaceable."

SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
When Hotels Add Hospitality to History

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
WHEN his real estate broker told Philip Pilevsky in 1998 that the 24-story American Radiator Building was for sale, he barely hesitated before offering $15 million. The site, at 40 West 40th Street, is directly across from Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library in the heart of Midtown, making it ideal for the upscale hotel he had in mind. The Japanese company that owned the landmark office building accepted the relatively low price because at the time the Japanese had largely soured on American real estate and the American Radiator Building had been vacant for several years. 
 For Mr. Pilevsky, the prize was not only that the building has a prime location but also that it had been designed in 1924 by Raymond M. Hood, who also designed the Daily News and McGraw-Hill buildings. Moreover, the American Radiator Building was a designated landmark, which by definition confers status. 
 In the two months that the hotel, now named the Bryant Park, has been open, it has been full much of the time, according to Elon Kenchington, its managing director, and seems likely to continue to do well even after its current introductory rate of $295 a night rises to $500. 
The cachet conferred by old buildings, many with architectural elements that would be difficult to replicate today, has long been part of the attraction of such grand hotels as the Plaza or the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan, just as a sense of place and history is inescapable at West Point's Hotel Thayer. The same attractions are part of the reason for the conversion of old buildings into hotels, a pattern that shows no signs of letting up. The following historic or landmark hotels have opened in Manhattan in the last 18 months: 
* The Regent Wall Street, a blocklong 144-room hotel that opened at 55 Wall Street in December 1999. Originally built in 1842, it housed the New York Merchants' Exchange, the United States Custom House and, for almost 90 years, National City Bank (now Citigroup). For a brief while, the building was operated by the Cipriani family, which had been running a catering service and concert operation in the building's great hall. But nine months before the hotel opened, Sidney Kimmel, the owner of the hotel, chose Regent International Hotels, owned by the Carlson Companies of Minneapolis, to operate all aspects of the property.
According to its architects, Anthony Morali and Michael Gadaleta of M. G. New York Architects, the Regent's vault is the room most requested for meetings, for up to 12 people. And its eight pre-Civil War jail cells, with dirt floors and arched ceilings, are occasionally open to groups that request tours, according to Christopher Knable, the general manager. 
* The 108-room Dylan Hotel at 52 East 41st Street, a 1903 Beaux-Arts building that was once the home of the Chemists' Club and for which the Dylan's owner, Morris Moinian, said he had earmarked $30 million for renovation, including $1 million for such architectural details as its three-story marble winding staircase.
* The Muse, a former manufacturing loft, now a 200-room hotel at 130 West 46th Street, whose original triple-arched limestone and brick facade has been restored.
* The 270-room, 20-story W hotel at Union Square at 201 Park Avenue South (17th Street), formerly the Guardian Life Building, built in 1911.
What has been happening in New York is also happening throughout the United States. In communities across the land old houses, factories, bank buildings, schools, post offices and railroad stations are in growing demand as hotels or apartments.
"We've definitely seen more historic and landmark buildings being restored as hotels in recent years, rather than just torn down," said Mary Foley Billingsley, a spokeswoman for the National Trust Historic Hotels of America. From 32 member hotels in 1989, when it was founded, the organization now has 171. Some of the buildings have been hotels since they were built, but others had been plantation houses, inns, private residences, taverns, even hunting retreats. 
A quarter of the 40 properties in the Omni Hotels group are historic or landmarks. And the company has allocated more than $200 million for the recent renovation and restoration of its San Francisco and New Orleans properties as well as the Parker House in Boston (which claims to be the longest continuously operated hotel in America), the venerable Shoreham Hotel in Washington and the former William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh.
Within the past two years, Marriott's Ritz-Carlton brand opened a hotel at a 101-year-old former department store in New Orleans, while Marriott's Courtyard brand transformed a Riggs bank in Washington into a hotel, restored a former molasses factory in New Orleans and opened a hotel in a City Hall annex in Philadelphia. Other notable buildings that have been transformed into hotels in Philadelphia recently include a former bank and office tower designed by McKim, Meade & White, now a Ritz-Carlton, and the modernist landmark Philadelphia Savings Fund Society Building, which is now the Loews Philadelphia Hotel. 
"I think part of what's going on," said William J. Higgins, a partner at Higgins & Quasebarth, a Manhattan based firm that specializes in preserving historic and landmark properties, "is that just as the world is becoming Americanized, America is becoming Europeanized -- at least to the extent of restoring and reusing old buildings, rather than just knocking them down."
And, he said, "Americans have also come to realize that preservation is part of our economic well being."
Mr. Higgins added that the typical office building is rather easily converted into a hotel, because usually only their main lobbies and elevator lobbies on the upper floors tend to be landmarked or otherwise worth preserving. 
Converting historic buildings can entail complicated calculations. If the building being converted has been designated a landmark by the city, there will be considerable additional expense in meeting the requirements of local landmark regulations. For many hotel owners, however, the landmark designation carries considerable cachet and usually translates into higher room rates. 
Hotels and other public buildings on the National Register of Historic Places must be at least 50 years old, and their owners must refrain from altering the architecture. But the designation makes owners eligible for a reduction of the federal income tax they owe, equal to 20 percent of the cost of the rehabilitation.
PROFESSOR RICHARD PENNER, who teaches at the School of Hotel Administration at Cornell University, said old buildings had been turned into modern hotels for decades, including many that were hotels to begin with but had been allowed to become rundown. While New York, Chicago, Philadelphia and Los Angeles still have many such buildings, there are also examples in smaller cities like Providence, Hartford and Burlington, Vt.
West Point's historic Hotel Thayer, an imposing five-story granite building that resembles a medieval fortress, reopened 17 months ago with 150 rooms after a $26 million rehabilitation by Hudson River Partners, a Washington company made up entirely of West Point graduates. Next year, according to Charles Barren, managing director of the Thayer, construction is scheduled to start on a second phase that will increase total capacity to 250 rooms. Some small function rooms that were added to the main building in the 1960's will be replaced. The four-story annex added in 1946 will be replaced by a free-standing five-story tower that will contain a conference center, business center, new restaurant, lounge, 6,000-square-foot ballroom and a fitness center. 
In the initial phase, the hotel's stone facade entrance, which had been enclosed by glass since the 1960's, was restored. "It took us about 12 months to do the historic preservation," said Douglas P. Bennett, the general partner of Hudson River Partners, a 1964 graduate of West Point and a Vietnam veteran. "But all of us were aware of what the hotel meant to us and to West Point, and now that restoration is used as a case study within the Department of the Army for what you can do with a military installation." While Hudson River Partners has a long-term lease on the hotel, the Army owns the land beneath it. 
In some cases, local authorities eager to have a landmark hotel restored or upgraded are happy to extend a helping hand to hotel companies. For example, the 305-room Omni New Haven Hotel at Yale, at 155 Temple Street, two blocks from Yale University across the New Haven Green, is not a historic building but has become something of a local landmark. Michael Deitemeyer, Omni's chief operating officer, said the state of Connecticut gave Omni $10 million toward the $30 million it spent to restore a 25-year-old hotel on the site that had been closed for about five years. Since the hotel reopened in 1998, "it has done very well for us," Mr. Deitemeyer added.
The Applied Development Company of Hoboken, N.J., a contractor and developer, primarily of multifamily residential properties, expects to do well with its first venture into a heritage hotel -- the early 20th century mansion in Morristown, N.J., of Theodore N. Vail, the first president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The municipality of Morristown bought the mansion in 1922 for government offices, and Allied Development, which plans to put up a 101-room luxury hotel, bought it from the town for $2 million. 
"We're obliged by our agreement with Morristown to restore it back to its historic standards," said Michael I. Barry, a principal in the 31-year-old family company.
This will entail restoring the lobby and lounge to their original condition, while adding a guest house in the rear that will not alter the facade. The design architect is Brennan Beer Gorman, and Dewitt Tishman is the construction architect. Moreover, the company has already hired a preservationist to make sure that each detail is done exactly as required by Morristown and the state.
Hotel owners and developers often differ about whether it is more economical (if one can use that word to describe multimillion-dollar properties) to buy an existing building and convert it or to build from the ground up. While restoring an old building may save as much as 40 percent in construction costs, the cost of equipping old buildings with the health clubs, spas, restaurants and the wiring necessary for the high-tech equipment that guests expect in high priced hotels can more than wipe out any anticipated savings. In addition, the time and material needed to duplicate the original buildings can be very high. 
Omni's $22 million restoration at its William Penn hotel in Pittsburgh includes $3 million just to repoint the bricks. In the case of the Bryant Park, Mr. Pilevsky spent $35 million in addition to the $15 million purchase price. 
The biggest part of that, of course, was overhauling the rooms and much else of the interior, almost none of which was landmarked, and the cost of hotel's overall architectural design, which was done by David Chipperfield, a British architect. Still, Mr. Pilevsky estimated that the restoration of the facade, including the black brick of the hotel's tower and its terra-cotta ornaments, added "at least $2 million to $3 million more" than it would have cost had the building not been a landmark. Even at that, he added, there were certain things he wanted but was prohibited by regulations from having. "We wanted bigger windows," he said, "but you learn to live with not having them.
Architects and preservations says they are sometimes surprised by what they find during restorations. Such was the case during the current $15 million makeover of the Waldorf Towers, the 70 year-old "hotel within a hotel" that has a dedicated separate entrance and lobby, despite occupying the 28th through 42nd floors of the Waldorf-Astoria on 50th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. 
IN adding to the 18th floor 13 contiguous meeting rooms and recreating the Art Deco splendor of the Starlight Roof, workers made what Waldorf officials said was a significant discovery: details that had been covered over in previous alterations of the hotel's public places, including arched ceilings with grill work in the center.
"We are uncovering incredible vintage architectural details that have been lost during the past 50 years of successive waves of modernization," said Pamela Graber, the executive director of the Towers.
Somewhat similarly, in their renovation of the Regent Wall Street, Mr. Morali and Mr. Gadaleta, the architects, were also often surprised. Above the flat ceiling of the building's arcade, Mr. Morali said, they found a hidden dropped ceiling, and when they removed that, they found a vaulted ceiling. Additionally, when they analyzed the paint on the ballroom ceiling, through a process known as photo microscopy, in order to determine the age and condition of paint, they were in for another surprise. 
"When we did the initial analysis, we found layers of blue paint," Mr. Gadaleta said, "but the ceiling now is beige with gold trim. And there's a gold leaf on the main dome in the center of the ballroom ceiling.
"So we're going to bring in conservators to analyze the paint, to further bring it back to its original color."
Although he could just as well have been speaking about the Waldorf Towers or many other restorations for that matter, Mr. Morali said, "When you find these discoveries, you feel like an anthropologist."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on June 24 about hotels in historic structures misstated the restriction on architectural changes by owners of buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The requirement that changes comply with federal standards takes effect only if a building has received federal tax credits for historic preservation or federal funds. Mere listing on the register does not restrict an owner's ability to change the building.

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD; 
The Longest Light

BYLINE:  By CAREN CHESLER 

 BODY:
A driver in West Milford could whip out an egg, hard-boil it and eat it. Or cook a TV dinner. Or, if a car full of fans were rushing home to watch a basketball game, they would miss nearly half of the first quarter.
 Welcome to West Milford, home of the country's longest traffic light. 
 Drivers pulling up to the light at the intersection of Clinton Avenue and Route 23 in Passaic County can wait as long as 5 minutes and 33 seconds during the morning rush hour if they approach it as it is turning red.
Looked at another way, residents on Clinton Avenue who need to use Route 23 could spend about 20 hours a year waiting at the light. The only light that comes close to being as long, transportation officials say, is in Delaware -- and that light lasts only four minutes.
Maurice Rached, a project engineer with the state Department of Transportation in Bergen, Passaic and Essex Counties, said that drivers trying to cross Route 3 in Bergen and Passaic counties and Routes 1 and 9 in Essex County had similar problems.
"Route 23 has experienced more and more demand over the last 20 years, to the point where it was difficult to manage the existing demand," Mr. Rached said.
He attributed the traffic congestion to housing developments that have sprung up like mushrooms in Sussex County. The problem is that many of the highways are flanked by stores and strip malls, making any road-widening project about as easy as putting another lane in the Lincoln Tunnel. So the transportation department came up with a simpler -- and more economical -- tool to manage congestion: manipulate the duration of the traffic lights at cross streets, allowing more cars to move through the main road.
The result is that the average waiting time at a traffic light during peak hours in New Jersey has doubled over the last 20 years, to about 150 seconds from 70 seconds.
For instance, the light in West Milford used to be 2 minutes and 40 seconds long. But during the morning rush hour, traffic on Route 23 would back up nearly two miles when the light at Clinton Avenue would turn red. The light there was made longer last June.
In fact, 5 minutes and 28 seconds was such an unusually long time for a signal to remain red that the transportation department had to tinker with the light to make it work since the signal's computer limited the amount of time a signal could stay red to 4 minutes and 15 seconds.
Afterward, Mr. Rached said he received complaints from residents who thought there was something wrong with the light -- though the letters and phone calls have subsided.
"We've received complaints about almost every traffic signal along Route 23," he said. "When you have a congested highway like this, you get complaints."
Not only are traffic signals longer, there are also more of them. In 1981, there were 1,765 traffic signals dotting the state's highways. Today, there are nearly 2,700.
This is yet another reason commuters in New Jersey are finding that their drive to work -- or just about anywhere -- takes much longer. In 1982, a commuter in the northeastern section of the state sat in traffic for 8 hours over the course of a year, according to the Texas Transportation Institute. In 1999, that figure was 34 hours.
Of course, Mr. Rached should know. His own daily commute from Lawrenceville to his office in Newark takes 90 minutes each way. When asked what will happen when the state roads reach their capacity, he said, "We're already at capacity."
These multiplying traffic lights also take a financial toll.
A traffic signal costs from $80,000 to $100,000 to install, and once it's up and running, it costs about $1,400 a year in electricity to run it. The result: New Jersey taxpayers have an $8.4 million electric bill each a year for traffic lights alone.
Steven Carrellas, the head of the New Jersey chapter of the National Motorists Association, contended that if state and local highway officials stopped relying on traffic lights -- or better synchronized the ones already up while at the same time increasing the speed limits -- more cars could be accommodated.
"It's an urban myth that higher speeds lead to more accidents," Mr. Carrellas asserted. "There's a smoothness factor. Faster, smoother traffic is generally safer than traffic that lumbers along haphazardly."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Sarah Schenck, John Donohue

 BODY:
Sarah Louise Hazlett Schenck and John Joseph Donohue were married yesterday by the Rev. Vernon Nichols, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Inn at Bally Springs, Pa.
 Ms. Schenck, 35, will keep her name. An independent filmmaker, she wrote and directed a short called "Love Potion," a modern-day version of Adam and Eve's fall, which won a gold medal last year at the International Film and Video Festival in London. She graduated from Bryn Mawr College and received a certificate in Spanish language and culture from the Universidad Complutense de Madrid and a master's degree in political science and international political economy from Stanford. 
 She is the daughter of Jane McClenathan Schenck and Dr. George H. K. Schenck of State College, Pa. Her father, who retired as a professor of mineral economics at Pennsylvania State University, is a consultant in mining engineering.
Mr. Donohue, 32, is the editor for the night life listings in the Goings On About Town section of The New Yorker. He graduated from Union College in Schenectady, N.Y. He is a son of Elizabeth and James F. Donohue of Katonah, N.Y. His father is a trial lawyer in White Plains and the town attorney for Bedford, N.Y.
The couple met in February 1998 at the Ohio Theater in New York, awaiting the start of "The Handless Maiden," an Adobe Theater Company farce based on the Grimm fairy tale about greed and impetuous action. They were sitting next to each other on folding chairs on the theater's wooden risers, and Ms. Schenck was impatiently jiggling her knee, causing the entire row to shake.
"I leaned over and politely asked her to stop," Mr. Donohue said. "She replied, 'You're lucky I'm not weaving and drooling.' "
That left him speechless, but not blind to her charms. After the play, they lingered to discuss its symbolism, and he asked for her telephone number.
"I found his forthrightness in asking for my number refreshing," said Ms. Schenck, who was then the senior policy adviser for education to the New York City comptroller. "I'd been around so many New York City guys who took forever to tell whether they were interested in me for my political connections, for a platonic friendship or for romance."

LENGTH: 1186 words

HEADLINE: MIRROR, MIRROR; 
Still Riding So High and Fine?

BYLINE:  By Penelope Green 

 BODY:
LAST Tuesday morning in the parking lot of Trader Joe's market in Mamaroneck, N.Y., one Lincoln Navigator, one Isuzu Trooper, three Chevy Suburbans, two Dodge Durangos, three Jeep Grand Cherokees, one Chevy Tahoe, one Toyota Land Cruiser, one Mazda Tribute and one Mercedes M-Class sport utility vehicle inched forward and back in an excruciatingly slow elephant ballet. 
 It was 11:40, hot and still, just 10 minutes past the last school pickup of the year. The car silhouettes blurred in the heat, and the faces of the children who had clambered in minutes before faded behind the tinted windows. The fleet seemed monolithic, but the drivers' attitudes were anything but. 
 "I definitely feel weird about this car," said Tricia McRae (Suburban No. 1). Gas prices make her feel that way, as does the environmental cost of driving such a behemoth -- front-page news again after all these years. "Maybe it's always felt a little weird," Ms. McRae said. "But it feels worse now because of the gas crunch. We like to travel, and it's put a damper on all that. When the lease runs out in December, we'll probably go for a station wagon. My husband wants a Miata -- can you imagine? We'd go from the elephant to the ant -- but that doesn't make too much sense with three kids." 
Heidi Hanley (Durango No. 2) has three children, too. "It becomes a juggling act in your head," she said. "Your concerns about your kids' safety with the horrible mileage. I have no conclusions. This is a leased vehicle, and I think about what other car I could get that doesn't guzzle gas. For me, this is definitely an issue connected to what's going on in the White House."
Because S.U.V.'s are less fuel efficient than cars, their runaway popularity has increased America's reliance on foreign oil -- average daily imports are twice as high as in 1981 -- and that has led in part to President Bush's call for drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. S.U.V.'s also pump out nearly three tons more carbon dioxide than an average car in a year, a pollutant that is said to cause global warming, and that issue, too, is back in the news because of the administration's rejection of the Kyoto treaty to limit greenhouse gases.
Americans love their S.U.V.'s, there's no question about it, but there are tiny pockets of what Alan Metrick, communications director of the Natural Resources Defense Council, calls "dis-ease," little bubbles of guilt over what was once the very symbol of suburban success. These S.U.V. owners don't sound brazen when they talk about their vehicles; they sound embarrassed. 
"It's a terrible time to ask me about my car," said Ardith Plimack, 39, who lives in Marin County, Calif. She has two children and a new Toyota Land Cruiser. "I have such a conscience, and at the same time I'm living my life. We used to have a Land Rover Discovery. I was in a terrible accident with it last year. Five kids on a field trip. In the rain. The car was totaled, and none of us had a scratch. 
"When you have a young family and you're schlepping kids all over the place, you know what starts happening? You start writing a lot of checks to the environmental organizations. Part of me thinks I'm paying Peter to keep robbing Paul."
Sales of S.U.V.'s slid almost 10 percent last year (sales of all cars were down a little over 6 percent, as the economy weakened). "We know the S.U.V. market is softening," Mr. Metrick said. "You have all these forces hitting this market: the gas prices, Ford making headlines every day. That can't be helping. Our guess is that there is a section of the S.U.V. market that is saying: 'Do I really need this? Isn't it a little bit silly to be driving this thing?' "
In Greenwich, Conn., the S.U.V.'s nestle together in little herds, two or even three to a family. Marybeth Manley has four children, one Lexus LX470 S.U.V. and a Chevy Tahoe. "I do think it's excessive," she said. "And I have thought we should be driving smaller cars. I didn't like it when Bush said Americans shouldn't have to change their lifestyle. I, for one, feel uneasy. My husband bought the cars."
Emmy Starr has three children and another on the way, a Land Cruiser, a Lexus S.U.V. and a Volkswagen New Beetle. She drives the Beetle to the market when the baby sitter has the children in the Land Cruiser. "It's the biggest one," she said. "It was the only one that you could fit three car seats across the middle. And it's very safe. But it gets terrible gas mileage. I'll probably have to cave to the minivan thing when we have our fourth."
In Martha's Vineyard, the sins of the S.U.V. are as much aesthetic as environmental. "Here it's an awareness that they are a bit of a cliche, something that goes hand in hand with the big trophy home," said Paul Schneider, an island resident and author of "The Enduring Shore: A History of Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket." 
In March, AutoPacific, an automotive product and marketing consulting concern, conducted surveys of S.U.V. owners who had bought their cars since September. It has just compiled the results. 
"These people don't like their cars -- they love them, a lot," said James Hossack, a company vice president. "They like to sit up high and see where they're going. They're not concerned about the environment or gas prices. Most people aren't seeing global warming, they're seeing less pollution than they ever did before. And if gas prices go up to $3 a gallon, who cares? These people don't. The press keeps talking about mileage, and nobody cares. No, sorry, it's not happening."
Is S.U.V. slippage wishful thinking on the part of environmentalists? Actually, the idea of what makes a car and what makes an S.U.V. is blurring. "I don't think they're going to evaporate," said Jerry Hirshberg, founder of Nissan Design International in San Diego and the creator of the Xterra, an S.U.V. he described as "blue jeans on wheels." 
"People like the bigness," he said. "On the other hand it would be naive to think that the image hasn't been tarnished. My own thinking is that something very interesting is about to happen in the car industry. You keep hearing the mantra about S.U.V.'s becoming more carlike. Well, what does that mean for the car? I think there's going to be a huge shift away from what used to define a car."
In designing the 2002 model of the Nissan Altima, a compact sedan, his team looked at what was "rational" about the S.U.V.'s, he said. "We know people love the high-command seating. And so in the Altima we've raised the seats over an inch. That's a big thing. Changes like that can really stimulate the idea of what a car might become." 
James Hall, vice president for industry analysis at AutoPacific, said the market was still S.U.V.-happy, but he noted that "customers are fickle." 
"Personally, and this is my bet, not my company's, I think there'll be a shift and it will come from the next cluster, the so-called Generation Y, the oldest of which are 23 right now. This is the first generation whose parents drove S.U.V.'s. And you know what? No generation before them has wanted to drive its parents' cars if it had an alternative."
