HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Ford Thunderbird; 
What's the Word on the T-Bird?

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
MY neighbor, who restores old cars as a hobby, telephoned. Could he photograph his 1966 Ford Thunderbird next to the 2002 model that I was test-driving? He wanted a shot of one of the last convertible Thunderbirds alongside the reborn model.
 His son, 17, who aspires to be an automotive engineer, took pictures as well. He cared little about the Thunderbird's illustrious heritage. He was born long after the trim original of 1955 and the classics that followed over the next decade or so. He remembered Thunderbirds only as bulky, boring, overstyled coupes, the last of which was produced in 1997. "It's cool," he said of the new Thunderbird. "It's about looking cool." 
 I encountered numerous similar reactions throughout my weekend driving the aqua T-Bird at elementary school soccer games, cruising Detroit's famous Woodward Avenue on a warm Saturday night and at dinner at a fancy restaurant. Everywhere I went turned into an automotive event, the likes of which I had not experienced since I drove early versions of the Chrysler PT Cruiser and the Volkswagen New Beetle. People of all ages, genders, ethnic groups and economic classes took notice and had favorable comments. Some wistfully told their stories about earlier T-Birds. 
Indeed, the new car, which arrives in showrooms in August after several delays, is every bit the head-turner that the original '55 and the subsequent classics were. Not intended to be a replica of those cars, the new Thunderbird is more of a modern interpretation, a spiritual successor.
By all accounts from people I queried, Ford has succeeded in meeting its goal. Baby boomers and older people immediately recognize what the new roadster is meant to be. Young people see the Thunderbird's design as something new and fresh.
In contrast with the original and the 1960's versions, the 2002 Thunderbird has a more rounded shape. Yet, its long body, at 186.3 inches (as compared with Mercedes SLK roadster at 158 inches), and distinctive proportions, with a small passenger compartment separating its stretched hood from its long trunk lid, are reminiscent of early Thunderbirds and American convertibles of the 1950's and 1960's.
The new Thunderbird also borrows styling cues from the past, including the large egg-crate grille, the round headlamps, the portholes in the hardtop and the turquoise, white and chrome Thunderbird badge across the trunk, the front and the steering wheel. Some of the available colors are nostalgic. In addition to traditional black, red and white, the Thunderbird comes in a pale yellow and aqua, the hue of my test model.
The optional hardtop matches the exterior color; the soft convertible top is black. The standard interior is black leather. As an option, the interior can be outfitted in some of the same colors used on the outside for a more nostalgic look. Red interior is available with a red, black or white model.
In my preproduction test model, which cannot be judged exactly like a production version, the entire lower portion of the cabin, from the driver's side door across the dash wrapping around to the passenger's door, was aqua. It was interrupted by only the bland-looking center dash, which borrows from the Lincoln LS.
The black vinyl of the upper dash and the lower exterior color were separated by a band of plastic intended to look like brushed metal, which mimics the aluminum trim of classic Thunderbirds. Indeed, the trim looked like metal. The bottoms and backs of the two bucket seats had aqua insets surrounded by black leather. The upper steering wheel and shift knob featured a shimmering aqua that reminded me of my teenage daughter's nail polish.
Interior quarters are intimate. Tall people complain of feeling cramped with the top up, and the top of the windshield may fall in their line of sight. I would have liked a tad more tilt on the back of the passenger seat. My back ached during a long stint as passenger because the seat forced me to sit too upright. The driver seat was quite comfortable, though.
For as long as the car is, space and storage are scant. A teensy space behind the seats accommodated little more than my purse, a sweater and a slim briefcase. The trunk, with 6.7 cubic feet of space, doesn't offer much storage either, enough for a set of golf clubs and an overnight bag perhaps. With the top up, the removable boot cover consumes most of the space.
Open-air motoring is quick by simply opening the center latch and pushing the button on the dash. The black cover to hide the folded-down ragtop, however, takes longer to attach. The snaps to hold it down were stubborn to align and fasten. Raising the top was fussy as well. I had to manually guide the hooks to latch the convertible top closed.
Though one can imagine being back in the 1950's while driving the Thunderbird, the car is outfitted with the usual array of modern conveniences, like cup holders, an in-dash six-disc CD changer and dual climate controls. Safety features include standard side airbags, a child seat latch for the passenger seat and a shutoff switch for the passenger airbag; traction control is optional.
The Thunderbird remains true to the original by being a two-seat roadster, as it was from 1955 to 1957, and being powered by a V-8 engine. In this case, Ford employs the same 3.9-liter V-8 used in the Lincoln LS. The engine generates 252 horsepower and 267 foot-pounds of torque. Fuel economy is estimated at 17 miles a gallon in the city and 23 miles a gallon on the highway.
Because of the Thunderbird's hefty 3,774 pounds (3,863 with the removable hardtop), it is no speed demon. Its power, however, is delivered smoothly and steadily. The V-8 is paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, which isn't nearly as smooth as the engine. It hung on to the lower gears too long before shifting.
The Thunderbird rides on the same platform as the Lincoln LS and Jaguar S-Type, a platform that also will be used for the next-generation Mustang. The Thunderbird is not a sports car; it is a boulevard cruiser. Ford engineers appropriately describe the Thunderbird's ride and handling style as "relaxed sportiness." I found it extremely comfortable in cruising around town and on the freeway and quite competent in winding curves at rather high speeds.
Like most convertibles, the Thunderbird experienced some body shake, but it wasn't excessive for a ragtop. Top up, the roadster had quite a bit of shake and road noise.
Most people I encountered thought the $34,495 base price, including destination, and $39,795 for the fully loaded model, with the hardtop, were reasonable. Of course, those prices do not include the inevitable gouging by dealers because of high demand. Ford intends to build only 25,000 Thunderbirds this year and virtually all are sold.
The 2002 Ford Thunderbird is far from a perfect car. Likely, anyone who buys one will purchase it as a summer toy. The Thunderbird, however, does exactly what Ford intended. It grabs attention; it conjures up romantic notions of the past; it brings back glamour in automobiles; and it's just plain fun.
Indeed, the remake of the Ford Thunderbird suggests an approach that Detroit's automakers could take that would help them regain an advantage over import brands: dig into their heritage and modernize their classic American dream cars. The beauty of such a strategy is that no foreign company -- not Toyota or Honda, or even Mercedes or BMW -- can compete on such a playing field.
No one but Ford could ever build a Thunderbird.

INSIDE TRACK: Something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue.

HEADLINE: Is This the Face of a Midlife Crisis? 

BYLINE:  By RICK MARIN 

 BODY:
HERE'S a guy who did everything right. Graduated from Yale. Married his high school sweetheart. Became a hotshot salesman at one of America's corporate giants. But that's all over now. He has divorced his wife, quit the wireless sales rat race and moved back to his hometown in northeast Pennsylvania. 
 The old midlife crisis strikes again, with one new wrinkle: the guy is 27. 
 "I was king of the world, but I didn't feel fulfilled," he said, asking not to be named because of embarrassment over his circumstances. "That started the snowball, and it all started rolling downhill from there." 
Regrets about the past. Yearning for work that is spiritually fulfilling, not just lucrative. Misgivings about relationships. It turns out that many 20-somethings are wrestling with the kinds of issues long associated with middle age. They're having their "American Beauty" moment a decade or two ahead of schedule.
Think of it as a mid-midlife crisis. Or as some are calling it, a "quarterlife crisis." 
Besides the classic midlife symptoms, 20-somethings have a few others particular to their generation. Having come of age in a period of spectacular boom and bust, they have extraordinarily high, often unmet expectations of wealth and success. The pressure to succeed young and fast is complicated by the instability of careers in the digit ocracy. The king-of-the-world generation suddenly suspects the boat they're in might be the Titanic.
The editor of an online magazine based in Austin, Tex., has started a Quarterlife Crisis support group, inspired by a new book, "Quarterlife Crisis: The Unique Challenges of Life in Your Twenties" (Jeremy P. Tarcher/Putnam), by two women in their 20's, Alexandra Robbins and Abby Wilner.
An e-mail desideratum making the rounds also seems inspired by the book. 
"You start feeling insecure and wonder where you will be in a year or two," it reads in part. "You see what others are doing and judge yourself a bit more than usual. Suddenly, change is the enemy and you try and cling on to the past."
In "Start-up.com," a recent documentary chronicling the rise and fall of an Internet company, one founding partner earnestly declares, "I've got a lot to do before I'm 30!" His plans did not include the dissolution of both his business and a lifelong friendship with his partner, precipitating a premature midlife crisis.
Dr. Marilyn Metzel, an adjunct professor of clinical psychology at the University of Kansas and the University of Missouri, said these issues are being raised by younger patients. "What I'm seeing in my clinical practice is that all the stages of life are now being telescoped," she said. "What we saw in the 50-year-old range, I now see in the 20-to-30-year-old range."
In "Quarterlife Crisis," Ms. Robbins, 25, outlined the distinction between her generation's crisis points and those of her parents' generation. "In midlife, the panic is caused by too much stability, too much predictability, too much security," she said. "With the quarterlife crisis, it's the opposite: no stability, no predictability, no certainty." The result, she added, is a "cycle of intense self-doubt." 
Ms. Robbins and Ms. Wilner, 25, interviewed 100 or so people in their 20's for their book. Ms. Wilner, a Web designer (recently laid off), summarized the problem: "People are taking longer to settle down, in terms of careers, relationships. That is a source of stress."
The instability is confirmed by the latest census and labor data, which show that the 36.3 million Americans in their 20's are marrying later and changing jobs more frequently than their elders. The median age for marriage among men has risen to 27 from 22 a generation ago, and to 25 from 20 among women. According to unpublished data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median length of time workers in their early 20's stay in one job has shrunk by half since 1983 -- from 2.2 years then to 1.1 now. 
Job-hopping and delaying marriage would appear to allow young adults more time to find themselves, but many complain this freedom has them feeling more lost than found. 
Amy Malissa, 23, was in New York a few weeks ago doing what she has been doing for the last six months: looking for work. Ms. Malissa knew that her last job, planning millennial events for the city of Philadelphia, had a built-in expiration date -- but that was fine. She wanted to keep her options open, in line with the conventional wisdom that company loyalty is dead in the new economy. A hundred-plus resumes later, sent from her old room in her parents' house, that wisdom is looking overrated.
"I thought I was being smart taking a job with the freedom to turn in different directions," Ms. Malissa said. "And I'm realizing maybe that was shortsighted or naive."
Cynthia Steele, 27, thought she had everything figured out when she married and found gainful employment as an administrative assistant at the Pittsburgh Symphony. But she is having classic doubts about her life trajectory. "You start wondering, Is this what I really want to do?" she said. "I want to have kids, but do I stay home?" 
William Strauss, the author with Neil Howe of several books on generational identity, sees "a strong historical analogue" between 20-somethings and the 20's Lost Generation. 
"They felt they were burning the candle at both ends," he said. "It was the end of a speculative boom. There was a sense of cultural exhaustion." He quoted a 1926 journal entry of F. Scott Fitzgerald: "Young people wore out early -- they were hard and languid. The city was bloated, glutted, stupid with cakes and circuses, and a new expression, 'O yeah?' summed up all the enthusiasms."
In his book "13th Gen," Mr. Howe defines anyone born from 1961 to 1981 as Generation X, the term made popular by the book of the same name by Douglas Coupland (born in 1961). It includes everyone from irony-clad slackers to the newly disaffected dot-commers. 
Mr. Howe contrasted what he called the "agoraphobia" of some 20-somethings ("too much openness") with the claustrophobia some of their parents in the Silent Generation felt growing up in the 50's and early 60's.
"They complained about too few options," he said. "The tremendous oppression, the man in the gray flannel suit. They felt like they couldn't express themselves, then in the 70's started trading jobs, trading spouses. If you had a neurosis, you bragged about it."
Witness Woody Allen's early movies and Gail Sheehy, who in her 1976 book "Passages" popularized the concept of the midlife crisis.
The Silent Generation's children, now in their 20's, far from bragging about their neuroses, are embarrassed to admit them for fear of seeming weak or derailed from the fast track. "Twenty-somethings need to appear that they have it together," Ms. Robbins said. "Therapy and antidepressants aren't chic."
Dr. Michael Jolkovksi, on the training faculty in the department of professional psychology at George Washington University, agreed. "Young people are often very anxious about their independence and guard it very jealously," he said. "Anything that makes it look like they depend on someone or something puts them in a lot of conflict."
Dr. Jolkovksi pointed out that the term "midlife crisis" was coined by the Danish-born psychoanalyst Eric Erikson to mean not an emergency but a watershed moment. But Dr. Jolkovski also expressed skepticism about the "quarterlife crisis" concept. "A lot of this might be ordinary early adulthood," he said.
Ms. Robbins and Ms. Wilner have met with mixed reactions to their book. Katie Couric expressed skepticism when they appeared on the "Today" show. "Oprah" empathized.
But the quarterlife concept rings true to many in its target audience. Micah Sommers, 26, is working at his third New York-based Internet company in a year. If he is unhappy in his job, he knows he can't claim, as his parents' generation might have, that "the system" is keeping him down.
"There's no one to blame," he said. "There's no scapegoat. We're very much relying on ourselves and looking to ourselves. But one of the big things that's missing is role models or mentors."
His "fantasy world," Mr. Sommers said, "is being an apprentice to some wise old man and I would follow in his footsteps." He said he would like to learn a tangible skill. "Working at an Internet company, everything's so nebulous. There's a need to create and do something real."
Like being a stone cobbler, say, not writing for a travel Web site. 
His roommate, Nathan Graf, 25, has similar preindustrial daydreams. "In the old days, you would apprentice to a blacksmith when you were 12, and when you were 24, you'd have your own blacksmith store," he said. "That sounds really romantic. There was never this smorgasbord of things to choose from."
As Meghan Daum, 31, the author of "My Misspent Youth" (Grove/Atlantic, 2001), a collection of essays written in her 20's, said, "What happens when you have too many options is that you are responsible for what happens to you."
Two years ago, Ms. Daum left Manhattan for a farmhouse in Nebraska, outside Lincoln. "Now I don't go to a party and get all anxious about what everyone else is doing," she said. "I wanted a place where I was so out of context that there would be none of those pressures."
Dr. Metzel said the young adults she treats often "judge themselves so harshly, and so much of judgment is predicated on financial success." She is troubled by their "willingness to sacrifice the internal life for the rewards of the external life."
Jeff Meyer, a software engineer, found himself doing exactly that.
"I'd always grown up knowing that math and sciences were this thing that would provide reason in life, and the idea of humanities and service to the community were absurd," Mr. Meyer said. "Then I left college and realized there's a lot of materialism that comes along with the engineering field and there has to be a place for emotion."
Now 30, he joined the youth ministry at his Washington church four years ago and began doing volunteer work. He leads Bible classes for high school students and takes them to soup kitchens to volunteer. "I have an extremely rich life in terms of the money I'm making," he said. "But there has to be more than those material aspects. A feeling of belonging."
To at least one 20-something, all this mid-midlife angst has translated into a business opportunity. 
Justin Sewell, 29, is co-founder of a Web site, Despair.com, which sells desktop novelties and other anti-motivational items for those running in place. "The glass is half empty: deal with it," says an advertisement for the "pessimist's mug" on the site.
"We just make products that let people know that most who try will fail, that hope often causes more pain than happiness and that the easiest way to become more successful in life is to lower your expectations," Mr. Sewell said "This may be part of what might prompt some 20-somethings to find our products amusing."
He said revenues for the site have doubled annually, from $250,000 in 1998 to $1 million last year. 
"Complain too much," he said, "and you deserve to hear that great rebuke from 'Broadcast News': 'You can't talk about feeling intimidated when you're on top of the world. It's unseemly.' "
But then, that was a boomer movie.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
Almost 50, And Sold On Stocks

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem @nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I DISCOVERED something disturbing when I turned 49 a few months ago. When friends heard how old I was, they gasped and shook their heads, acting as if I had already turned 50.
 So now they've got me thinking that way, too: "Gee, I'm 50. Gee, that's depressing." And gee, thanks so much, everyone, for ending my 40's a year too soon. 
 Turning 50, of course, is a milestone. The AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, which said I can expect a membership application next year, estimates that someone turns 50 in this country about every 8 seconds. Last year, it said, 3.9 million people celebrated that birthday (though maybe that is the wrong verb). Fifty is an age when baby boomers really start believing that it's not how old you are, but rather how old you feel. And isn't it also when we start reading the obituaries and checking rates on certificates of deposit?
But like my friends who are making me feel old before my time, I may also be rushing things. Just because I will soon turn 50 doesn't mean I have to start managing money in the style of my father, a conservative investor whose riskiest financial decision was whether to reinvest his C.D.'s for one year or two.
I have always heard, probably from my father, that as we grow older -- and closer to retirement -- we have to restructure our portfolios to reduce risk. Well, that's not exactly the best advice. Sorry, Dad.
Charles Schwab, the head of the nation's biggest discount brokerage firm and the author of "You're 50 -- Now What? Investing for the Second Half of Your Life" (Crown Business), didn't exactly laugh when I posed the C.D. strategy to him. But I could tell he wanted to.
"If you stay in C.D.'s, you are guaranteed to lose a third of your purchasing power every 10 years," he said, pointing to inflation.
Mr. Schwab's advice for my generation of aging boomers is to keep doing what we've been doing, but more so. That means continuing to invest aggressively, sticking with stocks and their superior growth because we're going to need the money. Although retirement may be only 15 years away, retirement itself can last a long time. Boomers may be living off their investments for decades.
"You just have to be a substantial growth investor, certainly at 50, although it will decrease to some degree at 60, 65, 70," he said. "But we simply know how few Americans are saving earnestly for retirement. We are undersaved as a nation. " So, he said, now is not the time to cut back.
Mike Sullivan, 54, of Dallas, who runs a consulting firm for start-up businesses, is an aggressive stock investor because he wants a comfortable retirement and is confident that stocks will lead him there. He decided on his strategy long ago, and he saw no reason to change it when he hit 50.
"You don't wait until 50," he said. "Fifty doesn't mean a gun has gone off and you say, 'Gee, I have to have a plan.'
"I determined the kind of lifestyle I wanted and did the analysis of what it would take," he added. "With that data in hand, I asked how should I invest to reach that goal. I've had a plan since I was about 28."
Glenda Kemple, president of Quest Capital Management in Dallas, said that turning 50 should make boomers realize that time was indeed growing shorter -- and that they could not afford mistakes. Becoming a timid investor too soon, she added, would be a big one. "One might argue that at 50 you might want to be a bit more conservative, but I don't agree with that," she said.
"Clients in our age group know that stocks will outperform bonds," she added, noting the historical pattern.
BECAUSE boomers may live to 80, 90 or 100, she said, "our time horizon for this money growing may well be 50 years; we need growth now and into the future for it to last us."
Mr. Sullivan said he altered his portfolio only if his goals or the investing environment changed. Ms. Kemple said investors should monitor their goals regularly. And Mr. Schwab suggested re-evaluating a portfolio about every five years. If our situation or the market has changed, we should consider adjustments. If those factors haven't changed, he said, our strategy shouldn't show our age until we turn 65.
Or, if you have my friends, 64.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Rebate History Doesn't Repeat Itself

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
PEOPLE are worried about energy shortages. Flared jeans are a common sight on Fifth Avenue. The Boston Red Sox are in first place. And the Treasury Department is preparing to mail billions of dollars in tax-rebate checks. 
 Now in its fourth day, the summer of 2001 is looking a lot like the summer of 1975. The question -- for fashion plates, Red Sox fans and economists alike -- is how far the similarities will go. 
 Most economic observers have assumed that the best way to predict the outcome of this year's tax rebate, and the likelihood that it will keep the country out of recession, is to look back 26 years. In 1975, President Gerald R. Ford and Congress agreed to send taxpayers about $8 billion in checks in an effort to increase consumer spending. This year, President Bush and Congress agreed to send out $38 billion -- or roughly $11 billion, in 1975 dollars -- for the same reason.
In the months that followed the Ford rebate, Americans spent between one-quarter and one-third of their small windfalls, according to academic studies, and appeared to save the rest. If they behave similarly this time, they will spend about $10 billion to $12 billion, enough to lift the economy in the second half of the year. Indeed, that is just what many Wall Street economists are predicting, and it is one reason that few expect the current downturn to last into the autumn.
But there are significant differences between then and now. To date, those differences have received almost no attention. They are worth considering one by one:

DISTRIBUTION -- At the core of the 1975 rebate was an idea that seems quite foreign today. Not only did the rebate give lower-income people a bigger percentage break on their taxes, it actually sent more cash to them than it did to wealthier people.
A household that made $20,000 or less received a check for $200. A household that made $30,000 or more received a check for $100. Households in between received rebates in between.
The goal was to get as much of the money as possible into the hands of people most likely to spend it, Donald C. Alexander, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service in 1975, said in an interview last week. "They wanted to have the greatest impact on moderate- to low-income people," Mr. Alexander said, speaking of policy makers at the time. "They felt these people would need the cash most."
Accounting for inflation, a similar plan this year would send $660 checks to families making $66,000 or less and $330 checks to families making $99,000 or more. Instead, because many poor and middle-class people pay little in income tax, they will end up receiving less than the well-off. Married couples making $27,000 to $44,000 will receive $356 this summer, on average, according to an unchallenged analysis by Citizens for Tax Justice. Couples making more than $72,000 will get $595.

SOCIAL SECURITY -- Of course, in 1975 as well, many people did not pay enough taxes to receive a full rebate. So the government also sent a $50 check to people receiving Social Security -- a group it felt still needed the money and was likely to spend it.
One could while away hours debating the relative fairness of the two approaches. (Who is more deserving of a check: those who pay taxes or those who need money?) But there is little question that Mr. Bush's approach should lead to less consumer spending than Mr. Ford's. Wealthy people simply spend a smaller portion of their income than others do.

STAYING POWER? -- When Americans consider a tax cut to be temporary, they spend less of it than they do if the cut is permanent, according to a study by Alan Blinder, a Princeton economist. The rebates of a quarter-century ago were part of a law originally set to last one year. The cuts in the new law are scheduled to last nine years. If people equate that with permanence, they may see the rebates as a down payment on future income, Mr. Blinder said, and spend more of them than they did in 1975.

INFLATION -- In the mid-1970's, inflation was running at an annual rate of about 9 percent, and people could reasonably expect that saved money would be worth a lot less in the future than it was on the day they received it. Today, inflation is about 3 percent.
This difference could explain why 46 percent of Americans said they planned to spend their rebate in 1975, according to one poll at the time. Recent surveys have found that 20 percent to 30 percent of people expect to spend most of their rebates.
Combined, the differences between the two rebates suggest that Americans will spend a smaller portion this year than they did 26 years ago. That could mean that economic growth will remain sluggish -- and that the optimism of most analysts could end up having the same staying power as bell-bottoms and the Red Sox usually do.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Suddenly, Less Plaid Is More for Burberry's Chief

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
RADIATING all the energy of an elegant exclamation point, Rose Marie Bravo, clad in a slim red coat and tartan scarf, strode into Burberry's flagship store here recently and surveyed the new fall collection.
 Save for an item or two, the Burberry plaid was nowhere in sight. Instead, black safari jackets and crisp white shirts lined the walls with almost military precision. 
 "It takes time to develop an identity, but we are getting there," said Ms. Bravo, Burberry's chief executive and the architect of its revival. 
After a dizzying year in which its iconic pattern was in demand by celebrities, socialites and everyday shoppers alike, Ms. Bravo -- who is in her late 40's, but declines to be more specific -- is poised to reinvent Burberry again, this time in a more sophisticated incarnation, dependent neither on its playful patterns nor on Kate Moss wearing one of its bikinis.
The path to maturity is never easy for a company whose fortunes are tied to fashion whims, but several factors make Burberry's growing pains particularly acute.
With its signature plaid at risk of becoming last year's fad, Burberry is more reliant than ever on the stylishness of its clothes -- yet its head designer has just left. Slowing economies have depressed sales of luxury goods, making it more difficult for Burberry to maintain the heady growth of the last fiscal year. And wobbly stock markets have cast uncertainty on the timing of an initial public offering of Burberry shares by its parent company, Great Universal Stores, even as a costly expansion requires cash.
"The challenge for Burberry is to move from being a niche company with one or two distinctive looks like the plaid or the trench coat to a more genuinely international brand on the same level as Gucci or LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton," said David Jeary, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.
More than a year ago, in step with a broader fashion trend in which logos became bigger and bolder, Ms. Bravo bumped up the Burberry plaid, splashing it on everything from bandannas to babies' booties.
But now some people wonder whether Ms. Bravo took the tartan too far.
"I don't want to look at it any more," said Pat Tunsky, creative director with Doneger Group, a New York fashion consulting firm.
It is not just industry insiders who were turned off. "I liked Burberry until it became fashionable to wear a G-string with a Burberry check," said Stephanie Epiro, of the online dating service Woowho in London. 
Burberry is pulling back quickly to what Ms. Bravo calls "check under cover."
"You will have to hunt for it," she said, under a collar, or inside a coat.
Accompanying the new look is an advertising campaign with tongue-in-cheek photographs of models juxtaposed against British icons, like Ms. Moss topless, save for a striped -- not plaid -- scarf, beside a bobby.
Burberry is making the leap under the leadership of an unproven designer. Roberto Menichetti, who is credited with putting the company back on the fashion map, left to spend more time with his family's clothes manufacturing business in Italy and was replaced in April by Christopher Bailey, plucked from Gucci's ranks.
Even though Mr. Menichetti confined his designs to the top-line Prorsum label, while two other Burberry designers, Mike McGrath and Deborah Lloyd, were responsible for commercial hits, Mr. Menichetti's work won raves from the fashion elite.
"I was a big fan of Roberto," said Julie Gilhart, vice president for fashion merchandising at Barneys New York. "I don't know Chris."
Ms. Bravo said Burberry needed a designer who would devote more time to all the lines, "giving the feeling of one hand guiding the brand."
Creating an identity is more important now that Burberry, having put its house in order in its core European and Asian markets, is turning to the United States.
Only one-fifth of Burberry's sales come from the United States, compared with two-thirds from Europe, while the split for other luxury-goods companies is more even, said Sagra Maceira de Rosen, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. "Expanding in the U.S. would be very important for Burberry," Mrs. de Rosen said. "It is a large market, but underpenetrated by luxury goods."
In New York, Burberry plans to expand its flagship store on East 57th Street in Manhattan, doubling its size. (During construction this summer, it will move temporarily to the site of the old Henri Bendel store on West 57th Street.) It will open its first store in Beverly Hills and refurbish several other stores, including one on Michigan Avenue in Chicago. It is also opening smaller stores in several upscale malls, including the Westchester in White Plains, combined with a push for larger boutiques in department stores like Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue. 
Opening even one large store can cost several million dollars -- David Tyler, Burberry's finance director, declined to say how many millions -- and the aggressive expansion is expected to eat into profits.
That means Burberry's stupendous growth in the fiscal year that ended March 31, when profits tripled to $:69.5 million ($98 million), on sales that nearly doubled to $:425 million, is unlikely to be repeated.
Credit Suisse forecasts a 12 percent increase in profits, to $:78 million, for the current fiscal year, on sales that are expected to rise about 16 percent, to $:495 million.
All of this casts uncertainty over a planned initial offering of as many as a quarter of Burberry's shares. Some analysts and investment bankers had expected Burberry to strike while its popularity was rising, selling shares no later than December, but rocky capital markets now make the timing unclear, they say.
Mr. Tyler said that no date had been set, but that Burberry was sticking to its plan to go public within a year. Mr. Jeary, the Credit Suisse analyst, said, "The big issue as far as the flotation is whether the brand continues the success of the past year."
Burberry has fallen in and out of fashion many times in its 145-year history. Originally known for its rugged fabrics -- its founder, Thomas Burberry, is credited with inventing gabardine, and for outfitting three expeditions to the South Pole -- Burberry became a luxury brand associated with the nostalgia of the British colonial empire.
Great Universal, a British company that runs a home-shopping network and other businesses, bought Burberry in 1955 and let it coast on its reputation, not investing in new designs, marketing or infrastructure.
When Ms. Bravo took over in 1997, distribution was a mess. Burberry had little control over where its products were sold or how they were displayed. Asia had become its biggest market, but most of those sales and profits went to licensing partners. Then the Asian economic meltdown hit all luxury-goods makers, but few as hard as Burberry.
Ms. Bravo weeded out some retailers and sold only to the most exclusive stores. She increased sales and profits by buying Burberry's Spanish licensee and by renegotiating contracts in Japan, a strategy she intends to repeat when the remainder of Burberry's Asian licenses come up for renewal in December.
Some of Burberry's biggest successes were more a happy accident than a planned strategy. An offhand suggestion by Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, that Burberry make a bikini spawned a swimwear line. A pregnant Stella Tennant, a Burberry model, inspired a baby collection. And on impulse, Ms. Bravo suggested stocking a plaid pump worn by Ms. Moss in an advertisement, even though Burberry did not sell shoes at the time. Known simply as the Kate Shoe, it created a frenzy, and led to a line of Burberry boots.
MS. BRAVO, known for her tenacity in business and keen fashion instinct, cut her teeth at the old Abraham & Straus, and went on to become chief executive of I. Magnin. As president of Saks Fifth Avenue from 1992 to 1997, she is credited with revitalizing the store chain, which had become stodgy, by giving exposure to fresh young designers like Alexander McQueen and Julian Macdonald.
Ms. Bravo would often rise for 5 a.m. jogs on business trips, some of her staff in tow, recalled Nicole Fischelis, fashion director at Saks at the time. A stickler for detail, Ms. Bravo would keep several jackets in the trunk of her car, donning an Armani for a meeting with Giorgio, or a Prada for one with Miuccia, Mrs. Fischelis said.
Domenico De Sole, chief executive of Gucci, said Ms. Bravo was one of the few executives to give him a chance in 1994, when his company was on the verge of bankruptcy. "People were worried that we wouldn't be able to deliver the product," he said. "But Rose Marie was one of the first to understand what we were doing."
Now industry executives are comparing Burberry's turnaround with the resurgence of Gucci. Asked if the comparison unsettled her, Ms. Bravo clasped her hands and rolled her eyes heavenward in mock prayer, saying, "It should only happen."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Derwood S. Chase Jr. And David B. Scott; 
Chase Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
DON'T confuse the global megabank Chase Manhattan with the Chase Investment Counsel Corporation in Charlottesville, Va., investment adviser to the $36 million Chase Growth fund.
 "We've always tried very hard to point out that we're not a Chase bank fund," Derwood S. Chase Jr., the president and chief investment officer of Chase Investment, who works with David B. Scott in managing the fund. 
 The Chase confusion has diminished, now that the mutual funds of the big Manhattan bank are being sold under the J. P. Morgan label. (Chase Manhattan merged with Morgan last year to become J. P. Morgan Chase.) But the tiny Chase Growth fund marches on, and its performance has been outstanding relative to the market and its peer group of funds. 
The fund returned 12.7 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 5.3 percent for its large-growth fund category and 5.3 percent for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The portfolio lost 5.2 percent in the last 12 months, compared with losses of 30.7 percent for its group and 5 percent for the S.& P. 500.
Mr. Chase, 70, and Mr. Scott, 46, the fund's senior portfolio manager, describe themselves as stock pickers who look for growth at a reasonable price. They combine fundamental, quantitative and technical research -- the same process they use to manage $1 billion in institutional and individual accounts for Chase Investment Counsel.
The managers start by screening about 5,000 domestic stocks with market capitalizations of more than $500 million, searching for consistent earnings growth. They look for annual average earnings growth of at least 10 percent for 4 of the last 5 years and 7 of the last 10. That brings down their list of companies to about 600. Then they conduct a series of tests, looking for return on equity of at least 15 percent, a debt-to-equity ratio of no more than 50 percent and substantial reinvestment of earnings.
The 40 to 60 companies that pass all the screens become "buy" candidates. Two senior analysts review the data and pore over balance sheets.
"We want to see that cash-flow returns are still strong after the balance sheet is adjusted for noncash items like depreciation, good will and amortization," Mr. Chase said.
They do on-site research of companies, too, looking for evidence that suggests strong fundamentals and rising stock prices.
THE managers like the Sysco Corporation of Houston, the big distributor of food and paper products to restaurants and institutions.
Sysco derives 65 percent of its revenue from the restaurant business, and it is gaining market share among hospitals and hotels and in other markets, Mr. Chase said. "It generally does well whether the economy is doing well or not," he said.
Its earnings growth has averaged 17 percent annually for the last five years, compared with 8 to 12 percent for most food, beverage and food products companies. He expects the company's earnings to grow 21 percent a year, on average, over the next three to five years.
The managers originally bought shares at $20 in December 1999. The stock closed on Friday at $28.43; the managers' 12-month target price is $35.
Another favorite is Boeing, which is aiming to diversify beyond its core business of aircraft manufacturing. The company's earnings have grown 20 percent a year over the last five years, Mr. Scott said, well above its competitors in the aerospace and aircraft industry.
Boeing is aiming to build the Sonic Cruiser, a jet that would fly at just below the speed of sound, and is adding variations of existing models, he said. It recently announced advanced research and initial production on a satellite to direct aircraft for landing and takeoff, supplementing or replacing the radar systems currently used by the Federal Aviation Administration.
The managers originally bought shares in March at $61.50. They closed on Friday at $57; their target price is $75.
A new holding is Calpine Corporation of San Jose, Calif., which develops and operates power plants. As demand for power surges in California and elsewhere, Calpine is building plants in markets where none have been built for years. Mr. Scott expects earnings to grow an average of 32 percent a year over the next three to five years.
The fund bought the stock at $51 in April. It now trades at $37.70, compared with the managers' target price of $64.

HEADLINE: A Fast Track for Mexico 

BYLINE:  By Fernando Margain and Walter Russell Mead; Fernando Margain, from the National Action Party, is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee of the Mexican Senate. Walter Russell Mead is senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.

 BODY:
It is Mexico's turn for an economic miracle. After World War II it took less than a generation for Western Europe and Japan to go from poverty to affluence. Later came transformations in Spain, Portugal, Ireland, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan. Mexico, with 100 million citizens impatient for social and economic progress, can be next -- if its partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement adopt a strategy to help.
 Mexico has made radical political and economic changes over the past 20 years, reducing tariffs, privatizing industries and opening its electoral system. Since Nafta took effect in 1994, Mexico's annual exports to the United States have gone from $51 billion to $120 billion but wages in Mexico, adjusted for inflation, have fallen 15 percent. The gap between Mexico's impoverished South and relatively prosperous North has grown. 
 As Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, frequently points out, 51 percent of Mexicans live in poverty, and 17.9 million, including the great majority of Mexico's Indians, live in severe poverty, on less than $2 a day. If Mexico is to become a truly modern society, more of its citizens must become part of the middle class. Such a transformation would also help Mexico's Nafta partners, the United States and Canada, by making Mexicans better customers and reducing the pressure of migrants seeking work in richer countries to the north.
The Nafta nations should learn from the example of the European Union. Worried that migrants from Spain, Portugal and Ireland would flood into the richer E.U. nations, the union provided loans and grants for large-scale development and public works programs to create jobs for these workers in their own countries.
In North America, a similar strategy could work. Public agencies with equal representation from all three Nafta countries could be created to borrow money cheaply, with loans backed by the governments, to finance large public works projects across Mexico like highways, with money set aside for environmental cleanup. A three-country panel could ensure that projects complied with environmental and fair labor standards.
The Nafta partners, in helping Mexico, should also move toward a regional approach to energy. Mexico's Constitution now limits foreign participation in its energy industry. But in the context of a deeper Nafta partnership, Mexico might be persuaded to end this limitation as part of a broader plan for developing North America's energy reserves. There is already interdependence; Mexico provides 12 percent of American petroleum imports and is a net importer from the United States of refined petroleum products. Both countries would benefit from creation of more pipelines and electrical lines to carry energy north from Mexico.
Gradual, measured steps to create open borders should also be part of a new Nafta relationship. American citizens are concerned about illegal migration while Mexicans see border issues as partly about economics but also about human rights. More than 400 people die every year trying to enter the United States from Mexico. The best long-term solution is economic development that raises wages and creates new jobs in Mexico. In the near term, allowing an expanded flow of seasonal and guest workers would improve conditions on both sides of the border.
In the long term, we will need a more creative approach to migration. More than 100 million Americans and about 12 million Canadians will turn 65 in the next 30 years. Why not make it easier for these people to retire to Mexico, where the weather is warm and living costs are low? An agreement allowing retired citizens from all three Nafta countries to live freely in all of them -- and United States legislation letting Medicare benefits be used in other Nafta countries -- could open the border to a new kind of migrant and help create jobs in Mexico to serve this new population. 
With commitment from its Nafta partners, Mexico can become an advanced industrial democracy within a generation.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Reality Check; 
Will Patients' Rights Fix the Wrongs?

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN; Michael M. Weinstein is a former economics columnist and editorial writer for The New York Times who specialized in health-care issues. He is now a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.

 BODY:
HOVERING above last week's Senate debate over the so-called patients' bill of rights was an unspoken question: was all the speechmaking really just a smokescreen that obscures the truly tough health care problems facing the country?
 Democrats said the Republican bill would maroon patients with managed-care plans that would deny lifesaving medical procedures. Republicans countered that the Democrats were hawking a "trial lawyers bill" that would encourage frivolous lawsuits, driving up costs and making coverage unaffordable for millions of Americans. President Bush vowed to veto the Democratic bill. 
 On key points, however, the two bills are nearly identical. Indeed, a co-sponsor of the Republican bill conceded that he would "not lose sleep" if the Democrat version passed. 
The more profound question is whether the Senate debate is a sideshow. The legislation being considered would fail to reach the roughly 40 million Americans without insurance, as well as the 15 million others, many chronically ill, who buy stripped-down coverage at exorbitant prices because they can't buy coverage through an employer. Even among those who would be affected, the actual number of complaints about health-plan denials of medical treatment remains tiny. 
But the real crisis in health care, say many health experts, lies not with care denied, but with the quality of the care that's given. 
"The biggest threat to life and limb," said Michael L. Millenson, a health expert with the human resources consulting firm William M. Mercer, comes from "what happens to you once you reach the doctor's office or hospital."
The bills that were debated last week in Washington have little to do with that. Instead, they focus on giving patients the right to sue for damages when their health plan denies coverage for necessary treatments. 
A quirk in federal law currently immunizes many employer-based health plans from major lawsuits when they refuse to pay for what patients believe to be medically necessary care. Public pressure has been mounting for Congress to eliminate the exemption, and federal courts have already begun to chip away at it. 
Republicans and Demnocrats propose essentially the same solution: mandatory external review. 
Patients whose health plans refuse to pay for what they believe is necessary care would be first required to take their case before independent medical experts. Under the Democrats' bill, patients could then go to court to overturn the experts' findings. Under the Republican bill, patients could seek tort damages only if they won their case before the external reviewers.
The theory is that external review will give patients a fair hearing and wipe out the need for most litigation. The experience of states in which mandatory external review has been tried, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, confirms these expectations. When the external review sides with the patient, the plans almost always back down, unwilling to bear the legal risk of continuing to deny coverage for the disputed treatment. When the external review sides with the health plan, few patients, or their lawyers, waste time and money by going before a jury to argue against a plan that has won approval from independent physicians.
The bills also include similar consumer protections. Each guarantees patients access to emergency rooms, specialists, clinical trials and pharmaceutical drugs. 
There are some differences, however. The Democrats' bill would subject plans to more regulations and more litigation, including in state courts, with a threat of substantially higher monetary damages. The Democrats would also more readily impose new federal rules on states with weaker consumer protections. But few of these differences rise to the level of important principle.
THE more vexing concern is whether the attention being lavished on patients' bills of rights is out of proportion to the impact. After all, the number of people who are likely to take advantage of external review is minute. Medicare already offers external review for its 40 million enrollees. So do dozens of states, though federal law does not allow states to impose external review on plans that cover the employees of most large companies. 
The Kaiser Family Foundation has found that there are fewer than 2 external reviews each year for every 1,000 Medicare enrollees. In Pennsylvania there were fewer than 200 external reviews in 1997 among 5 million eligible enrollees. In Maryland, 255 cases from a pool of about 3.5 million enrollees were adjudicated last year under the state's external review system. In 120 cases, the plans backed down before settlements were reached. The patients won about half the remaining cases -- so fewer than 70 people won relief from their health plans. 
Despite the small numbers, mandatory external review can yield tangible benefits. Dr. Michael A. Stocker, chief executive of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, says external review, which the plan adopted before the New York State legislature made it mandatory in 1999, has helped to cut litigation. And few would argue that all patients benefit from the knowledge that they have a right, if needed, to impartial dispute resolution. 
Dr. Lucian L. Leape, a professor at the Harvard University School of Public Health and the co-author of two major reports on health-care quality from the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, said that given the fact that only a few cases go to external review, patients' rights legislation is "unlikely to lead to dire consequences. But," he added, " neither is it likely to improve health outcomes very much." 
To truly improve the quality of medical care, Washington needs to look in a different direction, says Dr. Leape. The scandalous fact about American health care, he and other experts have noted, is how little of what physicians do is backed by careful scientific evidence. A committee of the Institute of Medicine concluded this year that the nation's health-care system is a "tangled, highly fragmented web that often wastes resources by providing unnecessary services and duplicating efforts, leaving unaccountable gaps in care and failing to build on the strength of all health professionals." The panel called for reorganization and reform to fix "a disjointed and inefficient system."
Dr. Leape and other experts estimate that perhaps 20 percent to 30 percent of medical procedures are wrongly prescribed. And a 1999 report from the institute showed that hospitals lack basic systems to catch errors before they kill or maim patients, leading to as many as 100,000 deaths each year from preventable errors. 
Fewer than half of all Medicare patients who suffer heart attacks receive proper drugs. This shortfall cannot be attributed to penny-pinching bureaucrats at for-profit health plans, because Medicare is, after all, largely fee-for-service.
DR. LEAPE'S solution to America's health care woes includes widespread adoption of information technology to reduce errors, including computerized patients records and electronic ordering of pharmaceutical drugs. He also wants hospitals to identify and retrain substandard physicians before they harm patients. Many health-care experts want to collect and publish information on the quality of hospital and physician performance, arming patients with the information they need to decide where to be treated. 
Patients' rights, along the lines debated in Congress, does not rank near the top of the experts' lists. Mr. Millenson speaks for many in the health-care field when he says: "I'm all for holding health plans accountable for their actions. But if we truly care about patients' rights, we need to hold doctors and hospitals at least equally accountable."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Breadline, What Breadline?

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
THIS month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the nation's unemployment rate had fallen slightly in May, to 4.4 percent. The decline was the first in nine months, and with many stocks rising again, it suggested that the economic slowdown of 2001 might be near its end. 
 But that measure was almost the only labor-market gauge to improve in May. Fewer people held jobs than in April. More people applied for unemployment insurance. A greater percentage of those without jobs had been fired or laid off rather than had quit. And a larger number of people who wanted full-time work could find only part-time work. 
 "Fewer people are working, but it looks like good news," said Alexander Keyssar, a historian at Duke. "It really doesn't make sense."
The unemployment rate is the single most widely followed measure of the American people's economic health. The government publishes it on the first Friday of each month, and it immediately assumes a status of unassailable truth.
But the history of this sacrosanct number is as much about politics as about statistics, and at a time when joblessness is rising, the history has a new relevance.
In the 1870's, an economic downturn was throwing people out of work. According to one estimate, three million workers were unemployed.
Carroll D. Wright, the head of the Massachusetts Bureau of Statistics of Labor in 1878, did not believe it. The three-million figure was "reckless," he said, a "wild guess." Partly to disprove it, Wright undertook the first recorded study of unemployment in the United States. He found that fewer than 30,000 people were unemployed in Massachusetts, about one-tenth of what the doomsayers -- or "croakers," as he called them -- were claiming.
"We have given the croaker the benefit of every doubt," Wright wrote, according to "Out of Work," a history of joblessness by Mr. Keyssar. An "intelligent canvass," based on the facts, had shown the croakers to be wrong, claimed Wright.
The canvass may have been intelligent, but it also defined unemployment in the narrowest way possible. People whom the police judged to be uninterested in work were excluded, according to Mr. Keyssar. The result, as even Wright acknowledged, was that a "large percentage" of people without jobs were not counted. 
Almost 125 years later, the methods and views of Wright, who became the first chief of the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, still determine how unemployment in America is measured. 
Today, only people who are without a job and have actively looked for work in the last four weeks are considered unemployed. Those who have stopped looking -- because they have given up, for example -- fall into the same category as children or retirees. They are not part of the labor force.
The result is that, in a typical month, about five million Americans who are without a job and say they want one are not counted as unemployed. Were they included, the unemployment rate would double. 
The government once used a more inclusive measure. About a century ago the Census Bureau began tallying the number of Americans who had been out of work at some point in the previous six months or year. But after a few decades, policy makers opted for a system that produced a smaller number.
This preference for rosier data sums up the conflicted attitude that the United States, and virtually all free-market societies, hold toward joblessness. On the one hand, governments habitually say they're on the side of the worker. On the other hand, the presence of a pool of unemployed labor has long been considered a necessary part of an efficient market economy. It is the natural result of some companies failing while others succeed. 
Economic circumstances have usually determined which attitude dominates. During the Depression, the United States spent huge sums on public works to keep people employed. Then, at the close of World War II, concern that a wave of returning soldiers would flood the labor market led Congress to pass the Full Employment Act. (They later dropped the "Full." ) The bill declared that creating "useful employment opportunities" was "the continuing policy and responsibility of the federal government," according to "Unemployment in History," by John A. Garraty, an emeritus professor of history at Columbia.
 BUT after the "stagflation" of the 1970's, when unemployment and inflation rose simultaneously, economists and politicians began to rethink the idea that government should help find people work or underwrite their joblessness. The free-market policies of a century earlier returned. State governments paid benefits to a smaller portion of the unemployed than before; labor unions lost key court cases; and eventually, a Democratic president and a Republican Congress limited the amount of time in which those without jobs could receive welfare payments. 
In recent months, unemployment has fallen to its lowest level in three decades. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, frets about the inflationary effect, should it fall further, and yet few complain that he is indifferent to the average worker, noted Gary Gerstle, a professor of American history at the University of Maryland.
"The United States has been enormously successful in lowering the unemployment rate through efforts to strengthen the market, rather than regulate it," he said. As a result, "concerns about unemployment are secondary to concerns about the stock market." 
This victory over widespread joblessness would seem more assured, however, if it did not rest in part on the government's incomplete statistics. In May, 6.2 million Americans were counted as unemployed, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics' seasonally adjusted numbers. Another 5.2 million wanted work but had not actively searched for it in the four weeks before the survey. And 3.4 million people held part-time jobs because they could not find full-time work. If the government were to include all these groups, the current jobless rate would be 9.9 percent, instead of the official 4.4 percent.
Most economists expect unemployment -- both the rate and the real thing -- to increase in the coming months. That is precisely the time, Mr. Keyssar said, that people may want more information about the job market than government's definition of unemployment provides.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Economic Anxiety Among the Affluent

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino

 BODY:
The economic slowdown and stock market volatility have made many Americans nervous about their finances, and survey results released last week show that even the nation's most affluent people are a little jittery.
 In a sampling of affluent Americans, 70 percent said they thought that stock market gains would now be lower than in recent years, and a nearly identical percentage expressed concern that the next generation would have a more difficult time financially than they did. 
 Almost all -- 92 percent of the 151 people questioned -- said their investment portfolios had declined in value since the middle of last year. On average, they said, their stocks and stock funds lost 13 percent during the first four months of this year.
But they are not panicking, said Jeffrey S. Maurer, chief executive of the U.S. Trust Corporation, the wealth management company in New York that conducted the survey. "Although they are clearly more nervous about the short term," Mr. Maurer said, "they seem to understand, correctly, that investing is a long-term proposition." Fifty-seven percent of those surveyed had no plans for changes in their portfolios.
The survey defined affluent Americans as having annual household income of at least $300,000. Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Rate-Cut Hopes Overpower Profit Worries

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

 BODY:
Despite new warnings about corporate earnings shortfalls and reports showing that the economy remains weak, many stocks ended the week modestly higher, buoyed by expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates when it meets this week. 
 On the down side, first-time jobless claims remained near their recent highs while the trade deficit narrowed, mostly because of slackening consumer demand. 
 But there were positive surprises. The Oracle Corporation said it would beat expectations for the second quarter. And tobacco stocks got a lift after the government said it was open to negotiating a settlement in its longstanding lawsuit against tobacco companies.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose slightly, finishing at 1,225.35, up 10.99 points, or 0.9 percent. The Nasdaq composite also edged higher, to 2,034.84, up 6.41 points, or 0.3 percent. Only the Dow industrials fell, finishing at 10,604.59, down 19.05, or 0.2 percent. 
 In the bond markets, comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, that inflation remains moderate lifted expectations for a half-point cut in interest rates. Bond prices surged, with the yield on the 10-year note falling to 5.12 percent from 5.24 percent the previous week. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: How Pipeline And Landscape Live Together 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: FAIRBANKS, Alaska 

 BODY:
Just as the United States is now debating the trade-offs between energy and the environment, particularly in Alaska, a generation ago a similar debate was focused on the Trans-Alaska Pipeline. Ferocious claims were made by proponents and opponents alike. 
 A photographer's journey along the pipeline, from end to end, suggests that the starkest fears of ecological devastation have not come to pass. And yet, just as the current debate over drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge centers on the value of leaving a wilderness alone, the pipeline offers a powerful glimpse into a wilderness touched. 
 Eight hundred miles long, 48 inches in diameter, stretching across the Arctic tundra, over (or under) more than 800 rivers and streams, and through three mountain ranges, the pipeline bisects the nation's biggest state. Even the critics who wish it had never been built agree that its construction, in the 1970's, was an epic feat of engineering, one that employed 28,000 men and women at the peak of construction and claimed 31 lives. 
For the Trans-Alaska Pipeline has definitely become a part of the landscape. Its beauty, or its decided lack of beauty, is in the eye of the beholder. Those in the oil industry, and many of the tourists who come to marvel at it, say the pipeline blends in with the scenery, so much so that grizzly bears romp around it in the north and seals sun near it at Valdez. Vice President George Bush memorably observed in 1988 that some caribou even like to "snuggle up next to the pipeline." Other people, of course, see an eyesore, an ugly gash by the hand of man across a magnificent natural landscape. 
Since the first drop of crude in 1977, more than 13 billion barrels of North Slope oil have traveled from Prudhoe Bay in the far north to the southern terminus at Valdez. Oil transformed the Alaskan economy. It provides 85 percent of the state budget and is the basis of the state's optimistically named Permanent Fund, whose dividends are parceled out annually: last fall, every man, woman and child in Alaska received a check for $1,963.86. 
Now nearing its 25th anniversary, the pipeline is delivering oil at only half the peak rate, reached in the late 1980's, of two million barrels a day. Alaskans tend strongly to favor President Bush's proposal to open the Arctic refuge to drilling as a way to continue the bonanza. 
And they enthusiastically support plans for another pipeline, to deliver the huge natural gas reserves locked in the Arctic. This one could parallel the oil pipeline for much of the way, then divert east to Canada and south to the lower 48 states, running longer than the Great Wall of China. 
Environmentalists say that as the oil pipeline ages, its corrosion will make it increasingly susceptible to leaks and other damage. A spokesman for the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, which operates it and is jointly owned by the six oil companies that send the oil from the north, says: "The pipeline is not infallible, it is not indestructible. But with proper maintenance, the life of the pipeline is indefinite."
Every inch of the pipeline is monitored by computers, and it shuts down when an unexpected drop in pressure is detected, limiting the size of any spill. Since it opened, 19 spills of 100 barrels or more have been reported, none close in size to Alaska's biggest oil spill. The company once calculated that the amount the pipeline had spilled represented just .0000025 percent of the amount delivered. 
When John McPhee wrote "Coming Into the Country" in 1977, he found Alaskans who were, presciently, much more concerned about what would happen once the oil got to the end of the line. "There is the real problem," Mr. McPhee wrote -- "not the possible spills on land but the spills that could happen in Prince William Sound." Twelve years later, the Exxon Valdez ran aground on Bligh Reef, spilling 260,000 barrels into the sound. 
About 375 miles of the pipeline run underground -- including a four-mile stretch that is refrigerated to prevent the earth above from softening, which could make it harder for caribou herds to cross. The remaining 425 miles are elevated, in part to keep pipes that are warm with the coursing oil from melting the tundra permafrost. It is these elevated sections that seem to stretch on and on when viewed from an airplane, that attract tourists, and that are a perpetual element of the land for Alaskan wildlife to contend with, as these photographs attest.

HEADLINE: A Kennedy Readies Herself to Run for Maryland Governor 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 21 

 BODY:
One by one her male siblings in the Kennedy clan have taken their turn in the spotlight but shown mixed results in the family's endless call to politics. But not Robert F. Kennedy's firstborn, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, who, in her seventh year as lieutenant governor of Maryland, has worked quietly at grass-roots politics to position herself as the front-runner in the race for governor next year.
 In this possibility, Lieutenant Governor Townsend promises to trump all living Kennedy men for executive bragging rights. But even more, her victory would thrust a different kind of Kennedy into the national arena -- a working mother of four daughters, a scandal-free Kennedy whose style mixes policy wonkery and passion for public service with a wisp of her father's amiability on the stump. 
"When I was growing up, I never dreamed of getting involved in politics; needless to say I had very successful men in my family," Ms. Townsend observed in her statehouse office. "The Kennedy women did not run for public office," she said, sitting near a war bond poster of Joan of Arc, proclaiming "Women of America, Save Your Country." The poster was a gift from her husband, David, a professor who for years has arranged his schedule at St. John's College here so he can be the family homemaker and free time for his wife to politick.
Under such circumstances, the lieutenant governor, a lean, intense 49-year-old who has not yet declared for the Democratic nomination, offers no harsh words for the male chauvinism of her upbringing.
"I try not to resent things; that's a bad emotion," Ms. Townsend said. "A better analysis is to understand that when I was growing up it was not a time when women ran for public office. But the women's movement opened up possibilities for me that I had not seen."
As a girl, she thought of being a nun, she said, but gravitated toward politics, where her father's old advice to the family has become her mantra: "It's only God and angels who are lookers-on. Each of us must get involved."
In seven years, Ms. Townsend has ascended in the state from shaky political neophyte to poll standings that run double digits ahead of most of her male rivals in a state where voters register Democratic almost two to one.
Republicans are having trouble fielding an experienced candidate to run against her. They criticize the lieutenant governor's record as little more than a nurturing of the Kennedy name. But they concede that their best hope to derail her would be a Democratic primary between her and Baltimore's new mayor, Martin O'Malley, who is not expected to run.
"She's more hype than substance," Michael S. Steele, chairman of the state Republican Party, said, stressing that Ms. Townsend has yet to win an election on her own. "She's long on being a Kennedy, and that's all that's there."
Longtime political friends scoff at that.
"Listen, Kathleen wasn't created by some sort of Kennedy organization that runs around and salts the earth with new Kennedys for the dynasty," Adam Walinsky, one of Robert Kennedy's aides, said. Mr. Walinsky has been close to her since she was 16; he attended her father at his deathbed. "Whatever she has in Maryland she had to do all by herself, working enormously hard."
Politicians are particularly aware of the lieutenant governor's role in the 1998 re-election, when she surprised critics by emphatically asserting herself. She became featured more prominently in campaign advertisements after bringing in national campaign specialists to repair the ticket's early image problems. Her political mentor, Gov. Parris N. Glendening, credits her with crucial help in winning another four years.
"The lieutenant governor now finds herself in the right place at the right time with a great name," Herb Smith, political science chairman at Western Maryland University, said. "She's got the clear path to the office. In her early years, insiders treated her like Rodney Dangerfield, no respect. But I think she's shown there's a there there. She has built a very real presence in Maryland with an extensive network within the state and nationally. That's a tough combination to beat."
A sometimes awkward speaker, Ms. Townsend has a style like her father's, showing enthusiasm for plunging into crowds as if as an antidote to shyness. She has worked to nip criticism of her early speaking gaffes. The most celebrated of them -- her proud assertion at a Super Bowl visit that "the team made a football" rather than a touchdown -- is treated lightly by Democratic strategists as hardly harming her with female voters.
With the major portfolios Governor Glendening delegated to her, including economic development, criminal justice and the state police, Ms. Townsend can talk issues in detail and has developed contacts with an array of business and civic leaders. But as the election year approaches, some friends in the public sector are awaiting a stronger definition of her independence.
"The feeling among a number of us is that it will be interesting to see what she will really be like in her own right," said H. Furlong Baldwin, chairman of the Mercantile Bankshares Corporation, who needled the lieutenant governor at a business meeting this week to come out for some popular suburban road construction that Governor Glendening fiercely opposed. "There's a general feeling that since we never knew her as an independently elected person, it's time she starts defining herself as someone who's more than just a loyal lieutenant."
It is clear that Ms. Townsend loves to talk issues as an activist in the Democratic Leadership Council, the party's middle-ground vehicle, which Bill Clinton rode to the White House. The council accommodates her variegated agenda in which she favors gun control, work for welfare and capital punishment.
For years, Ms. Townsend was identified as the only Kennedy ever to lose a general election -- the 1986 race for Congress in suburban Maryland, which she leaped into somewhat quixotically two years after moving to the state.
"If I had not lost that race I wouldn't be lieutenant governor today," she said. In losing, she said, she was inspired by young campaign volunteers to stay in public service as a community program organizer, where she quietly built her reputation. That, her sex and the Kennedy name proved irresistible when Mr. Glendening needed a running mate.
Seventeen months from the chance to win an election on her own, Ms. Townsend seems not at all fazed at being the odds-on favorite to gain a major executive trophy for the Kennedys.
"It's a pretty pleasant position to be in," she said, applying a classic political clubhouse poke of emphasis to her listener's arm. "I intend to be in politics a long time."

HEADLINE: Building Costs For Schools Investigated 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE FLANDERS

 BODY:
The city has begun an investigation into cost overruns on school construction projects by the Board of Education because spending is running about 20 percent over budget in the second year of a five-year, $7 billion capital plan, officials said yesterday. At the current spending rate, there would be a $1.5 billion budget gap by the end of the five years.
 City budget officials believe that only about half of the overspending can be explained by citywide inflation in construction costs. The remainder, they said, is the result of flaws in the board's budgeting procedures, including a tendency to underestimate costs so as to be able to promise more new schools. 
 "It is serious mismanagement and incompetence at the board that has resulted in this shortfall," said Adam L. Barsky, the director of the city's Office of Management and Budget.
Mr. Barsky said that the board had made the city aware of the overspending only in the past two weeks, leading Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office to request an investigation by the city's auditors, KPMG Peat Marwick. News of the study, which is expected to take several months, was reported yesterday in The New York Post.
Board of Education officials said that the city's Office of Management and Budget had been aware of the overruns for some time and blamed the overruns on rising construction costs.
"This sounds a little like Claude Rains in 'Casablanca' being shocked to find out there's gambling going on," said Anthony Shorris, a deputy chancellor on the board. "There was no secret made of the individual impact of higher construction bids on board projects in our regular meetings with the O.M.B."
Gov. George E. Pataki's special commission on New York city schools is also investigating the board's management of its capital plan, and expects to issue a report on the first two years of the plan at the end of June.
Roslynn Mauskopf, the chairwoman of the commission, said that its preliminary study, which was published in May 2000, had signaled many of the issues now being raised by the city, including a long-running tendency to underestimate construction costs.
"Our report put the board on notice over a year ago that the current capital plan was already going well over budget," Ms. Mauskopf said. "This is not new news."
