HEADLINE: Struggling to Carve Out Common Ground, U.N. Tackles AIDS 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 22 

 BODY:
The devastation is not in dispute. Worldwide, 36 million people are estimated to have AIDS or be carrying the virus that causes it. Nearly 22 million have died, many of them children. And new infections gallop on, at the rate of 5 million last year. 
 But trying to forge a consensus for action has exposed fault lines at the United Nations. Starting Monday, 3,000 diplomats, government officials, health experts and members of advocacy groups will gather for three days in the General Assembly to discuss how to cope with a medical catastrophe that has accumulated political baggage since the virus was identified two decades ago. 
The scheduled speakers at the United Nations Special Session on H.I.V./AIDS include two dozen heads of state or government, many from Africa, where the disease has taken its highest toll. The United States will be represented by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and a delegation of more than 40 officials.
"We know what works, we know what to do and the biggest job now is to get resources to get the job done," said Dr. Peter Piot, the executive director of the Joint United Nations Program on H.I.V./AIDS. 
Agreeing on a common strategy is another matter, however. While delegates have struggled over the wording of a formal declaration outlining goals and targets to be issued at the end of the conference, debate continues over whether the resources should be concentrated more on prevention or treatment, on where the money should come from and on how plain-spoken the United Nations message about AIDS should be. 
Some Muslim countries have objected to language in the draft declaration specifying that efforts must be made to help "men who have sex with men, sex workers, injecting drug users and their sexual partners," along with other groups like prisoners, refugees and migrants. "If they cannot even be named in a U.N. document, it's such a reflection of the way they must be treated in the everyday circumstances in their countries," said Joanne Csete, a public health expert at Human Rights Watch. "It's telling that 20 years into this epidemic, we can't even name the vulnerable groups and do something for them."
The United States deputy assistant secretary of state for international organization affairs, E. Michael Southwick, said the draft declaration already included strong language about a commitment to respect human rights and to be mindful of issues affecting the vulnerable. "Considering where the world had been in the last 15 or 20 years, this has been a big advance," he said. Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, said, "Countries are bringing an extraneous moral agenda in a way that is detrimental to efforts to combat AIDS. This is not the time or place to allow moral squeamishness to dilute a clear and effective message." 
Mr. Roth and other critics argue that AIDS must be addressed in the context of human rights. The United Nations Development Fund for Women said that nearly half of new H.I.V. infections now occur in women; in sub-Saharan Africa, teenage girls are five times more likely than boys to become infected, with most of the girls contracting AIDS from older men. The fund also wants female and male condoms made more accessible and affordable. 
"As long as we do not address the power relationship, we are not going to address H.I.V./AIDS," said Noeleen Heyzer, executive director of the fund. "Too often, women and girls do not have the power to say no to unwanted and unprotected sex." 
Deputy Secretary General Louise Frechette acknowledged that sticking points exist. "They'll have to find the right words that deal with the realities but do not offend the sensibilities of some cultures," she said. 
"The issues that remain on the table are sensitive issues," Ms. Frechette said. "They relate to cultural issues that are not always easy to handle." 
Secretary General Kofi Annan, who will open the conference on Monday, announced in April the creation of a global fund to finance the fight against AIDS at a cost of $7 billion to $10 billion annually. The United States has pledged $200 million, France $127 million, Britain $100 million and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation $100 million. But this is far too little, say some groups that insist the debt of poor countries be forgiven so those countries can use that money to save lives. 
Advocacy groups also want the United Nations conference to press drug companies to slash the prices of anti-retroviral medications. 
There are other complaints from some nongovernmental organizations about being excluded from taking part in four round-table discussions scheduled on AIDS prevention and care, AIDS and human rights, the disease's social and economic impact and international support and cooperation. One group, the International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission, said it was invited to a discussion and then its invitation was withdrawn after some governments objected. 
In the long run, said Ms. Frechette, the deputy secretary general, there is no alternative to cooperation. "Everybody will have to bear in mind that this is a battle that we will be fighting for years to come," she said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 1, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday on the global tradeoffs in the fight against AIDS referred incompletely to the multibillion-dollar AIDS fund proposed by the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan. The fund is also intended to address malaria and tuberculosis.

HEADLINE: Yugoslavs Act On Hague Trial For Milosevic 

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 23 

 BODY:
The Yugoslav cabinet adopted a decree today committing itself to sending the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, to the United Nations tribunal in The Hague to face trial on war crimes charges.
 The extradition of Mr. Milosevic could set the stage for a remarkable international trial, in which a one-time national leader who defied the West would stand in the dock accused of a campaign of terror that killed thousands of people in the Balkans. 
 Mr. Milosevic, who was indicted by the tribunal in May 1999 along with four of his top officials for war crimes in the Serbian province of Kosovo, is first on the list for transfer to The Hague, government officials here have suggested. 
The decree takes effect Sunday, and some officials suggested that the former president, already in detention in Belgrade central jail, could be extradited "very soon."
Other officials suggested, however, that it could take until the end of the month, because lawyers and supporters of Mr. Milosevic have promised to challenge the legality of the decree, which conflicts with national laws that forbid the extradition of Yugoslav citizens. 
Still, Deputy Prime Minister Miroljub Labus made clear at a news conference today after the cabinet meeting that the government intended to carry out the measure. 
"There are, I think, 16 indictments, and there will be no bargaining," he said. "The Hague will ask for the transfer and we will respond." 
Beta news agency quoted the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, as saying before the vote that Mr. Milosevic's transfer to The Hague "will pass without problems, in regular, public procedures" and that such developments might take "15 to 20 days."
The action today was taken after the government failed this week to garner enough votes to pass a law in the Yugoslav Parliament that would have allowed the extraditions, and it was precipitated by pressure from Western nations to demonstrate that the government was sincere in its cooperation with the tribunal before an international donor conference next week in Brussels. 
The United States has indicated that it will not take part in the conference unless it is satisfied that the Yugoslav government has taken concrete action to cooperate with the tribunal. Without American participation, the Yugoslav government would have difficulty raising the $1 billion it needs to overhaul an economy that is in ruinous shape after 10 years of international sanctions, corrupt rule and regional conflicts.
American officials are to decide by Wednesday whether they will participate in the conference and have indicated that concrete action, namely the transfer of indictees to The Hague, or at least a timetable of planned transfers, would be necessary for them to take part. 
The decree adopted today was a last-ditch attempt to show that the government was committed to cooperating with the tribunal. 
"This is a positive step we will be watching closely," a senior American official said in Washington. "The goal is to see Milosevic extradited so he can be tried for the crimes for which he has been indicted." 
The strongly worded measure, which will go into effect on Sunday once it appears in the official gazette, orders all courts, prosecutors and other state bodies to act urgently on Hague tribunal requests for the handover of those indicted on war crimes charges, and to inform the government of their action within at least three days. It also outlines cooperation with Hague tribunal prosecutors and investigators. 
Mr. Milosevic is wanted for crimes against humanity for the campaign unleashed against the ethnic Albanian population in Kosovo in the spring of 1999, during NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, when thousands of ethnic Albanians were killed and hundreds of thousands were expelled from their homes. 
The Hague tribunal issued an indictment against Mr. Milosevic and four of his close officials in May 1999 while the war was still going on. Since October, when a popular uprising forced Mr. Milosevic out of power and an anti-Milosevic alliance took over, his fate has been in question. 
Yugoslavia's new reformist leaders were nevertheless divided on the issue, and public opinion was firmly against sending Mr. Milosevic to The Hague. President Vojislav Kostunica was opposed to extraditing him and others to the tribunal, which he said was a political court and biased against Serbs. 
Playing for time, Mr. Kostunica insisted on drafting a law to regulate cooperation. But his deputy prime minister, Mr. Labus, an economist who has masterminded a plan of economic reform for the country, threatened to resign if Yugoslavia's international standing with donors and economic institutions was jeopardized. Other ministers criticized the delay, saying a law on cooperation was not necessary.
International pressure, namely the risk of losing United States economic assistance, pushed the authorities to arrest Mr. Milosevic on April 1. Since then, he has been in detention in Belgrade, under investigation for corruption and abuse of power. 
Another case, meanwhile, has been opened linking him to war crimes committed in Kosovo and for allegedly ordering a cover-up of killings of ethnic Albanians. And government officials have started disclosing details of several mass graves in Serbia of ethnic Albanian victims from Kosovo in a clear attempt to prepare the public for the possible extradition of Mr. Milosevic. 
Mr. Kostunica himself appears to have accepted the necessity to cooperate with the tribunal after his meeting in Washington last month with President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. Still, the government was forced to issue a federal decree through the cabinet, where Mr. Kostunica and his reformists have a majority, after losing its battle with Parliament this week. 
But the move has raised questions about the survival of his Yugoslav government. Mr. Kostunica's partners in the government, former allies of Mr. Milosevic from Serbia's sister republic, Montenegro, refused to support the draft bill, would not vote at the cabinet meeting today and said they were now considering whether to leave the government. 
"A coalition partnership is supposed to mean that decisions are taken by mutual consent and not like this," said Predrag Bulatovic, leader of the Montenegrin Socialists. "It is a difficult decision, but this business with the decree is all highly questionable from a legal stand."
Mr. Milosevic's lawyers and supporters have argued that a decree on cooperation with The Hague is unconstitutional and extradition of Yugoslav citizens remains illegal under current Yugoslav laws.
One of Mr. Milosevic's lawyers, Veselin Cerovic, quoted today by the daily Glas Javnosti, also questioned the constitutionality of the decree, raising the prospect of a legal fight ahead over Mr. Milosevic's transfer.
"With or without a law on the International Criminal Court, there is no clause in the Constitution allowing for the extradition of one of our citizens, regardless of whether it is requested by a state or an international organization," he said.

HEADLINE: Bayonne Journal; 
Members Debate a Legion Hall's Fate

BYLINE:  By MARIA NEWMAN

DATELINE: BAYONNE, N.J. 

 BODY:
Perhaps it is only fitting that less than two years after an Army base closed here after defining this working-class city for more than half a century, a "for sale" sign went up on the local veterans hall, the Frederick A. Mackenzie American Legion Post No. 165.
 But while the Army base, the Military Ocean Terminal, closed quietly in 1999 after a gradual shutdown, the proposed sale of the American Legion post property on Avenue E has been noisy and anything but a sure thing, "for sale" sign notwithstanding. 
 Once the state's largest American Legion posts, with 1,431 members, the Mackenzie post now has about 600 on its roster and less than a dozen at its regular monthly meetings.
The hall, built in 1948 by local veterans, used to be a hangout for veterans and their families, many of whom later worked around the corner at the marine terminal opened by the Navy in 1942 and taken over later by the Army. 
Over the years, the two-story post became something of a community resource, with a ballroom accommodating 500, bars and meeting rooms. It was a hall for inexpensive weddings and banquets, a room to play bingo, a place where a veteran could just walk in and learn about his benefits, have a nickel beer or a 15-cent whiskey with someone else who had worn the uniform of the United States. 
Now, though, the bars -- as well as the cheap drinks -- are gone, the post has been losing money for five years and a veteran looking for help will usually find only Clayton B. Petty inside. And after 30 years managing the post's day-to-day operations, mostly single-handedly, Mr. Petty, who is 75 and a Navy veteran who worked at the marine base until 1971, wants to retire. But seeing no one clamoring for his job, for which he is paid $28,000 a year, he came up with the idea of putting the place up for sale about three or four months ago.
With Bayonne now connected to Manhattan via a light rail system, Bayonne's real estate prices have been skyrocketing. Some post members believe the property can fetch $2 million to $3 million, and a condominium developer has expressed interest.
The problem is, Mr. Petty contacted a real estate agent and put up a sign before he had approval from the members. And now, the new commander of the post, Joseph Lopez, who is opposed to the sale, has called a general membership meeting to put the matter up for a vote.
"This place serves not only veterans, but also the entire community," said Mr. Lopez, 59 and a Vietnam veteran. "It's an economical place to have functions like weddings and bingos. Where are people going to go if the Mackenzie post is gone?"
The controversy has pitted member against member, with some agreeing that its time has probably passed, and that there is no need for such a large hall. With Mr. Petty wanting to retire, who would run it, they ask. Others say the post would lose stature if it moved to smaller quarters.
But there is also debate over who would receive the proceeds from the sale. Mr. Petty, who is president of the holding company that owns the property, has suggested that its board of directors -- he; Brian Petty, his son; and three other Legion members -- divide 10 percent, for their years of service at the post. The other 90 percent would go to the post itself, to buy smaller quarters or lease a storefront to run the much-reduced operations.
Mr. Lopez, who was installed on Tuesday, said: "A few people got ahead of themselves here. As the new commander, I have to make sure things are done the right way."
When they learned of Mr. Petty's plans, he said, he and the other new officers sent a notice to all 600 members, inviting them to the July 9 meeting to vote on the matter. But he conceded that it was not clear whether the post membership or the holding company had the final word on selling the building or what to do with the proceeds. 
Both sides are consulting lawyers. 
Paul Griffin, the immediate past commander of the post, who is a Korean War veteran and an old friend of Mr. Petty's, said he was trying to stay neutral on the matter. He noted, though, that there was little need for a big banquet hall because the catering business everywhere was on the decline. 
But he said he did not believe selling the property and moving the post would hurt it. "The post will survive no matter where they go," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clayton B. Petty's idea to put the Frederick A. Mackenzie American Legion Post No. 165 up for sale has stirred debate over its future. (Jeff Zelevansky for The New York Times)

PERSON: Dr. James H. Sammons 

HEADLINE: J. H. Sammons, 74, Who Helped A.M.A. Through Financial Crisis 

BYLINE:  By ANAHAD O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Dr. James H. Sammons, a former top executive of the American Medical Association who turned the organization around during a financial crisis in the 1980's, died on June 17 in Chicago, where he lived. He was 74. 
 The causes were cancer and a heart ailment, an A.M.A. spokeswoman said. 
 Dr. Sammons was executive vice president of the medical association for 16 years. His appointment to that post in 1974 came in a turbulent time for the association. He put its finances on a more solid footing, then resigned in 1990 during a controversy over two financial deals made by the group.
In 1974, the association was approaching bankruptcy, losing members and forced to take out monthly loans of $1 million just to meet its payroll. By the time Dr. Sammons stepped down, the association had nearly $200 million in assets and had become one of the most influential medical organizations in the world.
Dr. Sammons's overhaul of the association included raising membership dues and slashing the number of association committees and councils to 8 from 100. He also made a 20 percent reduction in staff budgets, which angered many association members. According to a 1984 account in American Medical News, a publication of the association, when the editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association walked into Dr. Sammons's office one day and threatened to resign over some changes, Dr. Sammons replied, "You just did."
In the 1984 interview, he said, "The fiscal crisis motivated us to bring A.M.A. into the 20th century and turn it into a modern corporation."
Dr. Sammons was born in Montgomery, Ala., in 1927. He graduated from Washington and Lee University and then the St. Louis University School of Medicine in 1951.
He is survived by his wife, JoAnne Halloway; a son, Dr. James Harris Sammons Jr. of Laken-Heath, England; a daughter, Patricia Sammons Sheats of Bastrop, Tex.; two stepchildren, Nancy Bond and Joseph Bond of Chicago; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Slighted by the Rebate 

BYLINE:  By Nancy Staudt; Nancy Staudt is a tax professor at Washington University School of Law.

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS 

 BODY:
Though President Bush claims that tax rebate checks will make virtually every American family $300 or $600 richer by the end of summer, 34 million American adults, or 26 percent, will be getting no checks at all. And another 17 million, or 13 percent, will get only a partial rebate.
 The reason for this exclusion of nearly 40 percent of Americans in a major benefit of the new tax law is that the rebate is tied to the income tax. Families that paid no federal income tax will fail to qualify for the rebate altogether, and those who paid very little will get partial rebates. 
 This may sound reasonable: those who don't pay taxes shouldn't get rebates. But the vast majority of those now being excluded do pay federal taxes, and pay far more than just their income tax bills would indicate. The federal government also imposes Social Security taxes on all workers and excise taxes on consumers, and these taxes are paid regardless of whether the taxpayer pays income tax. These other taxes played little or no part in Congressional debates on tax rebates. But they do play a central role in the tax calculations of 75 percent of all taxpayers: nearly three-quarters of all Americans pay more in Social Security and excise tax than they do in income tax.
The tax rebate program is only the most recent example of the federal government's awarding special preferences to payers of the income tax. People who donate to charities are permitted to take tax deductions offsetting the contributions, but the deduction can reduce only income taxes. If the taxpayer makes a contribution to a charity but owes no income tax, the deduction is completely lost. The same is true for virtually every deduction found in the tax code, including those for medical care, home mortgages, casualty losses and countless other everyday costs.
The creation of a taxpayer hierarchy results in the allocation of benefits based on one's contributions to the state. Just as voting is no longer reserved for those who can afford to pay the poll tax, rebates and deductions should not be reserved for a select group of taxpayers to the exclusion of all others -- especially those who contribute a substantial portion of their income through other taxes.
Of course, different taxes were originally justified in different ways. The income tax was levied primarily to finance the day-to-day operations of the federal government. The Social Security tax was adopted as a means to ensure that aging Americans would have a steady stream of income in retirement. And excise taxes were presented as promoting other purposes: discouraging consumption in the case of the taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages, building highways in the case of the gasoline tax. Greater fairness in taxation would require major changes in the tax structure, like allowing most taxpayers to obtain deductions currently tied only to the income tax. But at the very least, when Congress gives a one-time rebate to share the surplus and give a boost to the economy, that rebate should apply to all taxpayers, not just those who happen to pay income tax.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Trust And Antitrust

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
When the European Commission indicated it was likely to block the proposed merger between General Electric and Honeywell, American politicians from George W. Bush on down cried foul, with some alleging that the decision was politically motivated. They're almost certainly wrong about that, but it is true that the E.C.'s case against the merger is far from watertight. Mario Monti, Europe's competition referee, may have made a bad call on this play.
 Nonetheless, our politicians should lower their voices. Mr. Monti is one of the good guys in today's global economy. He should not be made the target of attempts at political intimidation. 
 To put the G.E.-Honeywell affair in context, you need to realize that this case is a triple switcheroo: it contradicts not one but three pieces of conventional wisdom.
First, the conventional view is that globalization weakens governments, because it forces them to compete for private investment. Broadly speaking, this view is right. (Conventional wisdom usually is.) There are, however, exceptions to the rule, and antitrust policy is one of those exceptions. In today's world, no company can compete effectively unless it can operate freely on both sides of the Atlantic -- which it can do only with a green light from antitrust authorities in both the United States and Europe. The result is that instead of eroding the power of those authorities, globalization has extended their reach: American regulators can block European mergers, and vice versa.
Second, this case inverts traditional roles. Until recently, only the U.S. seemed to take antitrust policy seriously. Europeans might have U.S.-style legislation on the books, but they often seemed to feel that cartels, like extramarital affairs, were nothing to worry about as long as the participants were discreet -- and they were scornful toward puritanical Americans who insisted on enforcing the letter of the law. Lately, however, Europe has gotten serious about antitrust, giving the competition commissioner broad powers to block mergers and investigate allegations of anticompetitive behavior. Mr. Monti, an American-trained university professor who assumed that office in 1999, has used those powers aggressively. General Electric and Honeywell are by no means the first companies to find Mr. Monti blocking what they thought was a done deal.
Was Mr. Monti right to block this particular deal? It's a complicated issue. Let's just say that the case against this merger is similar to the case for breaking up Microsoft, though it seems a lot weaker. On the other hand, you don't need as strong an argument to block a merger as you do to break up a going concern. We're in a gray area, with the precise shade of gray a matter of opinion. 
Even if you disagree with Mr. Monti's opinion, however, his sincerity is not in doubt. The best answer to those who claim that this is really a protectionist ploy is Mr. Monti's track record: he has repeatedly shown himself willing to oppose the demands of powerful European interest groups. Why would he suddenly become a tool of protectionists?
And that leads us to the third switcheroo. Europeans are accustomed to cozy cohabitation between politicians and businessmen; Americans tend to insist on at least the appearance of an arms-length relationship. But just at the moment when the Europeans have placed competition policy in the hands of a sternly upright professor, the United States has acquired an administration that seems oblivious to normal concerns about conflict of interest.
It's not yet clear whether the Bush administration really is a government of, by and for big corporations to an extent not seen since Warren G. Harding was president, or whether it just looks that way. But the stories keep accumulating. Intel's chief lobbyist says that his highly inappropriate meetings with Karl Rove were "quite useful" to its merger case -- and Mr. Rove didn't even get a slap on the wrist. According to the outgoing chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the head of Enron offered to support him at the White House if he changed his policy positions. And it took three months -- and a sharp prod from Jake Tapper at Salon -- before Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill honored his promise to sell his Alcoa stock. As a consumer, I'm not sure I trust these people to protect me from the market power of giant corporations.
And so it's nice to know that Mr. Monti is out there, looking after my interests.

HEADLINE: The World: Free Trade's Promise in Latin America; 
The Poor Survive It All. Even Boom Times.

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
FOR months now, President Bush has been asking Congress for something really big: authority to negotiate the largest free trade agreement the world has ever seen, one that would create a market of 800 million people in the Americas, from the Arctic to Antarctica. In exchange, he has promised that the trade zone will not only create markets for the United States, but will fortify democracy in Latin America and spread the economic benefits equitably. 
 Last week, it became clear he has a big fight ahead. The capital was flooded with critics who fear the deal's impact on workers' rights and environmental standards, and supporters eager for bigger markets and increased economic opportunities. 
 But their debate barely touches a far more fundamental question: does the combination of democracy and free enterprise guarantee achievement of the larger goal -- higher living standards? In Latin America, the answer often is no. 
On the surface, descriptions of trade, democracy and shared prosperity as inevitably linked represent a logical bind for the Bush administration. The Western Hemisphere already is more politically democratic than ever; excluding Cuba, every nation has an elected government. And the markets have never been more open; most governments have sold state-owned businesses, cut tariffs and torn down other walls that protected national industries. 
What has this produced? According to the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, an enormous number of Latin Americans -- 224 million of them -- live in poverty. They represent roughly 36 percent of the population -- an improvement from the 41 percent who were considered poor in 1990, but higher than the 35 percent so defined in 1980.
More perilous for social peace, Latin America maintains the broadest gap between rich and poor in the world, and the gap has narrowed only marginally, if at all, from what it was under the generals, dictators and caudillos. 
To some Latin American scholars, the linking of democracy, trade and shared prosperity suggest that Mr. Bush and many Latin American leaders are out of touch with reality. "These guys are just whistling Dixie," said Riordan Roett, director of the Western Hemisphere program at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies. "They're ignoring the basic issues that everyone's been pointing out to them for a decade."
The most effective way to ensure a fairer distribution of the economic benefits of market openings, according to Professor Roett and many other experts, is by improving education. Greater skills translate directly into higher wages. But only 15 percent of Latin American children make it to the ninth grade, even though spending on education has increased in at least 13 nations.
The increases tend to be less effective than they might be because Latin American governments spend disproportionately on universities -- a strategy aimed at mollifying politically active middle class students. 
And that kind of spending decision underlines a basic problem throughout Latin America: the way to fairer distribution of wealth is known, but the will to make the necessary changes gets waylaid between the people and their governments.
Nobody expects miracles overnight. Economic ministers in Latin America always counter reports of current problems with references to how bad things were before, and they usually are right. But their critics say they miss a crucial point. The region's rigid social structure isn't equipped to equitably distribute wealth, and this has been true whether a society was a democracy or an autocracy, protectionist or free-trading. 
AS Mexico learned when it abandoned protectionism in the 1980's and 90's, capitalism unbound puts lower-wage people at the mercy of global market forces. In order to counteract those forces and create more winners than losers, a nation needs strong democratic institutions -- a sound judiciary, free media and officials who are responsive to voters.
Far too often, however, Latin America's fledgling democracies have been too weak to effectively defend against such elite forces. For example, the elected governments of countries like Guatemala did little to stand in the way as the rich amassed tremendous wealth, allowing a coalition of agricultural growers and financial groups to block tax reforms. In Ecuador several years ago, so many rich people were evading income taxes that the government just abolished them, putting a tax on financial transactions instead. 
In such cases, checks and balances intended to hold officials accountable don't function; policy decisions are based on their impact on the powerful few, not on the poor majority. 
And so, even after decades of market opening and democratic elections, the richest 10 percent of Guatemalans and Brazilians control almost half of their national incomes, while the bottom 50 percent have access to just 10 percent of the wealth. Chile, Uruguay and, until recently, Argentina have had fairly sophisticated and stable economies, but they too have barely narrowed the wealth gap. 
In fact, over the last 40 years, the most effective efforts to bridge the gap took place under populist authoritarian governments that rejected both democracy and free trade. They erected protectionist barriers that kept vast numbers of people employed, but not productively. The governments made up for shortfalls by borrowing heavily from foreigners. The system worked, but only for a while. It led to the debt crisis of the 1980's, which worsened income inequity. The region recovered in the early 90's but most of the progress was wiped out by Mexico's debt crisis of 1994-95.
 THE region's economies climbed back again, but as they did something else occurred. The economic restructuring intersected with democratic opening in many countries, creating unforeseen new pressures. Competing globally meant becoming more productive, which brought layoffs. New standards of openness forced the governments to reveal economic data on once-guarded items like foreign cash reserves. This cleared the way for newly liberated news outlets to investigate corruption on every level. 
The result? "People now see the corruption and the problems with education, health and judicial impunity, and they think that is democracy," said Cesar Gaviria, a former president of Colombia who is secretary general of the Organization of American States. "All of that has created a sense of skepticism about democracy."
That disenchantment has put democracy itself at risk, and some Latin American intellectuals fear that the door has opened for the region to return to what the Mexican writer Carlos Fuentes has called the area's "oldest and most deeply rooted tradition -- authoritarianism."
The stirrings of such a shift are already evident. Using resentment against the maldistribution of wealth in Venezuela, Hugo Chavez led an unsuccessful coup attempt in 1991. A few years later, he won the presidential election and began dismantling parts of Venezuela's constitutional system that he said were unresponsive to the masses. 
A coup in Ecuador last year was a backlash, in part, against the country's economic morass and a decision to adopt the American dollar as Ecuador's currency. After international pressure forced the generals to surrender control, the new president promised to work to distribute economic benefits equitably. But one of his first moves was to complete dollarization, which helped businesses but not the poor.
And in last year's historic election in Mexico, perceptions that economic opening had enriched a few families while leaving most Mexicans in poverty helped to oust the ruling party that had controlled the presidency for seven decades. This victory for democracy could prove a tenuous one; sustaining the victory may well depend on President Vicente Fox's ability to persuade most Mexicans that they too are benefiting from free trade.
Mexico, Ecuador and Venezuela were among the 34 nations at the recent Summit of the Americas in Quebec, which voted to limit participation in future summits -- and perhaps the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas that the Bush administration supports -- to democracies.
But critics of such a simple linkage say it is not merely a democratic constitution and elections that determine the fairness of a society, but how deeply democratic understandings reach into the culture. Hernando De Soto, the Peruvian economist whose ideas have influenced public policy in the region, believes that raw capitalism has trumped principles of fairness in Latin America because many of the region's democracies haven't developed completely.
"LATIN Americans get to choose their leaders, but once they are in place, it's the old cliques that make the bottom-line decisions that are suitable to their own needs, not the people's needs," said Mr. De Soto. Latin American newspapers commonly refer to "the arrival of democracy" after elections, but the process doesn't end there.
"These nations may look like democracies and sound like democracies," said Mr. DeSoto, "but they certainly do not function in the same way that true democracies function."

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Red-Eyed, Not Blindsided

BYLINE:  By Jennifer L. Rich 

 BODY:
The optimism exuded by Arminio Fraga, president of Brazil's central bank, apparently is not the only contagious thing about him.
 Mr. 
Fraga, 43, a former fund manager for George Soros, and a Princeton-educated economist who speaks flawless English with a New Jersey accent, has been at his family's home in Rio de Janeiro for the past several weeks battling an eye infection. His red eyes gave the world the impression that he had been spending long hours slaving away at his desk. 
 Last Thursday, Mr. Fraga, after warning reporters to keep away and banning flash photographs because of his condition, announced a series of measures to thwart currency speculators who he says have gone too far in pushing down the value of Brazil's currency, the real. (It has fallen more than 20 percent against the dollar this year.) Though his plan has received mixed reviews, praise for Mr. Fraga, described by the Brazilian media as bold and decisive, is widespread. Jennifer L. Rich

HEADLINE: Giuliani Tries to Balance 2 Lives: Busy Mayor and Warring Spouse 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
The two lives of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani merged shortly before a City Hall news conference last week, when he took a call from an important man in his life: Raoul L. Felder, his divorce lawyer, who was across the street tangling in Manhattan's matrimonial court with a cranky, impatient judge. "The judge wants to put this on a fast track," Mr. Felder told the mayor. Could he set a date to go to the office of his wife's lawyer for a deposition?
 Mr. Giuliani, who was preparing for questions about a deadly hardware store fire in Queens -- he would soon go out and say that two surviving firefighters were "still in a great deal of pain" -- quickly came back with the date of July 17. The conversation, Mr. Felder said, lasted less than a minute. But other discussions that Mr. Felder has had with Mr. Giuliani about his divorce, some as early as 5 a.m. at Mr. Felder's Manhattan home, have taken two hours. 
 "It's longer than I talk to my wife," said Mr. Felder, who describes the mayor, a former prosecutor, as wholly absorbed in the details of his explosive divorce. "It's a whole new body of law to him, but he grasps it very quickly. He says, 'Is that statute, or is that case law?' I say, 'Case law.' And he says, 'Let me read the case.' And literally, a building could fall when he's zeroing in on it."
Nonetheless, Mr. Felder said, Mr. Giuliani does not like to meet at City Hall. "He won't leave his job," the mayor's lawyer said. "The only time I catch him is when the day is over or when the day begins."
Such are the parallel lives these days of Rudy Giuliani, mayor and warring spouse. By most accounts, Mr. Giuliani has remained focused on his day job even as he has become consumed by the breakup of his 17-year marriage to Donna Hanover. Colleagues say that Mr. Giuliani often uses his work as an escape from the emotional rage he expends on his divorce. 
"He feels that he can control what happens in the city, but he can't control what happens in his personal life," said City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, a Democratic mayoral candidate, who meets weekly with Mr. Giuliani. "I'm sure it's a tremendous personal strain, and I'd be the first one to tell you that he isn't focused on the city. But he is."
Still, it is the divorce that dominates the mood at City Hall, particularly as the Giuliani administration winds down. With only six months left because of term limits, the mayor has made his last $40 billion city budget deal, hammered out the wording of a crucial merit-pay agreement with the city's largest union and not come close to his dream of a football stadium on the West Side of Manhattan. Staff members, many bewildered by Mr. Giuliani's handling of his divorce, particularly Mr. Felder's harsh public criticism of Ms. Hanover, are busy looking for work. 
Mr. Giuliani is also looking ahead. Despite the chaos in his life, he has made extensive notes for a book on management, tentatively titled "Rudy's Rules," to be published by Talk Miramax Books next spring. Last week Mr. Giuliani and his publisher agreed on a collaborator, Ken Kurson, a business writer and an editor at large at Money magazine. Mr. Kurson, who is expected to turn in the manuscript for the 250-page book next January, is to begin working with Mr. Giuliani as early as this week. 
"The thrust of the book is how to run your business using the principles that Giuliani has used to run New York City," said Mr. Giuliani's editor, Jonathan Burnham.
A more personal memoir, part of a $3 million, two-book deal that Mr. Giuliani made with his publisher in January, is to follow later.
Mr. Giuliani has told friends that he is ready to take a break from public life, and even said lightheartedly at a Gracie Mansion barbecue not long ago that two terms as mayor was enough. Friends say he is eager to make money.
"I have got to find a way to make a living next year," Mr. Giuliani said shortly after he made his book deal. "I want to do something interesting. I want to do something that is creative. I want to do something that is fun. I want to do something that is enlightening."
At the same time, Mr. Giuliani's political future is more uncertain than it has ever been. Two schools of thought prevail in the city: one, that Mr. Giuliani's treatment of his wife as just another enemy has destroyed him politically; and two, that voters have short memories and will therefore allow him to ride back into Rome on his chariot should the city be economically depressed and crime-ridden after the next mayor's term is up in four years. Mr. Giuliani, who is allowed by city law to run again for mayor in 2005, has often said he would consider it.
Edward I. Koch, the former mayor who has become a regular critic of the current mayor, is of the first school. "He is unraveling," he said. "I believe that what he's doing vis-a-vis Donna is so irrational, it has got to be part of the syndrome that he can't run again at this time." Mr. Koch added that Mr. Giuliani's so-far unsuccessful court fight to bring his friend Judith Nathan to Gracie Mansion had appalled voters.
"The fact is, everybody is probably happy that he has a lady friend to comfort him," Mr. Koch said. "But not when he rubs your nose in it, and his wife's nose, and his children's noses." 
George Arzt, a Democratic political consultant, is of the second school. "If his successor doesn't do well, and he gets mired in deep financial troubles and crime is on the upswing, people will look to Rudy as a savior," Mr. Arzt said. "They'll put his personal life aside. In politics you never say never."
A poll released last week by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion showed that so far, Mr. Giuliani's divorce has not significantly changed voters' minds about him. A majority of those surveyed, 57 percent, rated Mr. Giuliani's job performance as excellent or good, a number statistically unchanged from a similar Marist poll conducted last March. Similarly, 57 percent in the current poll said that they thought the mayor's marital problems were not interfering with his job. On the other hand, 43 percent said that they were.
Not all voters necessarily see Mr. Giuliani as the perpetrator of the family's unhappiness. Some loyalists see him as the victim of an ambitious woman who dared to have a television and acting career when she should have been tending, they say, to concerns at home.
"She's too much on TV," said Alice Miller, 71, a Democrat from Maspeth, Queens, echoing the comments of other traditionalist Giuliani supporters. "Who takes care of her kids when she's on those shows? I believe he should have his life. She left him a long time ago, before he had this girl. She was too busy for him."
Members of Mr. Giuliani's inner circle explain the mayor's public battle with his wife with a simple phrase, "That's Rudy," and say it is not so different from the mayor's trademark fights with Mark Green, the public advocate, or Ramon C. Cortines and Rudy Crew, the two schools chancellors whom he chased out of town. 
The city's veteran divorce lawyers see something else: a man recovering from prostate cancer, in love with a new woman, and ready to move on with his life. "Except for the fact that it's the mayor and his wife, it's a garden-variety case," said Adria Hillman, a prominent divorce lawyer who represented Ronald O. Perelman in his divorce from Patricia Duff. "Getting a divorce is like a death in the family, only worse. You go through various stages. You are angry, you are sad, you are upset. You don't understand why this is happening to you. You see good people at their worst."
Now, as summer has arrived, Mr. Giuliani is spending time on the golf course, most publicly last week with his son, Andrew, 15, who will start ninth grade at St. Joseph Regional High School in New Jersey in September. On Wednesday, Andrew took his father's place in a pro-am tournament with Tiger Woods at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y., leaving Mr. Giuliani, who has a sore left foot, to clump around behind him or to watch with his security guard from a golf cart.
"Got a lot of talent," Mr. Giuliani said softly.
Uncharacteristically on the sidelines, he sat in the shade by a small brook at the eighth hole, watching his son hit the ball with Mr. Woods.
"Very cool," the mayor said.
Meanwhile, Mr. Giuliani is scrambling to make deals for new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets, and is pushing yet another Charter Revision Commission, his third in four years, to consider nonpartisan New York City elections. "I think he is aware of the fact that people think he's not focused," said Mr. Vallone, who has had battles with Mr. Giuliani in the past but is, for now, on his good side. "But he is probably more focused now than ever before. He wants to complete this year and he wants to leave a legacy."
Mr. Vallone added that for whatever reason, he and Mr. Giuliani have grown closer in recent months.
"He's told me things," Mr. Vallone said, "like I'm the only one who's never lied to him."

HEADLINE: The False Promise of Casinos 

BYLINE:  By Richard C. Leone; Richard C. Leone, president of the Century Foundation, was a member of the National Gambling Impact Study Commission.

 BODY:
Governor George Pataki and many in the State Legislature, acting with a dispatch normally associated with disaster relief, are trying to rush through legislation to permit tribal casinos in Buffalo, Niagara Falls and an undetermined third location in upstate New York. Is this happening because hearts in Albany go out to the Native Americans who have been mistreated for hundreds of years or because of a new empathy for community leaders struggling to save declining cities? Maybe a little of both. But my guess is it's because gambling revenues are an easy way to raise taxes without public disapproval and campaign contributions from the gambling industry are a growth area in American politics.
 The governor's plan to expand gambling is the latest installment in a process that has transformed the nation. In the 1970's, legalized gambling was still unusual and largely limited to a few lotteries and a wide-open Nevada. Today, 47 states have some form of legalized gambling, with lotteries in 37 states. Moreover, as gambling sites proliferate on the Internet, more bettors can place a wager without ever leaving home at all. 
 If anything, governmental pursuit of gambling revenues is intensifying, as states increasingly feel the need to expand and diversify to match "competition" from their neighbors. The National Gambling Impact Study Commission, on which I served, reported to Congress in 1999, calling for a pause in the spread of gambling. While some public officials listened, most just don't want to hear about the social and economic costs of increased gambling.
Just this month, for example, a conference in New York City sponsored by the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse, the National Institute of Mental Health and the Century Foundation highlighted new evidence that gambling affects the brain in the same way addictive drugs do. Brain imaging in a study led by Hans Breiter of Massachusetts General Hospital showed that the anticipation of winning money stimulated gamblers -- changing the patterns on their brain scans -- in much the same way an infusion of cocaine affects the brains of cocaine addicts. There's further evidence of gambling's physiological effects from research on treatment of gambling problems, which has shown that drugs used to treat heroin addicts and alcoholics may be useful for pathological gamblers as well.
The evidence also shows that gambling is not always an effective cure for local economic ills. Oh, most of the casinos do well and states get more taxes, but what about the promise of delivering real economic opportunities? Try walking around Atlantic City; one block from the boardwalk, it almost seems the major "retail" is pawn shops. Casinos, after all, are designed to keep the customer inside their walls, without even windows to indicate the time of day.
Nationally, we are clearly playing a game that is a bit like slash-and-burn farming. Eventually the land, or in this case the bettors, will be played out. Though there's always the hope that gambling will generate tourism, too often the gamblers are local residents whose losses will redound on the community.
There is one other reason this is happening now. For a decade, governors across the nation have built political careers by promising tax cuts. When they run again, they often face a growing public realization that the state tax reductions simply caused a shift to higher property taxes and rents. Political leaders who claim to disapprove of both gambling and taxes are finding that they cannot have it both ways. Trapped by this contradiction, they hope to get lucky with the next big expansion of gambling. Well, that isn't likely to be anything better than a sucker's bet.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Melinda Beck)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Online Animators Redraw Game Plans

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
For anyone still harboring the illusion that the World Wide Web is going to overtake the television set anytime soon, Buzz Potamkin has a story to share.
 Mr. Potamkin, a former executive producer at Hanna-Barbera Productions who helped develop the 1980's hit cartoon "The Berenstain Bears," left Hollywood three years ago to produce an animated series called "WhirlGirl" for Visionary Media, a Web site based in Manhattan. 
 "WhirlGirl" seemed like an allusion to what Mr. Potamkin's company promised to do to old media companies. The main character, Kia Cross, nerd by day and superheroine by night, prevents an evil media empire from controlling viewers' lives. 
But for Mr. Potamkin, it was much easier in cartoonland than it has been in real life.
"At first we thought we would be a destination site that would attract millions of people and advertising, then we tried licensing our shows to other sites like Showtime," Mr. Potamkin said. "What we've learned is that the audience is just not out there on the Web yet."
Mr. Potamkin is still the chief executive of Visionary Media, one of the dot-coms that vowed to circumvent the major networks. But now, Visionary is among the few online animated companies remaining, and it is trying to survive by turning to the very networks it promised to make obsolete.
Most online television companies that once sprouted in San Francisco and Silicon Alley in Manhattan have faded out, abandoning their loft studios and selling their equipment at dirt-cheap process. When Pseudo.com, the high-profile online television and animation company, went out of business last summer, it seemed the sector would collapse.
Critics say these companies miscalculated how long it would take for high-speed Internet connections, which make watching television on the Web practical, to spread into homes and offices. Experts now say the all-purpose box that delivers the Web and television and monitors the heating in the house is a long way from reality.
"It may never happen," said David Card, an analyst at Jupiter Media Metrix, the New York Internet research firm. "We are still feeling our way around it and certainly have not come up with an online television business model."
Two of the most prominent Web animation companies left standing, Visionary and Bullseye Art, both based in Manhattan, are trying to stay alive by using the technology and techniques they developed for Web animation to create broadcast television programming more quickly and cheaply.
Visionary and Bullseye both started as Web animation companies in 1997, with hopes that they would become destination sites where viewers would come for animated programming and that profits would flow from the advertising. But as it became clear that they could not attract the advertising dollars, both companies adjusted their business plans and began licensing cartoons to other Web sites.
Visionary landed a deal to produce weekly episodes of "WhirlGirl" to be broadcast on Showtime's Sho.com, and Bullseye was able to place its cartoons at Razorfish Studios, Icebox.com, Atom Films and other sites. But the companies ran into trouble last year as the economy began to slow and the companies they were working with began to reduce spending.
"People were eager to produce content for the Web, they had the talent and the tools to do it, and people were going to the sites," said Mark Schneider, the president and self-proclaimed designated adult at Bullseye. "But there was not a financial model to make it work."
Faced with growing costs and decreased revenue, both companies began working last year to adapt their Flash technology, originally designed to move large vector graphics through small Internet pipelines, to produce animation for broadcast television. "The realization on our part was that traditional media, broadcast media, has been there and is there, and that is where we need to be," Mr. Schneider said.
The normal process for developing television animation is expensive and involves Hollywood animators' drawing storyboards that are actually sent out, generally to India and other countries where labor is much cheaper, to be redrawn frame by frame.
It often takes about 20,000 drawings to make one 30-minute episode of "The Simpsons" or "The Smurfs," at a cost of $350,000 to $500,000 even before paying the writers, executives and voice talent. Slight changes, in color or events, later in the process can increase costs exponentially. Cost overruns are one of the greatest concerns among studios, experts say.
But Flash can cut costs by allowing animators to cut and paste from file to file, speeding up the process and eliminating the need for drawers overseas. This computerized process also allows files to be linked and slight shifts in color to be seamlessly made as well as other changes later in the process.
Mr. Potamkin estimates that Visionary can produce a 30-minute episode for $140,000 to $180,000. Mr. Schneider believes that the benefits are not just the reduced prices, but that animation can be done so much faster and at the last minute.
The problem with Flash had been that, despite its ease, studios were convinced that it did not measure up to broadcast quality. That was until Bullseye produced a 30-second introduction for "The Rosie O'Donnell Show" that was nominated for an Emmy this year.
But there are those who defend the traditional methods.
Eric Radomski, the executive creative officer at Film Roman, an animation studio in North Hollywood, Calif., that handles "The Simpsons" and "King of the Hill," said that even though the firm had done programs in Flash, the highest-quality programs must have some elements of the traditional process. 
"Flash technology is great, but it can't be looked at as anything other than a new technique," said Mr. Radomski, a three-time Emmy winner who has overseen recent changes in the studio's animation unit. "It is not going to really change the industry. It is more of a technological enhancement and a step in the right direction of a hybrid of traditional and digital animation."
Despite such hurdles, Mr. Card, the Jupiter analyst, said the new companies had some advantages. "The technology is finally there to do high-quality, low-cost animation, with the idea that studios can have more control over the process and the costs," he said.
Visionary has since developed a 14-minute broadcast-quality episode of "WhirlGirl," and it is negotiating a contract to create half-hour episodes of the program for an international distribution company. Bullseye has since signed a deal with MTV to develop a television version of its Webtoon "Miss Muffy and the Muff Mob," a hip version of "Strawberry Shortcake."
Even with the high hopes for the future, Josh Kinsberg, the chief creative officer and founder of Bullseye, said he no longer had visions of transforming Hollywood. "Best-case scenario now is that we get funded, keep growing and compete with the studios on our own," he said. "Getting acquired and becoming a part of a studio is not the worst thing that could happen."

HEADLINE: Offstage Drama at Long Wharf; 
The Feud That Led a Proud Theater's Director to Resign

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
They started on friendly terms. Barbara L. Pearce led the search committee that in 1997 selected Doug Hughes as the first new artistic director in 30 years to lead Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. Mr. Hughes backed the decision to make Ms. Pearce chairwoman when he came to the theater. Ms. Pearce says she introduced Mr. Hughes to Lynn Fusco, whom he married last year. At fund-raising events, the two regularly performed an impressive pitch on behalf of the theater, with no evident signs of tension between them. 
 But almost from the beginning, Mr. Hughes said, the relationship was strained. So much so, that last month Mr. Hughes asked the board to have Ms. Pearce resign as chairwoman. And it was the inability to reconcile their differences that ultimately led Mr. Hughes himself to resign on June 4. 
 The news shook the regional theater industry, particularly the small artistic world of the city that is Long Wharf's home. And of course, in tales like these, figuring out the truth is a bit like deciphering "Rashomon." Was it just a clash of personalities or a conflict over corporate management? A case of an upstart artistic director who chafed under the oversight of his chairwoman? Or an overbearing chairwoman who wouldn't leave her artistic director room to lead? Are there larger lessons for the regional theater about the growing conflicts between creative and commercial interests? 
While Ms. Pearce acknowledged instances of tension, she said the relationship ultimately broke down over who called the shots. "This is not a personality conflict," she said. "This is a philosophical conflict about governance." 
Mr. Hughes said: "I was in no way trying to run the board. What this was was an attempt by an artistic director, recognizing I am an employee, to seek collaboration on a problem that was making it very difficult to do my job."
On one point all parties agree. Artistically, Mr. Hughes was a gift to Long Wharf Theater. This institution was at a crossroads when he arrived: his predecessor, Arvin Brown, had helped put the theater on the map in its early days with celebrated productions like "The Gin Game" and "The Shadow Box," but 30 years later, it was languishing.
Good artistic directors are hard to come by. Many have abandoned their institutional theaters recently, and few seem to be in the pipeline to take their places. Running a nonprofit theater is a grind, requiring a constant and increasingly delicate balancing act between filling seats and taking artistic chances. 
Mr. Hughes, 45, comes from a theater family. (His parents, Barnard Hughes and Helen Stenborg, are both actors.) Though he had never led a theater before, he had been associate artistic director at Manhattan Theater Club and at Seattle Repertory Theater and director of programming at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. 
In his first Long Wharf season, 1997-98, Mr. Hughes succeeded in reactivating the theater's smaller second space, which had been dormant for three years, enabling Long Wharf to produce eight plays on two stages, compared with five plays on one stage the previous season. 
One of those plays was "Wit," the drama by Margaret Edson, which moved to New York, won the Pulitzer Prize and was made into an acclaimed television movie. 
During Mr. Hughes's tenure Long Wharf also erased its $600,000 deficit. And if a few shows ran over budget last season, like the musical "Golden Boy," board members agreed that his artistic judgment proved a financial boon for the theater. The budget increased to $6.7 million from $4.8 million. And last year the theater was awarded the largest single grant in its 36-year history, a combined gift of about $1 million from the Andrew Mellon and Doris Duke foundations.
Board members say that Mr. Hughes was a strong spokesman for the theater as well: articulate, charismatic and intelligent. And while subscriptions have remained steady at slightly under 11,000, single-ticket sales are up slightly since he took over.
"He put a lot of creative fire into the institution," said Nicholas Fox Weber, a writer who recently joined the board.
Board members say Ms. Pearce, 46, has also been a powerful force for Long Wharf, a tenacious fund-raiser who is fiercely committed to the institution. "Barbara's the kind of person that just steps up to the plate and gets it done," said Richard A. Ferguson, vice president of the board. "For every dollar I raised, she raised 20 times that. She is just extraordinary in her efforts." 
So what went wrong? Why couldn't these two people -- who by all accounts made for an effective team -- find a way to work together or at least coexist for the greater good of the theater? 
Mr. Hughes said Ms. Pearce had made his job untenable. Though he declined to offer specific examples of the behavior that bothered him, what emerged from conversations with members of the board and staff was that Mr. Hughes regarded her as a meddlesome micromanager. 
When there were fund-raising telephone calls that he had promised to make, for example, she would keep after him until he made them. Indeed, Michael Ross, the theater's managing director, having tired of being the middleman, almost resigned himself over the tension between Mr. Hughes and Ms. Pearce. 
"It was a difficult situation that I had been living with for a number of years," he said.
Mr. Hughes also said that he felt that he could not continue working with Ms. Pearce, given that Long Wharf was about to embark on an ambitious capital campaign to raise $30 million to $50 million for a new building. This project, unprecedented in the theater's history, would require close collaboration between artistic director and chairwoman.
Mr. Hughes's complaints date to early in his tenure, his colleagues say, but though he made them known to Ms. Pearce, the circumstances did not change to his satisfaction. 
In an incident that seems to have been the breaking point for Mr. Hughes, he arranged -- with the help of his wife, Ms. Fusco, a real estate developer in New Haven -- a meeting with Connecticut economic development officials to discuss Long Wharf's plans for expansion. He did not invite Ms. Pearce. She said she was outraged and ultimately insisted on attending the meeting, along with Jerry Meyer, the president of the board, and Mr. Ross. Ms. Fusco was also present. 
Mr. Hughes said he viewed the meeting simply as an informational session to learn the protocols by which nonprofit institutions like Long Wharf could apply for grants or appeal to the state legislature for funds. Ms. Pearce said it was a rare opportunity to plead Long Wharf's case to the government and because she was chairwoman, it was appropriate for her to attend. 
She said she was surprised when Mr. Hughes demanded that she step down. So were most members of the board, who were unaware of his difficulties with her. 
Mr. Hughes took his concerns to the board's officers in April. He told them that he believed that the healthiest course would be for Ms. Pearce, who had two years remaining in her six-year term as chairwoman, to resign and be replaced. 
The officers told him that this was unthinkable and asked him to consider a compromise and take it before the executive board. 
The internecine battle at Long Wharf is complicated by an intricate local network of social and political relationships. Ms. Fusco is president of the Fusco Corporation, a 75-year-old construction and property-management company founded by her grandfather. Ms. Pearce has served on several other boards and is president of H. Pearce Company Realtors, the company owned by her father, Herbert. Her husband, Norman Fleming, is a partner at Wiggin & Dana, a New Haven law firm where C. Newton Schenck, a founding member of the Long Wharf board, is also a partner and for years represented Ms. Pearce's father. 
Ms. Pearce was present on May 14, when Mr. Hughes returned to the board with a compromise: he would be willing to work with her for one more year, with minimal contact, provided that she step down the following year. 
Over the next two weeks the board evaluated the situation -- meeting with Mr. Hughes on several occasions without Ms. Pearce -- and decided not to seek her resignation at any time. "We didn't think it was appropriate for someone on the staff to select the board chairman," said Ruth Lord, a founding member of the board. "It didn't seem to me it was up to him. There is always going to be somebody somewhere people don't get on with." 
Mr. Hughes ultimately asked that the board put forth a compromise of its own, in writing, and begin dealing with his lawyer. He said he felt debilitated by the wrangling and was leaving for Chicago to direct "Hedda Gabler" at the Steppenwolf Theater. 
Instead, Mr. Hughes said, he was called at home on June 1 by Mr. Ferguson, the board's vice president, who told him that a message would be coming over his fax machine. Mr. Ferguson read it to him first. The letter, prepared by Mr. Schenck and signed by Mr. Ferguson, referred to Mr. Hughes's original request to have Ms. Pearce resign as chairwoman. "You still have not withdrawn this revised condition," the letter said, "so we believe, as matters now stand, that you have in effect submitted your resignation." 
In particular, the letter took issue with Mr. Hughes's introduction of lawyers into the negotiations, suggesting that they be brought in only after the two parties had resolved the issues independently. Three days later Mr. Hughes sent a letter of his own, describing Mr. Ferguson's letter as "self-serving and inaccurate." 
Mr. Hughes said he had "never, as you so disingenuously put it, in effect submitted" his resignation. "Now, however," he wrote, "you have my resignation -- effective immediately." 
This time Mr. Hughes sent the letter to the full board. Until then, most of the board members, of whom there are more than 45, had been unaware of any problems between Mr. Hughes and Ms. Pearce. "I view it with great regret," Mr. Weber, the writer, said of the resignation. 
Other board members were disappointed but stalwart about Mr. Hughes's departure. "That theater's going to be absolutely fine," Ms. Lord said, adding, "I'm awfully sad about this rift." On June 13 Long Wharf announced that Greg Leaming, the theater's director of artistic programming, would serve as acting artistic director. 
It was clearly in the final stage that communication broke down. The Long Wharf's board apparently interpreted Mr. Hughes's involvement of his lawyer as a red flag, the potential introduction of a legal claim of constructive termination, whereby an employee tries to prove that he was forced to resign. 
Mr. Hughes, however, said that by continuing to negotiate even after realizing that Ms. Pearce would remain, he was signaling a commitment to continue in his job. "This was about me getting some advocacy in negotiations," he said. "This was not about legal action." He added that he had just signed a five-year contract and planned to direct three plays in the coming season.
He said that he had also taken to Long Wharf a production of Chekhov's "Cherry Orchard," featuring Kathleen Chalfant, the star of "Wit," who quit the "Cherry Orchard" production after Mr. Hughes resigned. His father, who was in the cast, also left. (His mother had appeared in "Wit.") 
Now, however, Mr. Hughes sounds resigned to a future apart from Long Wharf. "It was the peak of my career, working with this theater, and I wish it well," he said. "I wish it very well."

HEADLINE: Rising Costs Result in a Proposal To Delay 6 New Queens Schools 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Board of Education staff members have proposed delaying the construction of six new schools in Queens and postponing most major school renovations in the five boroughs for two or more years because of soaring construction costs, according to board documents.
 The delays, which could begin as soon as the next school year, are part of a plan being considered by school officials to deal with a growing shortfall in the school construction budget. Under the five-year capital plan outlined by the Board of Education in 1999 and approved by the City Council and the mayor, the city planned to spend about $7 billion on construction and renovation from July 1999 through June 2004. 
 But projects already under way are coming in so far above the original estimates that Board of Education officials now predict the projects are likely to cost up to $1.9 billion more than estimated, according to the documents, which were obtained by The New York Times from an official within the school system. 
Any proposed changes in the capital plan would have to be approved by the seven-member board, said Anthony Shorris, a deputy chancellor. The changes would not affect the 19 schools now under construction, he said, adding that several ways were being considered to spread the cuts among projects not yet begun in each of the five boroughs and between renovations and new school projects. But board staff members have come up with detailed proposals for $1.5 billion in cuts that would draw nearly half the savings from Queens, including the elimination of $283 million planned for the construction of six schools there.
The higher costs have been driven mainly by a shortage of skilled workers available for public projects, according to the documents and interviews with city and education officials. In an economy that until recently had been soaring, contractors have found plenty of private work, where residential developers and homeowners have often been willing to pay more than the going rate on publicly financed projects to get them completed quickly.
Two years ago, for example, officials estimated that new schools could be built over the next five years for an average cost of $34,800 per seat, or roughly $21 million for a typical 600-student elementary school. When contractors made bids over the last two years to build the planned schools, however, they demanded up to $51,000 per seat, or $31 million for a 600-seat school, about 45 percent more than school officials expected.
"We're not getting as many people bidding on projects in this tight market as we might expect," said Dan McCormack, a spokesman for the School Construction Authority. "These are things that are not uncommon to the construction industry in boom times, but that doesn't mean that you don't go ahead and build a school that you were going to build when you only get three or four bids."
Of the schools now under construction, 13 are in Queens, which has the city's most crowded schools. Half the schools now being built are scheduled to open either this fall or next, with the rest to open in the fall of 2003. In addition, 10 major additions to existing schools are under construction and expected to be finished over the same period.
In total, 23,000 of the 50,700 new school seats outlined in the five-year plan are under construction, and 14,000 more are being designed. Therefore, any cuts would come from those schools that have been proposed but not yet started.
Several other factors appear to have contributed to the cost overruns. Many of the building projects now under way originated under the previous five-year plan, which ended in June 1999. It is unclear whether the cost of those plans, originally estimated in 1994, were updated to account for rising construction costs over the last decade. In addition, the Board of Education has had trouble finding enough sites for new school buildings, and those they find sometimes have environmental problems requiring extensive cleanup.
Before the decisions are made, however, the construction budget will undergo an audit ordered last week by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. In addition, the Board of Education has asked for an accounting of spending so far and for more information on expected overruns, and a special commission appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki is continuing a multiyear investigation of the board's construction process.
The costs of renovating the city's aging school buildings are also rising faster than expected, and are projected to cost nearly $3 billion, or 18 percent more than projected in 1999. 
A program to replace all the remaining coal-fired boilers in school buildings, for example, is expected to cost $353 million, $68.5 million or 24 percent more than forecast. Charges for window replacements are running 38 percent over expectations, and repairs to the exterior masonry of buildings are likely to total more than double the original estimates by the time the current capital plan runs its course in June 2004.
More than $1 billion of the proposed spending cuts would come from renovation projects, with plans for exterior modernizations, upgraded heating systems and window replacements bearing the brunt of the savings.
Officials at City Hall have expressed both outrage and skepticism over the budget projections, accusing the Board of Education of serious mismanagement and incompetence and at the same time surmising that the dire forecasts are a ploy to get more money for the school system. 
But while city officials have been quick to chastise the board for the overruns, few have pointed fingers at the School Construction Authority, whose board of trustees is overseen by Howard Wilson, who was appointed by Mr. Giuliani. The other two trustees are Charles A. Stillman, appointed by Mr. Pataki, and Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy.
Representatives from the board's division of school facilities meet regularly with executives from the School Construction Authority to review the status of construction projects. Despite their responsibility for soliciting bids and awarding contracts for construction projects, construction authority officials have held themselves blameless for the higher-than-expected costs, saying they can spend only what they are authorized to spend by the Board of Education.
Terri Thomson, the board member who represents Queens, said in an interview that if promised schools were not built, there would be plenty of blame to go around. 
"There are a lot of players in this capital plan," she said, adding that the Board of Education had been expecting for more than a year that the School Construction Authority would integrate its computer and financial systems with the board's. That is now scheduled to happen by the beginning of next month.
