HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue Chips Languish as Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks sagged but technology shares made modest gains in listless trading yesterday as investors awaited this week's Federal Reserve meeting on interest rates.
 Many investors also sat on the sidelines to wait out the storm of companies saying slowing United States economic growth will crimp their profits, analysts said. Technology stocks found buyers, however, amid hopes the Fed's widely expected interest rate cut will help the battered sector. 
 "The closer we get to completing the earnings preannouncement period the more likely it is that there will be a base in some of these technology stocks for at least another quarter," said Rick Meckler, a senior managing director at Liberty Asset Management, which oversees $1 billion. 
Some investors are pinning their hopes on further interest rate reductions by the Fed, which meets on today and tomorrow, hoping that its aggressive monetary easing can engineer a comeback for the economy.
"There hasn't been too much good news to prop up this market," said Guy Truicko, a portfolio manager at Unity Management, which oversees more than $1 billion. "Yes, rates are coming down, but the economy has not turned yet as far as we can tell."
The Nasdaq composite index rose 16.03 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 2,050.87. Cisco Systems, the maker of equipment that powers the Internet, helped lift the tech-packed index with a 99-cent gain, to $18.51.
The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 100.37 points, nearly 1 percent, to 10,504.22. Home Depot, the home-improvement retailer, was a drag on the blue-chip index, as its shares were hurt by a bearish article in the financial weekly Barron's. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.75 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,218.60.
Trading was subdued on the Nasdaq, with 1.5 billion shares changing hands -- well below the average 2.1 billion in May. The New York Stock Exchange volume was average with 1.0 billion shares traded.
Home Depot fell $1.71, to $49, and was the Dow's biggest percentage loser after Barron's said the stock of the company was overvalued.
Coca-Cola, however, offered the Dow support after Goldman, Sachs added the company to its recommended list, saying "sentiment has become decidedly too negative toward the stock." Coke rose 74 cents, to $43.59.
Honeywell International fell $1, to $35.60, while its fellow Dow component General Electric declined $1.61, to $50.25. A European Union advisory committee supported commission experts yesterday and, on a split vote, opposed G.E.'s purchase of Honeywell.
International Business Machines slipped 22 cents, to $112.65. I.B.M. said it built the world's fastest silicon transistor, a breakthrough that it said would yield microchips within two years that run five times the speed of current models.
Biotechnology stocks declined as Biogen took a hit from downgrades by Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch. Lehman cited uncertainties related to the patent on a new psoriasis medicine. Merrill said two of the leading drugs made by Biogen would not provide as much lift to earnings as hoped.
Biogen sank $5.46, to $54.41, and the Nasdaq biotechnology index fell 2.8 percent.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Drop
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell as some investors speculated that the Federal Reserve would stop lowering interest rates after a decrease this week.
Bear, Stearns doubled its forecast for the possible Fed rate reduction to half a percentage point. All told, 11 of the 25 primary dealers, companies that trade with the Fed, say a rate cut that big is likely. Yet 14 also say it would be the last of the central bank's recent attempts to spur the economy.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 1/32, to a price of 99 2/32. The note's yield was unchanged at 5.12 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 96 30/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.59 percent from 5.58 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Stealth Bomber, Once Scorned, Gains Fresh Backing 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WHITEMAN AIR FORCE BASE, Mo. 

 BODY:
A pair of Air Force pilots recently locked themselves inside a closet-size metal box here for 50 hours, subsisting on cold pizza and instant noodles, amusing themselves with crossword puzzles and paperback books, and taking occasional catnaps on a fold-up chaise longue from Wal-Mart.
 The box was a B-2 bomber simulator, and the point of the exercise was to demonstrate that the pilots could overcome the tedium, confinement and sleep deprivation entailed in attacking distant targets -- in Asia, say -- from Missouri, home of the nation's B-2 fleet. But to B-2 devotees, a broader proposition was being tested: that the bat-winged stealth plane, once derided for its high price and questionable durability, could play a lead role in President Bush's new Pacific-oriented military strategy. 
 The B-2, the world's most expensive aircraft, is trying to make a comeback. Four years after the Northrop Grumman Corporation stopped producing the planes because Congress had balked at their $2.2-billion-apiece price, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld is considering buying 40 more of them, this time for $735 million each. 
B-2 fans say it is about time. Mr. Rumsfeld is developing a military strategy that seeks to reduce American dependence on overseas bases in favor of stealthy, precision-guided, long-range weaponry. To B-2 advocates, that is a recipe for their plane, which, with the help of airborne fuel tankers, flew nonstop raids from Missouri to Serbia during the 1999 air war there, dropping radar-guided bombs with apparently great accuracy.
"People focus too much on the cost of the plane rather than its effectiveness," said Representative Norm Dicks, a Washington Democrat who is helping to lead a bipartisan charge for the B-2 in Congress. "You don't need nuclear weapons when you have this kind of capability."
Mr. Rumsfeld, who along with Dick Cheney endorsed the plane in a 1995 letter to President Bill Clinton, has remained silent about his intentions.
But the B-2's critics say it remains a luxury the Pentagon cannot afford, particularly as the services cry poverty when it comes to buying basic things like bullets, housing and spare parts. As the technology develops, less expensive weapons, among them long-range cruise missiles and unmanned aircraft, will do the job just as well, they say.
"If you were bombing the way we did in Vietnam, maybe it would make sense to buy them," said Michael O'Hanlon, a military analyst with the Brookings Institution. "But that doesn't seem to be where things are going. Given that, there are more economical ways to go."
Moreover, those critics say, the plane is not all that stealthy. During the air war over Yugoslavia, the B-2 conducted raids only at night, because its huge black V-shaped body is readily visible by day. Some of those planes were also accompanied by radar-jamming aircraft. 
Even senior Air Force officers argue for buying the F-22 Raptor fighter jet instead of more B-2's. Their reasoning is that the Air Force needs faster, stealthier fighters to protect its relatively slow and insufficiently stealthy bombers, particularly since potentially hostile nations are developing more powerful radar and better air defenses.
And because radar-jammers, fighters and fuel tankers cannot fly all the way from the United States, buying B-2's would not eliminate the need for overseas bases.
"The B-2's are stealthy," one Air Force general said, "but they still need help." 
The B-2 was conceived in the early 1980's as one leg of the nation's strategic force, capable of sweeping undetected into Soviet airspace to drop nuclear bombs. In the Reagan administration, plans were drawn up to build 132 of the planes at Northrop plants in Palmdale and Pico Rivera, Calif.
The program was plagued, however, by cost overruns and production delays, at one point failing a radar-detection test. And with the collapse of the Soviet Union, Congress began slashing the B-2 budget during the 1990's, stopping production after 21 aircraft had been built for $44 billion. (That price included research and development costs that would not be part of any new production run, Northrop points out.) 
After the first B-2's were delivered here to Whiteman Air Force Base in 1993, new problems emerged. In 1997, the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative and auditing arm, reported that the aircraft's radar-absorbing skin could be damaged by moisture and extreme weather conditions. The plane, the report concluded, could not be deployed overseas without special climate-controlled shelters.
And to maintain stealth, every nick or dent on the plane's specially designed skin must be repaired with particular kinds of tape and epoxy that require as long as 80 hours to cure. Stealth also requires that each time crews open panels to reach internal parts, technicians spend hours sealing the minuscule gaps around the panels.
As a result, Pentagon testers found, the B-2's were often grounded, reducing the number of sorties they could fly and sharply increasing maintenance costs, nearly $140 million last year. (The B-2 wing at Whiteman, the 509th, has more than 1,000 maintenance workers for the 20 planes.) Northrop is trying to redesign the aircraft to reduce the time required to replace panels.
"Every aircraft has some challenge," said Col. Anthony F. Przybyslawski, commander of the 509th Wing. "This one's challenge is keeping it pristine."
The B-2 managed to quiet some of its critics on its first combat mission, in 1999, when six of the planes took part in strikes over Kosovo and Serbia, flying nearly 50 missions, all from Whiteman. Though that number accounted for just 1 percent of NATO's sorties, the B-2's dropped 11 percent of the bombs, the Clinton administration reported.
By most accounts, the B-2 performed well. Using Global Positioning Systems, the planes accurately hit targets with precision-guided bombs even on cloudy days that stymied other allied aircraft. On a visit to Whiteman in 1999, President Clinton called the B-2 a "truly remarkable aircraft."
The goal of the 509th Wing now is to prove that with the prospect of fewer overseas bases, the B-2 can fulfill the kind of missions over the Pacific that it performed over Kosovo. And that is why pilots like Capt. Andy Gebara have been spending 50 hours at a stretch here inside the simulator that closely replicates the B-2's cramped cockpit.
"It's a long time to be stuck in a small container," Captain Gebara said. "But given the constraints we have with the shrinkage of bases, we kind of have to do this. We can't go anywhere we want in the world anymore."

HEADLINE: Belgrade Begins Process of Sending Milosevic to The Hague 

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 25 

 BODY:
The Yugoslav government took the first legal steps today to hand over the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, raising expectations that he might be transferred this week before an international conference that could bring aid to Serbia.
 The Justice Ministry forwarded a request from the tribunal for Mr. Milosevic's transfer to a Belgrade district court today, in keeping with a decree on cooperation with the tribunal adopted on Saturday, the official Tanjug news agency reported. The request established "concrete" proof, the agency said, of the government's willingness to hand over indicted war crimes suspects. 
 The government ignored a legal challenge by Mr. Milosevic's lawyers calling the decree unconstitutional and asking that it be suspended.
The Constitutional Court convened today but did not announce any ruling. Justice Minister Momcilo Grubac, who drafted the decree, appeared unperturbed by the challenge and said he did not expect the court to find the decree unconstitutional.
Mr. Milosevic, who has been in detention in Belgrade's city jail since April 1 under investigation for corruption, is wanted in connection with crimes against humanity in Kosovo during the war in 1999. Four of his senior officials were indicted with him, but they remain at large, while Mr. Milosevic's transfer appears increasingly certain. The district court has to act on the request by the Justice Ministry within three days.
The international conference of donors will convene in Brussels on Friday. Government ministers are hoping to raise more than $1 billion at the conference, money badly needed to rescue Yugoslavia's crippled economy. The United States has linked its participation to Yugoslavia's cooperation with The Hague, and officials have said they want to see concrete steps in addition to the decree, namely arrests and transfer of indicted war crimes suspects. 
Today, European Union officials said they would go ahead with the conference, and urged the United States to take part. American officials have yet to decide whether they will do so. 
In Belgrade it is becoming increasingly clear that Mr. Milosevic's days in Serbia are numbered. 
President Vojislav Kostunica told a delegation from Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party that his extradition was the "lesser of two evils," the Belgrade radio station B92 reported. A party delegation met with Mr. Kostunica to protest the transfer, saying it represented national surrender, but he told them it would be a "lesser evil than what would happen to the country if we did not do it." 
The deputy prime minister, Miroljub Labus, said Saturday that the government intended to extradite all 16 suspects indicted by the tribunal who are thought to be in Yugoslavia. 
The Serbian interior minister, Dusan Mihajlovic, backed that promise with a challenge. "Do you doubt Mr. Labus will keep his word?" he asked.
And even as they tried to fight off the decree, Mr. Milosevic's lawyers showed signs of exasperation and resignation. "We do not think the transfer will happen," Toma Fila, Mr. Milosevic's chief lawyer, said at a news conference. "We are going to do everything we can to fight it."
But a lawyer in his office later admitted that he expected Mr. Milosevic to be in The Hague by Friday. 
There remains some uncertainty about the appeal process under the new decree. Mr. Milosevic may be allowed to appeal a court order for his transfer, in which case he may have two or three weeks' reprieve.

 BODY:
Seattle Failure Weighs On Future of Trade Talks
While momentum is gathering behind the idea of a new round of global trade talks, fundamental differences between rich and poor nations and the United States and its trading partners over what should be on the agenda are clouding talks before they can begin.
 The divisions follow a pattern that was largely evident before the failed meeting in Seattle in 1999. Mindful of the stakes, trade officials traveled to Geneva to try to advance the process. World Business, Section W. 

Women Forced to Delay Retirement
Hundreds of thousands of women in their 60's, part of the surge of divorces that started a generation ago, are finding they must stay in the work force because they lack the money to retire. Wages in effect are their pensions. A1.

Jean Doumanian, left, who was Woody Allen's closest friend for 30 years and produced some of his films, responded to a lawsuit he filed against her. Home Resales Rose 2.9% in May
Sales of previously owned homes rose 2.9 percent in May to the third-highest level as falling mortgage rates kept housing resistant to the economy's slowdown. Resales increased to an annual pace of 5.37 million houses from 5.22 million in April, the National Association of Realtors said. If the current rate holds, 5.25 million homes will sell this year. HEADLINE: U.S. Drops Case Over AIDS Drugs in Brazil 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 25 

 BODY:
The United States unexpectedly withdrew a patent complaint against Brazil in the World Trade Organization today and agreed to settle out of court a dispute widely seen as symbolic of the debate over who may manufacture and sell drugs to treat AIDS in poor countries.
 Coming on the first day of a United Nations General Assembly debate on the AIDS crisis, the decision was welcomed by campaigners for cheaper medications for developing nations, where AIDS is taking a devastating toll. Brazil, which had been moving to the forefront of an international challenge to large Western pharmaceutical companies and their high-priced anti-retroviral medicines, has sharply cut its mortality rate from AIDS in recent years with an aggressive campaign to make drugs available cheaply and effectively, experts say. 
 "Brazil has the most successful AIDS treatment program in the developing world, and this decision shows that the U.S. is no longer threatening its existence," said Seth Amgott, spokesman for Oxfam, the British charity. 
Paul Davis, of Act Up Philadelphia, a protest group concerned with AIDS issues, said the American move will serve as an important precedent for other nations desperate for ways to make treatment more affordable to their populations against the strong patent protections and pricing policies of companies in rich nations. "It will also remove barriers to access in many poor countries by illustrating that a country can withstand this kind of pressure," he said.
Specialists from around the world gathered here for the three-day summit-level meeting on AIDS -- an event that has thrown activists, medical experts and government officials into intense debate on priorities for fighting the epidemic. Those gathered said the decision today by the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, added to the sense that pharmaceutical companies can no longer expect governments to protect them against a rising tide of concern about the denial of drugs to poor victims of AIDS.
In recent months, several companies have lowered prices on medications that slow the course of the virus that causes AIDS and at least one has decided to give away a medication needed to treat opportunistic fungal infections that often accompany the disease.
"The United States has been supportive of Brazil's bold and effective program to combat the H.I.V.-AIDS crisis," Mr. Zoellick said in a statement today in Washington. "With this positive step, we will be able to harness our common energy toward our shared goal of combating the spread of this dangerous virus."
Under the agreement, Brazil and the United States will set up a joint panel to deal with the drug issue and other patent cases.
Under a 1996 Brazilian patent law, foreign companies lose patent protection if they don't either make the drug in Brazil or license a local company to make it within three years of securing a patent. Brazil already permitted government-run laboratories to copy any foreign drugs with patents that predate the 1996 law.
American officials, who had threatened Brazil with trade sanctions, said two months ago that this case was important to uphold the general principle of protecting intellectual property rights and that Brazil was using a provision in its law to pressure patent owners to make products there. Brazil's AIDS chief, Dr. Paulo Roberto Teixeira, responded on May 2, saying that his country was being punished for challenging American companies in ways that other nations did not.
Today, Brazil agreed to give the United States 10 days' notice of any plan to apply the provision demanding local manufacture and allowing forfeiture of patent rights. In return, the United States dropped its insistence on a formal review of Brazil's policy at the W.T.O. but reserved the right to revive its complaint if the consultation process fails.

HEADLINE: Serfs on the Web 

BYLINE:  By Walt Crowley; Walt Crowley writes frequently on Pacific Northwest history and is the author of the National Trust for Historic Preservation's guide to Seattle.

DATELINE: SEATTLE 

 BODY:
But how do you make any money?" This is the automatic response of virtually everyone upon learning that I run a nonprofit Web site -- a dot-org -- devoted to local history.
 The question is usually posed in quizzical but sympathetic tones, as if addressed to someone who poses a potential danger to himself, if not others. "We make money the old-fashioned way," I reply. "We beg for it." This satisfies no one, but it's the truth. 
 Things have not improved since the dot-com meltdown. People assume anyone left on the Internet has gone from riches to rags and been reduced to selling off vintage pinball machines to pay the mortgage. But those of us in the domain of the dot-orgs, the gentle realm of "venture socialists" who measure success in community service and usefulness, haven't experienced that change of fortune.
Dot-orgdom was the first civilian settlement in cyberspace after its invention by the military-industrial-academic complex. The dot-coms arrived later, building a tangled Web of virtual strip malls. Now their skydiving fortunes threaten to take the Web, or at least its credibility, with them. Fortunately, there is a safety net (sorry): the dot-orgs, dot-govs, and dot-edus that happily provide free data without having to post losses on the Nasdaq.
But just as many venture capitalists have discovered that the same basic economic rules apply in cyberspace as in the real world, so it is with public service. I have learned this the hard way in developing HistoryLink.org, a community history site for the Pacific Northwest written for the Internet, offering the electronic equivalent of 12,000 printed pages.
This project is not an inexpensive undertaking, when you take the radical step of paying historians, writers, designers and editors a living wage instead of stock options. At first, I naively assumed that this resource would appeal to local sponsors motivated by community pride. 
I soon discovered that globalization had severed ties many corporations had to their local communities. Most traditional foundations also proved skeptical, if not openly suspicious, of the Internet, while younger cyber-riche philanthropists were already bored with it.
The project would have died early but for local governments and a few progressive donors who recognized its value in promoting history education and citizen debate. Still, fund-raising remains a daily struggle, and in this, a dot-org is no different from any other nonprofit group. Practicing venture socialism may not make you rich, but it's more honest than a lot of defunct dot-com business plans.

HEADLINE: Is a Patients' Rights Bill the Cure? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, June 23) implies, the country's health insurance system won't be universal unless it is compulsory, like Social Security and Medicare. As Dr. 
Angell says, the system will be vulnerable to dropouts if costs rise. 
 But the solution need not entail the single-payer system that she advocates. 
 As an alternative to the Clintons' cumbersome employer-based plan, Prof. Michael Graetz and I proposed offering Medicare-type coverage to every family or individual at the government's average cost, while encouraging health maintenance organizations and other private insurers to compete by offering equivalent packages. Government subsidies would be given to every insured for whom the cost of the standard package exceeded, say, 10 percent of income.

JAMES TOBIN
New Haven, June 23, 2001

The writer, professor emeritus at Yale, won the 1981 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Summer Rite Returns To Borough of Churches

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
There was a baseball game in Brooklyn last night.
 It took 44 years to say this, but the professional game returned to the holy and haunted borough that was plundered after the 1957 season. 
 The Brooklyn Cyclones, named for a roller coaster just to the east, opened with a 3-2 victory in 10 innings last night at their new $39 million publicly subsidized playpen alongside the sea in Coney Island, only a few miles from Flatbush, where the Dodgers used to play at a ballpark named Ebbets Field. 
Their opponents were the Mahoning Valley Scrappers of Ohio in the Class A New York-Penn League -- not exactly the hated Giants of the equally vanished Polo Grounds, but you have to start somewhere. 
The Cyclones are in the enviable position of having it both ways. Their owner, Fred Wilpon, who also owns half of the Mets, and his son, Jeffrey, the chief operating officer of the Cyclones, issue a caveat that their team is not the Brooklyn Dodgers of Jackie Robinson -- and Oisk and Newk and Campy and Gil and Pee Wee and Duke and the Reading Rifle.
Rather, these are a bunch of prospects trying to work their way up the very steep hill of baseball, but the team, the concept of a team in Brooklyn, taps into the great sadness of the borough.
"This is giving something back to this borough that was taken from them," said Fred Wilpon, who once lived at 23rd Avenue and 62nd Street in Bensonhurst. 
Earlier in the day he talked by telephone to his high school teammate Sandy Koufax, who later pitched for the Dodgers, which is like saying Picasso painted a bit. 
"I said, 'Sandy, did we ever go on the Parachute Jump?' " Wilpon said, nodding at the gaudily painted but inactive tower looming behind the right-field stands. 
They decided they had never had the courage or the time to go up in the Parachute Jump, being too involved in their dream of pitching for the Dodgers. Wilpon also described how he conned the school bus driver to make a detour to Nathan's at 7:30 a.m.
"I'd have the hot dog, garlic and all," Wilpon recalled, almost with wonder at the strength of his stomach, way back then.
A lot of those memories have become heightened with the passing of the years. All spiritual Brooklynites know, in our blood and our bones, that the Dodgers were taken away after 1957 by the O'Malleys, whose only claim to the franchise was that technically they owned it. 
(In a twist of fate, that team is currently based in Los Angeles, is owned by an Australian-born guy named Rupert, and does not make the playoffs. As they say in parts of Brooklyn, "My heart bleeds borscht.")
The Cyclones are all about justice. As the New Jersey poet Bruce Springsteen put it in his ode to another seaside town called Atlantic City: "Everything dies, baby, that's a fact/But maybe everything that dies someday comes back."
So now Brooklyn baseball comes back. Brooklyn is known as the Borough of Churches. You can see that on approach to the airports at La Guardia or Kennedy -- the spires of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Park Slope and Sunset Park and Bay Ridge. 
Immigrants from Jamaica and Odessa -- and Indiana, in the case of that departed settler Gil Hodges -- came to Brooklyn for a different life. 
Brooklyn has the claim of a holy place, unlike the other boroughs. It is to New York City what Cholula is to Mexico, the home of the spirit, a place where frightful things happened, and were covered up, or built upon. Cortez massacred the Cholultecas at Cholula; the 365 temples, one for every day in the year, were torn down or covered. The O'Malleys took away a team from Brooklyn; nobody forgot. 
Baseball remains the sacred rite in Brooklyn. They also play soccer and cricket and basketball in the borough now, but they never forget that a team called the Dodgers won six pennants in the first postwar generation and then vanished, along with the Giants of Manhattan.
In popular folk tradition, Brooklyn thereupon died, but losing the Dodgers was only a convenient symbol for worse things -- neglect, poverty, white flight, corporate greed -- hardly unique to Brooklyn.
Somehow, life went on in dozens of neighborhoods, and now there is life pulsing at the edge of the ocean, near the fast-food stands and arcades of hardscrabble Coney Island. The new ballpark, KeySpan Park, has been built with $39 million worth of largesse from the city, which also unveiled a $71 million home for the Staten Island Yankees on Sunday. 
These parks were supposed to be warm-up exercises for Mayor Giuliani, who is still talking about doing much more expensive favors for the Yanks and Mets in the last months of his regime. 
"The weight of economic evidence, however, shows that taxpayers spend a lot of money and ultimately don't get much back," Adam M. Zaretsky, an economist in the Research Division of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, wrote in an article in the Regional Economist, a quarterly published by that bank.
"And when this paltry return is compared with other potential uses of the funds, the investment, almost always, seems unwise." 
He goes on to cite the social optimism about sport that often tips the balance toward such extravagances. It is easy to lament money not spent on schools and hospitals and mass transit -- until I see people packing this modernistic ballpark on a gorgeous summer evening, with the ocean glistening out past the well-kept boardwalk.
Old Dodgers named Ralph Branca and Joe Pignatano took part in the pregame ceremony, and a young Cyclone named Edgar Rodriguez became the first hero of the new generation with a two-out, two-run homer in the ninth to tie the game.
The Cyclones won in the 10th, and the exquisite sound system, which played tasteful New York tunes all evening, broke into Neil Diamond's "Brooklyn Roads," a song about nostalgia, a perfect way to honor the tribal memory of a team called the Brooklyn Dodgers that did not die.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fans like Jonathan Farina, 11, foreground, watched the first professional baseball game in Brooklyn since 1957. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Seen the Ads? Now, Take the Test; 
Armed With a No. 2 Pencil, and Ready to Join the Police

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
A bumper sticker on a tollbooth on the Triborough Bridge promised work. It read: (212) RECRUIT. The New York Police Department was looking for a few of New York's finest.
 Why not? Could be a story. Could be a career. I called the number, and was told to go to the nearest precinct station house and fill out the exam application. I did. Within weeks, there was a packet in my mailbox that contained a form with the time and place of my exam, a practice test and a list of free preparatory classes. 
 The classes were at inconvenient times, and I did not attend them. I studied the practice test for 10 minutes on the day of the exam, which was last Saturday at 3:30 p.m. It seemed to be straightforward, multiple-choice, strictly SAT style. 
I took the subway to Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers, on Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan.
There were about 300 people standing in the downpour with No. 2 pencils and pocket calculators. The crowd was half-white, half-not, and there was a good mix of women. Fashions ranged from sandals to tight pants, nylon stockings worn on heads to dyed hair, gold chains, tattoos and pierced noses. Nobody wore a jacket or tie.
The department has had problems getting qualified people to take the test. It is a mix of apathy, a good economy and a low opinion of the force in the wake of the Abner Louima and Amadou Diallo episodes, police and criminal justice experts agree.
There were about 1,600 slots available in the last Police Academy class, police union officials said. But only about 1,100 people were willing and qualified to take them. The Police Department worked hard this year to get people to take the exam. It advertised extensively. It waived the $35 application fee. So 12,652 people signed up to take the test. Only 6,654 took it, however, said Thomas Antenen, a spokesman for the department. 
To qualify for the exam you had to be under 35 years old by March 7, at least 17 1/2 by May 15 and never convicted of a felony. 
Emilio Zapata, 23, said he had no criminal record whatsoever. He is the manager of a pharmacy in Brooklyn and said he had come to take the exam because he was looking for something better.
"You don't make enough in a drugstore," Mr. Zapata said. "I hear the police benefits are pretty good compared to what I got now."
And what benefits does a manager of a pharmacy get?
"None," he said.
The following are the benefits given to city police officers, according to the department: 
*$31,305 per year; $49,023 per year after five years of service. 
*Excellent opportunities for promotion. 
*A choice of paid medical and dental programs. 
*Twenty paid vacation days the first year. 
*Twenty-seven paid vacation days after five years of service. 
*Unlimited sick leave with full pay. 
*Optional retirement at one-half salary after 20 years of service.
*An annuity fund.
James Barnes said that growing up, he never even wanted to be close to a cop, that the opinion of them in his Staten Island neighborhood was not very high. Mr. Barnes has a child now and explained his reasons for taking the exam like this: "I got nothing to lose."
We were led into a dimly lighted auditorium that had a musty municipal smell to it. There was a sleepy-looking police officer sitting on a folding chair on the stage. The American flag was touching the ground. A group of Staten Island guys sat behind me joking about Abner Louima.
We were then led out of the auditorium and given a room and a seat assignment. The air-conditioning was high, and it was cold. The wet sneakers squeaked on the floor. I could not find a bathroom.
Room 431 had graffiti-scarred desks and no windows. There were two elderly proctors who were ostensibly there to pass out the exams and prevent people from cheating. The old man came around to give me my test, tripped over an umbrella and came tumbling toward me. I caught him, but impaled him with my pencil. The tip broke. I had a spare. (I had taken tests before.) He shook it off.
The first part of the test was a photograph of a crime scene. We were given 10 minutes to memorize it before it was taken away, and then we were quizzed on it. It was a subway scene with two uniformed police officers and a hooded person pointing a revolver.
Taking notes was strictly forbidden during that part of the test, the proctor said. I saw people scribbling notes on their desks. 
Carol Wachter, assistant commissioner for examinations with the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, which administers the test, later said, "As a candidate, if you saw someone cheating, you should have reported it to the room monitor."
I was being asked to violate the blue wall of silence before I had even joined the force.
The test consisted of 85 multiple-choice questions. We were given 2 hours 45 minutes to complete it. The first 10 questions pertained to the photograph. The 75 others had to do with reading comprehension and deductive reasoning. 
It was against the rules to take the test questions or any notes out of the classroom, the proctor said. The following are merely my recollections rather than certainties.
One typical question began with a seven-step list that a police officer must follow when responding to a domestic dispute call. A three-paragraph scenario followed, ending with the question, "What is the next step the officer should take?" You had to refer to the list to find your answer.
It was easy to see that those with more test-taking experience would do better than those without, since you could save valuable minutes by simply starting with the question and working backward, thus avoiding having to read all the text.
One of the more inane questions had to do with finding a matching footprint. There was a similar question about hubcaps asking you to match the pictures.
Eugene O'Donnell, a professor of law and police science at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice and a former New York City police officer, said it was unclear what the test was supposed to measure.
"At best, it is a minimal screening tool in an atmosphere where there are not that many people interested in taking the test," Professor O'Donnell said.
After the written test, eligible applicants have to undergo medical, psychological and physical agility examinations and submit to a background and character investigation.
According to the Police Department, qualified applicants are then hired and sent to the Police Academy for seven months. By the date of hiring, an applicant must have 60 college credits with at least a 2.0 grade-point average, two years' active military experience or two years' experience as a meter maid or crossing guard. A valid New York driver's license without restrictions is also needed. 
I completed the test in an hour and ran to find a bathroom. Outside, the rain had moved on and people began to file out of the building. By the look of it, the first 50 people to complete the exam were white men with military-style haircuts.
"White dudes from the suburbs," said Mark Leaks, a 24-year-old black man who was waiting for his friend to finish the test. "But a good education doesn't mean you're a good cop, believe me." 
The test results will be posted in late July, the police said.

(Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times); Our test-taker's re-creation of one question on the police exam: Which footprint most closely matches the first one? (Charlie LeDuff/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Passaic Joins Suit to Bring Help for Preschool Programs 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PASSAIC, N.J., June 25 

 BODY:
This city's superintendent of schools, Robert H. Holster, stood today under the blazing sun in a parking lot where 11 trailers are supposed to serve as temporary classrooms for 165 of the projected 2,083 toddlers eligible in September for full-day prekindergarten classes ordered by the New Jersey Supreme Court. But while the state's own timeline indicates that today was the date when the 11 trailers -- and 69 others elsewhere in Passaic -- were to be installed, they were nowhere to be seen.
 "June 25, which happens to be today, was installation of units," Mr. Holster said later, quoting the timeline. "Where are they?" 
 Standing on the site, Mr. Holster announced that Passaic had become the third individual district to join in the latest legal battle in the protracted Abbott v. Burke school financing case. The plaintiffs have asked the State Supreme Court to appoint a monitor to oversee implementation of the prekindergarten programs that the court ordered for the 30 poor urban districts involved in the Abbott case in 1998.
By asking the Supreme Court to appoint a monitor, three districts -- Elizabeth, Perth Amboy and now Passaic -- have joined with the Education Law Center in Newark in asking the court to enforce its second ruling on prekindergarten programs in 2000, which provided specifics like maximum class sizes of 15 students and certification for teachers. The State Economic Development Authority is supposed to arrange for temporary and permanent facilities for the programs, and handle tasks like arranging for building permits, laying foundations and contracting for trailers. 
"They're supposed to do everything," Mr. Holster said. But nothing has been done to install any of the 80 trailers prescribed for Passaic, where none of the site preparation work has been done, Mr. Holster said. And like Passaic, many of the so-called Abbott districts are concerned that they simply will not have facilities in place by September.
Spokesmen for the state attorney general's office and the Department of Education would not comment about Mr. Holster's criticisms. 
Today was also the state's deadline for responding to the districts' request for a monitor. In the 65-page response, the attorney general's office alluded to the construction delays and defended efforts in the face of such "daunting" facilities needs. It also criticized demands for prekindergarten programs by the Education Law Center, which represents students in the Abbott districts, as unsupported by the State Constitution's call for a "thorough and efficient" education for all students.
"This case presents to the court a record of the extraordinary efforts undertaken by the state to implement a preschool program of unprecedented scope," the response said. "The E.L.C.'s motion is not directly premised on a constitutional right; the 'thorough and efficient clause' does not speak to children below the age of 5."
But David G. Sciarra, executive director of the law center, said the Supreme Court already ruled in 1998 that preschool is, in fact, part of a "thorough and efficient" education. Mr. Sciarra said the court could issue a ruling based on the parties' filings, or schedule oral arguments.
"They're trying to reopen a settled issue," he said of the state's response. "They define progress as very slow, and then they try to argue that's good enough."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Arena Bill Clears Panel 

BYLINE:  By Ronald Smothers (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The New Jersey Senate's budget committee approved a measure yesterday to create a Newark sports and entertainment district whose sales tax revenue would be earmarked to help finance the proposed $355 million Newark arena. The bill also creates a similar district for the Meadowlands to help finance a family entertainment and sports complex to replace Continental Arena. 
The measure, created to keep Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's promise to Bergen County lawmakers that they would not be left without an economic engine for the vast Meadowlands, also earmarks $300 million for a long-sought rail spur into the Meadowlands and extensive road work. The bill is likely to pass the full Senate this week as the state rushes to meet a July 1 deadline set by YankeeNets, developers of the proposed Newark arena. At the last minute, authority was added to the bill for the districts to impose hotel taxes to help finance development. The bill would allow Newark to increase its hotel tax up to 12 percent, from 6 percent, and the Meadowlands district to impose a hotel tax of up to 6 percent. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

HEADLINE: Home Resales Near Record, Climbing 2.9% 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25 

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes rose in May to the third-highest level as falling mortgage rates kept housing resistant to the economy's slowdown.
 Resales increased 2.9 percent, to an annual pace of 5.37 million houses from 5.22 million in April, the National Association of Realtors said. Only in March of this year and in June 1999 was the pace of sales faster than it was last month. 
 Through May, sales were 2.6 percent higher than in the period a year earlier. If the current rate holds, 5.25 million homes will sell this year, which would beat the record 5.21 million sold for all of 1999.
"Each month is just getting better," said Brenda Shipplett, an executive vice president at Long & Foster Real Estate Inc., a mid-Atlantic agency.
The median price of a home rose 1.7 percent last month, to a record $145,500. That compares with $143,100 in April and is 5.7 percent higher than in May of last year. The increase in home values has made housing an attractive investment, analysts said.
By region, sales of previously owned homes rose 3.8 percent in the South, 3.5 percent in the Midwest and 2.3 percent in the West. Sales were unchanged in the Northeast.
The supply of homes available for sale, another gauge of housing demand, fell to 3.4 months' worth in May from 3.7 months in April.
Mortgage rates that are lower this year than last year have underpinned demand. The weekly average rate on a 30-year mortgage this year is 7.07 percent, compared with the 8.05 percent average for all of 2000.
Still, the slowing economy may become an obstacle to the housing market later this year. Companies have been forced to lay off workers to protect profits. The economy lost 201,000 jobs in April and May, the largest two-month decrease since April-May 1991. "If we don't see layoffs begin to taper off, we may see home sales weaken" in the next few months, said Mark Vitner, an economist at First Union Securities Inc. in Charlotte, N.C.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
To End Deadlock, Large TV Networks Cut Rates

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
In the stalemate between Broadcast Row and Madison Avenue, most of the TV folks are blinking.
 Several of the big broadcast networks are lowering the rates they had planned to charge the major agencies for commercials in prime time during the coming fall season. Those "sale" signs are finally breaking the logjam in the negotiations between the two sides, which had caused the most sluggish start in years for the so-called upfront market. 
 The effect is the same as when retailers cut prices on leftover fashions so shoppers rethink their reluctance to buy, and the garments fly out of the stores.
The reductions mean that for the first time since the recession of 1991, the amount that advertisers must pay to reach 1,000 viewers will probably decline on average. The total dollars spent in advance of the 2001-02 season will also be 10 percent to 15 percent less than what was spent before the beginning of the 2000-01 season, a larger shortfall than had been estimated even a month ago. 
The cutting of rates for the cost per thousand viewers, which has the upfront market moving briskly after weeks of torpor, is being done because of widespread doubts that the slowdown in the national economy will end soon.
"The prices have come down versus a year ago in reflection of the economy," Jon Mandel, co-managing director at MediaCom in New York, a large media services agency owned by the Grey Global Group, said yesterday. "So the upfront is being written at good rates."
"It's somewhat like a divorce, with rejection, denial and acceptance," he added. "Most networks have gotten to the acceptance stage."
The result is that those networks' executives would rather book business now than gamble they can do so at higher rates when the 2001-2002 season is under way.
"It took time to read the market," said Randy Falco, president at the NBC Television Network unit of NBC in New York, owned by General Electric.
"We read the marketplace last week," he added, "and the assessment was we wanted to get out quickly. We made modest price concessions, and we're pleased with where we are."
However, one network, CBS, is by all accounts holding firm to its risky strategy of insisting that commercial time will not be sold at rates lower than last season's. CBS, and to a lesser degree its smaller sibling, UPN, both part of Viacom, are betting that advertisers will be eager to pay more later on, in what is known as the scatter market. The theory is that by then, the economy will have improved and advertisers will be more willing to spend money.
"Our position has been, with our performance last year, with our growth on Thursday night with 'Survivor' and 'C.S.I.,' that we feel our programming is worth what we've been asking for it," said Dana McClintock, a spokesman at CBS in New York.
"As we continue to sell," he added, "we're more concerned with price than volume."
Typically, the broadcast networks sell 70 percent to 80 percent of the commercial time available in a season during the upfront market. In hewing to the strategy outlined in the spring by Mel Karmazin, president and chief operating officer at Viacom, CBS may sell far less of its inventory than that while the other networks sell about that amount. That sets up another gamble for CBS, that agencies will not divert dollars from CBS to other broadcast networks -- or to cable networks or nationally syndicated programs.
"This is far and away the most fascinating upfront I've been through after 20 of them," said Dan Rank, managing partner at OMD in New York, a media buying unit of the Omnicom Group.
"The key word here is 'uncertainty,' " he added. "Clearly, the other networks said, 'Let's take the money and run,' because of the uncertainty."
On the other side of the bargaining table, most network sales managers agreed, with various degrees of reluctance.
"The total dollars surfacing weren't what we'd hoped for," said Mike Shaw, president for sales and marketing at the ABC Television Network unit of ABC in New York, owned by the Walt Disney Company.
The agencies' adamance that they weren't going to pay a lot for commercial time in the upfront market was "more than mere posturing," he added.
As a result, ABC has rapidly followed NBC in cutting its rates per thousand viewers, known as cpm's. The Fox Broadcasting Company did the same, but by less.
"We've more than offset our cpm losses with our ratings growth," said Jon Nesvig, president for sales at Fox in New York, part of the News Corporation.
The one network so far that is selling commercial time at a a cost per thousand viewers higher than last season is WB, owned by AOL Time Warner and the Tribune Company.
"We will be the only network to receive cpm increases and revenue increases in this upfront marketplace," said Jed Petrick, president and chief operating officer at WB in Burbank, Calif.
"With our growth last year in the 18-to-34-year-old demographics," he added, "more and more marketers are realizing the importance of reaching the next generation of consumers."
Based on discussions with executives at the networks and the agencies, the consensus estimates for the networks when the upfront market is completed, which may come as soon as this week, are as follows. Note well, though, that all numbers are, as the old railroad timetables once admonished, subject to change without notice, because as Mr. Rank observed, "Some agencies still haven't bought." 
*WB is raising its cost per thousand 3 percent to 5 percent and will take in $450 million to $475 million, compared with an estimated $425 million sold in the upfront market last season.
*Fox is lowering its cost per thousand 1 percent to 3 percent and will take in about $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion, about flat compared with last season.
*NBC is cutting its cost per thousand 5 percent to 8 percent and will take in $1.9 billion to $2.1 billion, compared with $2.2 billion last season.
*ABC is cutting its cost per thousand 6 percent to 9 percent and will take in about $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion, compared with $2.3 billion last season.
As for CBS and UPN, Mr. Mandel at MediaCom said he thought that by waiting to sell most of his commercial time in the scatter market, Mr. Karmazin "may be right in the second and third quarters of next year," when the economy is expected to be much stronger than in the corresponding quarters of 2001 and higher demand would bring higher prices. "But the question is, will he make up then for what he loses in the fourth quarter of this year and the first quarter of next year?"
CBS sold $1.6 billion in the upfront market last year and UPN sold $150 million. Most estimates are that CBS has sold only $500 million so far, on the way to $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion, but there are also estimates that CBS has sold more than $800 million.
The UPN estimates are harder to come by; by some accounts, UPN has sold only $30 million so far, on the way to $160 million to $180 million.

HEADLINE: Liberal Radio Mainstay May Sell to Make Way for ESPN 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
The trouble began five months ago. That is when the rumors began to surface that the venerable WEVD radio station was going to be sold and then turned into an ESPN sports station.
 Managers at WEVD (1050 AM) began drifting into mysterious meetings, and top executives at the Walt Disney Company's ABC Radio began boasting to others in the industry that they were going to buy the station in order to bring ESPN Radio to New York City. 
 Demonstrations were planned. A Web site, www.savewevd.com, was set up for listeners to complain and organize an attempt to block any sale of the station. At least one WEVD talk show host expressed concerns on the air.
Talks have bogged down since then, but industry analysts view the sale as inevitable. Meanwhile, the campaign to oppose the sale remains in full swing.
At a time of vast consolidation in the radio industry, WEVD has been an exception. The station, founded in 1927 to promote fiercely liberal programming, took its call letters from Eugene V. Debs, the co-founder of the Socialist Party and a five-time presidential candidate. The station was bought in 1931 by The Jewish Daily Forward. For decades, it was very profitable.
But times have changed.
The association that owns the station and The Forward, now published weekly, has seen the newspaper's circulation drop and its losses increase to more than $2 million a year. Radio industry executives estimate that WEVD, which is marginally profitable, could bring $80 million to $90 million in a sale, enough to keep The Forward running for at least four more decades.
Samuel Norich, the president of the group that owns the station, the Forward Association, did not return telephone calls to his office and home. Timothy McCarthy, the ABC Radio executive who would most likely become the general manager of WEVD if it were bought by Disney, did not return calls either.
But ABC executives said that talks had indeed started and that Mr. McCarthy envisioned using WEVD to compete against WFAN (660 AM), the CBS/Infinity Broadcasting sports station, which brings in more advertising revenue than any other radio station outfit in the region.
The talks have stalled in recent days, but Tony Sanders, a senior analyst with Duncan's American Radio, sees a sale of WEVD as inevitable. He said that because of a recent trend toward packaging advertising accounts across groups of affiliated stations, the two best ways a station owner can compete is to buy stations and consolidate or to sell stations to other group owners. 
Selling WEVD would give the Forward Association a profitable escape at a time when Disney is working hard to find ways to get ESPN Radio into New York. But the economic realities of the radio industry do little to mollify those who listen to and work at WEVD.
"If the goal is to use WEVD as a way to help the financial underpinnings of The Forward, that can be done without selling the radio station," said Alan Colmes, the liberal co-host of Fox Television's "Hannity and Colmes," who has a weeknight talk show on WEVD. "To let go of this would be a true shame in a marketplace where there are so few independent voices."
The station, calling itself the Voice of Labor in the 1920's and the University of the Air in the 1930's, was best known for helping immigrants make the transition to America with shows in Yiddish, Polish and Greek. It later became known as the Station That Speaks Your Language.
What upsets many who work and listen to WEVD is that the station managers are not speaking at all.
Bill Mazer is an old New York radio man with a young voice who has been on the air since 1947 and has a morning show on WEVD. He said that the thing that irks him the most is that management has not told employees of any potential changes.
"The funniest thing to me is that there is the rumor that it is going to be a sports talk station, and I am the father of sports talk in New York," Mr. Mazer said, noting that he started a sports show on WNBC in 1964. 
Charles Zlatkin, a postal worker in Manhattan who started savewevd .com, said, "The thing that has irritated us, the group of listeners all over the area, is that not one person who has called, sent a letter or e-mail has received even a postcard response, which is curious."
Mr. Zlatkin said that listeners were trying to block the sale of WEVD or buy it themselves. His group plans a protest on Thursday afternoon in front of the association's offices at 45 East 33rd Street.
Edward I. Koch, the former mayor, whose talk show began running on WEVD three years ago after being canceled by WABC for low ratings, said that WEVD seemed as much a New York landmark as City Hall.
"WEVD is an institution that goes back as far as I can remember in giving voice to ethnic groups and giving voice to the poor," Mr. Koch said. "And the call letters say it all -- it is for the great Socialists."
Mr. Koch then joked about his openness to change.
"I am enjoying it, and I hope WEVD does not sell the station because I am not good at sports," Mr. Koch said. "But if they sell it and I have to do the Yankees, I'll do the Yankees."

HEADLINE: Seattle Failure Weighs on Future of NewTrade Talks 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 25 

 BODY:
While huge diplomatic momentum is gathering behind the idea of a new round of global trade talks, fundamental differences between rich and poor nations and the United States and its trading partners over what should be on the agenda are clouding the talks before they can begin, just as they did in Seattle in December 1999.
 After being mired for a year after the Seattle debacle, the trade-round juggernaut began to gather speed again early in the year when Pascal Lamy, the European Union's trade commissioner, spoke strongly in favor of starting a new round at the World Trade Organization's next ministerial meeting, to be held in November in Doha, Qatar. In May, President Bush declared free trade a "moral imperative," and the United States trade representative, Robert Zoellick, promoted the idea on a subsequent swing through Europe. 
 Trade ministers from Asian nations added their voices, saying a new round is urgently needed to head off the protectionism that often flares when economies slow down. Last month, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development also called for a trade round. 
For the Doha meeting to succeed, the trade group must find enough common ground among its members to hammer out a workable agenda before it starts. To that end, trade officials have gathered at the organization's headquarters in Geneva in recent weeks, and early soundings have found deep disagreements. 
"It's obvious there is a large gap in views," one European envoy said.
The divisions follow a pattern that was largely evident before the failed Seattle meeting. The European Union leads a group of nations favoring a broad mandate for the talks to make trade concessions more palatable domestically. They want to include food safety, environmental standards, foreign direct investment and national competition policy in the talks.
The United States, which has yet to state its position unequivocally, is believed to want to sidestep fractious subjects like antidumping rules and limits on import surges. In May, Mr. Zoellick said Washington favored a "focused agenda" concentrating on better access for services and agricultural and industrial goods.
So far, the American and European representatives here have played down differences in public, most recently at a joint news conference today, where both sides used the term "ambitious agenda" for their positions. But President Bush's steps to curb steel imports and a belief that he wants to avoid signing any agreements that would foreclose such actions have irritated some United States trading partners.
But the developing countries that make up the bulk of the trade organization want limits on such antidumping actions to be high on the agenda. Led by India and Pakistan, the developing nations have spoken about opposing a new trade round because they say their interests received inadequate attention at the last set of talks, the Uruguay Round, which ended in 1994.
"We are not ready for it," India's trade envoy, Srinivasan Narayanan, said of plans to start a new round at Doha. "We'll lose more than we'll gain." 
The person who is trying to reconcile these competing views is Mike Moore, head of the World Trade Organization, who has been trying to build momentum for a new round since the Seattle meeting fell apart a few months into his term. Mr. Moore wants an outline agenda in place by the end of July, so that negotiations will not stretch into the 11th hour as they did at Seattle.
Mindful of the stakes, a group of high-level trade officials traveled to Geneva from their home capitals today to try to move the process forward. "If we fail for a second time, it will contaminate the atmosphere and create the idea that we can't take the hard decisions," Japan's trade negotiator, Yoichi Suzuki, said last week. Japan is generally aligned with Europe in the talks.
Some diplomats believe that most of the bare-minimum ingredients of a new round are already in place -- the talks on agriculture and on services, including banking, insurance and telecommunications, that were agreed to during the Uruguay Round. If one or two more areas, like tariffs on nonfarm products or trade facilitation, can be added, the talks could be labeled a new round.
Looming in the background is the volatile issue of linking labor standards to trade. Developing countries bitterly oppose making labor standards a matter for the trade organization, which can authorize sanctions. "For them, this is not a line in the sand, it is a canyon," Mr. Moore said. But American and European labor unions have pressed hard for a system that can impose real consequences on countries that fail to protect workers and the environment, and street protests over the issue helped sink the Seattle talks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mike Moore was the new head of the World Trade Organization when it met in Seattle in late 1999. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Bush Makes Airline Strike Unlikely 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25 

 BODY:
The White House today effectively halted any chance of a strike next week by the flight attendants of American Airlines, saying President Bush would intervene if no contract settlement was reached this week.
 A White House statement said federal mediators overseeing the contract talks had requested the appointment of a presidential emergency board, which would extend the current cooling-off period that is preventing a walkout for an additional 60 days. 
 The cooling-off period expires at 12:01 a.m. Sunday, and the White House said an emergency board would be appointed at that time if no tentative contract agreement was in place.
"The president will accept that recommendation and create an emergency board if the parties are unable to reach a negotiated settlement," the statement said.
American, a unit of AMR, and its flight attendants union are scheduled to resume talks with federal mediators on Thursday.
"The president is concerned a major airline strike could threaten the economy," the statement said. "He also wants to assure the public that they can enjoy the upcoming Fourth of July holiday without fear that their travel plans will be disrupted by a strike at American Airlines."

HEADLINE: Shield Is Sought for Employers Under Patients' Bill of Rights 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25 

 BODY:
The Senate began a second week of debate today on a far-reaching bill to define patients' rights, with Democrats looking for some way to limit the liability of employers who might be sued by employees in disputes over health care benefits.
 The Democrats' bill would guarantee patients a wide range of rights and would make it easier for them to sue health maintenance organizations and other health plans in federal and state courts. President Bush has threatened to veto the bill, saying it would raise the cost of health insurance by exposing employers as well as insurers to new lawsuits. 
 Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, has offered an amendment that would provide employers with full immunity against lawsuits filed by workers or their dependents. 
Sponsors of the bill, led by Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, are working with Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, on a compromise that would allow employers to limit their liability. An aide to Ms. Snowe said she had discussed the proposed compromise today with Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff. 
Under the proposal, Mr. Edwards said, employers could name an outside entity as "a designated decision maker," and that entity would bear the liability if a patient was injured as a result of the denial of promised health benefits.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that he was working on an alternative that would provide much more protection to employers, insurers and H.M.O.'s. Under his plan, Mr. Breaux said, patients would have to exhaust all administrative appeals before filing any lawsuits, and the federal government would limit the amount of damages that could be recovered.
Senator Edwards said sponsors of the bill would strenuously resist Mr. Breaux's proposal because it did not adequately protect patients.
Republican senators said they were planning to offer numerous amendments to produce a bill that Mr. Bush could sign. But Democrats said that they saw no reason to make significant concessions and that Mr. Bush would pay a high political price if he vetoed a patients' rights bill.
House Republicans have drafted a bill more acceptable to Mr. Bush. They plan to introduce it on Tuesday.
The Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said today that the need for legislation defining patients' rights had been significantly reduced by voluntary corrective actions of health insurance companies and by passage of state laws to protect patients in most states.
"In most cases," Mr. Lott said, "the issues that caused this to come up in the first place have already been addressed. Some of the mistakes that were being made by managed care organizations -- they stopped making those mistakes." 
Mr. Lott said many states "have moved in this area and have acted responsibly, and it's working." He said Republicans would offer an amendment this week to ensure that the federal government, in setting minimum standards for health insurance, did not "overrun or pre-empt the state laws."
Senator Breaux said he would offer an amendment protecting any state laws that were "consistent with" the new federal standards. Democrats insist that the state laws must be at least substantially equivalent to the federal standards.
The Senate today continued debate on the bill, which would guarantee patients access to emergency care, medical specialists and an independent medical review of decisions denying health care benefits. Under the bill, doctors could prescribe any medically necessary drugs for their patients, regardless of whether the drugs were on a health plan's list of preferred medications, and health plans would have to provide access to clinical trials of experimental therapies if no standard treatment was effective.
The bill applies to more than 180 million people with private health insurance, but does not guarantee coverage for any of the 43 million people who are uninsured. The legislation does not expand Medicaid, Medicare or the Children's Health Insurance Program, nor does it provide tax breaks to help people buy private health insurance.
Most of the debate focused on Republican assertions that injured patients would use the bill as a basis to sue everyone in sight: H.M.O.'s, employers, doctors, nurses, hospitals.
Lobbyists for the managed care industry made available legal memorandums stating that the Democrats' bill would create opportunities for patients to file lawsuits against doctors and the trustees of multi-employer plans that provide health benefits to hundreds of thousands of union workers in industries like construction, mining and transportation.
The American Medical Association and many doctors strongly support the bill. In response to concerns expressed by some doctors, the sponsors of the bill limited the patient's ability to sue a "treating physician" in federal court.
But a legal opinion prepared for the American Association of Health Plans, which represents H.M.O.'s, says that the bill "does nothing" to protect doctors from new lawsuits that might be filed against them in state courts. Likewise, it says, the trustees of collectively bargained health plans could be sued in federal court for "unlimited economic and noneconomic damages and for a civil penalty up to $5 million" if their decisions caused injury to a patient.
Senator Lott complained that the bill relied too much on litigation, saying: "It's sue, sue, sue. That's not the answer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Trent Lott talked with reporters yesterday about a patients' bill of rights. (Carol T. Powers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Fed Credits a New Economy With Altering Old Patterns

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
About 2 o'clock this afternoon, the 17 members of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee will file into their second-floor boardroom on Constitution Avenue in Washington, find the large chairs with the brass plates bearing their names and sit down optimistic that the economy is about to improve. 
 It will have to defy history for them to be correct. 
 For the last 30 years, each time that the nation's payrolls have shrunk as much as they have recently, they have continued falling for months and a recession has ensued or has already been under way. Over an even longer period, the same is true of a broad measure of the value of goods that the nation's companies are selling and of a broad measure of the amount that manufacturers are producing. 
These are not merely a few statistics among many. They form the core of the definition of a recession given by the National Bureau of Economic Research, a group of academics widely considered to be the official referee of economic cycles. Last week, the group released a statement saying that there is now "the possibility that a recession began recently."
More important than what the statistics mean for an academic definition, they suggest that the worst of the economic downturn may not yet be over. In the past, when the economy weakened as it has this year, it has ignited a vicious cycle of layoffs, sluggish consumer spending and yet more layoffs that took almost a year to end.
"It's very likely that we are in a recession now" and recessions typically last about 10 months, said Lakshman Achuthan, the managing director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute in New York. "They snowball."
But Alan Greenspan, his colleagues at the Fed and nearly all Wall Street economists think that the $10 trillion American economy can be turned around more quickly than ever before. The credit, they say, belongs to a "new economy" that has survived the bursting of the dot-com bubble and is altering decades-old economic patterns.
"Is there a new economy?" Laurence H. Meyer, one of the Fed's governors, asked in a speech earlier this month. In the United States, "the answer, I believe, is yes, we are in a new economy."
The technological innovations of recent years have allowed the average worker to produce more goods in an hour, most economists say. This has kept inflation low because companies do not have to raise prices -- even as the long expansion has caused wages to rise -- to increase their profits. With inflation low, the Fed could reduce interest rates more aggressively than it had at the start of other slowdowns, when it was concerned that the stimulus would send inflation to unacceptable levels.
Since January, the Fed has cut interest rates five times, and it is expected to do so again at the two-day meeting that starts today. If it makes a one-quarter-point cut -- and a growing group of analysts is predicting a half-point reduction instead -- the Fed will have lowered rates by 2.75 percentage points in less than six months. During the last recession, in 1990-91, it took more than a year to do so.
Technology also enabled many businesses, like automakers, to notice the slowdown almost as soon as it started late last year. The companies then decreased their production sharply, sold some of their bulging inventories and are now in better shape than they were at a similar point in earlier downturns, according to the consensus. 
On average, analysts are predicting that the economy will hit a nadir in the current quarter, growing just 1 percent, slightly less than it did during the end of 2000 and the first three months of this year, according to Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter based in Kansas City, Mo. In the final six months of this year -- with inventories shrinking, tax rebate checks going out in the mail and lower interest rates encouraging consumers and businesses to spend money -- growth will accelerate to about 2.5 percent, according to this forecast.
In speeches around the country in the last two months, Mr. Greenspan, who is the Fed's chairman, and other members of the rate-setting committee have offered a similar if less specific analysis. "Looking forward, I'd say the U.S. economy still has a lot going for it, and that we're likely to see an acceleration in growth by the end of the year," Robert T. Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said earlier this month.
Late last month, in language typical for him, Mr. Greenspan said that the Fed's "front-loaded policy actions this year should be providing substantial support for a strengthening of economic activity later this year."
If so, it would be an occurrence extremely rare in the last 50 years. Since World War II, manufacturing-and-trade sales -- the measure of goods sold -- have fallen at least 1.8 percent, as they have in recent months, on 10 other occasions, according to the Economic Cycle Research Institute. Each time in the past, the measure continued falling by at least two more percentage points, and with the single exception of the early 1950's and the Korean War, a recession ensued.
Of the 20 times that employment has declined by at least as much as it has recently, a recession has followed (or had recently ended) 17 times, and all three exceptions happened before 1969. Industrial production -- the measure of manufacturing output -- has a perfect record of predicting recessions since World War II.
The fourth variable in the official definition of recession -- in addition to employment, output and sales -- is income, but it frequently continues to rise even during recessions, Mr. Achuthan said.
Some of the optimists say that the historical strength of the economy, relative to almost every other period besides last year, will be the difference. With unemployment still low, consumers have continued to buy everything from clothing to houses at a fairly brisk pace.
"You have to be careful with growth rates; they can be misleading," Arthur J. Rolnick, the director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said. "We're still really well off."
Even if unemployment rises this summer, weakening consumer spending, the interest rate cuts and tax rebates will keep the economy from recession, the optimists say. 
But none of this is an exact science, Mr. Rolnick said. The chances that the consensus will be wrong, and the economy will indeed worsen in the coming months, are about "30 to 40 percent," he added.

HEADLINE: Sharon, in New York, Urges Arafat to 'Put Out Flames' 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, speaking last night in New York, demanded an end to violence by Palestinians as a condition of carrying forward peace efforts, and called on Yasir Arafat to bring a halt to attacks on Israelis. 
 "It is not enough that Arafat lower the flames of violence temporarily," Mr. Sharon said at a dinner at the Pierre New York hotel for the America-Israel Friendship Committee. "He must put out the flames of violence permanently. That is our demand; that is the birthright of our nation." 
 Mr. Sharon, who is to meet with President Bush today, stopped short of offering concessions, like support for a freeze on the building and expansion of settlements, which was one of the recommendations made in support of peace by an international committee led by George J. Mitchell, the former United States senator. 
But Mr. Sharon's spokesman, Ra'anan Gissin, left open the door for some concessions on settlements. "If they are illegal, they will not be there," Mr. Gissin said. But he repeated the Israeli position that there would be no "political negotiations," as he put it, until hostilities cease.
The Mitchell plan calls for a halt to violence, a cooling-off period, confidence-building measures and then the resumption of talks. 
"Today we are facing a campaign of terrorism against us," Mr. Sharon said. "For us, peace is the natural choice, and I will spare no effort in order to achieve it." Therefore, he said, Israel accepted the Tenet proposal. 
"We insisted that the cease-fire includes all forms of violence and hostilities," he said. His written text included a demand that the throwing of rocks and gasoline bombs also cease, but he did not mention the point in his speech.
He said Palestinian leaders should re-arrest "terrorists who are now free but still seek to attack innocent Israeli civilians." The Palestinians say they want to negotiate immediately, but they add that demanding a total end to violence is unreasonable. 
For its part, Israel faces increasing pressure from the right and from settlers to respond strongly to the violence. American officials fear that tough retaliation will cripple the latest peace effort and push the situation back into chaos, after the period of relative calm that has held since the June 13 cease-fire. 
Mr. Sharon, who arrived from a meeting in London with Prime Minister Tony Blair, used the dinner speech as a stepping stone toward Washington, for his second meeting with President Bush since becoming prime minister on March 7. He is also to meet today with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who is to travel to Israel.
The cease-fire and the Mitchell report will be on the agenda, but Mr. Sharon's aides made it clear last night that Israel would assert its right to take action against Palestinian militants. 
"We will act for our right of self-defense," Mr. Gissin said. 
Dore Gold, a Sharon adviser, said Israel had specifically "targeted" Palestinian militants whom it blames for terror attacks over the last several months.
Palestinians say Israel did so, for example, on Sunday, when a Palestinian militant, Osama Jawabri, 29, was killed by an explosion as he talked on a public telephone in Nablus, on the West Bank. The manner of his death was similar to the killings of other militants.
"We have nothing to do with that," Mr. Gissin said. "That was an on-the-job accident. Maybe he shouldn't make phone calls."
Mr. Sharon is also expected to raise allegations that Osama bin Laden, the exiled Saudi dissident and accused terrorist, is seeking to establish a network of agents in Israel, his aides said.
Mr. Sharon also touched on economic issues, saying his government was committed to a low deficit, a lighter tax burden, more government spending on infrastructure and education, and low inflation. 
He said he would push ahead with privatization, and strive for "the necessary reforms in tax, capital markets, pension funds and the liberalization of foreign currency."
