HEADLINE: Trenton Budget Nears Passage Despite Democrats' Objections 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 25 

 BODY:
A $22.9 billion New Jersey budget was cleared for final passage today as two Republican-dominated committees brushed off Democrats' complaints and approved the plan in party-line voting.
 The budget is now scheduled for votes Thursday in the Republican-controlled Senate and General Assembly and, in light of today's partisan voting, appears headed for easy approval before the start of the state's new fiscal year on July 1. 
 Democratic critics focused today on uncertainties about projected revenues. Barbara Buono, the ranking Democrat on the Assembly Budget Committee, denounced the budget as dishonest and a fraud. She also criticized the state treasurer, Peter R. Lawrance, for refusing to appear before the panel for questioning about his recent projections that revenues from major taxes were $948 million below estimates made in January. 
A nonpartisan branch of the Legislature that analyzes the state's fiscal affairs, the Office of Legislative Services, contends that the slump is worse and puts the shortfall at $1.6 billion for the rest of this fiscal year and the 2002 fiscal year.
Ms. Buono argued today that the extent of the shortfall would not be known until next April, months after New Jersey voters choose a new governor and a new Legislature.
The head of the Budget Committee, Leonard Lance, a Flemington Republican, said he, too, was disappointed that Mr. Lawrance had avoided his committee. Mr. Lance called the budget challenging but responsible, without any cuts in essential state services. And he said the budget's $1 billion surplus would satisfy Wall Street institutions that rate state bonds while providing a cushion in the case of a recession. 
The Assembly committee approved the budget, 7 to 4. Later, the plan passed the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, 7 to 2. The chairman of that panel, Robert E. Littell, a Franklin Republican, said, "It's a budget we can all be proud of." Then he took note of questions about projected revenues. "If we made a mistake, we will come back and correct it," he said.
Like Assemblyman Lance, Senator Littell praised the budget's two multimillion-dollar tax rebate programs sought by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco. One, the New Jersey Saver program, increases the average annual payment to homeowners in September to $500 from $240. The other, the Homestead Rebate, increases a state payment to elderly and disabled homeowners to $750 from $500.
A Democrat on the Senate committee, Sharpe James, who is also the mayor of Newark, broke ranks with two fellow Democrats on the panel and voted with the Republicans. He said he was supporting the budget because Mr. DiFrancesco was pushing for construction of a new arena for the Nets and the Devils in downtown Newark. Mr. James was also the only Democrat to voice any concern today about the tax rebates. He said homeowners who earned more than $200,000 a year did not need the $500 from the New Jersey Saver program.

HEADLINE: POWELL, AT U.N., ASKS WAR ON AID 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 25 

 BODY:
Striking an assertive tone for the Bush administration on AIDS policy, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell told the General Assembly today that "from this moment on," the world's response to the disease "must be no less comprehensive, no less relentless and no less swift than the pandemic itself."
 During a special session on AIDS, Secretary Powell held out the possibility of further American contributions to a global fund being set up to finance the fight against the disease, following the $200 million offered by the Bush administration last month. The secretary of state, who expressed his concern over the AIDS crisis in Africa during a visit last month, said the United States would also continue to lead the world in providing money for research. 
 Secretary Powell stopped short of saying how much more money the administration would contribute to the global fund, or when. But he said the initial contribution was "only a beginning." 
As the session got under way, the United States also announced in Washington that it would drop its World Trade Organization litigation against Brazil for planning to produce and market generic anti-AIDS medicine. Page A4. 
Echoing the basis of that decision, Secretary Powell told the delegates: "No war on the face of the world is more destructive than the AIDS pandemic. I was a soldier, but I know of no enemy in war more insidious or vicious than AIDS, an enemy that poses a clear and present danger to the world."
Later, answering questions from reporters about the Bush administration's plans, Secretary Powell said, "I would expect that additional funds would be found in the future and appropriated" by the United States. He said he expected the new global fund, which Secretary General Kofi Annan proposed in April, to start showing results by the end of the year. "To date, the United States has dedicated over $1.6 billion to combat AIDS in the developing world," Secretary Powell said in his speech. President Bush's budget for the next fiscal year seeks $480 million to fight AIDS, the secretary said, more than twice that spent during the 2000 fiscal year.
President Bush is also requesting more than $3.4 billion for AIDS research, Secretary Powell said. "The United States, I pledge today, will continue to lead the world in funding vital research," he said.
The special session, to conclude on Wednesday, is the first devoted to a public health issue. For all the talk today in more than 70 speeches, success hinges in large part on Mr. Annan's ability to attract donors to the global fund, which would spend $7 billion to $10 billion annually to combat AIDS and other infectious diseases, notably malaria and tuberculosis.
Mr. Annan said his goal was to have the fund operating by the end of the year. "We must mobilize the money required for this exceptional effort, and we must make sure it is used effectively," he said today.
So far, the United States, France and Britain, as well as the the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, have together pledged a little more than $500 million. Norway came forward today to offer $110 million. "The counteroffensive against AIDS cannot be won without a bigger war chest," said the Norwegian minister for international development, Anne Kristin Sydnes.
The secretary general opened the conference today with a plea for more compassion for people with AIDS. "When we urge others to change their behavior, so as to protect themselves against infection, we must be able to change our behavior in the public arena," Mr. Annan said.
"We cannot deal with AIDS by making moral judgments or refusing to face unpleasant facts -- and still less by stigmatizing those who are infected, and making out that it is all their fault," he continued. "We can only do it by speaking clearly and openly, both about the ways that people become infected, and about what they can do to avoid infection."
The secretary general's appeal for tolerance was the latest in his continuing effort during the last year to curb divisions and antagonisms -- prejudice against AIDS patients, poor countries' resentment of richer ones and suspicion of big business, especially pharmaceutical companies -- that have frustrated the formation of an effective united front against the epidemic.
Mr. Annan demonstrated anew his instincts for conciliation, which further assured his anticipated nomination this week for a second five-year term as secretary general. The Security Council is expected to endorse him on Wednesday and the General Assembly appears in a mood to approve another term.
Still, it was unclear how much would be accomplished at the General Assembly session, which was attended by two dozen heads of state and hundreds of health ministers, other government officials and diplomats. An estimated 3,000 people have attended, inside and outside the conference.
Clare Short, the British secretary of state for international development, complained that AIDS had been around for 20 years, and that too much time and energy were being wasted at United Nations conferences. "We use up enormous energy in arguing at great length over texts that provide few, if any, followup mechanisms or assurances that governments and U.N. agencies will carry forward the declarations that are agreed," she said.
"There have been enough conferences and declarations," Ms. Short said. "What we need now is urgent and much more effective action on a much wider scale to prevent the terrible suffering, loss of life and costs to development that this terrible disease is inflicting across the world."
The conference is scheduled to conclude with the signing of a declaration setting out goals and targets containing and reversing the AIDS epidemic. But some Muslim countries have objected to explicit references in the draft text to homosexuals, prostitutes and intravenous drug users as people vulnerable to the disease, delaying its completion.
In another contentious event, a private advocacy group, the International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission, regained its seat in one of the roundtable discussions outside the General Assembly after Canada, Norway and Sweden pressed its case. The group was excluded when some conservative delegates objected to its participation.
Mr. Annan reminded delegates that AIDS had set back development in some African countries by a decade or more, and was now spreading "with lightning speed" through Eastern Europe, Asia and the Caribbean. He recited statistics underscoring the toll taken by AIDS around the world: nearly 22 million dead, 13 million children orphaned, more than 36 million living with AIDS or H.I.V. "Every day, another 15,000 people acquire the virus," he said. 
President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria painted an even bleaker picture of Africa as home to 70 percent of the adults and 80 percent of the children infected with H.I.V. in the world and three-fourths of those who have died from AIDS.
"With this trend in statistics, the future of our continent is bleak, to say the least, and the prospect of extinction of the entire continent looms larger and larger," Mr. Obasanjo said. "We do not have any choice but to contemplate exceptional measures to contain the spread and devastation of H.I.V./AIDS."
President John Agyekum Kufuor of Ghana said: "These statistics are frightening and more so when we know that only about 40 percent of the cases are recorded. What this means is that our social security and our economic development efforts are being undermined faster than we can by ourselves contain." 
President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, who once expressed doubts that AIDS was caused by a virus, did not attend the session, despite his visit to Washington this week.
His government recently set aside plans to distribute antiretroviral AIDS drugs, after battling pharmaceutical companies for the right to do do.

HEADLINE: Air Fare Sale for Internet Buyers 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines began offering discounts of up to 20 percent yesterday for round-trip tickets purchased over the Internet in an effort to spur summer and fall leisure travel spending at a time when corporate spending has fallen off sharply. 
 American and America West airlines announced similar savings shortly thereafter, matching Delta's attempt to drive traffic to its Web site and to encourage low-cost bookings. 
 Fares booked on airlines' Web sites are less expensive for carriers in that they do not have to pay distribution fees to the electronic reservation systems used by travel agents.
"They're saying, 'If you help us save, then we're going to help you save,' " said Sam Buttrick, an airline analyst at UBS Warburg. 
The online discounts came as Delta began an overall summer fare sale. However, aside from the potential savings from booking on the Web, Mr. Buttrick called the Delta rate cuts unremarkable. 
Consumers without Internet connections are eligible to take advantage of the savings through travel agents who offer special services through Delta's Web site. 
Delta, American and America West were among the many airlines that posted large losses in the first quarter after a slowdown in the economy prompted major companies to trim spending on business travel. 
Shares of Delta closed down $21.71, at $41.83. American's parent, the AMR Corporation, fell $1.12, to $33.24. Shares of the America West Holdings Corporation dipped 7 cents, to $9.03.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Turning California On

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Those wimpy Californians, with all their fuzzy talk about conservation and their hostility to Big Energy, were supposed to spend this summer sweltering in the dark. But events are not following the script. Summer has begun, yet so far power supplies have been adequate -- and prices have been fairly reasonable. In fact, in the last few days wholesale electricity, which often sold for $750 per megawatt hour this time last year, has been going for less than $100, sometimes less than $50. 
 Everyone seems reluctant to talk about this good news, out of fear that saying anything optimistic would be a self-defeating prophecy. And it is still possible for things to go very wrong. Still, the contrast between dire expectations and the relatively benign picture so far demands an explanation. 
 One big reason for California's improved energy situation is conservation. Taking temperature into account, California consumers are using between 5 and 10 percent less electricity this summer than expected.
Another reason is a sharp drop in the price of natural gas, an important part of the cost of generating electricity. More on that in a minute.
The most important factor in the turnaround, however, is that the state's power plants are back on line. In March, with air-conditioners turned off, there should have been plenty of spare generating capacity. But around 15,000 megawatts, a third of the state's capacity, was mysteriously unavailable. Now the offline capacity is less than 4,000 megawatts. 
Why are the state's power plants operating again? More to the point, why weren't they operating back when the state was desperately short of power, and prices were much higher than they are now?
Many economists now accept the uncomfortable answer: Generators deliberately withheld electricity from the market in order to drive high prices even higher. Until recently the evidence for this market manipulation was purely circumstantial; but it has now been reinforced by direct testimony by former employees of one generator. 
So why did the market manipulation stop? Generators now sell much of their output under long-term contracts with the state, which reduces the incentive to drive up prices in the spot market. But the main answer is probably that intense public scrutiny, culminating in the recent decision by federal regulators to impose price caps, has convinced generators that they had better behave themselves. (The details of the price caps, it turns out, may be less important than the signal that the regulators are, finally, prepared to do some regulating.)
The natural gas story may be similar. Last year El Paso Natural Gas, which controls one of the crucial pipelines serving California, leased a big chunk of that pipeline's capacity to its own marketing subsidiary. That subsidiary has been widely accused of using its control of the pipeline to withhold gas from the California market, and thereby drive up prices. The company denies the accusation, and says that an internal document that talks about "ability to influence the physical market to the benefit of any financial/hedge position" wasn't saying what it seemed to be saying. But when the lease expired at the beginning of this month, gas prices in California promptly plunged 50 percent. 
And so, sooner than anyone expected, it seems that the worst may be over. A drought or a heat wave could still cause rolling blackouts. But time is on California's side; some new power plants will come on line in a few weeks, and many more over the course of the next 18 months. 
The big loser from all this -- for somebody always gets hurt even by good news -- is, of course, Dick Cheney, the architect of the Bush administration's drill-and-burn energy plan. Remember that Mr. Cheney sneeringly dismissed conservation as a mere "sign of personal virtue," and was scathing about people who thought price controls would help. Now things are suddenly looking up -- partly because of conservation, and partly because price controls and the threat of further government intervention have deterred energy producers from manipulating the market. 
It turns out, in other words, that Mr. Cheney -- who prides himself on his tough-mindedness -- was naively out of touch with reality. And the real realists were those silly people who thought that California could solve its crisis by saving energy and suing energy producers.

HEADLINE: Along With Signs of Growth, Words of Caution on Economy 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence rose in June to the highest level this year, a private research firm said today, indicating that shoppers could keep the record economic expansion trudging along.
 The Conference Board's index increased to 117.9, the second consecutive increase, from a reading of 116.1 in May, which was greater than previously estimated. The June index is the highest since it was 128.6 in December. 
 Separate reports showed sales of new homes rose in May along with factory orders for durable goods. The data suggested that the economy might be on track to improve as Federal Reserve policy makers deliberate whether to make additional cuts in interest rates. Economists expect at least a quarter-percentage point cut when the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee concludes its meeting on Wednesday.
"The economy should continue to expand at its current slow rate," said Lynn Franco, an economist at the Conference Board, based in New York. Growth slowed to a 1.4 percent annual rate from October to March, the slowest six-month period since 1991, when the economy was emerging from its last recession.
Orders for durable goods rose 2.9 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase was unexpected and came after a 5.5 percent decline in April. Sales of new homes rose 0.8 percent in May, to 928,000 houses at an annual rate, the third increase in four months, the department said.
Economists say that signs of growth in today's data should be viewed cautiously. Consumer confidence was lifted by stock market gains that have since ebbed, they said. While factory demand increased in May for cars, aircraft and semiconductors, orders for all durable goods are still down 11.5 percent from May 2000.
Also, the confidence index showed declines in plans to buy expensive items, like cars, appliances and homes. The percentage of respondents planning to buy a car fell to 6.7 in June, the lowest since December 1997, from 9.5 in May.
Economists who determine whether the United States is in a recession have been on alert. The National Bureau of Economic Research said on May 15 that economic data "indicate the possibility that a recession began recently."
The bureau, based in Cambridge, Mass., repeated that statement on June 4 and June 18. Each time, the economists have said that the economy "has not declined nearly enough" to call a meeting of the committee that declares a recession.
Analysts had expected a reading of 114.5 in the confidence index after the 115.5 originally reported in May. Confidence is an important measure of economic health because it may translate into consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of all goods and services produced in the United States.
The June increase reflected greater optimism. A gauge of consumer expectations for the next six months rose to 93.2 in June, the highest since December, from 87.1.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Indexes Bounce Back From Sharp Decline Early in Day

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
The stock market climbed back from a sharp slide yesterday, with modest gains in the technology sector and modest losses elsewhere, as the Federal Reserve considered its next move on interest rates and investors wondered whether another rate cut would produce lasting results.
 A profit warning from Merrill Lynch, brought about by declining stock and bond trading activity, underscored an ambivalence that has been a drag on stock prices throughout the Fed's efforts to bolster the economy. Even an assortment of upbeat economic reports -- received with expectations that the Fed would cut interest rates by at least a quarter of a percentage point and maybe by a half-point -- did not distract investors from their concerns about corporate profits. 
 "The Fed's made all these cuts," said William D. Rutherford, the president of Rutherford Investment Management in Portland, Ore. But, he said, "without some encouraging news, the markets can't go up." 
"What they want is a C.E.O. to stand up and say things are going to get better."
On Jan. 3, the Fed made the first of five half-point rate reductions this year. While some of the cuts have touched off impressive one- and two-day rallies in stocks, the three leading market gauges are still below their marks of Jan. 2.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.74 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,472.48, after falling more than 100 points in the morning.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 13.75 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,064.62. But the broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.84 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,216.76.
The stock market was shaken early in the day after Merrill Lynch warned that a miserable quarter had only worsened in June, and analysts saw little hope for improvement during the summer. Merrill projected profits of 52 to 57 cents a share, below analysts' expectations of 82 cents a share. 
While mortgage refinancings have created business for some financial services firms that package and sell bundles of debt, Merrill's slow business highlighted a primary drag on the markets themselves.
Merrill's shares fell $7.54, or 11.4 percent, to $58.91. Other financial services companies, including the Dow components Citigroup, J. P. Morgan Chase and American Express, also declined.
Ahead of the Fed's decision on interest rates, which will be announced this afternoon, new reports provided evidence that the economy might not be as weak as some on Wall Street fear. The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence rose in June to its highest level since December. Orders for durable goods increased an unexpected 2.9 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported. And sales of new homes rose 0.8 percent in May.
Still, those reports failed to shake Wall Street's pessimism. "Has there been much of a change in the economy since they started cutting rates in January?" said John O'Donoghue, co-head of listed trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "You're seeing earnings warnings and layoffs."
Despite all the cost-cutting, businesses have not held up their side of investors' equation for hope. Indeed, Xilinx, a maker of computer chips, warned of a revenue shortfall after the stock market closed yesterday. Shares of Xilinx -- which ended regular Nasdaq trading up 15 cents, at $43.86 -- fell $2.52, to $41.34, in after-hours trading.
"No one is even thinking about building inventories yet," said John C. Forelli, portfolio manager for Independence Investment L.L.C., an institutional money management firm based in Boston. "We're still seeing capital spending flat to going lower."
If the Fed satisfies the market's best hopes with a half-point cut today, he said, "that's about the only positive news we're going to see for the rest of the summer." --------------------

By Bloomberg News
Bond prices fell yesterday as evidence of consumer optimism suggested the Federal Reserve will stop lowering interest rates after this week.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note fell 23/32 , to 98 11/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.22 percent from 5.12 percent on Monday.
The 30-year bond fell 28/32 , to 96 2/32 . Its yield rose to 5.65 percent from 5.59 percent.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate; 
Tight Retail Spaces Prompt Suit by the Disabled

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Every inch of retail space is valuable in Manhattan. And few retailers seem to pack as much into that inch as the ever-growing Duane Reade chain.
 Now an advocacy group for the disabled is charging that the layout of many Duane Reade stores, particularly those with multiple levels and obstructed aisles, has effectively made them inaccessible. 
 In a lawsuit filed last month in federal court in Manhattan, the group, Disabled in Action of Metropolitan New York, demanded that Duane Reade eliminate all barriers in its stores to those with "mobility impairments." 
The lawsuit accuses the chain of violating the Americans with Disabilities Act and the city's human rights law.
Duane Reade Inc., whose headquarters are in Manhattan, has until mid-July to answer the complaint. Without commenting on the lawsuit, Jim Rizzo, the vice president for human resources, said, "As a retailer we want our stores to be accessible." 
The lawsuit highlights the tension between a commercial tenant's economic need to wring every penny in sales from high-priced real estate and its obligation to accommodate customers with wheelchairs, motorized scooters, walkers, crutches or braces.
A couple of multilevel Duane Reade stores have recently been renovated to a single level, and wheelchair lifts have been installed in some others, but not as an acknowledgment of a problem, Mr. Rizzo said. "If we can make the stores easier to shop, we'll do so," he said, "but that doesn't mean the store wasn't accessible before that."
The case points out the inherent difficulty of laying out a drugstore with the pharmacy at the farthest reaches, a common practice that frees space in the front for merchandise.
"Not to have access to the pharmacy is not just an inconvenience," said Nadina LaSpina, who teaches Italian language and literature at New School University, uses a wheelchair and is a plaintiff in the case. "If you need to buy medication, that's a necessity."
In the Duane Reade at Lexington Avenue and 42nd Street, the pharmacy is reached by escalator. At 51 West 51st Street, it is up a flight of stairs. Neither store has an elevator or lift, although signs are posted conspicuously in the 51st Street store saying, "If at any time you require assistance obtaining merchandise or services in this store, please see the cashier or any Duane Reade associate for their assistance."
Jean Meyers Ryan, a retired child psychologist who lives in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and gets around the city on a motorized scooter, said an intermediary was unsatisfactory in dealing with a pharmacist.
"There are things you need to discuss that are private," said Ms. Ryan, who is also a plaintiff. She noted that nonprescription medications were frequently placed beyond her reach. "I can't ask somebody else to figure out which is the cheapest container, which is the cheapest brand," she said.
Duane Reade was singled out for the lawsuit in part because of the frequency of complaints from disabled customers and in part because of its increasing domination of the market, said Dennis R. Boyd of New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, which, with Fish & Neave, represents Disabled in Action.
There were 172 Duane Reade stores as of December, 102 of them in high-traffic areas of Manhattan, according to the company's latest 10-K report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Thirty-six stores were on two levels.
"We have demonstrated our ability to successfully operate stores using a wide variety of store configurations and sizes," the report said. "Flexibility in configuring stores provides us with a competitive advantage in securing locations for new stores, as many of our competitors target more standardized spaces."
In the Duane Reade at 155 East 34th Street, the selling floor is three steps up from the main entrance at Third Avenue. Nothing at the front door indicates that there is a step-free entrance about 75 feet away, which is locked in any case. ("Push button for handicap entry," a sign at the side entrance says. "Wait for assistance.")
Inside, there is a six-step ascent to the photo center and greeting-card department. The lift next to this stairway was blocked on Monday afternoon by a stack of detergent boxes and an unused display case.
"It's hard to pay the rents landlords want and utilize spaces to the highest efficiency without overstuffing them," said C. Bradley Mendelson, senior managing director in the retail group at the Insignia/ESG brokerage firm. Even so, he said, "Duane Reade, more than almost any other out there, tends to have stores that seem to be overstuffed."
Faith Hope Consolo, senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates Store Leasing, has a similar impression. "Some of these stores have cartons in the aisles in addition to everything that's packed on the shelves," she said. "These drugstores are more like grocery stores or supermarkets."

HEADLINE: Laguna Madre Journal; 
Welcome Mat's Out for Bombing in Scrub Country

BYLINE:  By ROSS E. MILLOY 

DATELINE: KINGSVILLE, Tex., June 26 

 BODY:
The rugged country south of here on the shores of Laguna Madre is an inhospitable tangle of mesquite chaparral and sand dunes with more cows than people.
 Just right for a bombing range, local officials say. 
 After the Bush administration announced last week that it would bow to protests and stop military bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques in 2003, officials here unveiled a proposal to move the maneuvers to a nearby area that would become an "expeditionary warfare training center."
The plan, which is backed by many of the region's business and political leaders, would create a training ground for bombing, ship-to-shore shelling and amphibious troop landings on 222,000 acres of privately owned ranchland just south of here in Kenedy County. It would attract jobs and other military missions to the area's three naval sites and insulate them from future cutbacks or base closings, said Dick Messbarger, director of the Kingsville Economic Development Council. 
But others in the area are far less welcoming. 
"I've got people ready to set their hair on fire over this," Mr. Messbarger admitted. 
Critics here assert, as they have in Vieques, that the warfare practices could threaten the health of residents, curb tourism and hurt the area's fishing industry.
Just north of the site, on Baffin Bay, where the state's record speckled trout was caught last year, a fishing guide, Dallas Furman, 36, said that a bombing range would put him and 250 other fishing guides in the area out of business.
"When they practice bombing, it will run the fish off for a month, and just about the time the fish are settling back in, they'll start bombing again," Mr. Furman said. "I get madder and madder every time I think about it."
Assaults by marines and armored vehicles along the 20 miles of coast would require amphibious crafts to plow over the barrier beaches of Padre Island National Seashore and then cut across the Intracoastal Canal and the ecologically sensitive Laguna Madre, an estuarial breeding ground of sea grasses. Those maneuvers could also require three 1.24-mile-wide corridors across Padre Island, home to the endangered Kemp's turtle.
"It would certainly add a whole new realm to the management of the island," said Ken McMullen, a spokesman at the National Seashore. "There would obviously be significant impacts on the environment and the 800,000 visitors we get here each year."
The amphibious craft could also stir up sediment in the tidal flats, destroy sensitive sea grasses and form "dead zones" in which no sea life could exist, Mr. McMullen said.
"In the event of a short-falling shell, the chemicals in explosives could be extremely destructive to marine life in the Laguna Madre," he said. "And that's before we get into things like accidental spillages of fuel or chemicals."
Navy officials have said that without Vieques, a new site is needed in the western Atlantic to train troops for joint military operations in the Mediterranean and Persian Gulf. Kenedy County, with 415 residents, offers many of the elements such a site requires: limited population, an area outside major air corridors, deep water ship access, and beaches suitable for practicing sea assaults.
"We've looked everywhere and found no place that would be a perfect one-for-one replacement for Vieques," said Lt. Cmdr. Cate Mueller, a Navy spokeswoman in Washington. "Now, we're looking at different combinations of places and training techniques, and there have been discussions about South Texas as an appropriate location."
Kenedy County is only one of several alternatives being considered, said Commander Mueller, who would not reveal the other locations.
A panel to select a replacement site for Vieques will soon be appointed by Gordon R. England, the secretary of the Navy, with its recommendations expected in October, she said.
"There will obviously be various studies and environmental impact statements required on whatever spot is ultimately selected," Commander Mueller said. "It's all very preliminary at this stage."
Mr. Messbarger, the economic development official, dismissed fears that the exercises would cause long-term environmental damage.
"These operations will only be for four or five days at a time every few months," he said, "and the military can mitigate or repair any damage that would be done." 
Besides, he said: "I'm just enough of a patriot to believe that I don't want my son or grandson getting their first experience with live fire in a combat situation. We're talking about the kind of training here that will save lives."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dick Messbarger, left, is among business and political leaders in Kingsville, Tex., who favor a bombing range on the shores of Laguna Madre. But Dallas Furman, a fishing guide, sees the plan as a threat to his livelihood. (Photographs by Greg Spaulding for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Victory Lap Takes Turn From Right

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
MONDAY afternoon, with the Republican primary election still a day away, Bret D. Schundler was already looking toward November. "I never believed it was my right to dictate to people," said Mr. Schundler, the candidate of New Jersey's rarely visible right wing.
 This was the gentler, general-election Bret Schundler, preparing to run as a conservative Republican in a staunchly moderate state. 
 Mr. Schundler has a knack for defying the natural laws of party politics. In 1992, he became the first Republican in 75 years to be elected mayor of Jersey City, a legendary machine shop of Democratic votes. A fluke, people said. Then he was re-elected twice. And yesterday he defeated the heavily favored choice of state Republican leaders to become the party's nominee for governor.
He had planned for years to build a victory by bringing together the party's pro-gun, anti-abortion and pro-school-choice forces, and his strategy caught the party's moderate leadership flat-footed. But those conservative positions were never really in play in Jersey City. 
When a caller to a television program this week said that some people in Jersey City were surprised to learn his position on gun control laws, Mr. Schundler said, "That's not an issue that a mayor has much involvement in."
And yesterday morning, while greeting voters at a train station here, he was asked about whether Jersey City's voters ever seemed to have strong feelings about his views on abortion. "Why would they care about the views of a mayor on that issue?" he asked.
But signature social issues like gun control and abortion are squarely in a governor's purview. For the first time in Mr. Schundler's unlikely career, he is likely to face sustained scrutiny of his most conservative positions..
This week, James E. McGreevey, the Democratic nominee who has been running against Trenton for years, began changing his message to attack Mr. Schundler. "Mayor Bret Schundler is an extremist and clearly out of the mainstream of New Jersey," he said after addressing a roomful of unionized Newark Housing Authority employees.
Voters who hate Trenton will love this campaign. "This campaign is about one inescapable fact: The need to change the way business is done in Trenton," Mr. McGreevey said in his acceptance speech last night. And Mr. Schundler won yesterday, in part, by denouncing the Trenton establishment led by his own party.
But the subplot of the campaign is likely to be a struggle over whether Mr. Schundler gets to define himself or whether Mr. McGreevey does it for him.
In his speech last night, Mr. Schundler reeled off a litany of issues he wants to deal with, from sprawl to urban schools, from taxes to tolls on the Garden State Parkway, to race. He didn't highlight the issues that rallied the far right. This was a message tailored to the mainstream.
"Bret has never run as a social conservative," said former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, the dean of moderate Republicanism in New Jersey. "If you listen to him as mayor of Jersey City, if you listen to his ads, it's basically an economic message."
But even Mr. Kean, who as of last night was supporting Mr. Schundler, has some of the same problems with his candidate as does Mr. McGreevey. "The gun issue is a concern, especially in North Jersey," Mr. Kean said. "We don't want people walking around carrying concealed weapons."
Mr. Schundler has said that in the unlikely event the Legislature passes a bill making it legal to carry a licensed, concealed weapon, he would sign it into law because "allowing people to defend themselves reduces crime."
On abortion, he acknowledges that the law of the land rests with the Supreme Court, but he said he thinks there is a consensus in New Jersey for outlawing late-term abortions.
YESTERDAY'S election was billed as a fight for the soul of the Republican Party. 
The general election is likely to be a fight for every cul de sac and town house development in New Jersey.
On Monday, Mr. Schundler's aides were considering various options for getting their man back on the road as soon as the primary was over. A bus tour was a favorite. Mr. McGreevey, not to be outgimmicked, announced he would take a three-week walking tour of New Jersey from High Point to Cape May.
This is shaping up as quite a summer on the political byways. Mr. Schundler will be running from the extremist label. Mr. McGreevey will be walking across the state. Travelers, beware.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
FEELING THE SLOWDOWN, OLIN WILL CUT ITS WORK FORCE 14%

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The Olin Corporation, a producer of metals, chemicals and ammunition, cut its full-year earnings forecast by half and will lay off more than 900 people, or 14 percent of its work force, citing a weak economy. 
Olin, based in Norwalk, Conn., lowered its 2001 earnings forecast to 50 cents a share from $1. Olin had been expected to earn 83 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Olin, which makes rolled metals and foils, chemicals used in papermaking and bleach, and Winchester brand bullets, said it was making the cuts because it did not expect economic conditions to improve this year.

HEADLINE: Fighting for Dominance on a Stretch of 42nd Street 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A 30-year-old tug of war on West 42nd Street has flared up again, pitting two old New York real estate families -- one quite wealthy and the other much less so -- against each other. Millions of dollars are at stake on this grimy piece of 42nd Street west of Avenue of the Americas.
 The Maidman family, once a powerhouse on the West Side of Manhattan, recently announced plans to transform their narrow, 22-story brick tower on the north side of 42nd Street, largely vacant since the 1970's, into a luxurious 27-unit condominium hotel. They have enlisted designing help from a distant relative, Isaac Mizrahi, the former fashion designer. 
 But the Durst family, which owns 90 percent of the block, including buildings on both sides of the Maidman tower, say that the idea is farfetched and that it would cost more to rehabilitate the tower than the Maidmans could ever hope to reap.
The Dursts contend that it is yet another transparent attempt by the Maidmans to try to increase the value of their dilapidated property in the event of condemnation by the state or of a sale to the Dursts. The Maidmans, who have resisted the Dursts' efforts to redevelop the block, are known in real estate circles as holdouts.
So the Dursts say they plan to take the tower away from the Maidmans. Last month, a chunk of concrete fell from the top of the Maidmans' building and plunged through the roof of an adjoining single-story building owned by the Dursts. The city evacuated the Durst building and cited the Maidmans for a series of violations.
"Mr. Maidman's building is falling onto our adjoining property and has caused us considerable damage," said Douglas Durst, who heads the family's company, the Durst Organization, which owns 10 Midtown skyscrapers. "We expect to be filing suit for values far in excess of whatever his property might be worth and therefore expect to own it in the very near future."
The Maidman-Durst dust-up is only the latest tale to emerge on the embattled block since Douglas Durst's father, Seymour, bought his first parcel there in 1967. And it is only the latest illustration of the pitfalls a developer can encounter in New York, where there is little vacant land and every property owner and tenant wants to hold out for the biggest pot of gold before selling.
The Durst Organization built the 1.6 million-square-foot office tower, 4 Times Square, at the west end of the block. The family wants to build a $1 billion, two-million-square-foot tower at the east end, if only the three remaining property owners will cooperate.
Mr. Durst says he believes that all that stands between his family and their long-sought skyscraper are the Maidmans and another family, the Bernsteins. He says he expects ultimately to strike a deal with the Rosenberg family, which owns the last parcel on the block.
A group led by Joseph Bernstein owns an L-shaped parcel that fronts on both 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas. In 1985, Mr. Bernstein nearly bought out the Dursts, but the deal fell apart when he became embroiled in a scandal over his role in secretly buying New York real estate for Ferdinand Marcos, the former Philippine dictator
Since then, Mr. Durst has sought to buy the Bernstein group's interests, but the sides failed to agree when Mr. Bernstein insisted on becoming a partner in any new development.
In 1999, the Dursts erected a large billboard on the block announcing the coming of 1 Bryant Park, a two-million-square-foot tower, a move the Bernsteins said was intended to scare potential tenants away.
More recently, Mr. Bernstein's group sued the Durst Organization and New York State, saying that the state was wrongfully conspiring to condemn the Bernstein properties, enabling Mr. Durst to benefit. At Mr. Durst's behest, the state has agreed to study the possibility of condemnation, but has taken little action so far.
The Maidmans, however, did not join Mr. Bernstein's lawsuit. Rather than trying to foil Mr. Durst's plans, Mitchel Maidman, whose grandfather bought the building in 1953, says he thinks the time is right to develop the property as a luxury residence. He hired H. Thomas O'Hara, an architect, and Mr. Mizrahi to transform the slim building, which offers unimpeded views of both the East and Hudson Rivers. Interior demolition has begun and the Maidmans say they have already spent $750,000 on the project.
"Mr. Durst has not made any offers for the property in years," said Mr. Maidman, whose family now owns about two dozen small properties in Manhattan. "We've always wanted to develop that building. We were just waiting for the right opportunity. This'll be a super luxury condo building."
As for falling debris and other building violations, Mr. Maidman said they would be taken care of during renovation.
"We understand a brick fell," Mr. Maidman said. "But we're not sure where it fell from."
The Buildings Department has cited the Maidmans for failing to maintain their building, where an arch is pulling away from the structure and the brick chimney and terra cotta ornaments are in danger of collapse. Responding to a complaint by Mr. Durst, the department also cited the Maidmans for failing to obtain a permit to erect scaffolding.
One additional benefit of his project, Mr. Maidman pointed out in a news release, was that his sole, longtime tenant, an adult video operation called Fun City Video, would close this summer. In a nod to Mayor Giuliani's anti-pornography campaign and a zinger for Mr. Durst, the release points out that the only remaining adult bookstore on 42nd Street east of Times Square is in a building controlled by the Dursts.
(Mr. Durst, in turn, said that the bookstore's lease had been canceled.)
Relations between the Dursts and the Maidmans were not always so hostile. In the early 1970's, Seymour Durst negotiated an option to buy the Maidman building, but the deal collapsed after a related real estate deal unraveled and a recession hit. The Dursts tried again in the 1980's and 1990's, but the two sides were millions of dollars apart on price.
Three years ago, the Dursts opposed the Maidmans' attempt to obtain a zoning variance to put up a billboard the size of a basketball court on the west side of the Maidman building, which faces the Dursts' new 48-story skyscraper, 4 Times Square. The Maidmans then argued that the billboard should be allowed because the building had little other value.
Late one Friday night, the two sides struck a deal: the Dursts would support the Maidmans' request for a billboard and share the revenue; the Maidmans would give the Dursts an option to buy the property. But that proved to be a momentary lull; the Maidmans tore up the contract the following Monday.

B10) Map of Manhattan highlights 42nd Street area: A hotly disputed stretch of real estate on West 42nd Street. (pg. B10)

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
With Jobs Plentiful, Latest Immigrants Have Found It Easier to Fit In

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
Illegal immigrants got most of the headlines in the 1990's, but they were only a small percentage of the immigration wave that poured into the country over that decade. In fact, recent census figures confirmed what many people already knew -- legal immigrants have become the biggest source of growth in the population and, not surprisingly, in the labor force. 
 Years ago, many Americans viewed new arrivals as threats to their job security. This time, though, few had much to worry about; the Internet-fueled economic boom lowered the jobless rate to the current rate of 4.4 percent from 7.8 percent in June 1992, and even created widespread labor shortages. As a result, immigrants often provided a vital source of labor, according to John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at City University. Nowhere was this more true than in New York State, where they filled the void created by people leaving for opportunities elsewhere. 
 If anybody suffered, it was those struggling the most to make ends meet, said Steven Camarota, research director of the Center for Immigration Studies. The latest immigrants were "less educated relative to natives than previous immigrants," he said, so they competed for the lowest-paying jobs. He said that drove down wages for people at the bottom of the economic ladder by 7 percent in real terms over the decade. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
As the number of corporate guests drops, many top-rated hotels offer discounts.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

DATELINE: CAREFREE, Ariz. 

 BODY:
GRANTED, it was 105 degrees by 1 p.m. Golfers were straggling off the startlingly green fairways laid alongside huge high-desert rocks. Even the people in the pool looked wilted.
 On the other hand, I was in a hotel, the Boulders, that often turns up on lists of the top domestic resorts. The price: $149 a night (plus a $22 service charge) for a 550-square-foot room. And it was just as hot in downtown Phoenix, an easy 45-minute drive away, where the convention-style Hyatt Regency was charging $139 a night during a recent conference based there. 
 Actually, I'm not wild about self-conscious resort hotels like the Boulders, with hyper-eager young employees who always seem to be murmuring earnestly into Secret Service-like lapel microphones. But the $149 rate seemed persuasive. At the Boulders, the usual summer rate is $195 (plus the $22 service charge) for a room that goes for about $650 in high season. This summer, the same room is going for $119 (plus that $22) in a new group-rate promotion.
Across the board, and for the first time in recent memory, many top-shelf hotels are having rate sales, partly as a way to fill rooms left empty by the sharp and sudden retreat of corporate clients, and partly in hopes of stimulating extra summer leisure travel as a potential catalyst for a hoped-for resumption of robust travel this fall or winter.
The National Business Travel Association predicted last week that business travel currently accounting for more than $185 billion in spending by domestic companies would double within five years. But right now, it's in the dumps. Hotels are having their worst time in 10 years. And domestic airlines, having their worst slump in 25 years because of the decline in business travel that started in January and accelerated in the spring, are so desperate to scratch up some revenue that the five biggest ones are all promoting special summer-travel sales this week, with some even discounting holiday travel like the July 4 weekend.
Even in tough times, hotels generally resist discounts. In fact, domestic hotels actually raised rates sharply, by about 7 percent, during the first quarter, according to American Express.
But now, discounts are blossoming even at some of the highest-level hotels, where managers are usually loath to cut rates because customers might still expect discounts when good times return.
"Major luxury hotels have started slashing rates in some cities and resort areas for summer travel," said Thom Nulty, the president of Navigant International, the travel management company. This occurred despite "a long-held belief" in the hotel industry "that the top end of the market was somewhat insulated from recession," he said.
Hotel stocks were banged up after analysts slashed earnings forecasts earlier this month. So it would seem that luxury hotel owners should be wailing in anguish. Some may well be doing that privately, but there is an interesting sidebar to the trend in which corporate travelers by the millions are either staying home more or staying at cheaper places.
According to hotel industry executives, many top executives -- the big cheeses who don't necessarily have to do what the corporate travel department decrees for everybody else -- are still insisting on traveling high on the hog.
"In our hotels, which are the definitive luxury hotels in the world," room rentals "are almost as good as last year -- and last year was a record year," said Paul M. McManus, the president and chief executive of Leading Hotels of the World Ltd., a company that operates a marketing network for 360 of the world's top luxury hotels. 
The rates for rooms booked by Leading Hotels remain higher now than they were last year, he said. In New York and other domestic cities and in Europe, rates are typically between $450 and $550 a night at these hotels, but can range well into the thousands of dollars for suites.
Member hotels in New York City include the Lowell, the Pierre, the Peninsula and the Plaza Athenee. In New York, overall occupancy rates are down about 8 percent this month. But "we're not seeing that in most of our hotels," even though "business travel is the primary market," said Marshall A. Calder, a senior vice president in the company. "If you take the Lowell, where the average rate is probably around $650, 60 percent or more of their business is repeat business. It's C.E.O.'s, entertainment executives, bankers. They go to the Lowell time after time, and they're certainly not going to downgrade and go to a lower-level hotel."
These customers, who "don't perceive themselves as being affected by the temporary economic woes," Mr. McManus added, "try and cooperate with the corporate travel directives." Still, he said, "the address they stay at in a certain city is very important in their communication with who they're doing business with; based on that, they stay where they want to stay." Luxury demand driven by top-executive travel is even stronger in European cities, Mr. Calder added.
The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company, which manages 39 luxury hotels and is building 20 more in the United States and abroad, also said that demand remained robust among its top-level corporate customers, though Vivian A. Deuschl, the vice president for public relations at the company, called the overall drop in business travel "significant."
She cited "continued strength" in demand for Ritz Carlton hotel rooms on business-club and concierge floors, however. "Customers at the upper tier want service and will pay for it," she said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Biggest Spenders For Ads Are Listed

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Spending leaders for the first quarter of 2001 in large advertising categories like automobiles, financial services and drugs are being identified by CMR in New York, formerly Competitive Media Reporting, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres. Overall ad spending for the first quarter declined 5.2 percent from the period a year earlier, according to CMR. 
 General Motors was the leading auto advertiser, spending $479.6 million in the first quarter, down 25.8 percent from $646.8 million in the first quarter of 2000. 
 The automobile brand with the largest ad spending was Chrysler, from the Chrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler, at $40.4 million, up 99 percent from $20.3 million. The Dodge Caravan minivan from Chrysler was a close second with $40.2 million, up 17.2 percent from $34.3 million.
The financial services marketer with the largest ad spending was Citigroup, spending $75.8 million, up 162 percent from $28.9 million.
The financial brand with the highest ad spending was the Discover Card credit card, part of Discover Financial Services, a unit of Morgan Stanley, which spent $34.9 million, up 13.7 percent from $30.7 million.
GlaxoSmithKline was the leading pharmaceutical company in ad spending in the first quarter, spending $193.3 million, down less than 1 percent from $194.5 million. Johnson & Johnson was second, at $114.3 million, up less than 1 percent from $113.4 million.
And the pharmaceutical brand with the highest ad spending was Singulair, an anti-asthma drug sold by Merck & Company, at $31.9 million, up 25.6 percent from $25.4 million.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: France: Consultant's Forecast 

BYLINE:  By John Tagliabue (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The big European consulting and computer services group, Cap Gemini of France, lowered its revenue forecast for this year and said it would cut 2,700 jobs, mainly in the United States, Britain and Scandinavia, as weaker economies on both sides of the Atlantic cause demand for its services to slow. Cap Gemini, which last year acquired the consulting business of Ernst & Young, predicted revenue for the full year of 9 billion euros ($7.7 billion), against an earlier forecast 9.6 billion euros. 
Geoff Unwin, the chief executive of Cap Gemini, said the group's operating margin would drop to about 7 percent this year, from 10.5 percent last year. Cap Gemini's share price dropped by as much as 24 percent to its lowest level since early 1998. John Tagliabue (NYT)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Nasdaq Rises and Dow Falls As Investors Await Rate Cut
As investors awaited today's announcement from the Federal Reserve about a cut in interest rates, technology stocks made modest gains while others posted slight losses.
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 13.75 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,064.62. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.74 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,472.48, after falling more than 100 points in the morning. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.84 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,216,76. Page C10. 

Consumer Confidence Up in June
Consumer confidence rose in June to the highest level this year, the Conference Board said, indicating that shoppers could keep the record economic expansion trudging along. The Conference Board's index increased to 117.9 from 116.1 in May. Separate reports showed sales of new homes rose in May along with factory orders for durable goods, while the prices of new homes fell 0.5 percent. C2.

Bear Stearns Chairman Steps Down
Bear Stearns announced that its chairman, Alan C. Greenberg, was stepping down. James E. Cayne, the company's chief executive, will add the title of chairman. C2.

Patent Cited as Microsoft Challenge
Intertrust Technologies, a small developer of software for protecting digital information, received a patent that it said would challenge Microsoft's strategy for linking its next generation operating system to Internet services and content like digital music. C4.

Palm and 3Com Report Losses
Palm, the biggest maker of hand-held computers, and 3Com, the computer networking equipment manufacturer, posted losses. C4.

Europe Rethinks E-Business Stance
Officials at the European Commission say they are considering abandoning a long-held position on Internet commerce that the laws in the country where a consumer is situated should govern. World Business, Section W.

Executive Coaches Bridge Gaps
Executive coaching evolved into a specialty in the United States more than a decade ago, but it did not make much headway in Australia until the mid-1990's. Since then, the practice has taken off. Management. C6.

Radio Days and Reality TV
John de Mol, chief executive of Endemol Entertainment, said his father, who was a popular singer in Holland, wanted him to study law or another profession. Instead, he said: "I wanted to be in radio. So I never went to college. I went to work on a pirate station that broadcast rock music from a ship in the North Sea." The experience gave him a kernel of an idea for the reality television programs he later created. "I'd spend two weeks on board sometimes with 10 radio people and 10 crew. Relations were pretty intense," he recalled. "You can imagine 20 people living together. It was a lot like 'Big Brother,' the reality television program I created." The Boss. C6.

ABC News Pulls Children Interviews
ABC News has removed an interview with schoolchildren from a special on the environment after parents complained of being misled about the nature of the questioning when they allowed their children to take part. C9.

House Passes Farm Aid Package
The House passed an emergency aid package of $5.5 billion for farmers, most of whom already receive federal subsidies. A20.

The two largest farm worker unions sued the Labor Department last week, accusing it of illegally failing to raise wages for more than 30,000 foreign guest workers. A15.

Top-Line Hotels Are Cutting Rates
Many top-shelf hotels are having rate sales, partly as a way to fill rooms left empty by the retreat of corporate clients and partly in hopes of stimulating extra summer leisure travel. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C7.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Losses Posted For Quarter By Palm Inc. And 3Com

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 26 

 BODY:
Reflecting the pervasive nature of the high-technology sector's continuing slump, the biggest maker of hand-held computers and a top computer networking equipment manufacturer reported losses today.
 Palm Inc. said it had a fiscal fourth-quarter loss as sales fell nearly 53 percent, partly because the introduction of a new device, the m500, was delayed by a defect. 
 The loss was $392 million, or 69 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 1, in contrast to net income of $12.4 million, or 2 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales fell to $165.3 million from $350.2 million. 
In its fourth quarter, the 3Com Corporation's loss grew to $517.7 million as revenue fell 39 percent.
The network equipment maker's loss widened to $1.52 a share from $146.8 million, or 42 cents, a year earlier, 3Com said in a statement. Revenue dropped nearly 39 percent in the period ended June 1, to $468 million from $763.7 million. Excluding reorganization charges and the amortization and write-down of intangible items, the loss would have been $206.3 million, or 61 cents a share, 3Com said.
Palm lowered its fourth-quarter sales forecast twice, as a technical defect delayed the m500. It said customers waited for the new device instead of buying older models.
Excluding amortization of good will, a charge for excess inventory and other costs, Palm said its loss would have been 16 cents a share. On that basis, it had been expected to lose 19 cents, according to analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call.
Palm shares rose as much as 18 percent, to $6.12, in after-hours trading, after falling 4 cents, to $5.19, in regular trading.
Palm's operating loss, which excludes amortization of good will and other costs, will be $60 million to $80 million in the first quarter, said Judy Bruner, Palm's chief financial officer. In the second quarter, she expects operating profit of $5 million to $20 million.
At 3Com, the chief executive, Bruce Claflin, plans to eliminate 4,370 jobs, or 37 percent of the work force, and trim product lines this year to try to turn a profit in 2002. 3Com, also based in Santa Clara, has suffered from the United States economic slump and a decline in spending by phone and Internet companies, investors say.
The company's shares fell 19 cents, to $4.84, and were down another 16 cents, to $4.72, in after-hours trading after the report. They had declined 43 percent this year.
Investors and analysts say the company's $1.64 billion in cash and short-term investments will help it survive, though it is unclear when sales growth will recover.

HEADLINE: Ending Corporate Welfare 

 BODY:
In his April budget proposals, President Bush indicated his intent to follow through on a campaign pledge to end many of the federal subsidies to business known collectively as corporate welfare. Now, with opposition mounting to his plan to end loan guarantees for risky commercial shipbuilders, Mr. Bush faces the first test of his resolve. Given his longstanding ties to corporate America and an otherwise overwhelmingly pro-business agenda, the president is well positioned to cut such subsidies without appreciable damage to his political base. In the case of the shipbuilders' loan guarantees, Mr. Bush also has the logic of national security and economics on his side. These are reasons enough to stand up to the members of Congress who want the subsidy. 
 There is virtually no justification for the subsidies apart from pork-barrel politics. The absence of a commercial shipbuilding industry would hardly threaten national security, since the country is unlikely to go to war with all three of the world's big builders -- Europe, Japan and South Korea -- at the same time. The alacrity with which the industry was revived by the loan guarantees, which began in 1993, also suggests that shipbuilding could be quickly rejuvenated in the event of an emergency grave enough to require wartime mobilization. And since military fighting ships are vastly different in design from commercial passenger vessels, enhanced production of the latter might not be the best course to military readiness. 
 Like many corporate welfare programs, the loan guarantees also fail the economic test. Without the national security argument to lean on, it is hard to justify a claim that the United States underproduces commercial ships. Costs of production here are roughly twice as high as abroad, and American competition certainly has not driven down world prices, which would have benefited domestic buyers. Any benefits to employment in poor urban areas, such as Pascagoula, Miss., could be generated more directly by enterprise grants or other targeted programs.
Mr. Bush's attempts to cut corporate welfare will undoubtedly cost him some political capital in Congress, at a time when he can ill afford to lose it. In the case of the shipbuilders' loan guarantees alone, 38 senators, led by Mississippi's Trent Lott (whose wife is from Pascagoula), have signed a letter asking not only that the program be spared but that its funding be tripled this year. But the damage is unlikely to be permanent, and in any case Mr. Bush could use these cuts to mend ties with John McCain, a perennial anti-pork crusader, and to win over conservative opponents of big government. Most important, Mr. Bush could gain back some of the electorate's faith by keeping a popular promise.

HEADLINE: South African Links AIDS To Broader Issue of Poverty 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26 

 BODY:
President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa skipped the United Nations conference on AIDS in New York today to come to the White House, where President Bush, in the gentlest of encounters, helped him deflect accusations that his government has all but neglected the AIDS epidemic.
 Mr. Mbeki, whose country has been hit harder by AIDS than any other nation, said during a brief photo opportunity in the Oval Office, "People must look at what we're doing in South Africa, not their perception of what they think we're doing." 
 Responding to the many critics who have said he has done little in the area of prevention or treatment, Mr. Mbeki said: "I don't think, on the basis of facts, that an accusation like that can be sustained. It cannot." 
Yet Mr. Mbeki, who has expressed outright skepticism that H.I.V. causes the disease, did not attend the AIDS conference, where he was bound to have faced extraordinary criticism.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell addressed the conference on Monday and promised additional assistance, beyond the $200 million that Mr. Bush has already promised as seed money for a multibillion-dollar AIDS fund, but he did not say how much the administration was willing to commit.
It was unclear why the Bush administration was giving Mr. Mbeki an easy alternative to appearing at the conference, and administration officials said little about that. Instead, today both Mr. Mbeki and Mr. Bush endorsed the establishment of the fund, but they offered no specifics of how they might increase its size.
"The AIDS pandemic in Africa is terrible," Mr. Bush said. "The president is concerned, as am I."
Mr. Mbeki repeated his oft-stated position that AIDS is one of a number of related problems and diseases that must be handled with a comprehensive policy. "In many instances, these are diseases which are not only caused by poverty, some of them, but also cause poverty." 
Mr. Mbeki left the White House after lunch with Mr. Bush, without speaking to reporters. 
While AIDS and Mr. Mbeki's theories about its causes overshadowed the meeting, the White House said it was only one of many subjects discussed. 
The men spent a considerable amount of time talking about President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, whose iron rule and widespread human rights abuses were condemned last month by Secretary Powell during his trip to Africa. Secretary Powell accused Mr. Mugabe of clinging to power and called for free elections in the country.
But today Mr. Bush and Mr. Mbeki were far more restrained. A senior administration official, briefing reporters this afternoon, said that although the two leaders recognized the problem with Zimbabwe, they did not spend a lot of time "talking and criticizing."
"They spent much more time on: how do we solve this problem?" the official said. "How do we deal with the issue of promotion of rule of law, democracy, getting beyond this land issue in Zimbabwe?" 
But again, he declined to provide any specifics.
The two also spent some time discussing global trade, a key issue for Mr. Mbeki, who has made growth through trade and debt relief a cornerstone of his presidency. But the meeting came at a politically difficult time for the 59-year old leader. His approval ratings have dropped dramatically, and even his core supporters, who praised him effusively after he took over from Nelson Mandela, now regard him as remote and aloof. His views on AIDS have only reinforced that view.
Last year his government scrambled to explain how $6.2 million of the country's $17 million AIDS budget went unspent. They said the money would be rolled over into this year's budget. 
That followed Mr. Mbeki's personal quest to determine the true cause of AIDS, which led him to consult some medical sources who doubt the consensus theory that H.I.V. infection leads to the devastating syndrome. His government decided against distributing the standard anti-AIDS drug, AZT, to public hospitals.
Mr. Mbeki also wrote a lengthy, peculiar letter to President Bill Clinton last year, arguing that South Africa had to chart its own course in fighting AIDS. He said there was a "campaign of intellectual intimidation and terrorism" akin to "medieval book-burning" to keep alternate theories about the causes of the disease from being heard. 
But South African clerics, labor unions, the Communist Party and even Mr. Mandela, who was Mr. Mbeki's mentor, all argued that the scientific consensus on AIDS should be followed. 
Mr. Bush used an event in the Rose Garden several weeks ago to declare that the United States would commit $200 million to a global fund being set up by the United Nations. Many AIDS groups said that was a pittance from the world's largest economy, and did not set a high enough contribution level for other developed countries. Mr. Bush responded that it was a start, and said that further contributions would be forthcoming.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa and President Bush at the White House yesterday. In addition to AIDS, the two leaders discussed global trade and the political situation in central and southern Africa. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PATIENTS' RIGHTS PICK UP MOMENTUM IN 2 SENATE VOTES 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26 

 BODY:
Senate Democrats won two significant victories today as the Senate rejected Republican challenges to provisions of a Democratic bill to define patients' rights for more than 180 million Americans.
 The back-to-back votes, combined with a similar vote last week, created a sense that the bill was gaining momentum, after being tied up in a partisan impasse for nearly five years. 
 The new Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, said today, "We have been very, very pleased overall with the victories that we've enjoyed so far."
By a vote of 57 to 43, the Senate rejected a Republican proposal to provide employers with complete immunity against lawsuits by employees who challenge the denial of their claims for health benefits. Republicans said the risk of such lawsuits would prompt employers to stop offering coverage, but Democrats said employers should be liable when they directly participate in decisions that harm patients. The other victory for Democrats came in a 61-to-39 vote that defeated a measure to pull the bill from the floor. 
President Bush threatened last week to veto the Senate Democrats' bill. And House Republican leaders today unveiled an alternative that was considered acceptable to the White House.
Asked about today's votes, Senator John McCain of Arizona, the chief Republican sponsor of the Democrats' bill, said they "continue the momentum we have, but there are still tough issues remaining."
The bill, a far cry from Democratic efforts in 1993-94 to guarantee health insurance for all Americans, would define a wide range of rights for people who have coverage. The measure would, for example, guarantee patients access to emergency care, medical specialists, clinical trials of new drugs and an independent medical review of decisions denying care.
The bill would make it easier for injured patients to sue health maintenance organizations and other health plans for the denial of promised benefits. Employers could also be sued if they directly participated in decisions to deny care to a patient.
Supporters of the bill claimed a significant political victory today, saying that it would improve the ability of covered patients to get quality health care. But the bill would not guarantee coverage for any of the 43 million people who lack health insurance. And opponents said that the rejection today of the proposed limit on employer liability meant that the bill would unleash a torrent of litigation.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader, said: "Employers beware. You are going to be sued. Under this bill, there is no limit on economic damages, no limit on damages for pain and suffering in federal or state court."
But Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, an architect of the legislation, denounced the proposal to give employers full immunity. With such sweeping protection, he said, "there would be no end to the irresponsible behavior of some unscrupulous employers, who could deny necessary medical treatment any time it became too costly or inconvenient." And backers of the bill said there has not been an explosion of lawsuits in states that have adopted similar legislation.
Employers are not required to offer or provide any health benefits to employees, but many voluntarily do so, through a variety of arrangements. Sponsors of the Senate bill said they did not know how many employers might be exposed to lawsuits. Most employers would not incur risk because they hire insurance companies or other entities to manage health benefits for their employees, and the employers do not rule on individual claims, Democrats said.
But Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said that plaintiffs' lawyers would name employers as co-defendants in lawsuits filed against H.M.O.'s and other health plans. Mr. Gramm said the bill would provide employers with a legal defense, but not with complete immunity, so employers would have to hire lawyers and defend themselves in court. The cost of such litigation would increase the cost of health insurance for employers and employees alike, Mr. Gramm said.
The action on employer liability came after the Senate rejected a Republican motion to pull the bill off the floor so it could be reviewed.
Last Thursday, by a vote of 52 to 45, the Senate killed a Republican amendment that would have increased the tax deduction for health insurance costs of the self-employed.
Democrats announced that the patients' rights bill would be the first order of business after they took control of the Senate this month.
The House Republican bill unveiled today would give patients a more limited right to sue and is closer to what Mr. Bush wants. When he threatened last week to veto the Senate Democrats' bill, Mr. Bush said it could lead to explosive growth in lawsuits and an increase in insurance premiums, prompting many employers to drop coverage.
J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker, said the House Republican bill was "the only one with a real chance of being signed into law by the president." White House officials endorsed the measure.
Under the House Republican bill, a patient could sue a health maintenance organization in state court if the patient was injured because the H.M.O. refused to provide care ordered by an independent medical reviewer. Damages would be subject to any limits set by state law.
Alternatively, patients could sue in federal court. Damages for pain and suffering would be limited to $500,000, and no punitive damages would be allowed.
Senators Olympia J. Snowe of Maine and Mike DeWine of Ohio, both Republicans, are working with Democrats on an amendment to limit the liability of employers, and Mr. Bush is encouraging their effort. They would allow employers to shield themselves by naming an outside entity, known as "a designated decision-maker," to assume liability. The House Republican bill includes a similar device.
In a statement of principles in February, Mr. Bush said employers should be "shielded from unnecessary and frivolous lawsuits." At the same time, Mr. Bush said, "employers who retain responsibility for and make final medical decisions should be subject to suit."
Ms. Snowe said Mr. Bush called her today and urged her to expand her efforts at compromise beyond the issue of employer liability. The president, she said, also wants Congress to channel most lawsuits into federal courts and to limit the amount of damages.
Senate Democrats showed today that they had some reliable Republican support. On the first vote, 12 Republicans and Senator James M. Jeffords, an independent of Vermont, voted with 48 Democrats in rejecting the motion to send the bill to committees for further work. On the second vote, relating to employer liability, six Republicans and Mr. Jeffords voted with all 50 Democrats.
