HEADLINE: Senators Hear Bitter Words on Florida Vote 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27 

 BODY:
At an acrimonious hearing that showed how bitter the fight remains over the Florida election last fall, two members of the United States Civil Rights Commission strafed each other today and called each other liars. Even Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, got into the act.
 Despite this hostility, senators of both parties who were listening to the exchanges tried to move beyond the Florida dispute and gave some signs that changes in the election system might yet be on the horizon. 
 The Senate Rules Committee was the staging ground for a discussion of the commission's report on the Florida balloting and bills that would funnel money to states for new election systems. It provided a platform for two members of the commission -- one appointed by Republicans, the other by Democrats -- to air their differences over whether some Florida voters were disenfranchised. 
The commission voted 6 to 2 this month to approve a report that said that blacks in Florida were at least 10 times more likely than other voters to have had their ballots rejected last Election Day.
One of the dissenting members, Abigail Thernstrom, presented her rebuttal to the report today. Relying on a statistical analysis by John Lott, an economist at Yale Law School, Ms. Thernstrom said that "voter error was the central problem in Florida, not disenfranchisement" and that the committee report was flawed and prejudicial.
"Inflated rhetoric depicting crimes for which there is no evidence undermines public confidence," Ms. Thernstrom said.
She also said the majority had withheld data from her.
Mary Frances Berry, the chairwoman of the commission, hotly denied the accusation as they sat next to each other at the witness table.
"It is an absolute falsehood," Ms. Berry said, noting that Ms. Thernstrom had asked for a disc of data and was told there was no disc but that the information was available on the Internet.
"She was not denied data," Ms. Berry said. "It makes a good story -- 'I was denied this, I was denied that.' It is a lie. I am 63 years old. I'm too old for playing games."
Ms. Thernstrom responded, "I would never publicly call a commissioner a liar, but I have just heard a lie."
Ms. Berry affirmed the findings of the report and said she was "surprised that people are so exercised" about it. She said it was clear that black voters had higher rates of problems than others, regardless of whether they were intentional.
"If I ran over you at 90 miles an hour and killed you, it doesn't matter whether I intended to or not, I still killed you," Ms. Berry said.
In another tense exchange, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, took on the credibility of Mr. Lott, Ms. Thernstrom's statistician. Mr. Schumer, a proponent of gun control, first belittled Mr. Lott in passing as the person who had found, in Mr. Schumer's words, "The more guns, the less violence."
In prosecutorial tones, Mr. Schumer then wrung out of Mr. Lott a defeated "yeah" to the question of whether "a greater percentage of black and Hispanic people are turned away than, or don't get to vote, than white people?"
The packed hearing room broke into applause at Mr. Lott's concession, prompting Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, to gavel the room to order, saying, "It's not a rally; it's a hearing."
Ms. Harris, the Florida secretary of state, was not present but sent a statement to the committee in which she accused the commission of "crafting a battle plan for politicians interested in wielding the sword of racial division."
Two election bills the Rules Committee is considering have strong support in the Senate. Both would offer about $2.5 billion to the states over five years to upgrade their election equipment. But one bill, sponsored by Senator Dodd, and supported by all 50 Democrats, would mandate that the states take certain actions. The other, sponsored by Senators Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, and Mr. Schumer and supported by 31 Democrats, 38 Republicans and one independent, has no mandates.
Supporters of both bills indicated that some compromise could pass the Senate later this year. Mr. Schumer said the question of mandates "will work its way through the process in the next several months and in fall we can sit down and have a compromise." And John Feehery, a spokesman for House Republicans, indicated there was "some cause for optimism" in the House as well, later in the year.
Larry Sabato, an election specialist at the University of Virginia who also testified today, said in an interview: "I was pessimistic for a long time, but I've changed now, not entirely because of the Democratic takeover of the Senate, but partly because of that. As we get closer to 2002, an awful lot of senators and House members on both sides of the aisle want to be able to tell African-American voters that they've done something, whatever that something is -- money or money plus mandates."
Mr. McConnell said in an interview that he thought the shift in power in the Senate was slowing election reform. Now that Mr. Dodd is chairman of the Rules Committee, he has said he will hold hearings on the matter around the country. Mr. McConnell noted that state and national panels had already held more than 60 hearings and that no more were necessary.
"That may be important to certain parts of their base, but we know enough to move forward," Mr. McConnell said.

HEADLINE: FED LOWERS RATES BY QUARTER-POINT IN 6TH CUT OF YEAR 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point today and signaled that its campaign to revive the flagging economy may be entering its final stages.
 The rate cut was the sixth by the central bank since it became clear at the beginning of the year that the economy was slowing precipitously. But the five previous reductions were all half a percentage point. In holding to a quarter-point reduction this time, the Fed suggested that it wanted to slow the pace of its response to the downturn while it waited to see the full impact of the steps it had already taken this year. 
 The move reduced the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks -- the Fed's primary tool for influencing the economy -- to 3.75 percent from 4 percent. The rate was last that low more than seven years ago. 
Analysts said that it now seemed likely that the central bank would cut rates at least once more this year, probably by another quarter-point, at its next scheduled meeting on Aug. 21.
Economists had been nearly evenly divided as to whether the Fed would cut rates by half a point or a quarter of a point today, and the news brought a muted response from investors. 
Stock prices fell somewhat after the announcement at 2:15 p.m., then bounced up and down the rest of the day. Investors, after months of disappointing earnings reports, no longer seem to expect the Fed's moves to bring an immediate lift in corporate results. Market Place, Page C1. 
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 37.64 points, to close at 10,434.84; the Nasdaq composite index rose 10.12 points, to 2,074.74. Most bond prices fell.
The Fed's decision was intended to stimulate more economic activity by reducing borrowing costs and bucking up consumer and business confidence. It will put modest downward pressure on interest rates paid by small businesses and consumers, including those on some credit card balances, auto loans and adjustable mortgages. 
But it is not likely to have much direct effect on most mortgage rates, which are determined largely by longer-term rates set in the bond market.
In a statement this afternoon at the conclusion of a two-day meeting, the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee provided little insight into its decision, and gave only the barest of hints as to how much of an internal debate there was about the scale of the rate cut. 
Comments by Fed officials in recent weeks have suggested that one camp within the central bank was growing increasingly concerned that it not overdo the rate cuts and create a situation in which the economy overheats next year. But another camp, led by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has played down any threat from inflation and implied that there was plenty of room for further reductions.
In that sense, today's decision was cast by some analysts as a compromise.
"We assume that the F.O.M.C. was divided and that the smaller 25-basis-point move allowed a consensus to be forged," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
In its statement, the Fed made clear that it was not yet declaring victory in its effort to avert a recession or promote a quick recovery if a recession has already begun. It did not contain any optimistic assessment about a possible rebound later this year and repeated the same laundry list of problems facing the economy that the Fed has emphasized after previous rate cuts.
In particular, the statement reflected Mr. Greenspan's position that inflation was not enough of a threat to restrict the Fed's ability to cut rates further if necessary. As a result, economists said, Mr. Greenspan still has leeway to fine-tune monetary policy through further quarter-point rate cuts this year.
"The patterns evident in recent months -- declining profitability and business capital spending, weak expansion of consumption and slowing growth abroad -- continue to weigh on the economy," the open market committee's statement said. "The associated easing of pressures on labor and product markets are expected to keep inflation contained."
Using its standard language indicating its expectation that it will cut rates further, the central bank said the economic risks "are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future."
Still, the decision to hold the rate cut to a quarter-point was read by most analysts as evidence that the Fed now wanted to give its cumulative rate cuts of 2.75 percentage points in the federal funds rate time to work. Changes in monetary policy typically take at least six months to have their full impact.
The central bank also cut its less frequently used discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system to 3.25 percent from 3.5 percent.
"We now expect the Fed to sit back and let the policy actions of the first half of the year work their magic," said Richard Yamarone, director of economic research at Argus Research in New York. "From here on out, we are likely to be in a wait-and-see mode. In the event that the trend of weaker economic activity picks up steam, then a few more 25 basis point cuts should be expected."
The economy has been especially hard to read in recent months, but there are few clear-cut signs that it is about to get back on the track of strong growth that characterized most of the last few years.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, has held up reasonably well. The housing market has been particularly robust, and consumer confidence seems to have stabilized.
But layoffs seem to be mounting, and the industrial sector of the economy is deteriorating steadily. Industrial production has fallen for eight consecutive months, corporate profits are tumbling, companies are reducing their investments in new technology and foreign markets for American products and services are becoming weaker.
The economy should benefit in the second half of the year not just from the accumulated punch of the rate reductions already made by the Fed, but also from the first stages of the $1.35 trillion tax cut signed into law this month by President Bush. Most taxpayers will receive rebate checks of up to $300 for single people and $600 for couples the next few months, and income tax rates will be reduced starting on July 1.
"Most of the people in the economic community believe that we're going to see a rekindling of substantial growth rates in the third and into the fourth quarter," Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, said in a speech in Detroit.
The economy grew at a 1.3 percent annual pace in the first three months of the year, and some economists say the economy may prove not to have grown at all in the second quarter -- or even contracted, bringing to an end the longest expansion on record. The last recession ended in March 1991.
The outlook depends to a great degree on how quickly companies begin investing again in computers, communications equipment and more efficient equipment for their factories. A boom in capital investment in the second half of the 1990's was one of the primary drivers of the strong economy, and the drop in investment this year has been one of the main anchors dragging the economy down.
Some economists say that in many cases companies overinvested the last few years based on unrealistic expectations that sales and profits would continue to surge. As a result, they said, it could be a long time before investment picks up again and lower interest rates are not likely to do much to accelerate the process.

HEADLINE: Schundler Talks of Unity, But Grin Says 'I Told You' 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, June 27 

 BODY:
Bret D. Schundler's campaign car was at a standstill in Lower Manhattan traffic at 4 p.m. today, when he burned out his third cell-phone battery of the day. Mr. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, won a surprise victory in Tuesday's Republican primary for New Jersey governor, and suddenly it seemed that half the world wanted a word with him. 
 After rising at 5 a.m. to do three hours of radio call-in shows, newspaper interviews and television appearances, then being showered with accolades at a New Jersey Republican Party luncheon, Mr. Schundler careered into Manhattan for a taping of CNN's "Crossfire" from 3 to 3:30 p.m. and, ever the optimist, headed to a photo opportunity scheduled for 4 p.m. in Jersey City. 
 But even on the day when you're the hottest political candidate in the country, there is no easy way through the Holland Tunnel. As his driver drummed his fingers on the steering wheel, Mr. Schundler took the phone from an aide and paused to share one of his trademark musings, this time about how cell phones had infringed on personal time by allowing work to follow people anywhere. 
"But right now, it's a little incredible to think of all the work we have ahead of us," Mr. Schundler said, before a series of calls from well-wishers, fund-raisers and even a Right to Life organizer who wanted him to fine tune his responses to questions about abortion. 
The traffic jam may have been the only snag in Mr. Schundler's first full day as the Republican nominee.
Fresh from his triumph over nearly the entire state Republican establishment, and a bit drained from three hours sleep, he tried to capitalize on his moment of political stardom by laying out his conservative platform for school choice, tax reductions and ending tolls on the Garden State Parkway. He also tried to make a pre-emptive strike against Democrats who portray him as an extremist because he favors expanded rights for gun owners but opposes abortion; he vowed his views would not prevent him from vigorously enforcing the state's existing laws.
Along the way, Mr. Schundler, whose confident manner has struck some as arrogance, had a hard time concealing his satisfaction that he had defied all the political experts and was reaping the spoils. 
Mr. Schundler, whose office displays a picture of himself and his wife outside the fence at the White House, was invited by President Bush to be a featured guest at a Republican fund-raiser in Washington today. (He declined because he had a previously scheduled event with New Jersey business leaders, but sent his wife in his place).
Most significant, Mr. Schundler was hailed by some of the leaders of state's Republican Party, who promised to unite behind him. When asked what it was like to be praised by some who had written him off as a fringe candidate, Mr. Schundler flashed a smile that suggested it was hard not to say "I told you so."
"It's encouraging," he said. "And it's humbling. A lot of people have put their trust in you, so now you don't want to blow it."
Many political experts consider Mr. McGreevey to be a slight favorite, but Mr. Schundler relishes the role of underdog and has overcome surprisingly steep odds before.
In 1992, after working as an account executive for Salomon Brothers in New Jersey, Mr. Schundler undertook a campaign many people considered a lark: he became a Republican candidate for mayor of Jersey City, a community where more than 90 percent of registered voters are Democrats. After a 19-way special election, Mr. Schundler became the city's first Republican mayor in 75 years. 
Democrats criticized him for running up the city's debt by using extensive bonding and tax abatements to spur waterfront development, but the decaying neighborhoods and blighted downtown have shown undeniable signs of revitalization.
Mr. Schundler handily won re-election twice and became the darling of Newt Gingrich and other Washington Republicans because of his ability to espouse conservative social views and business-friendly economic policies while still attracting votes in the urban centers, whose residents typically vote Democratic. 
In a sign that Mr. Schundler intends to compete on that turf, he pointed out that in his last election he won the majority of votes in five of the city's eight housing projects.
"We're not conceding one single urban vote to Jim McGreevey," he said.
Mr. Schundler, 42, lives in Jersey City with his wife, Lynn, a law professor at Seton Hall, their son, Hans Otto, 3, and daughter, Shaylin, 8. He was born in Morristown, N.J., the youngest of nine children and was an all-state football player at Westfield High School.
He became an evangelical Christian as a teenager, and after earning a sociology degree from Harvard in 1981, he considered a career as a minister before his interest in urban affairs led him to politics as a Democrat. His primary opponent, former United States Representative Bob Franks, made much of the fact that Mr. Schundler was a former Democrat who worked on former Senator Gary Hart's campaign for president in 1984. But Mr. Schundler said that he grew dismayed by the Democrats' reliance on extensive government programs and became intrigued by Ronald Reagan's brand of populism. He registered as a Republican in 1991. 
On the campaign trail, he is quick-witted and tireless -- even critics who accuse him of showing off his intelligence concede that he has an impressively broad grasp of policy. The pastiche of cultural and political influences that shaped Mr. Schundler have also given him an unusual grab bag of references on the campaign trail. When he took the stage Tuesday to make his acceptance speech, Mr. Schundler used the the curious greeting of "y'all"; the next day, he included casual, and incisive, references to the scriptures, Martin Luther King Jr. and Aristotle. 
Even on this victory lap of a day, as he savored the attention and newfound friends, the iconoclast in Mr. Schundler could not help but view the campaign as a chance to take on new political adversaries.
"I don't think there's a political figure in New Jersey who has more members of special interest groups against him, or gotten more votes by doing so" he said with a smile. "And this race is just getting started."

HEADLINE: Bridgestone/Firestone to Close Tire Plant at Center of Huge Recall 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 27 

 BODY:
Still reeling from a huge tire recall and the end of its long relationship with the Ford Motor Company, Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. said today that it planned to close one of its biggest tire factories.
 The factory, in Decatur, Ill., was singled out last August when Firestone recalled about 6.5 million tires after growing concerns about crashes of Ford Explorers equipped with its products. About 1,500 employees, mostly union workers and many with more than 20 years of experience, will probably lose their jobs. 
 The closing of the plant, which can produce more than seven million tires a year and accounts for 10 percent of the company's production, underscores just how difficult business has become for Bridgestone/Firestone, which is facing an industrywide downturn and persistent questions about the safety of its tires. 
Company officials said the decision to close the factory was driven solely by economics and not because Decatur had once been cited as a major source of problem tires.
"This is about balancing supply and demand," said John McQuade, vice president for manufacturing operations at Bridgestone/Firestone, a unit of the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan. "This has nothing to do with the quality or professionalism of our Decatur employees."
The company said that it had too much capacity and that Decatur was the oldest of its eight plants and would be the most expensive to upgrade. Firestone spent about $60 million in improvements for the sprawling plant in recent years.
At a news conference in Tokyo today, where the plant closing was first announced, Hiroshi Kanai, the managing director in charge of finance at Bridgestone, said it would be too costly to retain a 59-year-old plant.
"You are talking about a plant where if you don't do anything, the roof will fall down," he said.
Bridgestone/Firestone said it would take a $210 million charge to cover the cost of closing the Decatur factory. To complete the shutdown by December, as planned, the company must negotiate terms with the United Steelworkers of America, which represents the tire makers.
Bridgestone/Firestone laid off about 1,100 factory workers, or about 10 percent of its work force in the United States, seven months ago. And a month ago, Ford announced that it would spend $3 billion to replace about 13 million Firestone tires because of safety concerns.
Ford's action led to a sharp rebuke from Firestone, which insists its tires are safe. Firestone executives said Ford ignored evidence that indicated the instability of the Ford Explorer played a crucial role in bringing about 174 deaths in numerous accidents the last few years.
Firestone also decided to stop selling tires to Ford, ending a century-old relationship. Because of the corporate breakup, demand for Firestone tires has plummeted, and consumers appear to be losing confidence in the Firestone brand. 
Wall Street analysts said they had been bracing for today's announcement.
"I always thought that from the time Firestone severed its relations with Ford that at least one plant had to go," said Stephen Haggerty, a tire industry analyst at Merrill Lynch. "My sense is the Firestone brand is weakening in the replacement market, and this could lead to the need for a second plant's closing."
Bridgestone/Firestone, which is based in Nashville, has said it has no plans to abandon the Firestone brand.
Company officials also say the Decatur closing will improve efficiency at some of the company's seven other tire plants in the United States.
The steel workers union said today that it would try to prevent the plant's closing. But union officials were not optimistic.
"We would like to avert a shutdown, but if we can't, we'd like to negotiate the best package we can," said Roger Gates, president of the United Steelworkers Local 713 in Decatur.
Several workers said they were unfairly blamed. 
"I kind of saw this coming," said Randy Adkins, a 49-year-old tire maker who has worked at the plant for 29 years. "I've been preparing myself. I wanted to get to 30 years and then get out because the 12-hour days have not been good for anyone. It's 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. and that's taxing."
Mr. Gates said that the workers were simply the lowest on the totem pole.
"Ford put the blame on Firestone and then Firestone scapegoated the Decatur plant," Mr. Gates said. "And now, we're the ones who pay the piper."

HEADLINE: G.E. Is Said To Float Plan To Save Deal 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN with PAUL MELLER 

 BODY:
General Electric has held informal discussions with European regulators about selling a minority stake in its aviation financing business in hopes of winning approval for its proposed acquisition of Honeywell International, executives close to the talks said yesterday.
 The move is an about-face for G.E., which said last week that the chance of the deal moving forward was "zero" and that the proposal it submitted to the European Commission was final. 
 The commission has indicated it will block the $45 billion transaction unless G.E. agrees to modify its offer.
Yesterday, Paul H. O'Neill, the United States Treasury secretary, attacked the European Commission, saying that it would be "off the wall" for European regulators to block the deal, which American regulators have already approved. The commission plans to rule on the deal at its meeting on Tuesday, although it has until July 12 to submit its final decision. 
In an informal proposal yesterday to European regulators, G.E. lawyers discussed selling up to 20 percent of GE Capital Aviation Services, also known as Gecas, which owns and leases a fleet of 950 aircraft, the executives said. The European Commission has said that GE Capital could unfairly push its clients to buy G.E.'s aviation products over those of competitors like Rolls-Royce and Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies, by offering discounted package deals. 
European regulators previously asked G.E. to sell a stake in GE Capital to a competitor or to the public, a proposal that was rejected. G.E. is now floating the idea of selling 20 percent to a noncompetitor like a financial institution, thus allowing it to keep the aviation unit's earnings on its books, executives said. The investor would get seats on the unit's board, the executives said.
It is unclear whether G.E.'s latest proposal will satisfy the Europeans. An executive close to the company said yesterday: "I can't tell if the Europeans think this is enough. I'm still pessimistic. We can't offer much more. At some point, the deal's just not worth doing."
Another executive close to the company said yesterday that it had already put out a feeler to Citigroup about buying the stake. Citigroup has its own aircraft leasing business through its global equipment finance unit. A spokeswoman for Citigroup declined to comment about the company's possible involvement.
G.E.'s latest proposal is dependent on an agreement with regulators that would permit it to divest itself of less of Honeywell's avionics business, the executives said. G.E previously offered to sell parts of Honeywell that generate $2.2 billion in annual sales.
A spokesman for G.E. confirmed the discussions but declined to comment on their details. "I'm not going to characterize the probabilities," said Gary Sheffer, the spokesman. "We said last week that we were pessimistic and that we would continue to advocate our proposal. That's what we continue to do."
Executives close to G.E. said the company would submit a modified proposal only if it got an assurance in advance that regulators would approve the deal.
Gotz Drauz, the director of the European Commission's merger task force under Commissioner Mario Monti, also declined to provide details of the talks. "At this late stage, it would have to be a fully satisfactory proposal," he said. "We agreed with G.E. that because there is so much speculation, we will keep confidential any late talks that may or may not take place."
In a letter sent on Tuesday to Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat from West Virginia and the chairman of a Senate subcommittee on aviation, Mr. Monti suggested that selling a piece of the aviation financing unit would satisfy the commission.
"The only condition would have been to combine these limited aerospace divestitures with the implementation of a structural undertaking on Gecas, without putting in question the control by G.E.," Mr. Monti wrote.
If a deal is forged, it would not be the first time American companies adjusted a merger proposal at the 11th hour to satisfy European regulators. Boeing's $14 billion merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in 1997 was almost blocked by European regulators until Boeing agreed to drop its exclusive aircraft-supply agreements with AMR's American Airlines unit, Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines.
Shares of Honeywell rose 2.2 percent, or 80 cents, to $37 yesterday on speculation that the deal might be approved. Shares of G.E. fell 1 percent, or 53 cents, to $48.26. 
American officials have become increasingly vocal about their dissatisfaction with the European Commission's stance.
After a speech to the Economic Club of Detroit, Mr. O'Neill said that the European Commission had too much power. "They are the closest thing you can find to an autocratic organization that can successfully impose their will on things that one would think are outside their scope of attention," he said.
"When I see things like this, they're irritating," Mr. O'Neill added, "and yes, I'd like to say they need to stop, but they will stop in time."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Falling Unemployment 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The jobless rate has dropped more in New York City than in any other big metropolis over the last year, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. 
The unemployment rate in the city has dropped by 0.6 percentage points, from 5.5 percent in May 2000 to 4.9 percent in May 2001, the bureau said. Two other major metropolitan areas -- which the bureau defines as those with more than one million residents in 1990 -- had declines of 0.5 points: Indianapolis and Riverside, Calif. Because of the national economic slowdown, unemployment rates have risen in many cities. The biggest increase was in Charlotte, N.C.; the jobless rate rose by 2.3 percentage points, to 5.3 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: Japan Is Resisting Following the Fed on Rates 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 27 

 BODY:
Betting that the Federal Reserve would reduce interest rates today, putting irresistible pressure on the Bank of Japan to further loosen its own monetary policy, traders have bid Japanese government bond futures to record highs this week.
 But some economists here doubt that the Fed's decision to lower rates a quarter-point will have any impact on the Japanese bank, and the bank's governor, Masaru Hayami, has certainly made every effort to squelch the notion that the board will move this week. 
 "I think the chances that they ease monetary policy are not very high," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo.
Nonetheless, the bank is being prodded by a steady stream of grim data emerging from the Japanese economy. The bank's own influential Tankan survey of business conditions, to be reported on Monday, is likely to reinforce the trend. And Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's plans to radically overhaul the banking system, government budget allocations and a variety of other programs are putting pressure on the central bank even before any have become law because they would probably increase unemployment. 
The bank is trying to resist the pressure. Mr. Hayami recently compared Japan's economy to a potted plant drowning in too much water (a reference to liquidity) but lacking adequate sunshine and fertilizer (meaning structural and regulatory reform). The Bank of Japan maintains a huge pool of money for banks to draw on for lending, but banks are wary of making loans, and borrowers are trying to reduce their debts.
At a meeting last week, the government's Council on Economic and Fiscal Reform unveiled a blueprint for Mr. Koizumi's promised reforms, including a polite plea to the bank to do its part to help set the economy back on its feet.
Mr. Hayami reacted tartly. "On Page 6 of the guidelines it says, 'we expect flexible, quantitative easing' -- but deciding monetary policy is the responsibility for the Bank of Japan's policy board members," Mr. Hayami said, according to minutes of the meeting.
The bank is loath to loosen too much, lest it relieve the pressure on other policy makers to take the painful steps needed to revive the sagging economy. "There are a lot of metaphors for this these days, but I prefer a medical one," Mr. Feldman said. "A transfusion is not enough, surgery is not enough -- you have to have them both together. In this case, monetary policy will make the patient look better for a while, but it won't cure him."
None of the council's guidelines have been translated into concrete legislation, and many gaps remain. For instance, the guidelines call for the tax-financed agency that will buy bad loans from Japanese banks to try to recover the full loan amounts based on a debtor's potential for recovery. But they say nothing of what the corporation should do with debtors that are beyond saving.
"This is a dog that didn't bark," Mr. Feldman said of the guidelines, "and now investors want to know if it has teeth."
Two other factors argue against a move, at least this week.
One is the timing of the release of the Tankan index next Monday. Policy board members do not get the data in advance, and the bank goes to extensive lengths to keep the figures secure, locking the officials who collate it in a room starting at 3 a.m. to prepare the data for release at 8:30 a.m. The board would be unlikely to undermine such precautions by moving just beforehand.
The other is Mr. Koizumi's trip to the United States, his first, to meet President Bush on Saturday. A move before then could be construed as an attempt to curry American favor for the visit, which would be politically unpalatable domestically. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A New Ethanol Bill 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Ethanol Plan Fails to Reduce Use of Gasoline" (front page, June 21): While many of us are disappointed that the flexible fuel program has not yet realized its full potential, now is not the time to abandon it. 
 I have joined with Senators Tom Daschle and Richard G. Lugar on legislation requiring that a small but growing portion of the nation's fuel include renewable fuels like ethanol or biodiesel. 
Our legislation would create a sustainable environment for private investment in new ethanol production and distribution. The production and use of ethanol would more than triple over the next decade. Americans would benefit from substantial reductions in costly oil imports, reduced hydrocarbon emissions and a revitalized rural economy. 
It is time that Americans decreased dependency on costly imported petroleum, put economic strategies into effect to reduce greenhouse gases, and expanded alternative markets for our farmers and ranchers.

E. BENJAMIN NELSON
U.S. Senator from Nebraska
Omaha, June 26, 2001

HEADLINE: Fujimori Is Wined and Dined by Tokyo's Powerful 

BYLINE:  By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 27 

 BODY:
Not long ago, Dr. Torao Tokuda, a wealthy member of Parliament, invited about 15 of his colleagues to an exclusive Tokyo restaurant with geishas, promising that they would meet a "very intriguing" person.
 When the legislators arrived, they encountered the outspoken, nationalist governor of Tokyo, Shintaro Ishihara, who they assumed was the man they had come to meet. 
 But he was not, and as the drinking got under way, in walked the real guest of honor, a new resident of Japan who has become the darling of the wealthy, nationalistic political set of a country desperately in search of heroes these days: the former president of Peru, Alberto K. Fujimori.
Mr. Fujimori, who fled to Japan in November after revelations of rampant corruption and abuse of power in his government, may be widely despised in Peru, where the Congress has declared him "morally unfit" to govern, but he is as popular as ever here. 
And while his former spy chief was picked up in Venezuela this week and sent home for trial, Mr. Fujimori has been living here in comfort -- his expenses reportedly paid by Dr. Tokuda -- and he remains well protected by a secure web of political connections.
Several Japanese lawmakers who attended the gathering, which took place in February at the Fukudaya restaurant, said Dr. Tokuda had toasted Mr. Fujimori, saying the occasion was intended to form a support group for the deposed leader.
The legislators, who asked that they not be identified, said Governor Ishihara, too, gave a speech praising Mr. Fujimori as a "splendid individual" who he said was the victim of a diabolical scheme by the United States to unseat him.
"Japan has a responsibility to protect Mr. Fujimori, a son of Japanese immigrants, who was the first person of Japanese descent to lead a foreign country," the politicians recalled Mr. Ishihara saying.
The arrest and extradition this week of the man who at one time was Mr. Fujimori's most trusted aide, Vladimiro Montesinos, has placed new pressure on Japan to hand over Mr. Fujimori for trial, with Peru calling its ambassador home on Wednesday for consultations.
Mr. Montesinos, who used to collaborate closely with the Central Intelligence Agency, is facing myriad charges, including trafficking in arms and drugs, laundering money, directing death squad activities and rigging Mr. Fujimori's re-election last year. If convicted, Mr. Montesinos could spend the rest of his life in prison. Prosecutors have said they expect him to implicate Mr. Fujimori in an effort to gain a lighter sentence, and Peruvian officials are hoping that Mr. Montesinos will disclose the full extent of the Fujimori government's corruption.
But the Japanese government repeated this week that it would deny any request to send the former president back to Peru. 
Japan, which does not usually extradite its citizens, says it considers Mr. Fujimori a Japanese citizen because his name was entered in a family register in Japan after his birth, which Mr. Fujimori has always asserted was in Peru soon after his parents moved there. Birth in Japan would have made him ineligible to be Peru's president.
Moreover, Japan has no extradition treaty with Peru.
So now, not only is Mr. Fujimori secure in his new life in Japan, but he has also become something of a hero for what is proudly regarded as his decisive leadership of Peru. Over the course of his decade in power, Mr. Fujimori, who was often ready to back up his will with force, rejuvenated a deeply troubled economy and crushed two leftist insurgencies.
He is also greatly admired for his daring rescue of hostages seized by one of the insurgent groups at the Japanese diplomatic residence in Lima in 1997 by ordering military commandos to storm the residence.
"I am proud of former President Fujimori," said a Parliament member who attended the February gathering, "because he achieved something no other Japanese has ever done and may never do again. I am not in a position to judge whether his government was corrupt, but I have a feeling of strong sympathy for him that if he returns to Peru he will be in danger."
John Nathan, a professor of Japanese culture at the University of California at Santa Barbara, said that for many Japanese, especially "this group of wealthy, patriotic, nationalistic men who support him, Fujimori is kind of a folk hero, a source of considerable pride, at a time when Japan is searching its own identity."
"Fujimori is a refugee who fled Peru under questionable circumstances," said Mr. Nathan, who travels frequently to Japan, "but when he walks into a room in Japan, you can feel the excitement. There is a buzz. They see in Mr. Fujimori the type of strong leader Japan has long desired."
Some political analysts attribute Japan's infatuation with Mr. Fujimori partly to the fact that many Japanese know very little about the charges of corruption and abuses that have been levied against his government.
"There's been little reported in Japan about the dark side of Mr. Fujimori's government," said Kei ichi Tsunekawa, professor of Latin American politics at the University of Tokyo, "and people here don't have enough information to properly gauge him."
Mr. Fujimori owes much of his popularity here to his rescue of the hostages in 1997. At the time, Peruvians and foreign governments had nothing but praise for Mr. Fujimori for carrying out the raid with so few casualties among the hostages and rescuers.
But Hidetaka Ogura, a former Japanese hostage who was freed in the raid, said in a recent interview that the hostage crisis could have been resolved peacefully without force, and he sharply criticized Mr. Fujimori and the Peruvian military for executing guerrilla hostage takers who he said had tried to surrender.
Mr. Ogura, who worked for the Japanese Embassy in Peru and often translated for Japanese politicians who went to visit Mr. Fujimori, described the former president as an "emperor without clothes" who was heavily dependent on his aides.
"I think Fujimori should go back to Peru and explain to the people exactly what happened during his rule," Mr. Ogura said. "That's the responsible, Japanese thing to do."
But no one expects Mr. Fujimori to return to his birthplace anytime soon, if ever.
Mr. Fujimori, who did not respond to numerous requests by telephone and letter for an interview, has said in the past that he plans to remain in Japan for an indefinite period.
People close to the former president say he passes his days mainly in solitude in a luxury apartment here writing his memoirs and learning to adapt to life as a regular citizen.
Several members of Parliament, who met Mr. Fujimori at the February reception, said Dr. Tokuda, who owns a chain of 170 hospitals in Japan, has been paying Mr. Fujimori's living expenses.
Dr. Tokuda and Mr. Ishihara, the governor, both declined requests for interviews. The lawmakers said that they were not necessarily supporters of Mr. Fujimori and that they had attended the reception because Dr. Tokuda had been a major contributor to their political campaigns.
The legislators said they had been surprised when Mr. Fujimori made a speech in fluent Japanese at the reception and later confessed that he had in the past pretended not to understand Japanese in order "to hear what people really think." 
They said the bill for the evening was about two million yen, or roughly $17,000, which Dr. Tokuda paid.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Fed Cuts Interest Rates In 6th Reduction This Year
The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point and signaled that its campaign to revive the economy might be entering its final stages.
 The rate cut was the sixth this year. In holding to a quarter-point reduction, the Fed suggested that it wanted to slow the pace of its response to the downturn while it waits to see the full effect of its earlier steps. Page A1. 

Some economists in Japan doubt that the Fed's decision will have any effect on Japan's interest rates. World Business, Section W.

Schering-Plough President Quits
Schering-Plough, which has had repeated quality-control problems at its factories, said that its president and chief operating officer was resigning. Raul E. Cesan, 53, will step down on July 15. Mr. Cesan, who will also leave the board, has been responsible for manufacturing operations since 1994. Shares of Schering-Plough fell $1.67, to $36.98. C4.

More Job Cuts at Lucent and JDS
Lucent Technologies and JDS Uniphase plan even more job cuts than previously announced, heightening concern over weakness in the telecommunications industry. C4.

Tyson and IBP Recommit to Merger
Tyson Foods and IBP announced that they had settled their differences and recommitted themselves to a $2.7 billion merger. C6.

Stocks End Mixed After Fed Move
Blue-chip stocks fell modestly, while technology shares edged up after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 37.64 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,434.84, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.69 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,211.07. The Nasdaq composite index rose 10.12 points, or 0.5 percent, to 2,074.74. C9.

Japan Warns U.S. About Policies
Japanese officials have warned the Bush administration that some of the president's plans are likely to worsen Japan's economic troubles over the next few years, with potentially major effects on the American economy. A7.

WebMD Executive Moving to AOL
Patricia Fili-Krushel, who stepped down as president of the ABC television network in April 2000 to become chief executive of WebMD's consumer Internet operation, will become executive vice president for human resources at AOL Time Warner. WebMD said that Roger Holstein, an executive vice president, would succeed Ms. Fili-Krushel. C4.

Saudis Open Gas Fields to Foreigners
Saudi Arabia radically reshaped its energy industry this month, opening potentially vast natural gas fields to foreign oil companies in an effort to jolt awake an economy that fails to provide enough jobs for the kingdom's booming population. World Business, Section W.

Refineries May Avoid Blackouts
California oil refineries are expected to be granted an exemption from possible power shutdowns under a plan that the state's Public Utilities Commission will vote on today. C8.

Profit Rises 34% at General Mills
General Mills' fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 34 percent, buoyed by a gain from an insurance settlement and new products. C2.

Internet Directory Trims Its Ranks
The British Internet directory service Scoot .com said that its top executives would quit and that it would cut 285 jobs as it struggles to survive. World Business, Section W.

19th-Century Opposition to Merger
The European Union's recent recommendation to block the proposed $45 billion merger of General Electric and Honeywell International was based, in part, on an analysis by a 19th-century French economist whose book is still cited for its astute analysis of competition. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

Fallon Layoffs In Minneapolis

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
The Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, is making its first layoffs ever, dismissing about 30 employees, or 6 percent of its staff of 500. 
 "It was a last resort," said Julie Thompson, a spokeswoman at Fallon. "We held off as long as we could." 
 She attributed the layoffs to the economic slowdown, cutbacks in ad spending by clients and a decision by the AT&T Wireless division of AT&T to drop Fallon from the finalists in a review for its account, with billings estimated at $400 million.
Fallon had previously laid off 10 employees at its New York office, or about 10 percent of the staff.

HEADLINE: Wrong Signal on Money Laundering 

 BODY:
If Americans doubted the extent to which the country's banking system is being used to launder the profits of global criminals, they received fresh evidence this week with the arrest of the former Peruvian spy chief, Vladimiro Montesinos. His hiding place in Venezuela reportedly was exposed when he sent an emissary to Miami to withdraw $38 million he had sequestered in various American bank accounts. But now the Bush administration seems intent on weakening a worldwide campaign to clamp down on money laundering. If it does, coordinated global efforts to combat narcotics trafficking, arms smuggling, terrorism and other forms of organized crime will suffer a serious setback. 
 Ever since the first Bush administration, the United States has been a leader in international efforts to crack down on money laundering -- the main device by which criminals profit from and finance their activities. Among the most important weapons are longstanding rules that require banks to report any suspicious transactions to the government, as well as cash deposits over $10,000 -- a figure that Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill might raise to $25,000. The requirement that banks report suspicious activities has been an especially effective deterrent to money launderers and a valuable evidentiary tool for prosecutors. Mr. O'Neill, however, says that these and other laws impose "significant cost on society," an apparent reference to the paperwork required of banks. He has also questioned the value of the $700 million the government spends annually to fight laundering. 
 Rigorous scrutiny of costs and benefits is certainly appropriate, but it must also take into account costs imposed on society by organized crime. These include everything from drug addiction to human smuggling, arms trafficking and official corruption. Over the years, money laundering has also helped destabilize entire financial systems, most recently in Asia and Russia. 
Mr. O'Neill's decision to reassess broadly accepted rules has sent an alarming signal to America's law enforcement community as well as to the nation's allies even as Washington continues to join them in pressuring nations like Russia and the Philippines to adopt the same kinds of rules. The Treasury secretary's review is partly a response to the wishes of some in the financial industry, a generous contributor to George W. Bush's presidential campaign. A loose coalition of banks, privacy and free-market advocates helped persuade Mr. O'Neill a month ago to weaken a three-year effort by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to crack down on offshore tax havens. They also helped to block legislation last year that would have expanded rules that require banks to find out more about individuals and foreign jurisdictions they are dealing with.
The legislation won bipartisan support, but was blocked by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a foe of government regulation and a friend of Texas banks, which fear losing business with Mexican banks. Republicans cannot claim to be tough on crime as long as they continue to sabotage domestic and international efforts to prevent criminals from laundering their profits.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Incumbency And the Face Of the State

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
ONCE again, the great State of New York leads the way. We've devised the ultimate in the public financing of political campaigns. Only officeholders need apply. 
 Used to be, governors were content to stamp their names on a few billboards and buildings. Now they are television and radio celebrities. And the taxpayers pay the bills, for the privilege of seeing idyllic images of their top public servant in forests, glens and dells, and on river banks and the occasional battlefield. 
 We refer to the unavoidable George E. Pataki, who is so electronically ubiquitous that the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, has scheduled an audit of state advertising spending. Mr. McCall, who wants to be the Democrat to challenge Mr. Pataki next year, will not discuss his audit, but its purpose is clear: to determine what portion of the advertising budgets of 10 state agencies and public authorities go to commercials starring the governor.
The audit, reported Monday in The New York Post, is not likely to uncover any surprises, since even a casual TV viewer has to have seen Pataki ads over the last two years. They include seemingly everything that is good or could be interpreted as good in the state: tourism, children's health care, immunization, the environment, conservation, scholarships, housing loans, even baseball. To name a few.
In May 2000, a New York Times article estimated that the ads were costing taxpayers about $20 million. Mr. McCall's audit, which is to begin in two weeks, will presumably update the figure.
It's not only commercials. The governor has also proven effective at getting on television news programs, as he did traveling to Puerto Rico on the public dollar to protest the Navy's bombing exercises on Vieques -- a matter critical to the Puerto Rican community in New York, and the Puerto Rican voter next year, when Mr. Pataki will be running against the winner of the Democratic primary. 
That will likely be either Mr. McCall or Andrew M. Cuomo, in whom Mr. Pataki may have met his match. As Bill Clinton's secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Mr. Cuomo did an impressive job of building up his name at public expense, too. 
He made trips around the country and the world, and mailed out thousands of copies of shiny reports filled with photos of Mr. Cuomo (often posing with political and show business celebrities). Mr. Cuomo argues that issuing reports is standard in Washington, though the Bush administration apparently did not think so; it thwarted distribution of Mr. Cuomo's final report.
"He had a wonderful spin machine at HUD," said the governor's spokesman, Michael McKeon, almost sounding impressed.
Talk of a straight line. What about Mr. Pataki's spin machine, Mr. McKeon was asked. "We think people appreciate the fact that the governor is aggressively working to make sure children get health insurance, promote the environment and conservation, economic growth," he said. Dismissing the McCall audit as politically motivated, Mr. McKeon said New Yorkers valued the governor's television exertions: "People see that as part of the governor's job."
NOT all people. In fact, as an assemblyman in 1990, Mr. Pataki voted to ban the use of public money for any ads that featured statewide elected officials, who at the time included the man he later defeated and whose son wants to unseat him, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
"It's not party, it's incumbency," said Gene Russianoff, the senior lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group. "Once they have access, they can't resist. It's an irresistible impulse to use taxpayer money to promote themselves."
Three years ago, the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, sponsored a measure prohibiting public officials from appearing in city-financed ads during their election year. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, criticized for making such ads in his re-election year, signed it. 
A law like the city's wouldn't stop the Pataki ads from appearing now, a year before his campaign, though a state measure could be written to be more restrictive than the city's. A state version is stalled, though. This time, with a Republican as governor, the Democrats want a law limiting the taxpayer-financed ads, while the Republicans don't.
Given Mr. Russianoff's rule -- "it's not party, it's incumbency" -- don't count on a change. 
Not in New York, where politicians know better than anywhere else how to protect their own.

HEADLINE: At Center of Senate Battle, a Lawyer and a Doctor 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27 

 BODY:
Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, says his 20 years as a trial lawyer left him with an unshakeable belief that "regular folks" deserve a level playing field in fights with corporate giants like health maintenance organizations and insurance companies. And the belief that insurance companies, in the end, respond to the bottom line.
 Not surprisingly, Mr. Edwards has emerged as a leading champion of giving patients a broader right to sue their H.M.O.'s, the most volatile issue in the patients' rights legislation now under debate in the Senate. 
 Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, says his years as a heart surgeon left him with the belief that managed care has hurt the doctor-patient relationship with "haggling, bureaucratic intervention, loss of control at the local level of decision-making." But he also firmly believes that more litigation is not the way to solve it. He is a co-sponsor of a rival patients' rights bill that proposes a more restricted right to sue. 
The two men, and their very different views, are at the center of the debate over what rights should be guaranteed to Americans with health insurance, given the rise of managed care companies and their greater role in determining what treatments and services will be covered. It is a debate that, while often arcane, has to do with the fundamental changes in American health care over the past 10 years, and how best to adjust the balance of power that, both Mr. Edwards and Mr. Frist seem to agree, has tilted away from the doctors and patients and too far toward the insurers.
There is broad agreement on many of the patient guarantees in the bill now being debated, which is co-sponsored by Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, John McCain of Arizona and Mr. Edwards, and which has the support of most Democrats, consumer and patient groups and the American Medical Association. Those guarantees include guaranteed access to the closest emergency room and the use of an obstetrician-gynecologist without going through a gatekeeper.
The real sticking point, the issue that bitterly divides the Frist and the Edwards camps, is liability.
While a bipartisan compromise was reached today that would shield most employers from lawsuits, which Republicans considered a major problem with the original legislation, the basic divisions remain: Under what circumstances can patients sue their health plans, which are now largely protected from lawsuits? In which courts? For what kind of damages, and for how much? 
The Democratic bill would allow suits in federal courts and in state courts, where damages are often higher. It would allow patients to recover up to $5 million in civil penalties in federal court, but sets no limits on damages for economic loss or pain and suffering. Patients could recover damages in state courts up to the limits set by state law.
Critics assert it would open the floodgates for costly lawsuits that would drive up the cost of health insurance and reduce the number of Americans with coverage; the greedy trial lawyer has become their favorite target.
Defenders assert that the bill's right to sue is a basic remedy that, while little-used, will go far toward keeping H.M.O.'s in line. They note that states that have enacted patients' rights bills have not experienced a great surge in lawsuits.
"We just want to let regular folks have more control over their lives, over their own health care and their own decision making," said Mr. Edwards, who won his Senate seat -- his first elective office -- in 1998, but quickly became a star in a party that needs them. "This debate is not about lawyers, period."
Still, the patients' rights bill is a cause tailor-made for Mr. Edwards, a 48-year-old former plaintiffs lawyer, whose small firm in Raleigh gained renown for victories in personal-injury cases like that of a girl severely injured by a malfunctioning pool drain and malpractice cases involving newborns injured at birth. A trade journal, North Carolina Lawyers Weekly, estimated in 1998 that Mr. Edwards's firm handled more than 60 settlements or verdicts in the 1990's, amounting to at least $150 million in damages.
"He dominated our 'large verdict' list as long as he was practicing law," said Mike Dayton, editor of the legal journal.
Mr. Edwards also ended up an affluent man, who used some of his fortune in his Senate campaign..
Mr. Edwards said his firm dealt only once, to his knowledge, with a case involving a health plan's denial of care: a boy with cerebral palsy, whose doctors urged regular therapy to prevent further problems. "The only one who disagreed was his insurance company," he said. 
Mr. Edwards said he had regularly confronted other kinds of insurance companies in his work.
"The reality is, in most of those cases, the people you're dealing with are insurance companies," he said. "I know the way they function. They function on the bottom line. That's all they care about. And they respond when they feel legally they have a responsibility. Otherwise, they don't."
As for the dangers of runaway juries, Mr. Edwards replies, "If you don't trust juries, you shouldn't trust voters. They're the same people."
Mr. Edwards dismisses the idea that having a former trial lawyer involved in writing this bill amounts to any conflict of interest. "I'm not a lawyer any more," he says.
Senator Frist, 49, brings a very different set of experiences to the debate. As a surgeon specializing in heart and lung transplants, he watched the transformation of medicine from managed care.
"I would have a bureaucrat call me from 500 miles away and basically say, You are going to keep this patient beyond what is acceptable to us and therefore you need to write a letter and explain why," he said.
"I've seen the pendulum swing," he said, from no managed care to "coordination of care, in theory, but ultimately just looking at the bottom line."
But Mr. Frist, who no longer practices heart surgery but does medical mission and volunteer work, said he had also seen what litigation had done to doctors.
"It results in defensive medicine, getting more tests than necessary, changing the practice of medicine toward more paperwork," he said. "Why would you take that system and impose it on any other aspect of life?"
The senator from Tennessee comes from a prosperous medical family; his father and brother helped found what became Columbia/HCA, the huge hospital company. Mr. Frist said all of his holdings were in a blind trust, although he has occasionally been painted, by political opponents, as too sympathetic toward the health care industry.
Mr. Frist, who said he had never been sued, said his solution would be "very strong and responsive" review procedures to handle disputes between patients and their health plans, and a limited right to sue in federal court if the health plan fails to comply with the reviewer's decision.
Critics assert that his appeals procedures fall far short of what is in the McCain-Edwards-Kennedy bill. And Mr. Frist's position also puts him at odds with his colleagues at the A.M.A.
He said he still tried to keep his hand in the practice of medicine, as a reality check. He hopes to go to Africa next week, on a medical mission -- if the Senate finishes its work.

HEADLINE: Tense Macedonia 

 BODY:
The ethnic tensions that violently tore apart Yugoslavia, leaving hundreds of thousands of civilians dead and millions displaced from their homes, are now afflicting Macedonia, a landlocked Balkan republic that broke away from the old Yugoslavia in 1991. About two-thirds of Macedonia's two million people are Slavs, and most of the rest are ethnic Albanians. After a decade of tension between the two groups, and four months of sporadic violence initiated by ethnic Albanian guerrillas there, Macedonia is now teetering between political compromise and all-out warfare. 
 European diplomats are urgently pleading with the country's political leaders, particularly President Boris Trajkvoski, a moderate, to choose the path of compromise. Their efforts deserve strong American support. President Bush took a helpful step yesterday by banning fund-raising for the Albanian guerrillas in the United States. 
 For most of the 1990's, while Serbia and former Yugoslav republics like Bosnia and Croatia suffered through war and dictatorship, Macedonia seemed a relative oasis of democracy and ethnic coexistence. But beneath the surface there were points of friction. The Slavic majority dominates political life and government institutions, including the police. Language in the Constitution seems to define non-Slavs as second-class citizens. Ethnic Albanians also feel slighted culturally. Albanian is not officially recognized as a national language, and there are no accredited Albanian-language universities. 
The right place to redress these grievances is in the political arena, not the battlefield. Ethnic Albanian political parties have joined a broad coalition cabinet where they are pressing their Slavic partners to agree to carry out needed reforms. Doing so could drain support from the guerrillas, who still represent a relatively small group within the ethnic Albanian community. But real power within the government coalition remains with Slavic ministers who oppose compromise. 
With elections due early next year, and with many Slavic voters angry over guerrilla attacks and opposed to ethnic Albanian political demands, Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and other cabinet ministers are resisting reforms and looking to crush the guerrillas by force alone. But their tactics, including army shelling of the Albanians' villages and a wave of arrests and disappearances of Albanian community leaders, are dangerously fueling ethnic resentments and making political coexistence more difficult. 
The European Union's chief diplomat, Javier Solana, is working hard to persuade Macedonian leaders to agree to a full cease-fire and constitutional changes. The E.U. has also sent Francois Leotard, a former French defense minister, to serve as its special envoy in Macedonia. But not much more time may be left to work out a peaceful solution. Meanwhile, NATO has agreed to help disarm Albanian guerrillas should a firm cease-fire be reached. 
That kind of non-combat role would be appropriate and useful, as was Monday's impromptu escort of guerrillas out of a battle zone by American troops to reinforce a local cease-fire. NATO can help secure a peace agreement if one is reached, but first Macedonia's leaders must act responsibly to spare their country the agony of another Balkan war.

HEADLINE: Pentagon to Ask For Retirement Of MX Missiles 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27 

 BODY:
The Pentagon will ask Congress for permission to begin scrapping all 50 of its nuclear-tipped MX missiles as a possible first step toward a unilateral reduction in the nation's nuclear arsenal, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld announced today.
 The missiles with their multiple warheads and ability to decimate Russian missile silos, were a signature program of President Ronald Reagan, whose administration fought acrimonious battles with Congressional Democrats over the size of the program and the basing of the missile, which it called the Peacekeeper, in the 1980's. 
 But President Bush is, in essence, proposing to dismantle one of Mr. Reagan's legacies in order to advance another of Mr. Reagan's goals: building a system to defend the nation from long-range ballistic missiles. Mr. Bush has said he would be willing to cut "to the lowest possible number" the nation's nuclear arsenal as part of a new strategic "framework" with Russia that included a missile shield. 
The request regarding the MX will be part of the detailed 2002 budget proposal that Mr. Rumsfeld will present to Congress on Thursday. That plan will ask for an $18.4 billion increase over the $310 billion defense budget that the president proposed in February, with most of the additional money going toward health care, higher pay, spare parts and missile defense programs.
In announcing the MX missile proposal today, the Pentagon offered almost no details about how quickly the weapons system would be dismantled, what would happen to the warheads and whether the administration was considering reductions in other nuclear weapons.
Indeed, Mr. Rumsfeld portrayed the proposal purely as a budget issue, saying he had been forced to decide whether to set aside money to maintain the missiles or to retire them before he had time to consider the appropriate size of the nuclear force. Air Force officials say it takes more than $70 million a year to maintain the missiles. The new budget asks for an initial sum of $17 million to begin retiring the weapons system.
Mr. Rumsfeld is overseeing a review of nuclear policy expected to include recommendations on the size of the nuclear force, consisting of missiles, submarines and bombers.
In a news conference today, Mr. Rumsfeld said he was recently told, "You've got the Peacekeeper, there's no money in the budget for the next five years to keep it, there's no money to retire it, and there's a law that says you can't retire it."
But defense officials acknowledged that in making his budget decision to retire the MX, Mr. Rumsfeld had dictated nuclear policy.
"The president has talked about an overall reduction in the nuclear forces, so this is heading in that direction," a senior Air Force officer said.
To retire the MX, the administration must ask Congress to rescind a law enacted during the Clinton administration that prohibits the Pentagon from reducing the nuclear arsenal below the levels set by Start I, with Russia. Congressional Republicans who supported that law said they wanted to review the administration's MX proposal before commenting.
Advocates of arms control, who have been dogged critics of Mr. Bush's missile defense plan, welcomed today's announcement, saying it was a start toward the fulfillment of Mr. Bush's campaign pledge to reduce the nuclear arsenal.
"I was happy to hear it," said John Isaacs, president of the Council for a Livable World, a nonprofit group that promotes lower military spending. "Until I saw it, I couldn't be sure it would happen."
But Mr. Isaacs and other arms control experts said the significance of the proposal would rest in its details, which have yet to be worked out. For instance, it is not clear whether the warheads from the MX missiles -- each missile has as many as 10 warheads -- will also be retired or remounted on other missiles.
Even before the new proposal, the Pentagon had been considering dismantling its MX missiles -- which are based in hardened underground silos at F. E. Warren Air Force Base in Wyoming.
One plan called for remounting the missiles' W-87 warheads on Minuteman missiles scattered around the country and then retiring the older Minuteman warheads. The W-87 warheads are considered more powerful and reliable than most other nuclear weapons.
If all of the 500 MX missile warheads were retired, the American nuclear strategic arsenal would still include 6,700 warheads.
Bruce Blair, a former Minuteman launch control officer who is president of the Center for Defense Information, a Pentagon watchdog group, said Mr. Bush could have had a much greater impact on the debate over missile defense if he had proposed immediately deactivating all 50 MX missiles rather than retiring them over many years.
"It would be a spectacular announcement to say they are taking them all off alert at once," Mr. Blair said.
The MX program was initially approved by the Carter administration as a counter to a new generation of heavy Soviet intercontinental ballistic missiles. But Mr. Reagan championed the weapon, depicting it as a core part of his military buildup, but Congress whittled his request to build 200 missiles to 100, and eventually to 50.
Mr. Rumsfeld's budget proposal will also request a $3 billion increase in spending on missile defense, to $8.3 billion. The request will include restructuring missile defense programs to speed development of technologies that the Bush administration considers promising, including airborne and space-based lasers.
The plan will also call for developing new missile defense test sites in Alaska. Although Pentagon officials said those sites would be used to conduct more realistic flight tests on antimissile technology, they also said the Pentagon would consider declaring them fully operational if a missile attack against the nation seemed imminent.
Mr. Rumsfeld's plan also calls for cutting the nation's fleet of B-1 bombers to about 60, from 93, and for converting two Ohio-class submarines to carry conventional weapons instead of nuclear missiles.
After being adjusted for inflation, Mr. Rumsfeld's plan would represent a 7 percent, or $33 billion, increase over President Bill Clinton's final defense budget of $296 billion, making it the largest Pentagon increase since the Reagan years.
Despite that, some senior defense officials and their supporters in Congress have said the increase is too small. At the same time, fiscal conservatives in Congress have expressed strong skepticism about the size of the Pentagon request.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
No Fed Magic for Poor Corporate Earnings

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
When the Federal Reserve cut interest rates six months ago, investors stampeded into stocks, certain that lower rates would mean higher share prices. Yesterday, the Fed cut rates again -- by one-quarter of a point -- and investors simply yawned.
 The gulf between the two reactions shows what months of bad corporate earnings news can do to the normally buoyant mood of stock market investors. Now painfully aware that the Fed's moves do not translate into an immediate lift in corporate results, investors are taking a wait-and-see approach to stocks. 
 "What the market reaction says to me is that Fed easing is not going to immediately help stocks right now," said Bill Quan, director of research at Fuji Securities in New York. "Fed easing is not going to help companies cut costs or regain pricing power; they have to contend with those issues themselves. What the Fed is doing is keeping the consumer side of the economy afloat while the business sector readjusts for the excesses of the past few years." 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.64 points yesterday, to 10,434.84, while the Nasdaq composite index gained 10.12 points, to 2,074.74.
The muted reaction to the sixth rate cut this year is notable because the major stock gauges are lower than they were when the Fed began the reductions that have taken the Federal funds rate to 3.75 percent from 6.5 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average is 3.25 percent lower than it was when the Fed began easing and the Nasdaq composite is down 16 percent.
Investors seem worried not only that the United States has failed to respond yet to the medicine of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, but also that global weakness may further squeeze corporate profits. With world economies sagging because of the United States slowdown, foreign customers can no longer be expected to bail out American companies. 
In its statement, the Federal Reserve acknowledged that the economy was by no means out of the woods and mentioned slowing overseas growth in its list of woes. Since September, when capital spending on technology peaked, United States exports have plummeted 4.7 percent. 
The opening of borders that has meant so much to global economic growth now threatens to tip the world economy into recession as the engine of that growth -- the United States economy -- slows. Weakness in demand abroad will keep a lid on corporate profits.
Economists at Morgan Stanley expect world trade volumes to rise 4.3 percent in 2001, down considerably from a 12.8 percent increase last year. This will be the steepest decline in growth on record. The biggest previous decline was in 1975.
The problem is that global trade accounts for a growing portion of world gross domestic product. Morgan Stanley estimates that the volume of world trade amounts to about one-quarter of world output, double the share that prevailed in the 1970's. As a result, declines in world trade will reinforce the downtrends in the United States, Japan and Europe.
The Fed can do little to restart global demand for goods. Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, said: "The Fed funds rate at this point is not going to temper global contagion. It's a new dimension to this downturn. Stage 1 was the U.S.; Stage 2 is the world; and Stage 3 is what's happening in the world comes back to hit the U.S." 
The only ray of sunshine on an otherwise gloomy economic scene is the American consumer, who has remained willing to spend recently in spite of the downturn. But economists say that continued large-scale job losses and a stagnant stock market could alter that behavior.
John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investors Service, pointed out that in the first quarter of 2001, the market value of assets held by American households slumped an unheard-of 5.8 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. Not since the 1.4 percent drop that occurred in the third quarter of 1974, during a brutal recession, had the value of household assets declined year over year. The quarter after that decline, consumer spending fell almost 2 percent, Mr. Lonski said.
Most of the decline in household assets can be attributed to skidding stock prices. According to the Fed, the value of stocks and mutual fund shares held by Americans fell $8.7 trillion, or 31.6 percent from the year earlier. The plunge in wealth was partly offset by a 12.1 percent increase in real estate values.
"The Fed realizes that rate cuts may not have an immediate effect in the consumer's pocket," said Elizabeth K. Miller, portfolio manager at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen in New York. "But they are willing to cut to maintain the psychological effect."
Additional layoffs could be another factor damaging consumer confidence. On Tuesday, for example, Merrill Lynch said that declining profits might force it to eliminate more than the 3,300 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, that it has already cut this year. A total of 20,000 Wall Street jobs have been lost in 2001.
"Corporate America is plagued on three fronts," Mr. Lonski said. "The worst corporate profitability in 10 years, a stock market that continues to struggle and a plethora of corporate credit rating downgrades. The rate cut moves us in the right direction, but it's not going to remedy what menaces the U.S. economy immediately." 
In its statement, the Fed made no mention of its future stance on rates, but most economists expect more cuts. "I think ultimately they will have to cut a little more because the easing hasn't translated to easier financial conditions," said Jan Hutzius, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. But assessing the economy will be even trickier for investors in the coming months, Mr. Hutzius said.
"Over the next few months," he said, "a lot of indicators now deeply in the red will look somewhat better. But it will be very hard to distinguish between a normal bounce and a true recovery, and I think that's going to keep the markets on tenterhooks."
