HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Lucent and JDS Uniphase Prepare for More Job Cuts

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Concern over weakness in the telecommunications industry heightened yesterday as two large companies, Lucent Technologies and JDS Uniphase, prepared for additional job cuts.
 Lucent, the telecommunications equipment maker based in Murray Hill, N.J., may cut as many as 10,000 jobs in addition to the 10,000 layoffs announced earlier this year and the buyouts offered to 13,000 midlevel managers, people close to the company said. 
 More details were not available, although people close to Lucent said the reductions would probably take place in weaker parts of the company, like units that sold to small communications companies. 
Kathleen Fitzgerald, a spokeswoman for Lucent, which employs about 100,000 people worldwide, declined to comment on the reductions, which were reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal.
JDS Uniphase, the maker of tiny lasers used to send signals across fiber optic communications networks, expects to extend cuts beyond the 8,000 already announced, said Lori Goulet, a spokeswoman for the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif. JDS, which expects to have 20,000 employees after earlier rounds of cuts are completed, said the extent of the new cuts had not been determined.
The cutbacks at Lucent and JDS Uniphase are part of a shakeout in the communications business after abundant financing in the late 1990's spawned dozens of start-up companies seeking to compete with the industry's giants. That financing dried up last year, pushing several companies into bankruptcy and others to the brink of insolvency.
Problems at these upstarts led sales to decline at large equipment makers like Lucent and Nortel Networks of Canada, and a chain reaction of sorts ensued. Lucent, for instance, is one of the largest buyers of JDS Uniphase's lasers. Over 100,000 telecommunications industry jobs have been cut this year.
"We're experiencing further downturn in the economic condition of our industry," said Ms. Goulet of JDS Uniphase.
Lucent hopes to cut costs substantially by reducing its work force. Under its buyout program, for example, nearly half of the 13,000 managers eligible for the offers are expected to accept them, people close to the company said. 
Using rough estimates, Lucent could save up to $600 million a year if 6,000 managers, each costing the company about $100,000 a year in salary and benefits, accept the offers. The money for the buyouts will come from Lucent's pension fund, allowing the company to avoid using cash for daily operations.
Separately, Lucent said yesterday that it had won a three-year contract from Sprint PCS to provide as much as $1 billion worth of equipment. Nortel received a similar contract potentially worth $1 billion. 
The contracts, which will enable Sprint to build a so-called third-generation wireless network capable of quickly delivering Internet services to users of mobile devices, are an important victory for the wireless standard known as code division multiple access, which is more common in the United States than in Europe and Asia.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
He's Poor, She's Rich. Made for Each Other!

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
These days, a realistic Hollywood movie about teenagers seems about as likely as a naughty sex farce from Iran. Early on, "Crazy/Beautful," with its gritty, blue-tinged cinematography, its slangy, mumbled dialogue and its fine-grained feel for the neighborhoods of Los Angeles, looks like an exception. With artful economy, John Stockwell, the director, introduces Carlos Nunez (Jay Hernandez) and Nicole Oakley (Kirsten Dunst), classmates at Pacific High School who come, wouldn't you know it, from different worlds.
 Carlos, hard-working and disciplined, wakes up every morning at dawn to travel, by foot and by bus, from his working-class Mexican-American neighborhood to the school, where he is a football star. He hopes to attend the United States Naval Academy and become a pilot. 
 Nicole, meanwhile, is a troubled rich girl who lives, with her congressman-father and evil yuppie stepmother, in an elegant glass-walled aerie in the hills. She and her friend Maddy (Taryn Manning) lead lives of privileged dissipation. Their exuberant recklessness expresses the alienation of the overentitled, and is presented in pointed contrast to Carlos's straight-arrow diligence. 
He and Nicole first meet on Venice Beach, where she is performing court-ordered trash collection after an arrest for driving under the influence and Carlos is enjoying some rare downtime with his friends. What happens next? Let me consult my critic's dictionary of generic plot descriptions. Yes, here it is: opposites attract. Trouble rears its ugly head. Their lives are changed forever.
The story of their sweet and sexy courtship concludes with an obligatory montage of romantic bliss -- driving on the freeway, frolicking on the beach, watching the sun set over the ocean -- after which the inevitable confrontations ensue in the form of impassioned speeches.
To be fair, "Crazy/Beautiful" is not as bad as I'm making it sound. The frustration is that it could be so much better than it is. Ms. Dunst and Mr. Hernandez are both smart actors who come at what could have been cardboard characters from unexpected angles. Driven as he is, Carlos is also naive and sometimes indecisive. And Nicole, underneath her wildness and bad-girl bravado, is not only wounded and angry, but also sensible and decent. Ms. Dunst doesn't look or sound like a teenage movie idol -- her face is wide and a little blotchy, her voice sometimes squeaks at the upper registers -- but she has an emotional range that few actresses of her age can match. 
The problem is that the emotions she portrays with such raw authenticity have been pulled out of the dusty warehouse of melodramatic convention. The movie suggests she is not only angry and misunderstood, but mentally ill as well, and compounds this dubious notion with the even more dubious conceit that the love of a good man and a few truth-telling confrontations will accomplish what pills and therapy cannot.
And though Nicole and Carlos are conceived and acted with refreshing nuance, the people surrounding them have a flat, made-for-television feel that makes the movie schematic and responsible when it should be brave and honest. The other rich kids are a shade too nasty and selfish, and the nobility and hot-temperedness of Carlos's friends and family carry a whiff of the well-meaning liberal condescension that Nicole manages to avoid.
Speaking of well-meaning liberals, Nicole's father, though cannily played by Bruce Davison, is at once too flagrantly hypocritical to be sympathetic and too nice a guy to be an object of satire. 
Smoothed over by a lively and varied soundtrack that includes pop and hip-hop songs in Spanish and English, "Crazy/Beautiful" intersperses its moments of easy, lyrical sensuality and unassuming realism with canned plot points and reheated speeches. It is an enormous improvement over the brainless, patronizing teenage romances that have slouched into (and quickly out of) theaters in recent years. But it could, if the filmmakers had trusted themselves and the actors a bit more, have lived up to its title.
"Crazy/Beautiful" is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has a few sex scenes, some profanity, and implied drug use.

HEADLINE: Actors and Producers Turn Earnest in Talks 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 28 

 BODY:
Negotiators representing actors and producers stepped up the pace of their talks this week with a midnight Saturday deadline for the expiration of their contract.
 But the tone surrounding the talks among the actors' unions -- the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists -- and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers seemed to be more determined than defiant as negotiators have put in long hours since last weekend to hone proposals. Fears of a strike eased last month when the Writers Guild of America reached a $41 million three-year agreement with the producers. 
 Citing a news blackout imposed at the start of negotiations on May 15, representatives from both sides declined to be specific about the status of talks and what will happen at midnight on Saturday if a deal is not reached. 
Among the issues said to dominate the talks are residuals paid for programs shown on cable television, minimum pay for actors, payment for work shown in foreign markets and pay for so-called middle-class actors who are struggling to make a living in smaller television and film roles.
Actors are said to be seeking a 5 percent raise in their minimum rates and an increase of 1.5 percentage points in the license fees they are paid when shows go to cable. That amount is currently 6 percent. Representatives of negotiators declined to discuss figures.
As the deadline approaches so does the outside pressure to reach agreement. Two groups that at the request of Mayor Richard Riordan had issued a report on the economic impact if both writers and actors should strike at the same time reissued the report detailing the impact of a strike by actors only.
The report prepared by the Milken Institute and Sebago Associates predicted that a one-month walkout by actors would cost Los Angeles 21,700 jobs and $1.3 billion to the economy. If such a strike went on three months, the loss would be 54,000 jobs and $3.2 billion, it said.
Production has already slowed. The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees said work was down 50 percent among costumers, makeup artists and hairdressers; 40 percent for set artists and 30 percent among set painters.
One reason is that producers are not "greenlighting anything, fearful that anything can happen," said Thomas Short, president of the alliance, which represents some 50,000 skilled workers in the entertainment industry.
Mr. Short, whose group is monitoring the talks, said he was guardedly optimistic that the groups would reach agreement. He noted that beyond figures showing how a slowdown could affect the industry, the impact of the nearly six-month strike by commercial actors was also an incentive to settle. That strike ended in October, but some work never reappeared.
Mr. Short said the production of commercials was down 30 percent in Los Angeles and 40 percent in New York since that strike. "That shows you," he said, "what can happen to an industry."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Harlem Co-op Has a Financing Twist

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The first tenants will begin moving next week into the Renaissance, a 240-apartment co-op in central Harlem that was developed with an unusual financing method intended to make the apartments affordable to people with moderate incomes. 
 Buyers for the one- to three-bedroom apartments were chosen by lottery from 3,500 applicants. The apartments, with 675 to 1,100 square feet of space, are on the upper floors of the residential-commercial project on the east side of Lenox Avenue from 116th to 117th Streets. 
 There are 60,000 square feet of retail space on the ground floor of the $60 million building, which rises to 11 stories on the avenue and steps down to 8 stories and 6 stories on the side streets. 
It was developed, using public and private funds, by Suna/Levine Industries of Douglaston, N.Y., which is headed by Stuart Match Suna and Jeffrey E. Levine. The Malcolm Shabazz Mosque, across 117th Street from the Renaissance, is the apartment building's nonprofit sponsor.
Since sales began 10 months ago, 225 units have been sold to people with annual incomes ranging from $31,000 to $147,750, per apartment. Apartment buyers must put up $4,533 to $15,393 in cash, depending on the size and location of the apartments. Buyers then owe a proportionate share of the building's underlying mortgage, ranging from $113,000 to $381,831. Buyers pay the balance of the purchase price as part of their monthly fees, which include maintenance, and range from $794 to $2,696. Interest paid on the mortgage is tax-deductible. 
Mr. Levine said that to help quell community concerns over gentrification, half the units were being sold to buyers from Harlem. The developer, whose firm is based in Queens, added that many buyers were drawn to the project because of its low cash prices. 
That was the case for Sean G. Barrow, a 35-year-old accountant for a Wall Street investment firm. He is trading his one-bedroom rental on 104th Street and Manhattan Avenue for a three-bedroom unit at the Renaissance. Mr. Barrow said he is also betting on Harlem's future, "because there are no other areas left in Manhattan to develop." 
Prices for the apartments have been kept low in part by having individual buyers take advantage of the below-market rate for the buildingwide mortgage, and in part by property-tax abatements. The building's $46.3 million mortgage, primarily from the New York City Housing Development Corporation, carries a 6.65 percent interest rate. Property taxes have been waived for 21 years, and will then be phased in. 
The monthly payment would be $900 for an 850-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment with a down payment of $5,138 and a proportionate share of the underlying mortgage of $129,000. That covers taxes, operating expenses and the payment on the underlying mortgage.
Using this financing method, buyers do not need to secure separate mortgages for their apartments, on which the interest rate would have been significantly higher. Buyers who sell their units at a profit must split the profits with the city, which will use the proceeds to reduce the underlying mortgage.
The Renaissance was developed under the city's Anchor Program, which is aimed at spurring retail growth in areas where the city invested heavily in housing. Its sponsors include the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the New York City Housing Partnership.
"It is the first significant activity along 116th Street for some time and we expect it to be a catalyst for other development," said Jerilyn Perine, commissioner of the city's housing preservation department.
Of the 11 other Anchor projects, 3 more will be in Harlem and produce 647 condominium apartments and 174,000 square feet of retail space. The next is to start this summer on Fifth Avenue between 115th and 116th Streets and will have 25,000 square feet of stores and 128 condos.
The Renaissance's success "has made it significantly less difficult for developers to obtain financing for other multifamily housing initiatives in Harlem," said Charles A. Brass, executive vice president of the Housing Development Corporation.
He cited two co-op projects in central Harlem, totaling 203 units, which his agency recently agreed to finance. They are part of 3,000 rental and homeowner housing units planned in Harlem by the city over the next two to three years. 
The Renaissance, designed by Greenberg Farrow Architecture of Manhattan, has amenities like a laundry room and a landscaped courtyard. The retail space has been leased to eight tenants, including a 20,000-square-foot supermarket. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Renaissance, which has apartments geared to people with moderate incomes, will welcome its first tenants next week in central Harlem. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Markets Rally on Hopes for Higher Corporate Earnings

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks rallied yesterday on brighter hopes for corporate earnings, a day after the Federal Reserve made its sixth cut in interest rates this year.
 Technology stocks led the market higher, and Microsoft gained more than 2 percent. A federal appeals court reversed a judge's order to split Microsoft into two companies, although the court upheld the judge's findings that the company had violated antitrust law. 
 "The big part of the rally today has more to do with the tech world than it does with anything else," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management. "If you get a positive day in tech, it sort of wags the whole equities dog and you get a lot of people who are willing to sort of ride with it."
The technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index gained 50.72 points, or 2.44 percent, to close at 2,125.46.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which includes Microsoft among its 30 components, rose 131.37 points, or 1.26 percent, to 10,566.21. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 15.13 points, or 1.25 percent, to 1,226.20.
The Federal Reserve cut short-term rates by a quarter of a percentage point on Wednesday. Many investors and analysts had hoped the Fed would cut rates by half a point as it had five times this year. After a muted reaction to the smaller cut on Wednesday, investors seemed more enthusiastic yesterday, behavior similar to that after the rate cut on May 15.
Analysts said investors now wanted to see a payoff in strengthening corporate profits from the Fed's monetary policy.
"We're at a point now where investors shrug off rate reductions," said Owen Fitzpatrick, head of United States equities at Bankers Trust Private Banking. "They want to see companies come clean and basically throw in everything from this quarter."
He added, "What we want to see is stability."
Still, analysts said the Fed's action and the Microsoft ruling convinced some investors that stock prices might soon turn higher. 
Trading in Microsoft was halted nearly three hours after the court ruling was released, but resumed shortly before 3 p.m. The shares rose $1.60, to $72.74, and traded as high as $76.15. In their haste to take profits on Microsoft, investors overwhelmed two Nasdaq trading systems, shutting them down for over 15 minutes.
Investors also welcomed data from the Labor Department showing that first-time unemployment claims dropped for a third week. Claims fell 16,000, to 388,000, the lowest number since May.
Mixed signals persist about the overall health of the economy. Companies continued to issue profit warnings and layoffs. DaimlerChrysler said it would cut 1,120 jobs at four plants because of continuing weakness in the truck market. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Bonds fell yesterday after a decline in weekly jobless claims suggested interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year had started to spur economic growth.
"With the economy expected to recover, we're at the tail end of Fed rate cuts," said Eric Cheung, who helps manage $8 billion at the Wilmington Trust Corporation.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note fell 22/32, to 97 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.33 percent from 5.23 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond fell 22/32, to 95 26/32. Its yield rose to 5.67 percent from 5.62 percent.

HEADLINE: Kofi Annan: An Idealist Who Took the Heat, Shook Up the U.N. and Keeps Top Post 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 28 

 BODY:
Kofi Annan became the seventh United Nations secretary general at the worst of times. The organization was bankrupt, at war with the United States Congress and ridiculed for peacekeeping fiascoes on several continents. The Clinton administration had just driven Mr. Annan's predecessor from office in an unusual display of pressure that still rankles through the Secretariat and the diplomatic corps.
 On Friday, still six months' shy of the end of his first five-year term, Mr. Annan, the quiet Ghanaian who took charge with a decisiveness few had predicted and changed the organization from the inside out, will be given a second term by acclamation in the 189-member General Assembly. No nation thought twice about other candidates; he was considered unbeatable. The race was over before it began. 
 In the last few years, the United Nations has not grown rich, but it has achieved a better budget balance. Relations with Washington have improved dramatically, and searing reports on peacekeeping operations gone wrong -- commissioned by Mr. Annan in full knowledge that he would be criticized as the former head of the peacekeeping department -- have cleared the air and allowed for new thinking on how to tighten up existing missions or create more realistic new ones.
Mr. Annan has also weathered a rising tide of anger against international organizations and protests over globalization, while at the same time opening the doors of the United Nations to cooperation with some of the same corporations reviled on the streets -- and to some of the demonstrators themselves.
"He's been very creative at dealing with these new issues," said James B. Cunningham, the acting American ambassador, "and very adept at getting around ideological barriers and finding creative ways to try to build practical bridges." Mr. Annan has argued that corporations control more money than many countries, and they have to be brought into the mix -- whether in confronting the issue of AIDS, the information technology gap between rich and poor or the problems of the environment.
Mr. Cunningham said today that the Security Council hastened the selection process, which would normally take place near the end of the year, because everyone agreed that Mr. Annan should have as much time as possible to get started on his next term. 
Robert E. Rubin, the former United States Treasury secretary, remembers sizing up Mr. Annan for the first time at a private dinner at the secretary general's residence a few years ago. "I thought he had a very thoughtful and sensible view of the dynamics of the global economy and what needed to happen," Mr. Rubin said today. "He's idealistic, but it wasn't unrealistic." Mr. Annan subsequently asked Mr. Rubin, then out of government, to join a panel to propose ways of dealing with the failed economies of the world's poorest countries.
Mr. Annan, the son of a Ghanaian businessman from a family of chiefs, has worked hard to persuade African leaders to take charge of solving the continent's problems wherever they can, while pressing for more outside aid in helping them battle diseases and economic imbalances. This has not always made him popular in Africa, where the American-educated Mr. Annan is often seen as almost a foreigner, some African diplomats say. The secretary general has degrees from Macalester College in St. Paul and from M.I.T. His wife, Nane, is a Swedish lawyer and artist.
More generally in the developing world, Mr. Annan has been criticized for his strong advocacy of the need for outside intervention when the human rights of people are being abused by their governments. One of his most difficult choices over the next year will be to find a successor to the outspoken Mary Robinson as the organization's high commissioner for human rights. Some governments would prefer to see the position abolished.
Mr. Annan's efforts to reorganize and streamline the management of the organization met with skepticism in the General Assembly, which has also been reluctant to allow Mr. Annan to bolster the peacekeeping department with more independent experts and a greater intelligence-gathering capacity. Some developing nations have also worried that Mr. Annan would sacrifice aid programs in order to make institutional changes demanded mostly by industrial nations. But his introduction of a cabinet-style management team has been widely welcomed, even within the international civil service, which can be resistant to change.
To the surprise of many here and in Washington, the General Accounting Office concluded last year that he had met virtually all Congressional demands for reform that were within his power.
In Washington today, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is now chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called Mr. Annan's re-election "great news." 
"I've known Kofi for many years now, long before he was the secretary general," said Mr. Biden, a frequent visitor to United Nations headquarters. He said Mr. Annan had impressed him with his ability to bridge gaps between the third world and the industrial countries. "My grandpop used to say, 'Every once in a while, history delivers somebody uniquely suited to do a job.' I think that's Kofi." 
With a demeanor of practiced self-control and unfailing courtesy, Mr. Annan rarely raises his soft voice or allows flashes of anger to escape -- though aides say they know when not to question him. At the same time, he has greatly enlarged his circle of advisers, sometimes informally or socially, turning to a range of outsiders who have brought new ideas into an organization that often ran on autopilot under other secretaries general.
William H. Luers, president of the United Nations Association of the United States, the leading citizen-support group for the organization, said that Mr. Annan's ability to "keep cool" had made a difference as he tried to rebuild good relations with Washington, a campaign he undertook against the advice of some of his advisers and a number of governments.
"I think he managed that very difficult number of years without getting upset or hostile," Mr. Luers said today. "He was able to stay above it." Mr. Luers is optimistic about future United Nations-United States relations because Mr. Annan and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell have known each other for years and talk frequently. Mr. Annan has made at least one trip to the Middle East recently at Mr. Powell's request.
"The Powell-Annan relationship is a very hopeful relationship," Mr. Luers said. "Many secretaries of state start off with good relationships with secretary generals and then things come to pass that divide them. I think these two are determined to make it work."
Mr. Luers said the message Mr. Annan had often taken to Capitol Hill or relayed to members of Congress was: "This isn't a world government. This is an organization trying to coordinate the work of everybody who has to work together."

HEADLINE: Harlem Development Program Not Much Help, Critics and Officials Say 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Many Harlem community leaders have cast a skeptical eye on a $250 million federal, state and city program that was meant to bring economic development to their neighborhood, saying it has benefited national retailers but has not helped many local people start their own businesses.
 More recently, this criticism has found support among city and state officials, who are threatening to shut down the small-business lending arm of the program, the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone. In March, they said they would no longer authorize loans that were not already in some stage of approval. 
 On the surface, at least, the numbers tell a depressing story. Since the program began operations in 1995, the small-business unit, known as the Business Resource and Investment Service Center, or Brisc, has made only 38 loans. All together, these loans have amounted to $3 million. But $4.9 million has been spent operating the unit. 
Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington, the chairman of the board that oversees the empowerment zone program, said he was outraged by the ratio of operating costs to loans. "There are so few loans, it's crazy," Mr. Washington said recently. "Just look at the amount of money that's being spent, and then look at the productivity."
People familiar with this type of lending say, however, that weighing operating costs against loans is not a meaningful way to evaluate a program meant for people lacking the qualifications for a bank loan. They say that government officials have underestimated how challenging it is to identify promising businesses in an area in which more than half the population has no high school diploma and the median household income is less than $23,000.
Since 1991, the Regional Economic Development Assistance Corporation has run a similar loan program in Brooklyn. Its business manager, Joan G. Bartolomeo, said most of its applicants have already been rejected by a bank. "It's really, really hard to find clients for the programs," she said. "It seems counterintuitive, but other loan funds have expressed the same frustrations. A lot of time is spent holding hands." She said about 5 percent of the applicants in her program eventually got loans.
Despite all the talk about Harlem's recovery, it is still tough to make a living there. Most of the new retail development has occurred on 125th Street, where rents can be as high as $121 a square foot, well beyond the means of local merchants. Rents elsewhere in Harlem are much lower, but there is far less foot traffic.
In dollars, at least, the small-business unit is just a small portion of the empowerment zone program, which Congress created in 1994. But its problems reflect the pitfalls encountered by the New York program as a whole. Each level of government has veto power, an unwieldy structure that some observers say seems doomed to fail, particularly when opposing political parties are involved.
The attack on the small-business program is also a symptom of the strained relationship between Mr. Washington and Terry C. Lane, the president of the empowerment zone since 1999. Mr. Washington, who tangled with Mr. Lane's predecessor, Deborah C. Wright, said he was even more unhappy with Mr. Lane, whom he accuses of running a sloppy shop (an accusation Mr. Lane denies).
Mr. Lane has not ingratiated himself with either Mr. Washington or state officials. They thought he seemed overly eager to promote himself when he entertained foreign dignitaries like Prince Andrew of Britain and allowed his photograph to appear 16 times in a recent 12-page newsletter.
He also did not get along with William C. Landers, a veteran Citibank executive with a background in small business who was brought in to rescue Brisc in May 1999 after what is generally acknowledged to have been a disastrous start-up. "He was excellent," said Carlton Brown, a member of the Brisc board. "He knew the sorts of challenges you had lending to small businesses."
But Mr. Landers resigned suddenly in February and returned to Citibank. He will not publicly discuss his difficulties with Mr. Lane, other than to say: "I had some displeasure. I voiced my concern to the board chair." Mr. Lane also would not comment on his specific disagreements with Mr. Landers.
Edward G. Lloyd, the chairman of Brisc, said Mr. Landers has not been replaced because the loan unit has an uncertain future. He said it should be given a chance to prove itself. "Would we like to make more loans?" he said. "Of course. But I am in no circumstances apologizing. I think we have done a very good job." 
One of the concerns the loan unit has helped is Nubian Day Care on 135th Street between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. Annie L. Gooding, a longtime physician's assistant with no business experience, said Brisc taught her how to write a business plan for the private center and then gave her and her partner, Steven A. Robinson, a loan for more than $199,000. Subsequently, their center, which is expected to open in late summer, got two bank loans from EAB for a total of $235,000. 
Ms. Gooding said she and Mr. Robinson had advantages other applicants lacked, like master's degrees and a credit history. "I've heard people say that Brisc won't help you," she said. "But they don't understand that the money has to be paid back."
The fate of Brisc may be decided today, when the oversight board holds its quarterly meeting. Kevin S. Corbett, the chief operating officer of the Empire State Development Corporation, said one option would be to hand off the program to a commercial bank. At least one bank, Carver, has already rejected the proposal.
Mr. Lane said severing the program from his organization "would be detrimental to the community and to the spirit and mission of the Empowerment Zone, particularly given the turnaround of Brisc." 
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Mr. Lane's only ally on the empowerment zone board, said Brisc was needed to make Harlem residents feel they are not excluded from the economic development effort, which has lent millions of dollars to shopping center developers. 
But Stanley Gleaton, the chairman of Community Board 10, said there was a perception that the empowerment zone had fallen short of its goals. 
"I'm happy with the job they are doing," Mr. Gleaton said. "I just wish they could do more for the smaller person and strengthen the infrastructure. We don't see as much of that as we would like to see."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
With 2001 half over, experts' forecasts for spending become even gloomier than before.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
FOR Madison Avenue, the second half of 2001 will offer more of the same lugubrious mood that the first half did, as two leading forecasters are again reducing their estimates of advertising spending for the full year. Both are even predicting declines in ad spending in this country from 2000, which would be the first such drop in a decade.
 The reductions are the most recent in what has become a skein of skinbacks as the economic slowdown shows few, if any, signs of easing, particularly as it affects the advertising, marketing and media industries. 
 "We've now seen what was confined to the U.S. in the fourth quarter last year and first quarter this year moving into the major markets of Europe and Asia," said John Perriss, chairman and chief executive at Zenith Media in London. 
"Until corporate profitability improves," he added, so marketers can restore money to their ad budgets, "we're bumping along the bottom."
Mr. Perriss spoke yesterday about a worldwide ad-spending forecast that Zenith will formally announce today. Zenith, a media services agency owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and the Publicis Groupe, is reducing by more than half the estimates for ad spending in 2001 that Mr. Perriss made only six months ago.
The downward revisions in the estimates by Mr. Perriss and Lauren Rich Fine, an analyst who follows the advertising industry for Merrill Lynch, come after similar re-evaluations by other forecasters, including Robert J. Coen, considered the leading predictor of ad spending.
Mr. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann in New York -- part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies -- has cut his prediction of American ad spending growth this year to 2.5 percent, from an initial 6.5 percent and then 5.8 percent. His latest worldwide estimate is for an increase of 3.7 percent, down from 7.1 percent and then 6.1 percent.
In December, Mr. Perriss predicted that worldwide ad spending in 2001 in the major media would increase 6 percent from the record level of 2000. Now, that forecast is being trimmed to an increase of 1.4 percent.
"We had just the most fantastic boom in 2000, but now the world's economies are slowing down," Mr. Perriss said. "The U.S., Western Europe and Japan could all go into recession at the same time."
"As a result," he added, "we don't see the third quarter and the fourth quarter with any kind of uplift the way we did six months ago."
In the United States, Mr. Perriss said, ad spending in the major media, including television, newspapers, radio, magazines, billboards and the Internet, will decline 2 percent in 2001 from last year. That would be the first decline in American ad spending since 1991, a recession year.
Mr. Perriss attributed the rare reversal to softness in demand for commercial time on television networks and large cuts in ad spending made this year by major American marketers like Ford Motor, Johnson & Johnson and Philip Morris.
Ms. Fine, in an interview yesterday after she released a report with her revised estimate, also attributed her revisions to softness in the demand for ad space in magazines and newspapers. And she pointed to weak demand for TV commercial time, particularly this month, in the so-called upfront market, as agencies make buying decisions before the fall TV season begins.
"It's hard to predict positive gains for most categories of media," Ms. Fine said, "so you look at your forecasts and say, 'Why would you think there would be gains this year?' "
Last year, Ms. Fine estimated that ad spending growth in the United States in 2001 would be 4 percent to 4.5 percent. She trimmed that to a gain of 2.5 percent in a report she wrote in March. Yesterday, she cut that again, to a decline of 0.7 percent.
There are no signs at this point that there will be any improvement in the second half of 2001 compared with the first half, Ms. Fine said, "even with the easier comparisons" against the results achieved in 2000, which softened as that year went on.
Ms. Fine is, however, somewhat more sanguine as she looks ahead to 2002. She is forecasting a return to American ad spending gains next year, predicting an increase of 5.1 percent compared with 2001.
"The major media -- newspapers, magazines, TV -- will all be up less than 5 percent," she said. "But radio, direct marketing and the Internet" will grow more, she said, with that "pulling up the numbers." In her only previous estimate for 2002, Ms. Fine forecast an increase from 2001 of 5 percent to 6 percent.
Mr. Perriss, too, expects increases in ad spending in 2002.
"Next year looks a lot better," he said, with a gain in worldwide ad spending in the major media of 6.5 percent compared with 2001, and a gain in American ad spending in the major media of 4.5 percent.
Mr. Coen, in his first forecasts for 2002, predicted a gain in worldwide ad spending of 5.2 percent from this year and a gain in American ad spending of 5 percent.

HEADLINE: Bit of Dissent on Rates At Fed's Meeting in May 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were split at their meeting last month about how far to go in cutting interest rates, with one of the 10 voting members dissenting from the decision to reduce rates by half a percentage point and two others expressing reservations, according to minutes of the session released today.
 Within the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, open divisions are relatively rare, and this one appeared to explain why the Fed subsequently chose to cut rates on Wednesday by a quarter-point rather than the half-point that many economists and investors had been pushing for. 
 The minutes suggested that there had been a vigorous debate within the Fed about whether the series of aggressive rate cuts this year had created a risk of overstimulating the economy and igniting inflation.
At the meeting on May 15, Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo., voted against the decision to cut the benchmark federal funds target rate to 4 percent from 4.5 percent. 
Mr. Hoenig said he preferred a quarter-point cut because the Fed had already "added significant liquidity to the economy this year through its cumulatively large easing actions," the minutes said. In Mr. Hoenig's view, holding the rate cut to a quarter-point would have limited "the risks of producing an overly accommodative policy stance and rising inflation over time."
Two other members of the committee also said they would have been comfortable with a quarter-point cut, the minutes said. Those two members were not identified, but several Fed officials have spoken out in recent weeks about the threat of inflation, including Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has indicated repeatedly in public statements over the last few months that he sees little chance of a substantial uptick in inflation, and he presumably led the camp calling for a half-point cut in May.
In a speech in Chicago tonight, Mr. Greenspan suggested some of the inflationary pressures on the economy from higher energy prices might be easing. He also suggested that the squeeze on corporate profits from higher energy costs might be letting up, and he urged political leaders to allow markets to deal with energy shortages rather than pressing for price caps or other regulation.
The minutes of the May meeting suggest that the committee saw itself as coming to near the end of this cycle of rate reductions. While it voted to include in its public statement at the conclusion of that meeting a reiteration of its standard language signaling that further rate cuts were likely, the committee discussed whether that statement should be shifted soon to more neutral language indicating that no further rate cuts were on the horizon.
The debate in May seemed to capture a painful quandary for the Fed. The central bank has administered a powerful dose of anti-recession medicine to the economy. But the medicine has not yet taken effect. 
In the meantime, the economy is continuing to weaken, leaving the Fed with a choice between further rate cuts that might backfire later on or standing by, subject to criticism that it is blind to the continuing deterioration of business conditions, while it waits for its previous rate cuts to kick in.
The quarter-point cut that the Fed announced on Wednesday, and the inclusion of the language signaling that further cuts were possible, appears to have been a compromise. 
Those actions allowed those who see recession to be a greater threat than inflation to say the Fed is continuing to act. But by holding the rate cut to a quarter-point, the central bank also sent a signal that the current round of rate cuts is winding down, as the more inflation-wary members of the committee seemed to want.
But the Fed's own staff forecast for the May meeting showed that the central bank thinks it could be some time before the economy truly gets back on track.

HEADLINE: Mr. Milosevic in The Hague 

 BODY:
In 1995 Slobodan Milosevic went to Dayton, Ohio, to sign a peace agreement for Bosnia. The Dayton peace accords committed Yugoslavia to cooperate with the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, including transferring those who were indicted. Mr. Milosevic, it is fair to say, had little intention of meeting this obligation. Yet yesterday Yugoslavia kept his promise and transferred him to The Hague for trial. 
 Just nine months ago Mr. Milosevic was an omnipotent dictator. His transfer to a jail cell at The Hague is a historic moment and an affirmation of the importance of international justice. His indictment by the War Crimes Tribunal in 1999 on charges of crimes against humanity hastened his fall from power. His arrest and transfer have strengthened democracy in Yugoslavia and will open the way for the international community to assist in the country's economic reconstruction. 
 Yugoslavia's president, Vojislav Kostunica, who defeated Mr. Milosevic in elections last year, wanted to see him put on trial in Belgrade for election fraud, corruption and other domestic crimes. But more Western-oriented politicians, led by Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic of Serbia, orchestrated his transfer to The Hague.
Mr. Djindjic's position was strengthened by consistent pressure from Washington. The Bush administration made Mr. Milosevic's surrender a condition of American economic aid and participation in a donors' conference that began today. The administration, in turn, was prodded to hold firm by Congress, especially two senators -- Patrick Leahy, a Democrat, and the Republican Mitch McConnell. 
The internecine disagreements about Mr. Milosevic's transfer are likely to set off a political crisis in Yugoslavia. But his extradition may help calm passions in neighboring Macedonia, as it reminds government officials there that they, too, may be called to account for war crimes. The transfer to The Hague may also help Serbs come to terms with the crimes he committed. Polls show that most Serbs wanted to see Mr. Milosevic tried in The Hague, and politicians have uncovered evidence of his crimes to strengthen public support. State television began to show exhumations of mass graves said to contain bodies of people from Kosovo. The evidence has shocked many Serbs, and sparked the beginnings of a debate on Serbian crimes in Kosovo. Such a reckoning is crucial if Serbia is to transform itself into a fully democratic nation.
Yugoslavia must still send to The Hague other men it is harboring who have been indicted for war crimes. But Mr. Milosevic's transfer was a monumental step. A man accused of planning and instigating some of the most heinous crimes in recent years has fallen from near-absolute power to face justice for his acts.

HEADLINE: Albany Wins Right to Limit Power Prices 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 28 

 BODY:
Seeking to curb profiteering by power plant owners, the federal government has granted New York the power to limit spikes in the price of electricity this summer, to prevent the soaring rates that hit consumers last summer.
 The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission agreed today to the "circuit-breaker" on rising wholesale prices that had been sought by the Pataki administration and the New York Independent System Operator, the consortium that runs the state's power markets. The mechanism -- permitted through Oct. 31 -- will automatically lower a power producer's price bid that is significantly out of line with what it had been charging. 
 New York's energy market, once a tightly controlled monopoly, was opened to wholesale price competition in late 1999, in hopes that competition would lower rates that were among the highest in the country. Last June, in the first weeks of high summer demand, wholesale prices nearly tripled in New York City and consumers' overall bills jumped 40 percent. 
State regulators, legislators, utility officials and consumer advocates have said that price manipulation by power producers was partly to blame. Power producers deny that there was any such manipulation.
Wholesale prices in New York vary widely, depending on the part of the state, the time of day, the weather and other factors. At times they are close to zero, but in weeks like this one, with temperatures in the 90's and air-conditioners working much of the day, the weekday prices in New York City and on Long Island are often above $100 per megawatt-hour.
The circuit-breaker approved today would kick in only when producers seek a wholesale price above $150, a price not frequently sought. For instance, the peak price today was just under $170 per megawatt-hour for the period from 3 p.m. to 5 p.m. In contrast, the peak price on Wednesday was less than $65 per megawatt hour. For a peak period on Friday, the wholesale price has already been set at $229 a megawatt hour. 
The fluctuation in prices, however, is not necessarily a sign of manipulation. 
Under the new authority granted the state, if a power plant offers to sell power for $100 or more above its average for the previous 90 days, or for triple that 90-day average, the bid would automatically be reduced to the 90-day average.
That would still allow sudden increases, addressing only the most drastic rises. For instance, a plant that had sold power at a 90-day average price of $105 could abruptly raise its price to $200 without fear of a rollback. The new price would not be $100 above the old price, or more than three times the old price.
Last winter, Gov. George E. Pataki's administration, sensing an economic disaster in the making during the approaching summer, proposed price controls that required federal approval.
While the federal energy commission granted the circuit-breaker mechanism today, it has not yet acted on New York's call for financial penalties for power producers who are found to have manipulated prices. The commission recently granted that power to California's system operator. But, at this point, if New York's regulators find price-gouging, there is nothing they can do about it.
The federal commission "has taken an important step toward protecting energy consumers in New York, but there is more that must be done," Mr. Pataki said tonight in a statement.
Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, who also lobbied the federal commission to grant the market controls, said the commission must now agree to penalties for price-gougers. "It's incongruous that they would not extend to us what they extended to California," he said.
Independent Power Producers of New York, a group representing plant owners, noted that the federal commission's order is only in effect through Oct. 31 and said that meant it had reservations about its action.
"We believe that to have a really true, competitive marketplace, it has to be a regional marketplace across state lines, and to put New York generators at a competitive disadvantage defeats that purpose," said Gavin Donohue, executive director of the group.
The chairman of the federal commission, Curtis Hebert Jr., a Bush appointee, came into office this year expressing his opposition to any price controls. He has softened that stance in the face of enormous pressure to do something about the crisis in California, where rising demand, a shortage of supply and price manipulation have led to higher prices and frequent blackouts, the bankruptcy of major utilities and a multibillion-dollar intervention into the power market by the state.
Under deregulation, New York's utilities have sold their power plants to other companies. To supply their customers, the utilities now must buy power from those power producers on the wholesale market.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Appeals Court Throws Out Order to Split Up Microsoft
A federal appeals court unanimously threw out an order to break up Microsoft while finding that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in the software business.
 The court also chastised the judge overseeing the case and removed him from any further involvement because of his comments about the company and its senior executives. The opinion, welcomed by Microsoft, was also hailed by government officials. Page A1. 

G.E. Offer Is Called Insufficient
European regulators have told General Electric that its last-minute effort to revive its proposed acquisition of Honeywell International will not be sufficient, sounding a death knell for the $45 billion deal. While the stand does not represent a final, official rejection of the deal, it leaves G.E. with only a few days to come up with a new proposal to salvage it. Executives close to General Electric said that the company was unlikely to come back to the table with a new proposal given the timetable. Shares of Honeywell rose $1.20, to $38.20, while G.E. rose 61 cents, to $48.87. C2.

Tobacco Ad Limits Struck Down
The Supreme Court placed significant limits on the ability of state and local governments to regulate tobacco advertising in a Massachusetts case that also appeared to invalidate a similar law in New York City. A1.

Technology Shares Lead Stock Rally
Stocks rallied on brighter hopes for corporate earnings a day after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates. Technology stocks also rallied after the federal appeals court ruling in the Microsoft antitrust case. The Nasdaq composite index gained 50.72 points, or 2.4 percent, to 2,125.46. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 131.37 points, or 1.3 percent, to 10,566.21. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 15.13 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,226.20. C9.

Minutes Show Debate on Rate Cuts
Federal Reserve policy makers were split at their meeting last month about how far to go in cutting interest rates, according to minutes of the meeting. Meanwhile, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, suggested that some of the inflationary pressures on the economy from higher energy prices might be easing. C9.

Burger King to Monitor Meat Plants
Burger King said that it would begin checking the 160 slaughterhouses from which it buys meat to make sure that all of the animals are carefully stunned before being killed. C9.

Chairman of CNN Resigns
The chairman of CNN, Tom Johnson, who started at the network before it rose to glory with its coverage of the Persian Gulf war, resigned. Mr. Johnson said that he was leaving to spend time with his family. C4.

Editor Is Named at Marie Claire
Lesley Jane Seymour, left, the editor who transformed Redbook from a women's magazine packed with recipes and sniffle remedies into a publication with a mission to spice up the home life of the American working mother, was named the new editor of Marie Claire magazine. Ms. Seymour succeeds Glenda Bailey, who became editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar. All three magazines are published by Hearst. C4.

Talks Intensify in Hollywood
Negotiators representing actors and producers stepped up the pace of their talks this week with a midnight Saturday deadline for the expiration of their contract. C4.

Two Companies Cited in California
California legislators cited two energy companies, Mirant and Enron, for not handing over documents necessary in the state's hearings on market manipulation. A18.

Bus Operator Files for Bankruptcy
Laidlaw, the operator of school buses and the parent of the Greyhound bus lines, said that it was seeking bankruptcy protection as it struggles with debt. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
Thorn Had the Say In Rockets' Picks

BYLINE:  By LIZ ROBBINS 

 BODY:
When Rod Thorn, the president of the Nets, emerged from the team's draft strategy room Wednesday night, his face was resolute but he seemed drained from the moves he had made. As it turned out, that was only a preview for yesterday's blockbuster deal that sent Stephon Marbury to Phoenix for Jason Kidd.
 They may not have ended up with shooting guard Jason Richardson, who was drafted fifth over all by Golden State, or kept forward Eddie Griffin, but in the end the Nets received something better: three versatile talents to fit their needs. 
 "We went into the draft last night, trying to get accomplished exactly what we accomplished and those were the guys we were trying to get," Thorn said yesterday. 
When Thorn traded Griffin, the Nets' pick at No. 7, to Houston for the rights to the Rockets' three first-round picks, he then directed Houston to select Arizona swingman Richard Jefferson, Stanford center Jason Collins and Pepperdine guard Brandon Armstrong.
The Nets lacked a cohesive identity during a dismal, injury-ravaged 26-56 season, the sixth time in seven years they missed the playoffs. After selecting Brian Scalabrine, a power forward out of Southern California, with the 35th pick, the Nets were left wondering whether they wagered quality for quantity.
"I feel we got more potential quality at a number of positions," Thorn said. "I feel good about that. We accomplished what we wanted to do. Everybody was happy with the way things worked out."
The three-for-one deal was contingent on the surprise of Griffin dropping to No. 7, but one Eastern Conference league executive said that the Nets were inclined to make a trade to receive Jefferson, Collins and Armstrong anyway.
"We had him going in the top three," Houston General Manager Carroll Dawson said. On their wish list, the Rockets had Griffin ranked first or second, but Dawson said he never even brought up Griffin's name in predraft discussions with Thorn to trade the three picks, thinking it was a moot point.
So did Thorn. "I was a bit surprised yes; I thought he would go to Golden State," Thorn said of Griffin. The Warriors instead drafted Richardson, spoiling the Nets' hopes and fueling Houston's.
"We had known that they wanted a certain person, but if they could not get that person, they might be better off with three picks," Dawson said.
Unable to take Richardson and knowing that the Grizzlies would select Shane Battier, Thorn gambled that Houston would be interested. Working without a deal, but knowing from discussions he had leading up to the draft that the Rockets were willing to unload their first-round picks, Thorn made his selection.
In Houston, Dawson picked up the phone. "Do we have something to talk about?" Dawson recalled Thorn asking.
"We sure do," Dawson responded.
Within 10 minutes, the Rockets had agreed to the trade. The teams kept a phone line open so Thorn could tell the Rockets which players to draft.
The Rockets were not scared off by Griffin's history of fights with teammates, stretching from his senior year at Roman Catholic High School in Philadelphia to Seton Hall in January, when Griffin was suspended for a game after punching Ty Shine.
"It didn't bother us; I can't speak for the other teams," Dawson said. "You do your background checks and we got nothing but good reports."
Jefferson's stock had been rising among league executives, based on his strong workouts and his late-season performance in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Jefferson, a junior, led the Wildcats to the N.C.A.A. championship game, shooting 50 percent and averaging 13.5 points and 6.7 rebounds. He held Richardson and Illinois point guard Frankie Williams to a combined 15 points and 5-of-26 shooting.
"There aren't a whole lot of better athletes than Richard and this year he became our defensive stopper," Arizona Coach Lute Olsen said of Jefferson on Wednesday night.
Thorn said he could see Jefferson making an immediate impact, playing small forward and shooting guard, providing insurance if shooting guard Kerry Kittles cannot fully recover from knee surgery.
"I think he was one of the best athletes in the draft," Thorn said.
Collins, at 7 feet, 260 pounds, will vie for a starting position at center. The Nets started the second-year player Evan Eschmeyer in 51 games, with Jim McIlvaine out for most of the season because of a calf injury. 
The Nets did not bring in Collins for a workout, figuring he would go in the second round -- although they did bring in his twin, Jarron. Jarron Collins was selected by the Utah Jazz with the 53rd pick. Jason is considered the more polished of the two. Thorn saw Jason at the Chicago combine and was impressed with his toughness and his touch. "He can shoot the ball and he's a big, strong kid who plays very hard," Thorn said.
Because of two years of medical redshirts, Jason Collins still had two years of eligibility, but he graduated from Stanford 11 days ago with a degree in economics. He had a frayed meniscus cartilage in his freshman year, and dislocated his right wrist his sophomore year, but he did not miss a game in his last two seasons. "During this process, I did eight workouts in eight straight days, flying from city to city, never once taking a day off," Collins said. "My knee was fine. It hasn't bothered me all season for the past three seasons."
In Armstrong, Thorn sees a reserve shooting guard who can eventually learn to play backup point guard. As it turns out, he will be backing up Kidd.

HEADLINE: Legislature Passes Budget and Medical Lawsuit Bill 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 28 

 BODY:
In its annual frenzy before the summer recess, the Legislature took action today on more than 200 bills, approving what is being called the nation's strongest law allowing patients to sue their health maintenance organizations and passing a $22.9 billion budget for the coming year.
 But opponents of abortion rights failed to muster the votes needed to put on the November ballot a constitutional amendment requiring parental notification before minors can get abortions. And while the Senate approved a financing plan for a new sports arena in Newark, the General Assembly took no action on the project, leaving its fate uncertain. 
 All 40 Senate and 80 Assembly seats are up for grabs this November, and lawmakers who are running for re-election will use the next five months to campaign. On the last day of the session, however, they packed their agenda with items ranging from an "interior designer certification act" to a resolution condemning the Taliban regime in Afghanistan for requiring Hindus to wear identifying labels. 
Among the notable measures that received final approval were a change in the formula governing the teachers' pension plan, raising the payments to retired teachers by 9 percent, and a law extending the hours of voting, by requiring state polling places to open at 6 a.m. instead of 7.
The medical right-to-sue bill, which easily passed both houses today and awaits Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's signature, means New Jersey will be one of a handful of states where patients can sue their H.M.O.'s for denying, or even delaying, approval of medical treatments. But it goes further than some of those states, such as California, by barring insurers from requiring patients to waive future lawsuits as a condition of coverage, officials said.
The bill's passage comes as Congress is considering dueling versions of a patient's bill of rights. The New Jersey bill, which would apply only to state-regulated H.M.O.'s, creates a two-tiered threshold for lawsuits. Patients in the first tier, who could die or suffer serious or irreversible harm if treatment is denied or delayed, could sue immediately. Others would have to go through three stages of appeals first.
Dr. Angelo S. Agro, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, said that he believed the bill would help patients but also insurers, by cutting down on litigation, especially weak claims. "As a physician, I'm sticking my neck out to go to bat for the patient," he said. "So it's not going to happen in a frivolous sense. And if H.M.O.'s are held accountable for a patient's life, they will think twice about making medical decisions for monetary reasons."
The parental notification amendment actually passed the Senate today, but by a simple majority of 21-15, with four senators not voting. Supporters in the anti-abortion movement had hoped to attain a three-fifths majority, or 24 votes, in order to put the amendment on the November ballot. But the 15 Democratic senators voted against the amendment, and two Republicans who support abortion rights -- John O. Bennett, the minority leader, and Diane Allen, of Burlington County -- abstained. With a simple majority alone, the bill must be approved by the full Legislature in two consecutive years.
As expected, the state budget was approved by both houses, largely along party lines, and is to be signed into law by Mr. DiFrancesco on Friday.
Republicans said the process had been confused because two governors and three state treasurers had overseen its drafting. Leonard Lance, the Republican chairman of the Assembly Budget Committee, complained that the administration had refused to defend its revenue projections when challenged by nonpartisan legislative analysts.
Democrats, meanwhile, called it an election-year budget full of smoke and mirrors, and warned that it failed to account fully for a souring economy. "This budget is supported by pretending that we will have more revenue than we actually will," Assemblywoman Barbara Buono said. "To whom should the next governor forward the bill?"
In the Senate, Democratic efforts to amend it failed, by a 22-to-16 vote, and the entire budget then passed, 26 to 13. William Schluter, who is running for governor as an independent, was the lone Republican opposing it. Sharpe James and Ronald Rice of Newark, and Shirley Turner of Trenton, were the only Democrats to approve the budget.
The vote on the budget in the Senate came after it had approved Mr. DiFrancesco's financing plan for the arena in Newark as a new home for the New Jersey Devils and Nets. The bill would create a special taxing district in Newark to finance the arena's construction.
Assembly Speaker Jack Collins refused to put the arena bill up for a vote today, but he was said to be willing to convene a special session to consider it, if he is able to win economic-development projects for his political base of South Jersey.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Claims Decline 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28 

 BODY:
Initial claims for jobless benefits fell unexpectedly last week, the Labor Department reported today, but the number of people remaining on unemployment payments continued to increase as hiring remained weak.
 Initial claims dropped for the third week, falling by 16,000, to 388,000, in the week ended June 23, from a revised 404,000 the week before -- reaching their lowest level since May 5. 
 Economists expected jobless claims to rise to 412,000 from the 400,000 originally reported in the week ended June 16.
Even though the figures were better than expected, analysts said it was too soon to say that labor market conditions were improving.
"Those who have lost their jobs are having a harder time getting new jobs," said Bryan Jordan, who is an economic analyst at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio. 
The number of continued claims by unemployed workers who already filed for at least a week of benefits rose to 2.99 million in the week ended June 16, the latest period for which figures were available.
The last time it was that high was in November 1992.
The drop in initial filings for jobless benefits ended a five-week string of claims above 400,000.
Economists say that claims above that level are an indication of a sustained move to higher unemployment.
"We would have to see a few more weeks in the down direction," Mr. Jordan said, "to really get more comfortable that the labor market is tightening again."

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
'Other Half' Is Living A Little Better

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
FERNANDO FERRER wants to help "the other New York," he said in announcing his candidacy for mayor on Wednesday. That phrase has a noble ring to it, an echo of the classic advocacy for the poor in "How the Other Half Lives" and "The Other America." But who exactly are the "other" people? And why is it charitable to give them that label?
 Jacob Riis, a newspaperman who could recognize a good phrase, copyrighted the title "How the Other Half Lives" even before he wrote the book. Traditionally, he explained, "the half that was on top cared little for the struggles, and less for the fate of those who were underneath." But now, Riis wrote in his 1890 book, there were missionaries (like himself) devoting lives of "unselfish thought and effort" to rescuing the lower half. 
 Riis obviously cared for the poor, but he never understood them and didn't seem to like them. He had no patience for the poor when their desires conflicted with his. He insisted on banishing them from tenements that offended his sensibilities -- never mind that they wanted to stay in their homes and couldn't pay for his middle-class tastes. How could the other half be expected to know what was good for them?
The poor became objects of his pity and his insulting generalizations. Italians were "content to live in a pig-sty," he wrote, while the Chinese were "in no sense a desirable element of the population." As for Eastern European Jews: "Money is their God. Life itself is of little value compared with even the leanest bank account."
Czechs were spendthrifts and drinkers, he wrote; Irish were peculiarly susceptible to becoming lazy beggars; blacks were carefree. "Poverty, abuse and injustice alike the Negro accepts with imperturbable cheerfulness," Riis wrote. "He loves fine clothes and good living a good deal more than he does a bank account." 
As appalling as Riis could be in his condescension, he did at least see hope for the other half. With better homes, proper education, and hard work (he denounced able-bodied men who subsisted on charity), the poor could acquire the moral character and bourgeois habits of the top half. The other half could eventually join Riis's half.
By 1962, though, the other half had become "The Other America," the title of Michael Harrington's book. The poor were now a still more exotic entity, trapped in their own "fatal, futile universe" in which they "cannot help themselves." Only missionaries like Mr. Harrington could save them, and the key did not lie in Riis's old-fashioned ideas about work. Mr. Harrington called it "degrading" for young men in the ghetto to take minimum-wage jobs.
That philosophy became the norm in New York during the 1960's, as Vincent J. Cannato details in his new book, "The Ungovernable City: John Lindsay and His Struggle to Save New York." The welfare rolls soared during an economic boom, and Lindsay became the photogenic symbol of the white liberal reaching out to those beyond his social circle.
"He was the symbol of noblesse oblige," Mr. Cannato said. "He meant well and felt compassion, but it was compassion without any real knowledge of what was going on in poor neighborhoods."
FOR intellectuals, the other America became an exotic refuge from bourgeois values. Norman Mailer celebrated graffiti in poor neighborhoods, and James Baldwin said that Harlemites who threw garbage out their windows were engaging in social protest. Before long the poor had become the "underclass," which seemed even more alien and hopeless. 
One in six New Yorkers remained on welfare when Rudolph W. Giuliani took office in 1993. He set about cutting the welfare rolls, preaching bourgeois values and promoting a radical new description of the social classes: "one city, one standard."
That philosophy hasn't personally endeared Mr. Giuliani to the city's poorer residents, but they've become more content with their neighborhoods. A survey by the Columbia University School of Social Work, released in March, showed that people's satisfaction with their neighborhoods had improved more dramatically in poor areas than in affluent areas. 
Maybe, as Mr. Ferrer hopes, there are still enough unhappy poor people, and enough nonpoor people with guilty social consciences, to elect a candidate promising expensive new programs for the poor. Maybe Mr. Ferrer, a resident of Riverdale -- not exactly the wrong half of the Bronx -- will succeed by tapping into the alienation he sees in his other New York. 
Or maybe there are a lot of voters starting to wonder whether the people in the other New York are really so different after all.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Dweck to Shut Doors After a 9-Year Run

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Dweck in New York, an agency known for producing award-winning, attention-getting campaigns for smaller advertisers, said yesterday that it would close after nine years. 
 Michael Dweck, the chairman and creative director, said the closing, which affects 14 employees, was not related to the economic slowdown but rather to a desire to "concentrate on what I love, which is creative development." He said that may entail his taking a creative post at another agency. 
 Dweck had billings estimated in January at $30 million, from clients like Site 59 and UPN. The agency was founded in 1992 as Dweck & Campbell by Mr. Dweck and Lori Campbell, who left in 1999.
