HEADLINE: THE HANDOVER OF MILOSEVIC: THE OVERVIEW; 
MILOSEVIC IS GIVEN TO U.N. FOR TRIAL IN WAR-CRIME CASE

BYLINE:  By MARLISE SIMONS with CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Friday, June 29 

 BODY:
Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader blamed for starting four Balkan wars and impoverishing and isolating his country, was delivered early this morning to a prison cell and eventual trial by the United Nations war crimes tribunal here.
 Mr. Milosevic, who was indicted during the 1999 war over Kosovo on charges that his security forces committed war crimes in that province, was the first former head of state delivered by a government to face an international war crimes court. 
 The decision to send him to trial abroad caused deep divisions in Belgrade, both among the democratic leaders elected to replace him last fall and Serbs in general. 
The transfer was executed swiftly by the Serbian government without even informing Mr. Milosevic's successor as Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica. On a downtown Belgrade square that had been the scene of many pro- and anti-Milosevic demonstrations through his violent 13 years of power, thousands of his supporters gathered to vent their anger. 
On Thursday evening, as Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic of Serbia was announcing the surprising transfer, Mr. Milosevic was whisked in a police van from his Belgrade jail and flown on a Serbian government helicopter to an American air base in Tuzla, Bosnia, and from there to a military airfield near The Hague, the seat of the tribunal.
From there, a helicopter took him to a large jail compound, where hundreds of bystanders, many of them exiles driven by war from the former Yugoslavia, applauded outside the prison walls.
Mr. Milosevic was transferred exactly 10 years after the outbreak of war in Slovenia and Croatia, which had declared independence from the old Communist Yugoslavia, and on the fated Serbian holiday of Vidovdan, or St. Vitus's Day, the date in 1389 when Serbs lost a key battle in Kosovo. It was on the 600th anniversary of that battle, on June 28, 1989, that Mr. Milosevic addressed close to a million Serbs in Kosovo, promising to defend their interests, through war if necessary.
There was an immense international outpouring of relief that Mr. Milosevic was in the hands of those who hold him responsible for the deaths of tens of thousands of people in the last decade of war in the Balkans.
"Obviously this is an incredibly important moment in the life of this institution," Jim Landale, the spokesman for the tribunal, said as he confirmed that Mr. Milosevic was now officially in its custody. "It is now closer to fulfilling the mission for which it was set up, that is, to deal with the commanders and the architects of the policies that wrought so much havoc and caused so much misery to the people of the Balkans."
In Belgrade, the leaders who pushed through the transfer appeared quietly jubilant, if deeply aware that the move caused divisions that may lead to the fall of their young, fragile and virtually bankrupt government.
Prime Minister Djindjic went on television, telling Serbs that the government had been forced to take a "difficult but morally correct" decision to protect the interests of Serbia. The government badly needs the money only the West -- and particularly the United States -- can offer, and Mr. Djindjic and the Yugoslav deputy prime minister, Miroljub Labus, the country's leading economist, had been the main advocates for handing over Mr. Milosevic.
"To stop the cooperation with the Hague tribunal or to postpone this cooperation would have had major negative consequences for the present and future of our country," Mr. Djindjic said.
The United States had exerted strong pressure that Mr. Milosevic, who was ousted as president in October in a popular uprising, be detained -- as he eventually was on April 1 -- and then delivered to The Hague tribunal.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell spoke with Mr. Djindjic twice in the last week, and warned him that the United States was prepared to boycott a conference in Brussels today if Mr. Milosevic was not delivered to The Hague, a senior State Department official said. The new Yugoslav leaders hope to raise some $1 billion in aid at the conference -- a goal they cannot meet without American participation.
"We made it quite clear that we want to help them," the official said. "But they had obligations, and they had to meet those obligations, and the secretary never wavered from that."
In Washington, President Bush issued a statement calling Mr. Milosevic's transfer to The Hague a "very important step by the leaders in Belgrade."
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said, "We are witnessing one of the most significant events in postwar European history, where a nation has voluntarily turned over to an international tribunal for trial one of the most dangerous and maniacal European leaders since Hitler." 
Richard C. Holbrooke, who negotiated intensively with Mr. Milosevic to reach the 1995 Dayton accords that ended the Bosnian war, said he was very pleased that the former Yugoslav leader "is on his way to a well-deserved detention and trial."
Mr. Holbrooke said the tribunal should now expand its inquiry into Mr. Milosevic's role in Bosnia between 1992 and 1995, including the massacre in Srebrenica in July 1995, where as many as 7,000 Muslims are thought to have been killed after Bosnian Serb forces took over what was supposed to be an enclave with United Nations protection.
The commander at Srebrenica, Gen. Ratko Mladic, and the Bosnian Serb political leader Radovan Karadzic -- each indicted twice by the tribunal on charges of war crimes and genocide -- remain at large, most likely in Bosnia, despite the presence of tens of thousands of NATO troops.
Mr. Holbrooke and the tribunal's chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, each said on Thursday night that Mr. Karadzic and General Mladic must be arrested and brought to The Hague.
Timothy McFadden, the chief of the tribunal detention center, said in an interview this week that the former president would be isolated at least initially from other inmates. It was not clear when Mr. Milosevic would be brought to court and formally charged, but that hearing was expected within days.
Mr. Djindjic, noting that Mr. Milosevic basically called Serbs to war in his famous Kosovo speech 12 years ago, said this led only to "12 years of wars, catastrophe and ruin for our country."
The transfer decision was intended to save Serbia "not so much for ourselves and for our parents, but for our children," the prime minister said. "With this decision, we are saving the future of our children."
The Serbian government took things into its own hands on Thursday afternoon after the Yugoslav Constitutional Court ruled that a government decree adopted on Saturday and committing the country to cooperating with the Hague tribunal was unconstitutional. 
The government leaders had anticipated the court ruling; Mr. Djindjic called a cabinet meeting and used an article in the Serbian Constitution -- ironically written in on Mr. Milosevic's orders when he was president of Serbia in 1990 -- that allowed it to override the Yugoslav ruling.
Fifteen ministers voted to transfer Mr. Milosevic to The Hague, and one voted against, Mr. Djindjic said. Of the six ministers who were absent, five supported the move, and one opposed it, he said.
The Constitutional Court that declared the decree on cooperation with the Hague illegal was the same court that tried to annul the election results in September when Mr. Kostunica, leader of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, defeated Mr. Milosevic in Yugoslav presidential elections.
The decision to move Mr. Milosevic sharpened the differences between Mr. Kostunica and the rest of the leaders in the multi-party alliance. Mr. Kostunica, who has criticized the Hague tribunal for anti-Serb bias, had been slow to draft a law on cooperation with it, to the point that he has been accused of jeopardizing financial aid and the international standing of the country.
Mr. Kostunica went on television later last evening to address the nation, calling it an "extremely difficult and fateful moment for our country."
He said that the problem had been "unnecessarily and unwisely created," and that the removal of Mr. Milosevic could not be considered legal or constitutional. He likened Mr. Djindjic's tactics to the "lawless and hasty acts" of the Milosevic regime and warned that the consequences were dangerous. Those indicted at The Hague deserved a chance to appeal in their own country, he said.
"Yugoslavia deserves better," he said. "Those measures endanger our country, its citizens, and also the damaged peace in our region."
Dragoslav Ognjanovic, one of Mr. Milosevic's lawyers, arrived at the Belgrade prison where his client had been held on Thursday night only to find the former leader gone. "This behavior is savage," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic of Serbia, center with some of his cabinet, announced in Belgrade yesterday the government's decision to send Slobodan Milosevic to the United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. A12)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
CONAGRA PROFITS FALL 38% IN ITS FOURTH QUARTER

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 ConAgra Foods Inc. said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 38 percent because of higher energy and marketing costs and inventory reductions by grocers. 
ConAgra, based in Omaha, said it spent more to promote food products, including Butterball turkeys and Chef Boyardee pasta, just as the economy slowed. Reduced profits from its seed, pesticide and fertilizer businesses contributed to the second consecutive quarterly decline in profit. Sales in the quarter rose 4.7 percent from the period a year earlier, to $6.44 billion, in part because of its acquisition of International Home Foods. Income in the quarter ended May 27 fell to $121.4 million, or 23 cents a share, from $195.1 million, or 41 cents, a year earlier.

PUB-DATE: June 29, 2001
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 4701 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 977-7170 (through July 22). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, tries to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by an elegance, an economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Smith).

* AFRICAN GALLERIES, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (on long-term view). The museum has one of the oldest and most important collections of African art in the country. Just a few years ago, 250 objects from the permanent collection were installed in revamped first-floor galleries; now two dozen pieces have been added and the space has been redesigned again, this time with multicolored walls, mural-size color photographs, documentary films and ambient sound. Added works expand the definition of African to include both Morocco and ancient Nubia. And the overall selection, from familiar friends to treasures recently acquired, is thrilling. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

* "AFRICAN, OCEANIC AND ANCIENT AMERICAN ART: RECENT ACQUISITIONS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 28). One of the best new group shows in the city -- stimulating to mind and eye -- is sitting smack in the middle of the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Met, and you've probably never seen the likes of much of what's in it. The 70 pieces all came to the Met as gifts or purchases over the last five years. They take many forms, from devotional icons to notebook drawings to Sunday-best hats, and they span centuries and continents, from a tiny Mexican ceramic mask made around the ninth century B.C. to a hummingbird-colored silk mantle woven in Madagascar in 1998. A bottom line to such diversity? Almost everything here was meant to have some contact with the human body: to be worn, carried, caressed. This is art with the velvet ropes down. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"AZTLAN TODAY: THE CHICANO POSTNATION," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, (718) 681-6000 (through Sept. 9). Removed in time from the intensely political art of the Chicano civil rights era, almost everything in this show of recent work takes the form of conceptually based photography and video. The tone is low-key; the polish is high. A stance of rooted historical witness has been replaced by ambiguity. Ethnic identity is treated alternately with shrewd comic flair, tender theatricality or autobiographical intimacy. The work is strong; of particular interest is the way it suggests subtle changes in the nature of political art through the 1990's. Hours: Wednesdays noon to 9 p.m.; Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $3; $2, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "BEAUTY, HONOR AND TRADITION: THE LEGACY OF PLAINS INDIAN SHIRTS," Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through Nov. 4). To Plains Indians of the 18th and 19th centuries, magnificently decorated hide shirts were symbols of bravery earned only by the most courageous in battle. Obsessively fringed and embellished with porcupine quills, paint, ribbon, hair and, later, tight patterns of colored glass beads, the shirts took on the spirits of their owners and even today are made for wearing at powwows and in recognition of other accomplishments. Celebrating the power of this glory gear, almost 50 dazzlers in the museum's collection are on view, dating from about 1820 to the 1990's. Among the more fascinating examples are a brilliantly painted Crow shirt (1890) with beadwork in geometric patterns and frizzy fringes of dyed magenta and yellow hair and a Lakota shirt, circa 1890, which carries United States Army insignia, the American flag and stepped tepees topped by crosses, all worked in porcupine quills and metal beads. Hours: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Free. (Grace Glueck).

* JACQUES AND NATASHA GELMAN GALLERIES, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5000 (continuing). These glorious new galleries display 50 French modern works, almost all paintings, drawn from the Gelmans' collection. In addition to the paintings here, the collection includes five sculptures, more than 30 drawings and a major work on paper: a Matisse cutout, the Met's first, which will be shown in a subsequent hanging. The standouts installed here include Matisse's Fauve masterpiece "The Young Sailor II"; a matched set of small, classic Cubist paintings, one by Picasso, one by Braque, both from 1911, arguably the high point of their collaboration; and a fantastically refined, sexually fraught 1929 Dali, "Accommodations of Desires." It is a selection that is not only consistent in its high quality but also, for all the big names and visual firepower, surprisingly personal. It makes the museum a modern art destination in a way that it has never quite been before. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "EL GRECO: THEMES AND VARIATIONS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 29). This gemlike single-digit exhibition (just seven canvases) outweighs some of the more grandiose shows in New York museums at the moment. It brings together, mostly for the first time, four versions of the artist's tumultuous "Purification of the Temple," which provide a vivid time line of his transcultural development, and three versions of his resonant portrait of St. Jerome as a cardinal, which were all painted toward the end of his life when he skillfully copied -- always with interesting differences -- his works for private patrons. The show makes its small oval gallery reverberate with thoughts about painting: as craft, thought, commodity and lifelong pursuit. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

* "FRANK GEHRY, ARCHITECT," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Aug. 26). A full-dress retrospective that showcases history unfolding, even as we walk through it. Mr. Gehry has shown that even in architecture, a form notoriously resistant to creativity, it is possible not only to realize a personal vision but also to gain wide public support for it. The show is a tribute to the ideal of service: to an art form, to the city and to the continuous reconstruction of a democratic way of life. Nothing, not even familiarity with Mr. Gehry's buildings, can prepare you for the impact of seeing his work in Frank Lloyd Wright's magnificent rotunda. The energy hits you on entering the show and increases as you proceed. Hours: Fridays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Herbert Muschamp).

* WILLIAM KENTRIDGE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 16). By way of drawings and film animations, Mr. Kentridge addresses in searing images South Africa and its racial problems, along with the longings and frustrations of bourgeois lives played out in the country's deeply dysfunctional setting. The exhibition begins with his jarring "Shadow Procession" (1999), a ragtag parade of silhouetted moving images projected on a big screen, which evokes the displaced and dispossessed who haunt not only South Africa but also the history of the world. At the heart of the show are his drawings and the short animated films he makes of them, in which the process shares importance with the content. Many of the films contrast the lives of two antiheroes, one a crude rapacious businessman, the other a sensitive artist, in compelling medleys of images that touch on the personal and the political. Departing from this format is "Ubu Tells the Truth" (1997), a highly charged satire based on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, set up in 1995 to investigate human rights abuses during the apartheid era. It's not often that good art is shaped from such raw angry material, but Mr. Kentridge's powers of invention are equal to the challenge. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* "MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF ART," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Aug. 19). From Michelangelo to Louise Bourgeois, from Rembrandt to Franz Kline, this cornucopia of drawings from one of the most important collections in the United States bristles with the work of stellar talents. A standout is a double-sided drawing in red chalk by Michelangelo, probably done around 1510-11. One side reveals the trouble he had sketching a foot that fits the position of a youthful male nude on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; the other shows the headless nude itself, a powerful, ingeniously posed figure that emphasizes the sculptor's magnificent grasp of anatomical rendering. A rare compositional drawing by Fra Filippo Lippi, a subtly toned landscape by Claude Lorrain, a scene of battling horses by Gericault, a stately portrait by Ingres, one of Seurat's brilliant black crayon drawings of a French vaudeville scene, and works by Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec are among the highlights. The 20th-century American group is something of a disappointment, but there is enough great stuff from other eras to make this a masterpiece of a show. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 65+ (Glueck).

"PRECIOUS POSSESSIONS: TREASURES FROM THE LIBRARY OF THE JEWISH THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY," Jewish Theological Seminary, 3080 Broadway, at 122nd Street, (212) 678-8082 (through Sept. 24). These 90 or so charismatic entries date from the 11th to 20th century and come from all over the world. Almost every item has a story to tell or a name to drop. Want to see Maimonides's signature? Sigmund Freud's bookplate? A handwritten score by Leonard Bernstein? They're here. So are some spectacular illuminated manuscripts, minute and colossal, and objects that carry the warmth of ordinary life: marriage contracts, postcards and a 13th-century letter from a man in India to his wife in Egypt, assuring her of his unbroken devotion. Hours: Sundays, noon to 7 p.m.; Mondays through Thursdays, 8 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Fridays, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free (Cotter)

* "19TH- AND 20TH-CENTURY CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Aug. 19). The 19th and 20th centuries were shattering times for China, bringing wars, civil violence and the fall of an empire. In art, old forms survived and flourished but also changed. This exhibition surveys how elite painting traditions developed for a new audience and under Western influences from 1850 to 1980. Among the highlights is a group of paintings by Qi Baishi (1864-1957), deservedly one of the most popular of all Chinese artists. The big news is that a major museum has quietly taken a firm stand on modern art in Asia, seeing it not as a postscript to a great tradition but as an integral, living part of the continuum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

"TOURING WEST: 19TH-CENTURY PERFORMING ARTISTS ON THE OVERLAND TRAILS," New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089 (through July 7). A broad range of theatrical ephemera, among much else, traces the birth of the American entertainment industry in the westward progress of several generations of intrepid actors, singers and lecturers, and provides significant glimpses of the larger stage of history as well. Hours: Mondays, and Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Smith).

* "UNIFORM: ORDER AND DISORDER," P.S. 1 Center for Contemporary Art, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sept. 3). Originally shown in Italy, this exhibition traces the changing forms and symbolism of the modern military uniform as it progresses through the larger culture and is transformed by it: alternately respected and violated, examined and absorbed, abbreviated and exaggerated. The perpetrators include artists like Wolfgang Tillmans, Vanessa Beecroft and Maurizio Cattelan; fashion designers like Prada, Versace and Donna Karan; and scores of terrorists, punks and nameless teenagers. Eight well-stocked vitrines present a plethora of supporting material, much of which is also reproduced in a stylish catalog. The exhibition ends with the real thing: a gantlet of the uniforms and head gear -- from fatigues to parade dress -- worn by members of the different Italian military services. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5 (Smith).

Galleries: Uptown

LOCKWOOD DE FOREST, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through July 27). By no means a name to reckon with in the pantheon of American view makers, de Forest (1850-1932) specialized in unpretentious small sketches meant to convey the feeling of a place rather than dwell on its physical attributes. His work, until recently kept mostly in family hands, was a visual diary of his many wanderings. In contrast to the taste of the time, he regarded his sketches as finished works, focusing, even in exotic locations like Egypt, India, Syria, Greece and Mexico, on village life, stretches of dunes, desert rocks, tree-lined shores and distant mountains bathed in fog. For those who like their countrysides relaxed and uninvasive, this show will appeal (Glueck).

ALEX KATZ, Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338 (through July 13). Though famous mainly for his large, elegantly flattened and simplified pictures of beautiful, well-to-do people, Mr. Katz also has a lovely touch on a small scale. This modest but rewarding show with mostly small pictures of women as well as some funky little collages from the 1950's shows to advantage his delicate brushwork, perfect compositional sense and controlled eroticism (Ken Johnson).

MAX KUEHNE, "Artist and Craftsman," Hollis Taggart, 48 East 73rd Street, (212) 628-4000 (through July 13). A student of Robert Henri, Kuehne (1880-1968) was a competent painter, but his most distinctive contribution was his production of well-made richly decorative furniture, picture frames and wood carvings. Under influences ranging from Japanese to Art Nouveau, he incised outlines of flora and fauna into gessoed surfaces and added colored glazes and burnished metal leaf. The most engaging pieces here are a pair of smoothly carved, elegantly humorous silver giraffes (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Aug. 31). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop Art by the movement's stars. The 26 objects shown here, including works by Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist, are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. Among the signature works are Warhol's serial extravaganza, "200 Soup Cans" (1962); Mr. Rauschenberg's "Broadcast" (1959), a combine painting with a working radio attached; and Mr. Oldenburg's soft "Drum Set" (1967), a bodylike sendup of a professional drummer's instruments in vinyl and canvas that droops on a platform in a metaphor for its own spent energy. Collectors' collectors, the Powerses made the pursuit into an art of their own (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

MORRIS GRAVES, "Still Life," Schmidt Bingham, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-1122 (through Aug. 17). This small retrospective honors a great American original who died last month at 90. Ranging from vigorously palette-knifed paintings of drinking fountains, from the 1930's, to exquisitely delicate pictures of flowers in transparent bottles from the 90's, it gives a fine taste of Graves's craftsmanly versatility and his modest yet intense poetic sensibility (Johnson).

ALEXANDER LIBERMAN, "Maquettes for Monuments," Ameringer/Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through Aug. 10). In the late 1960's, this Modernist sculptor and Conde Nast editorial director produced gigantic abstractions using old, unearthed gas pipes. On view here are sleek little copies of those monumental works, compositions of standing, leaning or tumbling cylinders finished in glossy red or matte rust-colored patina. Though not deeply consequential, they are appealingly precious (Johnson).

"SIGNS OF LIFE," Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through July 27). This disjunctive but interesting six-artist show includes lively, comically erotic semi-abstract pink paintings by Fernanda Brunet; tires with treads recarved into traditional decorative motifs by Betsabee Romero; strangely clinical photographs of a man in his underwear by Ernesto Pujol; small, iconic realist paintings by Marco Arce; a droopy shaped painting by Leda Catunda; and a funny video by Ximena Cuevas in which the artist breathlessly practices introducing herself to the video curator John Hanhardt (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

LEIF KATH, DCA Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-5511 (through July 14). Blots, dots and linear markings cavort in these paintings and works on paper by the Danish-born Mr. Kath. Although they state nothing beyond their own presence, they make a strong visual showing, as in "San Cataldo," a suite of seven ink drawings. It has as its common theme bold white circles of different sizes strategically scattered on black grounds of varying density. All told, the works on paper are more impressive than the modest-size paintings (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

* "BETWEEN STREET AND MIRROR: THE DRAWINGS OF JAMES ENSOR," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through July 21). The show's pleasure partly involves serendipity. This feels like the perfect moment for an oddball like Ensor, but maybe any time would feel like the right time for somebody whose work, whether it is appalling or fantastic (and it can be both simultaneously), looks eternally modern. The drawings are from the 1880's and 90's. Some started out as ordinary sketches of household objects to which faces and monsters were added, like Rorschachs of the artist's imagination. They somehow become more luminous and translucent the more densely they are drawn, an extraordinary paradox. On the other hand, when the drawings aren't dense, they can be vaporous like Turners, with an effect akin to looking back on a dream: you can't quite place what you are seeing. But the emotion the images provoke is stronger precisely because of the frustration attached to it. Ensor is one of those artists Americans tend to forget or never really knew properly. A hero in Europe, he is vastly deserving of reappraisal here, and this excellent exhibition is a place to start (Michael Kimmelman).

RACHEL LEE HOVNANIAN, "Isolation Beauty," David Beitzel, 102 Prince Street, (212) 219-2863 (through July 20). In a simplifying style indebted in part to Alex Katz, Ms. Hovnanian paints the people, places and things of a comfortably privileged life. At her best, as in the nocturnal view of two white chairs under a yellow umbrella at the side of a glowing swimming pool, she conjures up a mysterious state of lonely suspension (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "COTE D'AZUR: ART, MODERNITY AND THE MYTH OF THE FRENCH RIVIERA," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through July 14). "A dream space created by artists for the 20th century" is how Kenneth E. Silver, author of the book that spawned this show, describes the French Riviera. And to prove the point, more than 70 works by 40 artists are on view, from Matisse and Picasso to the photographer Jacques-Henri Lartigue and the architect Le Corbusier and including more contemporary talents like Yves Klein and Eric Fischl. Rail access opened up the long-neglected southern coast to commerce and tourism in the 1860's, and the first artists, Renoir and Monet, arrived there in 1883 for a two-week tour. They evidently spread the word, for by the time of World War I the coast had become a mecca for artists whose palettes thrived on the dazzling quality of the light and the clear, fresh colors of the sky, water and vegetation. The Cote d'Azur's heyday is deftly covered, but one caveat: why clutter this persuasive survey, which really celebrates the coast as a garden of European modernism, with recent and peripheral works by a group of American artists? (Glueck).

TONY CRAGG, "Turbo-Ferryman," Doris C. Freedman Plaza, Fifth Avenue and 60th Street, (212) 980-4575 (through October). This year's Public Art Fund installation here consists of two bulbous bronze sculptures by a consistently interesting British sculptor. One is a perforated, biomorphic, bottlelike form with wiggly arms going in and out of its body; the other is a big, asymmetrical shape, like a toy top with odd lumpy places. In a gallery, either would be fine; outdoors, they look too small. If one or the other were five times larger, it would be terrific (Johnson).

"FACES AND FIGURES: CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHY IN SCANDINAVIA," Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, near 38th Street, (212) 779-3587 (through July 29). Nordic photography makes a good showing here with a mix of established and lesser- known talents using a range of approaches, from documentary to personal diary. The aim is to dispel stereotypes about "coolness, control and psychic remoteness" in the words of Ann Sass, chief curator. And the show succeeds, with a humanscape of transvestite haunts in Paris, high jinks in Swedish suburbs, hunting and farming in Iceland, plain folk at home in Sweden, Christmas in Finland, prostitutes plying their trade in Denmark and children frolicking in Norway (Glueck).

Last Chance

* VIJA CELMINS, McKee, 745 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, (212) 688-5951 (through today). Ms. Celmins just keeps making the same old thing: paintings that are at once rigorously formal and expansively illusory, quietly transcendental and materially sumptuous. This spare, beautifully installed exhibition features eight easel-size paintings: six of starry night skies and two of blurrily luminous spider webs. In the print room, crisp wood engravings of rippling ocean surfaces look like 19th-century illustrations for "Moby-Dick" (Johnson).

RALSTON CRAWFORD, "Phantom Forms," Laurence Miller Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-3930 (through today). This hard-edge painter often used his camera to record subjects taken up in paintings, but more often his photographs stood on their own. This small show of a dozen or so is a sampling from thousands produced by the artist over the years. His focus in most of the pictures is the play between light and shadow, as in "Buffalo" (1942), a view of the complex linear patterns cast by iron gratings and a lighting fixture on sunlit cement walls. More mysterious is "New Orleans" (circa 1961), in which a wall of peeling paint contrasts with a smooth white one. The appeal lies in the ambiguity of the hard-edge markings on the walls: shadows or substance? (Glueck).

* STEPHEN DEAN, Henry Urbach Architecture, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 627-0974 (through today). One of the most impressive debuts of the season is that of Mr. Dean, a young French-American artist whose obsession with intense, saturated color has taken him to India, where color is intrinsic to daily life. One result is "Pulse," a painterly, almost unbelievably gorgeous video of the annual spring Holi festival, when residents douse one another with colored powders and water until the streets flow with color (Smith).

"A FAMILY ALBUM: BROOKLYN COLLECTS," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Sunday). This big, uneven but frequently transcendental grab bag of an exhibition celebrates collectors of art or antiques who live in Brooklyn or come from there. Eighty-six collectors of all stripes lent some of their prized possessions. The grand, wildly pluralistic total of more than 300 items includes ancient Egyptian heads, Navajo rugs, 20th-century kitsch and 21st-century avant-gardism. The exhibition covers all the bases and includes some real masterpieces, like an early Miroesque painting by de Kooning or a vividly realistic Roman portrait of a worried-looking man from 40-20 B.C. Hours and admission: See above Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 am. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of the month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Johnson).

KEITH HARING, Skarstedt, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 79th Street, (212) 737-2060 (through tomorrow). Promiscuously generous an artist as he was, Haring was also very uneven. This exhibition of just four medium-large canvases from the early 1980's shows him at his best. Two in particular suggest the vision of a modern Bosch. Densely populated by manically interactive demons, monsters and little men, they combine graphic ingenuity, mythic narrative and erotic polymorphism to exhilarating effect (Johnson).

* SHIRIN NESHAT, Barbara Gladstone Gallery, 515 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-9300 (through today). Three videos isolate themes or devices that Ms. Neshat previously deployed in combination, to more impressive effect. The strongest video is "Possessed," which gains from its Philip Glass score and touches on the artist's main theme -- the plight of women in traditional Muslim societies. The near pitch-dark "Pulse" creates an aura of poetic ambiguity for the viewer to unravel, while "Passages" has groups of bare-headed men and chador-clad women, in separate groups, in a dramatic setting. United, these qualities succeed; divided, they are far less engaging (Smith).

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 4645 words

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT; 
Key Sections of the Decision by the United States Court of Appeals

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from yesterday's decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in the Microsoft antitrust case:
 . . . After carefully considering the voluminous record on appeal -- including the District Court's Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law, the testimony and exhibits submitted at trial, the parties' briefs, and the oral arguments before this court -- we find that some but not all of Microsoft's liability challenges have merit. Accordingly, we affirm in part and reverse in part the District Court's judgment that Microsoft violated Sec. 2 of the Sherman Act by employing anticompetitive means to maintain a monopoly in the operating system market; we reverse the District Court's determination that Microsoft violated Sec. 2 of the Sherman Act by illegally attempting to monopolize the Internet browser market; and we remand the District Court's finding that Microsoft violated Sec. 1 of the Sherman Act by unlawfully tying its browser to its operating system. Our judgment extends to the District Court's findings with respect to the state law counterparts of the plaintiffs' Sherman Act claims. 
 We also find merit in Microsoft's challenge to the Final Judgment embracing the District Court's remedial order. There are several reasons supporting this conclusion. First, the District Court's Final Judgment rests on a number of liability determinations that do not survive appellate review; therefore, the remedial order as currently fashioned cannot stand. Furthermore, we would vacate and remand the remedial order even were we to uphold the District Court's liability determinations in their entirety, because the District Court failed to hold an evidentiary hearing to address remedies-specific factual disputes.
Finally, we vacate the Final Judgment on remedies, because the trial judge engaged in impermissible ex parte contacts by holding secret interviews with members of the media and made numerous offensive comments about Microsoft officials in public statements outside of the courtroom, giving rise to an appearance of partiality. Although we find no evidence of actual bias, we hold that the actions of the trial judge seriously tainted the proceedings before the District Court and called into question the integrity of the judicial process. We are therefore constrained to vacate the Final Judgment on remedies, remand the case for reconsideration of the remedial order, and require that the case be assigned to a different trial judge on remand.

I. INTRODUCTION
B. Overview
. . . The litigation timeline in this case is hardly problematic. Indeed, it is noteworthy that a case of this magnitude and complexity has proceeded from the filing of complaints through trial to appellate decision in a mere three years.
What is somewhat problematic, however, is that just over six years have passed since Microsoft engaged in the first conduct plaintiffs allege to be anticompetitive. As the record in this case indicates, six years seems like an eternity in the computer industry. By the time a court can assess liability, firms, products, and the marketplace are likely to have changed dramatically. This, in turn, threatens enormous practical difficulties for courts considering the appropriate measure of relief in equitable enforcement actions, both in crafting injunctive remedies in the first instance and reviewing those remedies in the second. Conduct remedies may be unavailing in such cases, because innovation to a large degree has already rendered the anticompetitive conduct obsolete (although by no means harmless). And broader structural remedies present their own set of problems, including how a court goes about restoring competition to a dramatically changed, and constantly changing, marketplace. That is just one reason why we find the District Court's refusal in the present case to hold an evidentiary hearing on remedies -- to update and flesh out the available information before entertaining the possibility of structural relief -- so problematic. . . . 

II. MONOPOLIZATION
. . . We begin by considering whether Microsoft possesses monopoly power, and finding that it does, we turn to the question whether it maintained this power through anticompetitive means. Agreeing with the District Court that the company behaved anticompetitively, and that these actions contributed to the maintenance of its monopoly power, we affirm the court's finding of liability for monopolization.

A. Monopoly Power
While merely possessing monopoly power is not itself an antitrust violation, it is a necessary element of a monopolization charge. The Supreme Court defines monopoly power as "the power to control prices or exclude competition." More precisely, a firm is a monopolist if it can profitably raise prices substantially above the competitive level. Where evidence indicates that a firm has in fact profitably done so, the existence of monopoly power is clear. Because such direct proof is only rarely available, courts more typically examine market structure in search of circumstantial evidence of monopoly power. Under this structural approach, monopoly power may be inferred from a firm's possession of a dominant share of a relevant market that is protected by entry barriers. "Entry barriers" are factors that prevent new rivals from timely responding to an increase in price above the competitive level.
The District Court considered these structural factors and concluded that Microsoft possesses monopoly power in a relevant market. Defining the market as Intel-compatible PC operating systems, the District Court found that Microsoft has a greater than 95 percent share. It also found the company's market position protected by a substantial entry barrier.
Microsoft argues that the District Court incorrectly defined the relevant market. It also claims that there is no barrier to entry in that market. Alternatively, Microsoft argues that because the software industry is uniquely dynamic, direct proof, rather than circumstantial evidence, more appropriately indicates whether it possesses monopoly power. Rejecting each argument, we uphold the District Court's finding of monopoly power in its entirety.

2. Direct Proof
Having sustained the District Court's conclusion that circumstantial evidence proves that Microsoft possesses monopoly power, we turn to Microsoft's alternative argument that it does not behave like a monopolist. Claiming that software competition is uniquely "dynamic," the company suggests a new rule: that monopoly power in the software industry should be proven directly, that is, by examining a company's actual behavior to determine if it reveals the existence of monopoly power. According to Microsoft, not only does no such proof of its power exist, but record evidence demonstrates the absence of monopoly power. The company claims that it invests heavily in research and development, and charges a low price for Windows (a small percentage of the price of an Intel-compatible PC system and less than the price of its rivals.)
Microsoft's argument fails because, even assuming that the software market is uniquely dynamic in the long term, the District Court correctly applied the structural approach to determine if the company faces competition in the short term. Structural market power analyses are meant to determine whether potential substitutes constrain a firm's ability to raise prices above the competitive level; only threats that are likely to materialize in the relatively near future perform this function to any significant degree. The District Court considered and rejected Microsoft's claims that innovations such as handheld devices would soon expand the relevant market beyond Intel-compatible PC operating systems. Because the company does not challenge these findings, we have no reason to believe that prompt substitutes are available. The structural approach, as applied by the District Court, is thus capable of fulfilling its purpose even in a changing market. Microsoft cites no case, nor are we aware of one, requiring direct evidence to show monopoly power in any market. We decline to adopt such a rule now.
Even if we were to require direct proof, moreover, Microsoft's behavior may well be sufficient to show the existence of monopoly power. None of the conduct Microsoft points to -- its investment in R&D and the relatively low price of Windows -- is inconsistent with the possession of such power.

B. Anticompetitive Conduct
1. Licenses Issued
The District Court condemned a number of provisions in Microsoft's agreements licensing Windows to OEMs, because it found that Microsoft's imposition of those provisions serves to reduce usage share of Netscape's browser and, hence, protect Microsoft's operating system monopoly. . . . 

a. Anticompetitive Effect
The restrictions Microsoft places upon Original Equipment Manufacturers are of particular importance in determining browser usage share because having an OEM pre-install a browser on a computer is one of the two most cost-effective methods by far of distributing browsing software. By preventing OEMs from removing visible means of user access to IE, the license restriction prevents many OEMs from pre-installing a rival browser and, therefore, protects Microsoft's monopoly from the competition that middleware might otherwise present. Therefore, we conclude that the license restriction at issue is anticompetitive. . . . 

2. Integration of IE and Windows
b. Justifications for Integration
Microsoft proffers no justification for two of the three challenged actions that it took in integrating IE into Windows -- excluding IE from the Add/Remove Programs utility and commingling browser and operating system code. Although Microsoft does make some general claims regarding the benefits of integrating the browser and the operating system, it neither specifies nor substantiates those claims. Nor does it argue that either excluding IE from the Add/Remove Programs utility or commingling code achieves any integrative benefit. Plaintiffs plainly made out a prima facie case of harm to competition in the operating system market by demonstrating that Microsoft's actions increased its browser usage share and thus protected its operating system monopoly from a middleware threat and, for its part, Microsoft failed to meet its burden of showing that its conduct serves a purpose other than protecting its operating system monopoly. Accordingly, we hold that Microsoft's exclusion of IE from the Add/Remove Programs utility and its commingling of browser and operating system code constitute exclusionary conduct, in violation of Sec. 2. . . .

5. Java
Java, a set of technologies developed by Sun Microsystems, is another type of middleware posing a potential threat to Windows' position as the ubiquitous platform for software development. The Java technologies include: (1) a programming language; (2) a set of programs written in that language, called the "Java class libraries," which expose APIs; (3) a compiler, which translates code written by a developer into "bytecode"; and (4) a Java Virtual Machine ("JVM"), which translates bytecode into instructions to the operating system. Programs calling upon the Java APIs will run on any machine with a "Java runtime environment," that is, Java class libraries and a JVM. . . . 

c. Deception of Java Developers
Microsoft's "Java implementation" included, in addition to a JVM, a set of software development tools it created to assist ISVs in designing Java applications. The District Court found that, not only were these tools incompatible with Sun's cross-platform aspirations for Java -- no violation, to be sure, but Microsoft deceived Java developers regarding the Windows-specific nature of the tools. Microsoft's tools included "certain 'keywords' and 'compiler directives' that could only be executed properly by Microsoft's version of the Java runtime environment for Windows." As a result, even Java "developers who were opting for portability over performance . . . unwittingly wrote Java applications that ran only on Windows." That is, developers who relied upon Microsoft's public commitment to cooperate with Sun and who used Microsoft's tools to develop what Microsoft led them to believe were cross-platform applications ended up producing applications that would run only on Windows. . . .
Microsoft's conduct related to its Java developer tools served to protect its monopoly of the operating system in a manner not attributable either to the superiority of the operating system or to the acumen of its makers, and therefore was anticompetitive. Unsurprisingly, Microsoft offers no procompetitive explanation for its campaign to deceive developers. Accordingly, we conclude this conduct is exclusionary, in violation of Sec. 2 of the Sherman Act.

III. ATTEMPT TO MONOPOLIZE
Microsoft further challenges the District Court's determination of liability for "attempt ing to monopolize . . . any part of the trade or commerce among the several States." To establish a Sec. 2 violation for attempted monopolization, "a plaintiff must prove (1) that the defendant has engaged in predatory or anticompetitive conduct with (2) a specific intent to monopolize and (3) a dangerous probability of achieving monopoly power." Because a deficiency on any one of the three will defeat plaintiffs' claim, we look no further than plaintiffs' failure to prove a dangerous probability of achieving monopoly power in the putative browser market. . . . 
To establish a dangerous probability of success, plaintiffs must as a threshold matter show that the browser market can be monopolized, i.e., that a hypothetical monopolist in that market could enjoy market power. This, in turn, requires plaintiffs (1) to define the relevant market and (2) to demonstrate that substantial barriers to entry protect that market. Because plaintiffs have not carried their burden on either prong, we reverse without remand.

IV. TYING
Microsoft also contests the District Court's determination of liability under Sec. 1 of the Sherman Act. The District Court concluded that Microsoft's contractual and technological bundling of the IE web browser (the "tied" product) with its Windows operating system ("OS") (the "tying" product) resulted in a tying arrangement that was per se unlawful. We hold that the rule of reason, rather than per se analysis, should govern the legality of tying arrangements involving platform software products. . . .
There are four elements to a per se tying violation: (1) the tying and tied goods are two separate products; (2) the defendant has market power in the tying product market; (3) the defendant affords consumers no choice but to purchase the tied product from it; and (4) the tying arrangement forecloses a substantial volume of commerce. . . . 

B. Per Se Analysis Inappropriate
. . . Our judgment regarding the comparative merits of the per se rule and the rule of reason is confined to the tying arrangement before us, where the tying product is software whose major purpose is to serve as a platform for third-party applications and the tied product is complementary software functionality. While our reasoning may at times appear to have broader force, we do not have the confidence to speak to facts outside the record, which contains scant discussion of software integration generally. Microsoft's primary justification for bundling IE APIs is that their inclusion with Windows increases the value of third-party software (and Windows) to consumers.
Because this claim applies with distinct force when the tying product is platform software, we have no present basis for finding the per se rule inapplicable to software markets generally. Nor should we be interpreted as setting a precedent for switching to the rule of reason every time a court identifies an efficiency justification for a tying arrangement. Our reading of the record suggests merely that integration of new functionality into platform software is a common practice and that wooden application of per se rules in this litigation may cast a cloud over platform innovation in the market for PCs, network computers and information appliances. 

V. TRIAL AND REMEDY
C. Failure to Hold Hearing
. . . It is a cardinal principle of our system of justice that factual disputes must be heard in open court and resolved through trial-like evidentiary proceedings. Any other course would be contrary "to the spirit which imbues our judicial tribunals prohibiting decision without hearing." . . . 
The reason the court declined to conduct an evidentiary hearing was not because of the absence of disputed facts, but because it believed that those disputes could be resolved only through "actual experience," not further proceedings. But a prediction about future events is not, as a prediction, any less a factual issue. Indeed, the Supreme Court has acknowledged that drafting an antitrust decree by necessity "involves predictions and assumptions concerning future economic and business events." Trial courts are not excused from their obligation to resolve such matters through evidentiary hearings simply because they consider the bedrock procedures of our justice system to be "of little use." . . .
Plaintiffs further argue -- and the District Court held -- that no evidentiary hearing was necessary given that Microsoft long had been on notice that structural relief was a distinct possibility. It is difficult to see why this matters. Whether Microsoft had advance notice that dissolution was in the works is immaterial to whether the District Court violated the company's procedural rights by ordering it without an evidentiary hearing. To be sure, "claimed surprise at the District Court's decision to consider permanent injunctive relief does not, alone, merit reversal." But, Microsoft's professed surprise does not stand "alone." There is something more: the company's basic procedural right to have disputed facts resolved through an evidentiary hearing. 
In sum, the District Court erred when it resolved the parties' remedies-phase factual disputes by consulting only the evidence introduced during trial and plaintiffs' remedies-phase submissions, without considering the evidence Microsoft sought to introduce. We therefore vacate the District Court's final judgment, and remand with instructions to conduct a remedies-specific evidentiary hearing.

D. Adequate Explanation
We vacate the District Court's remedies decree for the additional reason that the court has failed to provide an adequate explanation for the relief it ordered. . . .

F. On Remand
. . . On remand, the District Court must reconsider whether the use of the structural remedy of divestiture is appropriate with respect to Microsoft, which argues that it is a unitary company. By and large, cases upon which plaintiffs rely in arguing for the split of Microsoft have involved the dissolution of entities formed by mergers and acquisitions. On the contrary, the Supreme Court has clarified that divestiture "has traditionally been the remedy for Sherman Act violations whose heart is intercorporate combination and control," and that " c omplete divestiture is particularly appropriate where asset or stock acquisitions violate the antitrust laws." . . .
The District Court also should consider whether plaintiffs have established a sufficient causal connection between Microsoft's anticompetitive conduct and its dominant position in the OS market. "Mere existence of an exclusionary act does not itself justify full feasible relief against the monopolist to create maximum competition." Rather, structural relief, which is "designed to eliminate the monopoly altogether . . . require s a clearer indication of a significant causal connection between the conduct and creation or maintenance of the market power." Absent such causation, the antitrust defendant's unlawful behavior should be remedied by "an injunction against continuation of that conduct." . . . 

VI. JUDICIAL MISCONDUCT
Canon 3A(6) of the Code of Conduct for United States Judges requires federal judges to "avoid public comment on the merits of pending or impending" cases. Canon 2 tells judges to "avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety in all activities," on the bench and off. Canon 3A(4) forbids judges to initiate or consider ex parte communications on the merits of pending or impending proceedings. Section 455(a) of the Judicial Code requires judges to recuse themselves when their "impartiality might reasonably be questioned."
All indications are that the District Judge violated each of these ethical precepts by talking about the case with reporters. The violations were deliberate, repeated, egregious, and flagrant. The only serious question is what consequences should follow. Microsoft urges us to disqualify the District Judge, vacate the judgment in its entirety and toss out the findings of fact, and remand for a new trial before a different District Judge. At the other extreme, plaintiffs ask us to do nothing. We agree with neither position.

A. Press Communications
Immediately after the District Judge entered final judgment on June 7, 2000, accounts of interviews with him began appearing in the press. Some of the interviews were held after he entered final judgment. The District Judge also aired his views about the case to larger audiences, giving speeches at a college and at an antitrust seminar.
From the published accounts, it is apparent that the Judge also had been giving secret interviews to select reporters before entering final judgment -- in some instances long before. . . . The Judge "embargoed" these interviews until he issued the Final Judgment. . . .

B. Violations of Code of Conduct
. . . While some of the Code's Canons frequently generate questions about their application, others are straightforward and easily understood. Canon 3A(6) is an example of the latter. In forbidding federal judges to comment publicly "on the merits of a pending or impending action," Canon 3A(6) applies to cases pending before any court, state or federal, trial or appellate. As "impending" indicates, the prohibition begins even before a case enters the court system, when there is reason to believe a case may be filed. An action remains "pending" until "completion of the appellate process.".
The Microsoft case was "pending" during every one of the District Judge's meetings with reporters; the case is "pending" now; and even after our decision issues, it will remain pending for some time. The District Judge breached his ethical duty under Canon 3A(6) each time he spoke to a reporter about the merits of the case. Although the reporters interviewed him in private, his comments were public. Court was not in session and his discussion of the case took place outside the presence of the parties. He provided his views not to court personnel assisting him in the case, but to members of the public. And these were not just any members of the public. Because he was talking to reporters, the Judge knew his comments would eventually receive widespread dissemination. 
It is clear that the District Judge was not discussing purely procedural matters, which are a permissible subject of public comment under one of the Canon's three narrowly drawn exceptions. He disclosed his views on the factual and legal matters at the heart of the case. His opinions about the credibility of witnesses, the validity of legal theories, the culpability of the defendant, the choice of remedy, and so forth all dealt with the merits of the action. It is no excuse that the Judge may have intended to "educate" the public about the case or to rebut "public misperceptions" purportedly caused by the parties. If those were his intentions, he could have addressed the factual and legal issues as he saw them -- and thought the public should see them -- in his Findings of Fact, Conclusions of Law, Final Judgment, or in a written opinion. Or he could have held his tongue until all appeals were concluded. 
Far from mitigating his conduct, the District Judge's insistence on secrecy -- his embargo -- made matters worse. Concealment of the interviews suggests knowledge of their impropriety. Concealment also prevented the parties from nipping his improprieties in the bud. . . . 
Another point needs to be stressed. Rulings in this case have potentially huge financial consequences for one of the nation's largest publicly-traded companies and its investors. The District Judge's secret interviews during the trial provided a select few with inside information about the case, information that enabled them and anyone they shared it with to anticipate rulings before the Judge announced them to the world. Although he "embargoed" his comments, the Judge had no way of policing the reporters. For all he knew there may have been trading on the basis of the information he secretly conveyed. The public cannot be expected to maintain confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the federal judiciary in the face of such conduct. 

C. Appearance of Partiality
. . . We recognize that it would be extraordinary to disqualify a judge for bias or appearance of partiality when his remarks arguably reflected what he learned, or what he thought he learned, during the proceedings. But this "extrajudicial source" rule has no bearing on the case before us. The problem here is not just what the District Judge said, but to whom he said it and when. His crude characterizations of Microsoft, his frequent denigrations of Bill Gates, his mule trainer analogy as a reason for his remedy -- all of these remarks and others might not have given rise to a violation of the Canons or of Sec. 455(a) had he uttered them from the bench. But then Microsoft would have had an opportunity to object, perhaps even to persuade, and the Judge would have made a record for review on appeal.

D. Remedies
1. Disqualification
. . . Although the violations of the Code of Conduct and Sec. 455(a) were serious, full retroactive disqualification is unnecessary. It would unduly penalize plaintiffs, who were innocent and unaware of the misconduct, and would have only slight marginal deterrent effect. 
Most important, full retroactive disqualification is unnecessary to protect Microsoft's right to an impartial adjudication. The District Judge's conduct destroyed the appearance of impartiality. Microsoft neither alleged nor demonstrated that it rose to the level of actual bias or prejudice. There is no reason to presume that everything the District Judge did is suspect. Although Microsoft challenged very few of the findings as clearly erroneous, we have carefully reviewed the entire record and discern no basis to suppose that actual bias infected his factual findings. The most serious judicial misconduct occurred near or during the remedial stage. It is therefore commensurate that our remedy focus on that stage of the case. . . . 

2. Review of Findings and Conclusions
Given the limited scope of our disqualification of the District Judge, we have let stand for review his Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law. The severity of the District Judge's misconduct and the appearance of partiality it created have led us to consider whether we can and should subject his fact-findings to greater scrutiny. We have rejected any such approach. The Federal Rules require that District Court findings of fact not be set aside unless they are clearly erroneous.
. . . Thus, although Microsoft alleged only appearance of bias, not actual bias, we have reviewed the record with care and have discerned no evidence of actual bias.

Terms of the Trade

API -- Application programming interfaces, the links between applications programs and the operating system.

IE -- Internet Explorer, Microsoft's browser.

ISV -- Independent software vendor.

OEM -- Original equipment manufacturer (PC maker).

OS -- Operating system.

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 1078 words

HEADLINE: 2 Election Finance Bills Go to House Floor 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28 

 BODY:
Drawing sharp battle lines over the overhaul of the campaign finance law, House Republican leaders put their might today behind a bill that would limit certain contributions but stops short of the comprehensive overhaul of the campaign finance law that passed the Senate. 
 The measure, sponsored by Representative Bob Ney, Republican of Ohio, was sent to the House floor on a party-line vote by the House Administration Committee, setting up a showdown on the issue when Congress returns from a July 4 recess. 
 Republican leaders hope that Mr. Ney's bill can defeat a broader campaign finance bill, modeled after the Senate measure, that is sponsored by Representatives Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, and Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts. And House Republican leaders began working hard today to rally support for Mr. Ney's bill. 
Mr. Shays and Mr. Meehan also introduced their own measure, including concessions that they hoped would keep blacks and Hispanics and liberals from bolting their coalition. Their bill, which has at its heart a ban on unregulated donations to the national political parties known as soft money, was also reported from the committee today, but with an unfavorable recommendation.
The action setting up dueling bills came nearly three months after the Senate passed a broad overhaul of the campaign finance law sponsored by Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, that put within reach the most comprehensive change in the law since the Watergate era.
The House passed the Shays-Meehan legislation in both 1998 and 1999 knowing that it would die in a Republican-led Senate filibuster. Now the House could be pivotal. 
"We've never ever been this close," Mr. Meehan said today. "So the stakes are very, very high."
With the outcome of the House struggle uncertain, the tug of war for votes intensified. Representative Dick Armey, the majority leader from Texas, held a series of private "listening sessions" with Republicans throughout the day to gather support for Mr. Ney's approach. Republican press secretaries were summoned by the Republican leadership staff members and given talking points on the issue designed to increase support for Mr. Ney's bill.
Both parties have raced to raise as much soft money as they can this year, given the possibility of a legislative ban on the unrestricted checks from corporations, labor unions and wealthy individuals. On Wednesday night, Congressional Republicans raised $20 million, the bulk of it in soft-money checks, at a gala featuring President Bush.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois endorsed Mr. Ney's bill in principle and spoke out against the Shays-Meehan measure, saying it would hurt the parties.
"What I don't want to do is dismantle the state party system," Mr. Hastert said.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, was battling to rally Democrats around the Shays-Meehan bill. In a sign of continuing restiveness in his ranks, Mr. Gephardt said, "I guess we've had 25 meetings in the last three or four weeks on this bill and we'll have many more before it's over."
Mr. McCain has also jumped into the fray, sending letters to 24 House Republicans he had campaigned for in the fall and urging support for the Shays-Meehan bill. In a letter to Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr. of Florida, who just squeaked back into office last year, Mr. McCain reminded him of their appearance together and said, "I remember our personal conversation about our shared passion for reform."
He added, "Now you have the opportunity to fulfill the campaign promise you and I made together in West Palm Beach."
Mr. Shaw had never supported the overhaul effort in the past but in his appearance with Mr. McCain said, "I've had a change of heart as to the intensity of the problem."
Today, Mr. Shaw said he thought Mr. Ney had the better bill and that he had never committed to support Mr. McCain. "I'm not going to be bullied into any position," he said.
The rival bills differ significantly. 
Mr. Shays and Mr. Meehan have been struggling to draw up a bill close enough to the Senate one that they can avoid having to reconcile differences between the two chambers in a conference committee. Such a committee, they said, would give Republican leaders another chance to kill the overhaul effort. Like the Senate version, their bill would ban unregulated soft money contributions to the national political parties and rein in issue-advertising by outside groups near an elections.
But they also made some changes in their bill from the Senate measure in hopes of winning dissident Democrats who opposed the Senate's move to raise the limits on how much an individual can give to a federal candidate to $2,000 an election, from the current $1,000. The Senate would also allow increases for inflation.
Mr. Shays and Mr. Meehan's bill would allow the $2,000 limit for Senate and presidential candidates, but keep the $1,000 ceiling for House candidates and adjust it for inflation. That brought some Democrats back on board, like Representative Sam Farr of California.
"We keep the credibility that it's a reform bill," Mr. Farr said.
To woo black and Hispanic lawmakers, Mr. Shays and Mr. Meehan decided to keep in place a little-noticed late amendment to the Senate bill that allows state political parties to accept donations of up to $10,000 a year from corporations, unions and individuals for such efforts as getting out the vote. 
Mr. Ney, by contrast, would cap soft money contributions at no more than $75,000 a year to the national political parties but leave such contributions to state parties unlimited.
In a bid for the support of black and Hispanic lawmakers who fear that a soft-money ban would hinder efforts to register minorities to vote, Mr. Ney would restrict the use of such contributions primarily to registration and efforts to get out the vote and bar the money from being used for television commercials. He would place no limits on advertising on campaign issues by outside groups, but require greater disclosure on sponsorship.
In another appeal to Democrats, Mr. Ney would keep in place the $1,000 limit on individual donations to federal candidates. 
Saying he was making headway over his rivals, Mr. Ney said, "Their coalition is falling apart."
He said that one member of the Congressional Black Caucus, Representative Albert Wynn, Democrat of Maryland, was supporting his bill.

HEADLINE: Brooks Bros. Expected to Get Discount Bids 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
It is summer clearance time, and everything at Brooks Brothers is on sale.
 Brooks Brothers, the retailer of classic American men's wear that popularized the button-down collar, is being sold in its entirety by Marks & Spencer, a flagship of British retailing that is retrenching because of financial troubles. 
 Marks & Spencer paid $750 million to Allied Stores for Brooks Brothers in 1988 and now hopes to sell it for a third less, or $500 million. 
Preliminary bids were due yesterday, according to executives close to the auction. 
The auction could be completed at a fire sale price, some industry executives said, noting that business has sagged and the economy is weak. Though Brooks Brothers is a solid brand and is said to be profitable, it has a staid image as a maker of boxy men's suits, while American tastes have shifted to more fashionable and more casual clothes.
Executives who have seen the offering materials said they expected the retailer to fetch no more than $400 million.
They said the companies that had submitted bids or were still considering an offer late yesterday included May Department Stores, which operates Lord & Taylor; Men's Wearhouse; the Della Valle Group, which already has a franchise agreement for Brooks Brothers in Italy; Luxottica, which owns the Sunglass Hut chain and makes eyewear for Brooks Brothers; the Texas Pacific Group, a buyout firm that owns J. Crew and Bally; and Dickson Concepts International, which operates Brooks Brothers franchises in Southeast Asia.
Spokesmen for the companies declined to comment or could not be reached yesterday. Morgan Stanley is managing the auction for Marks & Spencer.
May Department Stores is perhaps the leading candidate, stock analysts said. The company could keep the existing 220 Brooks Brothers stores worldwide and use the brand as a private label throughout its other stores, they suggested.
"Obviously, May has been looking at specialty stores," said Shari Schwartzman Eberts, a senior analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. Last year, May acquired David's Bridal, another specialty chain. "The Brooks name is very strong," she said, "and to the extent that they can provide an exclusive brand to their customers, it could work."
Nordstrom made a somewhat similar move last year by acquiring one of its long-time suppliers, Faconnable, which now provides private-label merchandise. Faconnable has a few retail stores in the United States and dozens of shops in Europe and Asia.
A New York mainstay with 80 stores and 72 outlets in the United States as well as 77 shops in Asia, Brooks Brothers was begun by Henry Sands Brooks as H.& D. H. Brooks & Company on the corner of Catherine Street and Cherry Street in Manhattan in 1818.
It was sold in 1946 to Garfinkel-Rhoads, a Washington chain of specialty stores, which took Brooks Brothers nationwide. Garfinkel and Brooks Brothers were swallowed up in 1980 by Allied Stores, which sold Brooks Brothers in 1988 to Marks & Spencer.
Last month, Marks & Spencer reported its third consecutive decline in full-year earnings. The sale of Brooks Brothers is part of a revamping plan Marks & Spencer announced in March. Marks & Spencer is retreating to Britain, where it has about 300 stores, abandoning stores in France, Germany, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Portugal and Spain, which posted a combined operating loss of more than $28.7 million last year. It also plans to sell Kings Supermarkets, a chain of 25 stores based in New Jersey.
Brooks Brothers' operating profit was only 4.5 percent of sales in 2000 and 2 percent in 1999, said executives who have seen the books. A price of $400 million would peg the company at 10 times its cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and other items. 
Though J. Crew and other retailers sold for such a multiple in 1997, the economic climate has since deteriorated. 
Brooks Brothers, too, has struggled to redefine itself for a younger audience.
"They have such a well-defined traditional business that it's been difficult for them to broaden it," said Walter F. Loeb, publisher of a retail industry newsletter bearing his name. "The truth is that the clothing business is in decline."
