HEADLINE: In Slap at Bush, House Votes to Bar Oil Drilling in Great Lakes 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28 

 BODY:
In another slap at President Bush's energy and environment policies, the House of Representatives voted today to prohibit drilling for oil and gas in the Great Lakes.
 The president has not taken a specific stand on exploration in the Great Lakes, but his energy policy is based on increasing domestic oil and gas production. 
 Last week, the House voted to ban drilling in the Gulf of Mexico off Florida and on the grounds of national monuments. And Congress has shown little interest in adopting the president's plan to drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. 
Although the Great Lakes prohibition had considerable Republican support, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, left no doubt this was a partisan matter.
"The Democrat leadership is constraining our economy," Mr. DeLay said, in an "energy straitjacket."
He accused Democrats of trying to "choke off every promising source of domestic energy" and added, "Their actual objective must be to eradicate America's energy security."
But Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip, said the main issue was protection of the environment.
"We depend for our drinking water, our recreation, the engine of our economy on the water in the Great Lakes," Mr. Bonior said. "We cannot afford to put our greatest natural resource at risk."
At the White House today, Ari Fleischer, the press secretary, said: "There is nothing in the president's energy plan that deals with the Great Lakes. That's a state matter."
Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican and a Bush loyalist, is a strong proponent of exploring for oil and gas in the Great Lakes. He is not running for re-election, and Mr. Bonior is running to succeed him.
The prohibition against drilling in the Great Lakes was approved, 265 to 157, as an amendment to a bill that would allocate $23.7 billion in the next fiscal year for energy and water development projects. The overall bill passed by a vote of 405 to 15.
Seventy Republicans, one-third of those who voted, joined nearly all the Democrats in voting to block Great Lakes drilling. Among those in favor were 4 of the 7 Republicans from Michigan, 6 of the 11 from Ohio and 6 of the 10 from Illinois.
Democrats obviously feel they have found a good issue on which to contest Mr. Bush. The latest New York Times/CBS News survey found that more than two-thirds of respondents favored energy conservation over increasing production.
The bill illustrated the difficulty the president will have this year in holding down spending on popular programs. It would allocate $4.7 billion for the Army Corps of Engineers' water projects, $568 million, or 16 percent, more than Mr. Bush requested.
The measure also provided a stage for airing regional differences.
For instance, Representative Tom Tancredo, Republican of Colorado, a state not known for its seashore, offered an amendment that would have limited spending for beach restoration. The proposal was strongly opposed by lawmakers from coastal states and was handily defeated.
Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a Democrat from upstate New York, where there are no nuclear weapons laboratories, tried to transfer $60 million from weapons research into projects for solar, wind and geothermal energy. But Mr. Hinchey also lost in the face of opposition from lawmakers from states like New Mexico and Tennessee, where there are large laboratories.
The biggest fight in this regard was over a section in the bill that would eliminate all money for processing federal permits for a gas pipeline that would begin in Alabama and run 750 miles into Florida. The section was inserted by Representative Sonny Callahan, an Alabama Republican who is chairman of the energy and water development subcommittee.
The matter has little practical significance. For one thing, the permits for the pipeline have already been issued. For another, Representative C. W. Bill Young, a Republican from the Gulf Coast of Florida, is chairman of the Appropriations Committee and will be chairman of the House-Senate conference committee that will write the final energy and water legislation. Mr. Young made it clear today that the pipeline section would not survive in conference.
But the debate threw into a spotlight the regional split on energy development and the environment.
Mr. Callahan conceded that he had put the section in the bill because his nose was out of joint over the vote last Thursday blocking oil and gas drilling off the Florida Gulf coast. Florida lawmakers from both parties oppose such drilling, but Mr. Callahan, like most other lawmakers from Alabama, Louisiana and Texas, favors it.
Six of Alabama's seven representatives were absent for the June 21 vote because they were with President Bush, who was giving a speech in Birmingham on energy conservation and could not "be here to defend ourselves," Mr. Callahan said.

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE OVERVIEW; 
APPEALS COURT VOIDS ORDER FOR BREAKING UP MICROSOFT BUT FINDS IT ABUSED POWER

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28 

 BODY:
A federal appeals court unanimously threw out a lower court's order today that the Microsoft Corporation should be broken up, although the appeals court found that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in the software business. 
 The appeals court also sharply chastised the district judge who oversaw the Microsoft antitrust trial and removed him from any further involvement in the case because of derogatory comments he made to reporters about the company and its senior executives. 
 The unsigned opinion was welcomed by Microsoft, which is no longer under immediate threat of being split into two companies. The company is already preparing the release of a new version of the Windows software operating system, which has features that industry executives say could further consolidate Microsoft's dominance of the personal computer software market. Page C1. 
But the opinion was also hailed by federal and state officials for affirming the principle that Microsoft had bullied smaller software rivals, computer makers and other large companies like the chip maker Intel, and had broken the law in ways that stifled competition.
Among other companies in the computer industry, reaction was muted, as many executives said they needed time to study the opinion.
Justice Department officials, some state attorneys general, and Microsoft executives said today that they had not decided what they would do next -- although Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, said he hoped the ruling might open the way to new settlement talks. 
The parties now have three options:
*They can appeal to the Supreme Court. 
*They can proceed to a new trial before a different district judge to consider some of the unresolved antitrust liability questions and reconsider an appropriate remedy. 
*Or they can reopen settlement negotiations, which failed during the Clinton administration but which Microsoft executives hope can be rekindled with the new leadership at the Justice Department.
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said that President Bush had been told of the decision this morning and would now await guidance from the Justice Department about how to proceed. 
Officials at the Justice Department said they were pleased but had not decided which avenue to pursue.
"We believe this is a significant victory in terms of the determination made by a unanimous court that Microsoft had engaged in unlawful conduct," Attorney General John Ashcroft said at a news conference this afternoon. "But I'm not prepared at this time to indicate what the final outcome to be pursued on the part of the Justice Department is. We'll shape our response to the decision after we have more time to digest it."
Executives at Microsoft, who have courted the new administration, said they were pleased by the decision.
"The sun was definitely shining today," Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, said in a telephone conference call with reporters. "Today's ruling goes a long way toward positively resolving this matter for Microsoft, our partners, our customers and shareholders. It lifts the breakup cloud from the company."
Mr. Gates, the company's co-founder, expressed hopes for a settlement. "With this ruling, there is a new framework," Mr. Gates said in a news conference, "and so it would be a good time for all parties involved to sit down together and see what kind of resolution can be worked out." 
The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled that Microsoft had violated Section 2 of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
The company, the judges found, had illegally used its monopoly position in the personal computer operating systems market through a series of anticompetitive license restrictions and other agreements with computer makers, software vendors and Internet service providers. 
But the court dismissed a central accusation by the government that Microsoft had attempted to monopolize the market for Internet browser software. And on a third count -- that the company had improperly tied its Explorer browser to its operating system -- the court said Judge Jackson had used the wrong legal standard and sent the case back down for further consideration before a different district court judge.
Without reaching a conclusion about the correct remedy, the appeals court suggested that a breakup of Microsoft would be inappropriate even if the trial judge found more evidence of antitrust violations. The court noted that a dissolution of a company found guilty of such violations was normally reserved for businesses -- unlike Microsoft -- that have grown through mergers and acquisitions. 
"Divestiture is a remedy that is imposed only with great caution, in part because its long-term efficacy is rarely certain," the court said. "If the court on remand is unconvinced of the causal connection between Microsoft's exclusionary conduct and the company's position in the operating systems market, it may well conclude that divestiture is not an appropriate remedy."
Short of a breakup, a court can impose a wide array of restrictions or remedies on Microsoft in an effort to prevent future antitrust violations. Such measures might include setting rules for the company's licensing deals or requiring Microsoft to offer stripped-down versions of its operating system. A court could also require the company to license its Windows software code so that other companies could produce their own competing versions. 
But the company's strongest critics have contended that nothing short of a Microsoft breakup could assure that the software market remain vibrant. That view was ultimately adopted by the Clinton administration. It filed the antitrust case in May 1998 after concluding that Microsoft had violated the terms of an earlier consent decree meant to keep the company from engaging in anticompetitive activity.
But the breakup stance has been criticized by some advisers to President Bush. And the court said that because the trial judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, never held a hearing about the breakup order or properly explained its basis, the order had to be reversed. 
The court also said that Judge Jackson had violated three judicial canons by discussing the case with reporters from several news organizations, including The New York Times, while he was considering the case. In those interviews, Judge Jackson spoke extensively about his views of the case, accused Mr. Gates of having "a Napoleonic concept of himself" and compared Microsoft's incriminating e-mails to intercepted conversations by drug traffickers who "never figure out that they shouldn't be saying certain things on the phone."
The appeals judges said Judge Jackson's ethical violations "were deliberate, repeated, egregious and flagrant" and that public confidence in the judicial process cannot survive when judges "pander to the press."
"Judge Learned Hand spoke of 'this America of ours where the passion for publicity is a disease, and where swarms of foolish, tawdry moths dash with rapture into its consuming fire,' " the court of appeals wrote. "Judges are obligated to resist this passion."
Judge Jackson did not return repeated calls to his chambers today seeking comment. Nor did Joel I. Klein, the former senior Justice Department official who was the architect of the government's case. Mr. Klein is now a senior executive for the United States operations of the German media giant Bertelsmann.
Investors reacted positively to the decision. Shares of Microsoft reached a high of $76.15 before closing at $72.74, up $1.60, or 2.25 percent.
Today's opinion was issued by seven appeals court judges: Harry T. Edwards, Stephen F. Williams, Douglas H. Ginsburg, David B. Sentelle, A. Raymond Randolph, Judith W. Rogers, and David S. Tatel. Three other appeals judges on the court removed themselves from the case without explanation.
For the government, the strongest portion of today's opinion was an examination of the accusations that Microsoft had repeatedly violated Section 2 of the Sherman Act by illegally maintaining a monopoly.
The court found that Microsoft had engaged in anticompetitive behavior by imposing license restrictions on computer makers that forced them to install the company's Internet Explorer browser and exclude rival Netscape's Navigator browser.
It found similar agreements with Internet providers like America Online had also violated Section 2. And the court concluded that Microsoft had violated Section 2 by threatening Apple Computer that it would cancel work on a suite of Office applications for Apple's own operating system unless Apple made greater use of the Microsoft browser. 
Finally, the court said that Microsoft had violated Section 2 by threatening Intel by refusing to deliver Intel technologies bundled with the Windows operating system. At the time, Intel was developing computer technology based on the Java operating system, which was viewed as a potential competitor to Microsoft Windows. But Intel capitulated under pressure from Microsoft.
Aside from the court's throwing out the breakup order, the biggest win for Microsoft was the court's decision to reverse Judge Jackson's finding that Microsoft had "attempted to monopolize" the browser market in violation of Section 2. 
The government also suffered a setback in its argument that the company had illegally "tied" the Internet Explorer browser to its Windows operating system in violation of Section 1 of the Sherman Act.
Judge Jackson had found that such tying was automatically illegal. But the appeals court said that the trial court should not use an automatic standard but a so-called rule of reason, which required an analysis of the economic and competitive impact of the melding of the browser and the operating system. Such a standard is generally considered to be more favorable to defendants.
The case began in the summer of 1994 when the Justice Department filed a lawsuit accusing Microsoft of unlawfully maintaining a monopoly in the operating system market through improper licensing and software development agreements. That suit was settled with a consent decree.
But three years later, the government filed a civil contempt action against Microsoft, accusing the company of violating a provision of the decree that the government said prohibited the company from binding its Internet Explorer browser to its Windows operating system.
In May 1998, the government and a group of states filed a separate broader complaint asserting a raft of antitrust violations.
Mindful that technology was moving far more rapidly than the courts, Judge Jackson put the case on a fast track, abbreviating testimony and limiting evidence. He completed the trial after 76 days of hearings and issued broad findings that the company had repeatedly violated the antitrust laws. 
After the failure of settlement talks conducted at Judge Jackson's request by a federal appeals judge, Richard A. Posner, Judge Jackson ordered Microsoft split into two companies -- one for its operating system and another for the various software applications it develops. 
But Judge Jackson stayed his order to allow Microsoft time to appeal the decision, leading to yesterday's action by the appeals court.

GRAPHIC: Photos: William H. Gates said yesterday he hoped for new settlement talks. (Reuters)(pg. A1); Seven members of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled unanimously in overturning the order to break up Microsoft. Three other judges removed themselves from the case. (Associated Press)(pg. C7) Chart: "The Issues and the Findings"The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit issued an opinion yesterday that threw out a lower court's decision to break up Microsoft. But the opinion did find that Microsoft had violated antitrust law. ISSUE: Monopoly maintenanceBACKGROUND: For a company to be a monopoly, it must have the power to control prices or exclude competition. For the monopoly to be illegal, the company must have acquired the power by keeping out other companies, rather than by having better products or a better business strategy. In the Microsoft case, the market in question consists of personal computer operating systems that rely chiefly on Intel's microprocessor chips.THE APPEALS COURT'S FINDINGS: The opinion agreed with Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that Microsoft had illegally used its monopoly through a series of licensing restrictions imposed on computer and software makers and Internet service providers. The court dismissed Microsoft's claim that the government needed to, and failed to, show a direct link between the company's anticompetitive behavior and its monopoly. "Suffice it to say that it would be inimical to the purpose of the Sherman Act to allow monopolists free rein to squash nascent, albeit unproven, competitors at will--particularly in industries marked by rapid technological advance and frequent paradigm shifts." ISSUE: Attempted monopolyBACKGROUND: Besides the question of whether Microsoft held a monopoly in operating systems, the government also sought to prove that the company tried to create a new monopoly in Internet browsers. Judge Jackson ruled in the government's favor, finding that Microsoft tried to use its operating system to force customers to use its browser.THE APPEALS COURT'S FINDINGS: The judges overturned this finding outright. The ruling said that government lawyers had not properly defined what the relevant market was and that they had not proved the browser market had significant barriers to entry. ISSUE: Linking productsBACKGROUND: When evaluating whether companies have violated the law by tying two or more of their products together, courts may use one of two standards. The first, called a per se analysis, holds that the linking of separate products is automatically illegal. The second, called the rule of reason, is more subjective, allowing a company to explain the economic benefits of a tie-in.THE APPEALS COURT'S FINDINGS: Using the per se analysis, Judge Jackson found Microsoft liable for the bundling of its Internet browser with its operating system. The appellate judges rejected this finding, saying the rule-of-reason standard was more appropriate, given the uncertain nature of the software business. "While every 'business relationship' will in some sense have unique features, some represent entire, novel categories of dealings," the judges wrote. This is one such case, they said, and as a result there is not sufficient evidence that Microsoft's actions hurt consumers. Barring a settlement or the Supreme Court's reversal of this ruling, a new district court judge will reconsider the issue, using the rule of reason. ISSUE: The case's timing and outcomeBACKGROUND: Judge Jackson created an unusually fast timeline for the Microsoft case, saying that the rapidly changing technology industry could not wait years for a decision. At the end of the trial, Judge Jackson ordered the breakup of Microsoft into two separate companies: one to sell the operating system and another to sell the remaining software.THE APPEALS COURT'S FINDINGS: The judges found no fault with the case's timeline. But they vacated the breakup order for three reasons. First, Microsoft had not had a chance to dispute key facts because Judge Jackson had not held an evidentiary hearing about the breakup. Second, Judge Jackson did not offer sufficient reason for a breakup. Third, he did not say whether the only government accusation still intact -- monopoly maintenance -- was enough to warrant a breakup. The panel also suggested that it believed a breakup was not the right remedy for a company that grew on its own, rather than through mergers. ISSUE: The judge's behaviorBACKGROUND: In the months since the original trial ended, a number of publications, including The New York Times, have printed interviews with Judge Jackson in which he criticized Microsoft's handling of the case and William H. Gates, the company's chairman. The judge gave the interviews before he issued his ruling, under the condition that they not be printed until afterward.THE APPEALS COURT'S FINDINGS: Citing the code of conduct for federal judges, and its ban on judges' commenting publicly on pending cases, the appellate panel harshly criticized Judge Jackson and removed him from the case. His violations of the code, the panel said, "were deliberate, repeated, egregious and flagrant." But the court rejected Microsoft's request that all of his findings be overturned. (pg. C7)

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE COMPANY; 
After 3 Years of Foreboding, A Light New Mood at Microsoft

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., June 28 

 BODY:
The weather is always a good source of conversation here in the Seattle area, and Microsoft officials liberally invoked meteorological analogies today in offering generally jubilant reactions to the appeals court ruling in the antitrust battle with the federal government.
 "I'm sure you'll understand if you live in Seattle the feeling of the sunshine breaking through, and all of us at Microsoft see this as the sunshine we've been waiting for," said Jeff Raikes, group vice president of the company's productivity and business services group. 
 William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, speaking to reporters here, said, "The ruling lifts the cloud of breakup over the company."
And from Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive, who interrupted a vacation in Northern California to hail the ruling by speaker phone: "The sun was definitely shining a little bit in Seattle, and also here on Lake Shasta." 
After more than three years of mostly cloudy weather on the legal front, Microsoft saw good news in today's appellate ruling by seven federal judges, who threw out some of the trial court rulings and halted its ordered breakup of the company.
Even as analysts cautioned that the case was far from over and that today's decision was far from an outright victory for the company, a sense of quiet elation seemed to stretch across much of Microsoft's corporate campus here on the other side of Lake Washington from Seattle.
"Well, we haven't been running around the halls screaming, opening bottles of Champagne, anything like that," said Ori Amiga, 23, a program manager in the company's .Net division. "But definitely people are walking around to each other's offices, exchanging e-mail, and in general it's a congratulatory sense."
The news first reached K. D. Hallman at 8:36 a.m. "My heart started beating and I couldn't wait to get into work and start reading the ruling," said Ms. Hallman, general manager of Microsoft's natural language group, which develops technology to help computers recognize and interpret human language. She heard a radio summary of the ruling that made things sound especially upbeat for the company. "I'd say the mood here is mostly very happy, very positive," Ms. Hallman said, "but I wish the whole thing had been resolved."
Mr. Gates and other top executives emphasized that sentiment. "It's a good time for all the parties involved to sit down and see what kind of resolution could be worked out," said Mr. Gates, who co-founded the company 26 years ago and now holds the titles of chairman and chief software architect. "It's absolutely worth making an effort there."
At times, Mr. Gates struck a tone sounding almost as if the case had been concluded, which it certainly is not -- the appeals judges found that Microsoft had engaged in illegal monopolistic practices and they ordered a new trial judge to decide what penalties it should face. 
Nonetheless, he responded as if his company had been exonerated. "The legal process can be hard on anyone who goes through it," Mr. Gates said. "The last four years have been challenging for all of us here at Microsoft, and for me personally. But despite the many twists and turns of the case, I have always had faith in our company, in our employees and in the magic of the software we're creating."
The upbeat mood here seemed to carry over to the state's Congressional delegation -- generally staunch defenders of the hometown software company. "This is a victory for creativity, for competition, for consumers and for the U.S. high-tech industry," Senator Patty Murray said. 
Microsoft competitors and other public officials offered starkly different characterizations of the ruling, saying it would help keep Microsoft from attaching anticompetitive features to its new Windows XP software and its Hailstorm system for linking a range of online services, from financial to entertainment.
Mike Pettit, president of ProComp, a trade association representing many Microsoft competitors, told The Associated Press: "Contrary to what Mr. Gates said, the court did not give Microsoft a green light to bolt any products together that they want. An awful lot of what Microsoft is trying to do with its Hailstorm and XP was ruled illegal by the court. They press ahead at their peril."
Seattle's mayor, Paul Schell, remarked: "The decision arrived at unanimously today by the federal court of appeals is very good news -- for our region and our state, for the high-tech economy and for consumers nationwide. My hope is that this case will now move along to a swift conclusion."
And Eric Liu, vice president for corporate communications at RealNetworks of Seattle, which pioneered audio and video software for the Internet, said: "This ruling lays out some important rules of acceptable conduct. While we have never built our strategy around expectations of any legal or regulatory actions, a detailed reading of today's ruling shows that it's a positive development for the industry and for consumers."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Toyota and Peugeot in Pact To Produce Car for Europe

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 29 

 BODY:
Toyota Motor of Japan and PSA Peugeot Citroen of France announced today that they would jointly develop and build a small fuel-efficient car for the European market.
 The companies said they expected to sign a formal agreement in July and announce details then. 
 Japanese news reports said that if the deal went through, the companies intended to build 300,000 of the small cars a year, sharing a common platform, or underbody. 
The benefits for Toyota would be an expansion of its model lineup in Europe beyond the Yaris, a subcompact known in Japan as the Vitz. The Yaris competes in Europe with market leaders like the Volkswagen Golf; Toyota has been manufacturing it at Valenciennes, in northern France, since January.
For Peugeot, the advantages would appear to lie in gaining a new small car below its Citroen Saxo and Peugeot 106 models while sharing the development costs with Toyota.
Bertrand Bellanger, a Toyota spokesman in France, said the companies were studying sites for a joint factory, including spots in Eastern Europe and the new Toyota factory at Valenciennes. But he also said that an Eastern European country, possibly Poland, appeared to be the probable choice because of cost advantages like low wages and Poland's expected entry into the European Union, which has eliminated trade barriers.
Toyota will deploy the new small car, for predominantly city use, as part of its effort to widen its market share in Europe, which at 3.7 percent is less than half its share in the United States. Though relatively strong in Britain and Germany, Toyota has lagged in other big markets like Italy and France. 
To overcome that weakness, Toyota opened the $570 million factory at Valenciennes where it makes the Yaris. Sales have been so strong that Fujio Cho, the president of Toyota, announced this month that Toyota would raise production to 180,000 cars a year, from 150,000. From January to May, Toyota lifted its European market share to 3.7 percent, from 3.6 percent in the corresponding period last year, even as the overall European market contracted by 3.3 percent.
For Peugeot, the deal is typical of the kind of industrial alliances it has pursued over the years to cut costs and gain economies of scale while sitting out the round of mergers and acquisitions that swept the global automobile industry.
Earlier this year, for instance, Jean-Martin Folz, the chairman of Peugeot, announced a similar agreement with Ford to cooperate in developing and building diesel engines. That agreement followed older and tested alliances with Fiat of Italy and Renault, Peugeot's domestic rival, to develop and manufacture components and entire vehicles. 
Marc Ferrant, a Peugeot spokesman, said the new model would be sold under Peugeot's two brands, Peugeot and Citroen.
Adam Collins, an analyst with Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, called the agreement "a helpful step to achieve greater economies of scale, without the irritations of being in a full-blown alliance."
Peugeot's strategy has yielded considerable success. Peugeot has overtaken larger rivals like Ford and General Motors to capture the second-largest share of the European market, after Volkswagen.

HEADLINE: Town Immortalized by Art Is Divided Over Industry; 
Can Culture and Factories Coexist on the River?

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HUDSON, N.Y. 

 BODY:
The tourism industry has worked hard in recent years to cast the Hudson River Valley as a ruddy-cheeked play land of nature, history, art and cute-as-a-button Victorian bed-and-breakfast hotels.
 But here in this old factory town 100 miles north of New York, you see the grittier truth: The Hudson Valley was also the nation's first industrial heartland. 
 Before River Rouge and Pittsburgh steel, before Chicago had shoulders, the mills of the mighty Hudson roared and belched their fire. The lush 19th-century landscape paintings of the Hudson River School and the clattering engines of the steam age grew up side by side in places like this. Whether art and industry can coexist again on the modern river, many residents here say, is now the question. 
A proposal for a huge new cement plant, in a town where cement-making roots run deep -- but where art galleries and antiques shops drive the new economy -- has deeply divided Hudson along lines of class, culture and, to no small degree, aesthetics. Would the plant destroy the town's charm, and so too its emerging tourist economy, or would the return of big cement be a restoration, a sign that old heavy-industry Hudson is on its way back? What is the value of the town's most celebrated and frequently depicted artistic motif, the view of Mount Merino? And who derives the benefit from that view, the old families that built the town or the recent arrivals who have helped revive its fortunes?
"I think it's the devil at work," said David Paulsen, 46, an Abstract Expressionist painter who moved here in 1994 from a loft in Brooklyn, partly for the natural beauty and partly because the rents were cheap. He said he would think about moving away again if the cement plant came to town.
Jim Sherman, 26, a Hudson native, said that as far as he was concerned, the people who were threatening to leave Hudson probably should. He just wants a cement plant job, he said, as his father had before him and his grandfather before that.
"I've already put in my application," he said.
The plant, proposed by a Canadian company, St. Lawrence Cement, presents a complex bundle of costs and benefits. It would replace an old and antiquated cement factory across the river in Catskill, and produce much less of the types of air pollution blamed for acid rain and smog. 
But the new plant would be four times larger. It would bring cement making back into Hudson, but with a technology that has changed greatly since the last plant closed here in 1975; cement plants no longer need the armies of workers they once did. It would feature high-tech air scrubbers, but the resulting smokestack, rising 40 stories above the limestone quarry, would be visible for miles. 
Meanwhile, the economic arc of Hudson has been going entirely the other way: toward art and tourism. As recently as the early 1990's, residents say, the city's downtown was a sad and sometimes frightening place of boarded-up buildings and aimless men. When Claude Carone moved here from New York City in the early 1990's to pursue his painting career, a three-story building could still be had for only $20,000. He and two friends bought one such place to use for their studios. Now the main shopping strip, Warren Street, is clogged with shoppers and chic new restaurants.
Art tourism has also thrived at Olana, the historic home of the artist Frederic Edwin Church, who built his mansion and landscaped grounds just a few miles south of here with the fortune he earned in the 1850's and 1860's from his gargantuan Hudson River School canvases. The home of Thomas Cole, who founded the Hudson River School and lived just across the river in Catskill, is being restored this summer as a museum and historic monument.
But there are many places the new economy has not touched. On Columbia Street, one block away from the thriving galleries, many houses remain run-down. Drugs and prostitution remain a problem, residents say. 
Jimmie C. Binford, a 57-year-old resident, was sitting outside on a recent sweltering afternoon having a beer with friends. He agreed that the plant would not do much for him personally, and probably would not add a lot of jobs to the community, either.(Most of the roughly 130 new jobs at the plant are expected to be taken by workers from the Catskill factory.) It might pollute and it might be noisy. But he supported it anyway, he said, for the future.
"That plant is for the kids coming up," he said.

A Required Stop for Artists
The view of Mount Merino, looking south from Hudson, became a required stop for any artist refining his or her skills in 19th-century landscape art. Mostly forgotten local painters like Henry Ary and the Parton brothers, Ernest and Arthur, lived only a few blocks from the place that became established as the ideal spot to set up an easel, just off Bay Road. Sanford Robinson Gifford grew up here and kept a studio even after he became famous down in New York City. The Merino view was painted on everything from pottery to furniture.
But when Don Christensen began assembling a museum exhibition here earlier this year showing how artists depicted Merino over the centuries, he kept stumbling over an odd phenomenon. Many of the artists had lied. 
South Bay, once a languid curve of the Hudson that lapped up on the shores just below Mount Merino, was being filled in bit by bit in the 1800's: by railroad lines and foundries, by dredging spoils from the river and by other long-defunct industries of various sorts. Many painters, however, simply left that development out of the picture. They painted South Bay as though it were still a pristine Arcadian sanctuary, where cows could drift down to the water to drink.
Mr. Christensen, a writer who opposes the cement plant -- he created the exhibition to remind people of the town's visual heritage -- said he found evidence from real-estate advertisements and railroad brochures suggesting that Merino's view was still a selling point in the town, even in the midst of its industrialization. But he still hasn't figured out what the artists were thinking.
The relationship of the Hudson River School and the Industrial Revolution is a subject that others have puzzled over before. Arnold Pickman, an archaeologist from New York who was researching the cultural history of Mount Merino and South Bay several years ago under a contract with the Army Corps of Engineers, ultimately concluded that by minimizing the impact of industrialization, the artists were tacitly approving of it. "They saw industrialization in harmony with nature," Mr. Pickman said. "The conflict is not expressed in most of these paintings." 
Officials at Scenic Hudson, a conservation group that opposes the cement plant, have argued on the other hand that omitting the evidence of Hudson's foundries and mills was an early environmentalist protest by the painters who -- in the spirit of Mr. Christensen's exhibit -- were showing people the landscapes being lost.
Other historians dismiss both theories. Leo Marx, a professor emeritus of American cultural studies at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the author of the book, "The Machine in the Garden: Technology and the Pastoral Ideal in America," said that things in the 19th century weren't as clear-cut as they are now. Most artists were not environmentalists as we would use the term, or economic boosters either, he said.
"Thomas Cole was terribly troubled by industrialization, but many other painters weren't," he said. Some were inspired by the ideas of Ralph Waldo Emerson, who asserted that the poet's role, or the painter's, was to reincorporate back into nature the sometimes messy trappings of human nature and so find a scene's inner beauty. 
"The artist sees beyond the surface ugliness," Professor Marx said. "That's the point. That's why he can dispose very easily of the most disagreeable facts."
Surface ugliness is one of the signature traits of a cement plant, as even its supporters admit. Officials at St. Lawrence said that part of their mission since coming to town here in 1999 was to work on their own plan of visual accommodation, if not quite deception. 
A new design was incorporated to try to bunch the plant's structures together to minimize their apparent bulk. A planned railroad link that would have required high-rise silos right on the river's edge was abandoned. The Air Force was consulted about how it painted its planes to make them harder to see against the sky. 
"We really tried to look at it as a piece of art," said Bob Bristol, the president of the Saratoga Associates, a landscape, architecture and engineering firm that has worked with St. Lawrence Cement. "What were the colors that would minimize its impact? How should it be coated? Should there be vegetation?"
Ultimately, a seven-shade color scheme of blues, grays and whites, based on the local atmospheric conditions, was selected for the high-rise stack and pipe system, Mr. Bristol said. The company's engineer in charge of the project is the first to admit that it doesn't entirely do the job.
"It doesn't hide it -- you can't do that -- but it does break it up a bit," said Phillip Lochbrunner, a vice president and a manager of the project.

The Past Is Prologue
The judge appointed to the St. Lawrence Cement plant case is expected to take months to consider the evidence before sending on her findings to the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Meanwhile, Hudson continues to evolve, and its past is still dictating the pattern.
The continuing strength of the economy to the south in New York City has meant a boom in the demand for cement, and it has also meant more tourist visits and art purchases, and more people ready and able to buy weekend homes two and a half hours north of the city. 
More construction and renovation work locally -- building and restoring homes and businesses -- has in turn meant more manual labor jobs than could have been imagined a few years ago, to the point at which the existing factories are struggling to find workers. Kaz Inc., a maker of health-care products, now features a banner outside its brick walls: Now Hiring.
And the presence of more working artists in the community has been a reminder that art, once common here and becoming so again, is also physical labor of a certain type, and that a lot of artists struggle hard to pay their bills.
Mr. Paulsen, the Abstract Expressionist painter, said he worked construction to support himself. He has learned taping and plastering over the years, he said, along with framing, plumbing, basic wiring and putting up wallboard. And with the local building economy booming, he said, he has to turn away work to allow himself time to paint.
"Anybody that can screw in a light bulb can get a job," he said.

In Art's Footsteps
The paintings of the Hudson River School are portraits of the Northeast, captured at a time when 19th-century America was re-examining its ideas about nature. The landscapes helped spur tourism and environmentalism. 
This is the fourth of 10 summer articles in which The New York Times returns to the places illuminated by Hudson River School artists. In the fifth article, seamen at the Coast Guard Station at Eaton's Neck on Long Island carry on a tradition of ocean rescue dating to the mid-19th century, and like the shimmering scene that John F. Kensett painted there on the beach, the elements are still timeless: youth, optimism, patriotism, and above all, the endless golden glow of high summer.

HEADLINE: Corporate Profits in Big Drop As Personal Spending Rises 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29 

 BODY:
Corporate profits shriveled as the economy barely limped ahead in the first quarter, the government reported today, but a brightening mood among consumers implied that a recession might be averted.
 The Commerce Department lowered its estimate of growth in gross domestic product in the first quarter to an anemic annual rate of 1.2 percent, from 1.3 percent. That was not much ahead of the 1 percent rate of advance in the fourth quarter of 2000. 
 G.D.P. measures total national economic output within United States borders.
Companies' profits after paying taxes shrank at a 6.2 percent rate, or by $39 billion a year in the first quarter, twice the pace estimated a month ago. It was the steepest quarterly decline in profits in three years and came after a 4.3 percent decline in the fourth quarter.
The decline in corporate profits has been one reason the Federal Reserve has cut interest rates six times this year. Companies invest less in new plants and equipment and lay more people off when their profits are pressed, lifting risks of recession. A recession is typically defined as two quarters or more of declining national output. 
The report today, however, contained some optimistic signs about consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of national economic activity. More of that appeared later in a private-sector survey of consumer sentiment.
The personal consumption expenditure component of the gross domestic product gained at a relatively healthy 3.4 percent annual rate during the first quarter instead of the 2.9 percent previously estimated. That was up from a 2.8 percent rate of growth in the fourth quarter and showed that shoppers were still in the stores.
A separate report, on the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, showed a gain for a second month in June, rising to 92.6 from 92.0 in May. 
"This is the type of reading we would expect to see as the economy turns into a recovery," said Drew Matus, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York.
The findings suggest that as government tax rebates begin to flow in July and as marginal tax rates fall, consumers may spend the money and keep the economy churning out goods and services.
Another report released today showed that weakness in manufacturing in the Midwest might be bottoming out. The Chicago purchasing managers index for June was 44.4, topping forecasts for a reading of 39.3 and well ahead of 38.7 in May. "This rise could indicate the worst is over," the National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said.
A broader countrywide survey to be issued by the group on Monday will be closely scanned for signs that the hard-pressed industrial sector is on the mend.
Some analysts say the economy may have contracted, or come close to it, during the second quarter, which ends on Saturday. The government will not release its estimate of second-quarter G.D.P. for another month, but private-sector analysts speculate that a sharp scaling back in business investment may have halted the economic expansion during the April-June period.

HEADLINE: U.S. Report Finds Flaws in Study Of California Power Companies 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29 

 BODY:
An investigative arm of Congress faulted federal regulators today for claiming that there was no evidence to support accusations that power companies manipulated California's electricity market.
 The General Accounting Office reviewed a study by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission issued in February. The energy agency found no evidence that companies withheld power to drive up prices. 
 Politicians in California and some economists have been asserting for months that power companies withheld available electrical generating capacity to create or worsen shortages. Generating companies had cited the energy agency's report to rebut those accusations.
The accounting office said the agency's work looked only at physical reasons for outages and did not explore the possibility that generating companies used bidding strategies to withhold supplies. Moreover, the office found that the study did not prove that cutoffs had occurred for unavoidable physical reasons.
"FERC's study was not thorough enough to support its overall conclusion that audited companies were not physically withholding electricity supply to influence prices," the accounting office said.
The office said that industry experts it consulted agreed it was "practically impossible" to determine whether cutoffs were justified merely by examining physical evidence because plants frequently ran with some physical problems.
The accounting office's study comes a week after three former employees of Duke Energy, a leading generator in California, told the State Legislature that the company shut production units to drive up prices.
The energy agency has an obligation under federal law to ensure "just and reasonable" electricity prices. It has found that electricity prices in California have not met that standard, but recently it began imposing price controls.
Some analysts have said they suspected generating companies kept generating units off-line, limiting competition and forcing California's grid operator to pay stratospheric prices to avoid blackouts. The accusations were supported by circumstantial evidence that showed supplies of electricity declining this year when compared with the year before.
Generating companies have said they are doing all they can to run aging power plants at full capacity to meet demand. They say they shut units only for routine maintenance.
The energy agency conducted inspections and telephone inquiries at several California generating plants. It found the cutoffs were justified.
Curt Hebert Jr., the energy agency's chairman, wrote a letter to the accounting office, saying he agreed with its "basic findings." But he said his agency's study was never intended to examine all accusations of withholding but only to explore whether price manipulation had occurred in the few cases that were examined.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Reassess Snowmobile Ban in a Park 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29 

 BODY:
The Interior Department said today that it would reconsider a Clinton administration plan to ban snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park.
 The decision prompted an outcry from environmentalists, who contend that snowmobiles damage the park, threaten wildlife and ruin the park experience. 
 The Clinton administration ordered the ban to go into effect starting in November 2002 and be in full force by 2004. The ban was strongly opposed by snowmobile makers, who filed suit in Wyoming to halt it. 
Today's announcement is a settlement of that lawsuit, which will need the approval of Judge Clarence A. Brimmer of Federal District Court in Cheyenne, Wyo., to become final. 
The Departments of Interior and Justice filed papers today in Cheyenne that instruct the National Park Service to conduct a supplemental environmental impact statement on the matter. The park service's original impact statement in 2000 formed the basis of the Clinton administration's decision to order the ban.
A senior Interior Department official said that the new assessment would simply allow the department to make a more informed decision and that it would do no harm since the ban was not to go into effect for another 18 months. But both the snowmobile industry and environmentalists saw today's announcement as tantamount to scrapping the ban.
The settlement, a product of months of negotiations between the government and the snowmobile makers and the Wyoming State Snowmobile Association, is the latest in a series that have the potential to reverse Clinton-era environmental policies. The administration announced last week, for example, that it would abandon a Clinton plan to reintroduce grizzly bears in the West. 
The snowmobile industry believes that with a new review process, it can persuade the administration that technology has made snowmobiles cleaner and quieter than they were during the 2000 assessment.
Doug Burdin, a lawyer for the International Snowmobile Manufacturers Association, said: "We just think this administration will be more receptive to a more reasonable approach than the prior administration."
In a statement, the Interior Department said that the Clinton administration had rushed the ban through and that a new review would allow comment from those whose voices "weren't sufficiently heard."
"This administration feels strongly that greater local input, new information, scientific data and economic analysis and wider public involvement can only lead to better, more informed decisions," said the statement, from Mark Pfeifle, the Interior Department spokesman.
Environmental groups disputed the idea that the Clinton administration's process had run roughshod over the snowmobile industry. Snowmobiles have been allowed in Yellowstone for 30 years, and their use has been under re-evaluation since 1990, including two dozen public hearings in the last three years, which yielded more than 71,000 public comments.
"They want another study to study what has been studied for 13 years," said Jon Catton, a spokesman for the Greater Yellowstone Coalition, an environmental group.
The park service was not part of the settlement, and Yellowstone's former superintendent, Michael V. Finley, who resigned in May, is an outspoken critic of snowmobiles.
"Had the park been asked, we would have resisted settlement and sought a vigorous defense," Mr. Finley said in a speech this month to environmentalists gathered in West Yellowstone.
"This is the first time that the opinion of the park was not sought or solicited or considered by an administration," Mr. Finley said.
The decision affects Yellowstone, Grand Teton National Park and the John D. Rockefeller Memorial Highway between the two. It is Yellowstone, however, that has been the capital of snowmobiling, with 83,548 people riding on snowmobiles in the last three-month season.
Under the settlement, the park service is to publish a draft supplemental impact statement by Jan. 21, 2002, and provide any modifications by March 15, 2002.

U.N. War Crimes Tribunal Expands Milosevic Charges
The war crimes tribunal in The Hague issued an expanded indictment against Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, charging him with additional atrocities and naming more victims of war crimes during the 1999 conflict in Kosovo. Carla Del Ponte, the chief prosecutor, pressed for the arrest of 38 other people indicted for war crimes who are still at large. A7

Prime Minister Zoran Zizic, the leader of the Montenegrin faction in the Yugoslav government, which was allied with Mr. Milosevic, announced his resignation after meeting with President Vojislav Kostunica. Mr. Zizic warned that "Yugoslavia is at the beginning of a crisis." A7

HEADLINE: Upper Manhattan Loan Program Gets a Three-Month Reprieve 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
A loan program for fledgling Upper Manhattan businesses that had been threatened with extinction won a three-month reprieve yesterday.
 City and state officials agreed to award $500,000 to the small-business program, known as the Business Resource and Investment Service Center, or Brisc, so that it can complete the four loans that are in the pipeline. 
But no new loans will be authorized. 
 The program, a unit of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, which is a $250 million federal, state and city economic development program, has come under attack in recent months. In six years, it has issued only 38 loans totaling $3 million and yet has cost an additional $4.9 million to operate.
The state will see how it measures up to similar programs for people without previous business experience, said Kevin S. Corbett, the chief operating officer of the Empire State Development Corporation, at yesterday's quarterly meeting of the board that oversees the Empowerment Zone.
Supporters of the program have sought to justify the slow lending pace by saying that it is hard to find qualified borrowers in communities served by the Empowerment Zone, like Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood.
State officials said after the meeting, however, that their preliminary study suggested that the program did not measure up to other so-called community development financial institutions in the region or across the country.
But Terry C. Lane, the president of the Empowerment Zone, said that the program had steadily increased its loan output and provided technical assistance to 13,387 people.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Technology Shares Advance Despite Technical Glitches

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Technology stocks advanced again yesterday, as the market continued to celebrate Microsoft's appeals court victory in its antitrust fight with the government.
 But technical glitches held up trading of Nasdaq stocks, prompting the exchange to extend its trading an hour, to 5 p.m., and delayed the compilation of major market indexes. 
 The Nasdaq composite index closed up 35.08 points, or 1.65 percent, at 2,160.54. 
Blue chips, meanwhile, gave back some of their gains made Thursday, when investors had a delayed positive response to the Federal Reserve's sixth interest rate cut of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 63.81 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 10,502.40. 
Wall Street's broadest measure, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, fell 1.82 points, or 0.15 percent, to 1,224.38. 
 On the last day of a dismal quarter, one that was marred by more than 600 profit warnings, analysts said the market was beginning to look ahead. With six interest rate cuts this year -- the latest delivered Wednesday -- investors seem to believe that business could turn around in the second half of the year.
 "We are seeing signs that the economy is stabilizing, and that is great news," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "And what we are seeing vis-a-vis Microsoft is that the current administration is pro-business, and that's good. That combination of news is going to spark a summer rally."
 Technology stocks continued to benefit by association with Microsoft. But the software maker retreated slightly from its gains of Thursday, when a federal appeals court reversed a lower court ruling ordering the breakup of the company. Microsoft, part of the Dow industrial average, gained 26 cents, to $73.
 Technology advancers included Hewlett-Packard, which rose $1.35, to $28.60, and Intel, which fell 39 cents, to $29.25.
 But the Dow's gain was severely limited by Honeywell. It tumbled $3.30, to $34.90, after proposing to reduce the price of General Electric's takeover offer by more than $1 billion and to sell off units worth $2.1 billion to win the necessary approval from the European Union.
 John F. Welch, the chief executive of G.E., rejected the proposal, saying it made no sense for shareholders and that it still fell short of what European Union regulators were seeking. G.E. gained 13 cents, to $49.
 Investors have been alternately skittish about earnings and the economy and optimistic that business will improve in the second half of the year. They were disappointed Wednesday by the Fed, which lowered interest rates by a quarter point, half the size many on Wall Street wanted.
 But after thinking about the Fed's move, analysts said the market saw the smaller cut as a sign that the economy was improving.
 "All the economic data over the last few weeks has been better than expected, and that shows a trend that things are getting better," Mr. Hogan of Jefferies said.
He was also encouraged by a string of stronger-than-expected reports, including two released yesterday. The Chicago Purchasing Management Association reported its June index rose to 44.4 from 38.7 in May.
Another positive for the economy came from the University of Michigan's report on consumer sentiment, which was reported to have risen to 92.6 in June from 92 in May.
In the bond market, Treasury prices fell. The 10-year Treasury note fell 18/32, to a price of 97. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.40 percent from 5.33 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 16/32, to 94 20/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.76 percent from 5.67 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Lobbying Is in Full Swing From Microsoft and Rivals
As federal and state prosecutors ponder what to do next with Microsoft, they have already come under enormous lobbying pressure from the company to quickly settle and from its rivals, most notably AOL Time Warner, to continue litigating.
 The lobbying campaign was in full swing even before the decision by a federal court of appeals on Thursday that vacated the order to break up Microsoft but also found that the company had engaged in a raft of anticompetitive practices. Page A1. 

Microsoft Celebration Continues
Microsoft made further gains yesterday, and other technology stocks continued to advance, in celebration of the software company's appeals court victory in its antitrust fight with the government. Technical problems caused a delay in trading on Nasdaq. The Nasdaq composite index closed up 35.08 points, or 1.7 percent, to 2,160.54. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 63.81 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 10,502.40. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.82 points, to 1,224.38. C3.

Patients' Rights Bill Clears Senate
Defying a veto threat from President Bush, the Senate passed a bill that would establish a range of patients' rights for more than 200 million Americans with health insurance. A1.

TMP Worldwide in Deal for HotJobs
TMP Worldwide, parent of Monster.com, the job search Web site, said it would buy its rival, HotJobs.com, for $460 million in stock. C2.

Primedia Said to Be Near Deal
Primedia, which publishes Seventeen and New York, is said to be near a deal to buy Emap's U.S. magazine unit for $515 million. C3.

Surplus Is Seen Dwindling Quickly
The Bush administration raised the possibility that the slowing economy could drive the federal budget surplus down this year by more than the government has previously estimated, perhaps by enough to create a budget deficit by the strictest of definitions. A1.

Investment Banker Pleads Guilty
James J. McDermott, 50, the former chief executive of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods whose conviction for stock fraud and conspiracy was thrown out by a federal appeals court in March, pleaded guilty to one charge of insider trading as part of a plea agreement to avoid further prison time and a new trial. C14.

Russia Takes Control Over Gazprom
Russia took control of Gazprom after its shareholders voted to give government representatives 6 out of 11 board seats. C2.

The Face of Corporate Kidnapping
The face of corporate kidnapping in the 21st century is money -- large sums demanded by kidnappers who know what international corporations have been willing to pay to save their workers. The employers, in turn, take out large insurance policies to defray this cost of doing business in the developing world. Specialists estimate that more than $500 million a year goes to pay off professional bands of kidnappers, mostly in South America. A1.

G.A.O. Faults Energy Regulators
The General Accounting Office faulted federal energy regulators for claiming that there was no evidence to support assertions that power companies manipulated the electricity market in California. A9.

G.D.P. Revised to 1.2% Annual Rate
The Commerce Department lowered its estimate of growth in the gross domestic product during the first quarter to an anemic annual rate of 1.2 percent from 1.3 percent. Corporate profits shriveled, but a brightening mood among consumers implied a recession might be averted. C3.

HEADLINE: Transforming Trust into Trade 

BYLINE:  By Mikhail S. Gorbachev; Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet president, heads the Gorbachev Foundation, a research institute.

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
Not only because of the recent summit in Ljubljana, but from my own discussions with both Vladimir Putin and George W. Bush, I have a new optimism about the future of relations between the United States and Russia. Unlike the hawks in Washington and Moscow who would like to put Russian-American relations on the foreign policy back burner, these two presidents understand the importance of the relationship.
 Now, for the first time in years the word "trust" has been heard in our dialogue. The predecessors of Mr. Putin and Mr. Bush shied away from that word out of excessive concern for their domestic political foes. But it was not just the word that fell into disuse; trust itself had begun to erode. 
 Something else was said at the summit: Russia and the United States are not enemies. Continuing to emphasize this truth is of crucial importance.
So, should we now just rejoice and wait for the new presidents' new style to be translated into concrete deeds? I don't think so. We cannot afford to wait, because we have very little time to make things work -- and also because it is only too clear that the words about trust and partnership are already being used by some in the United States as a rhetorical screen, with transparent and pernicious aims.
I am greatly worried by the attempts of some American commentators -- in politics and the press -- to hinge the entire Russian-American relationship on two goals: deploying a missile defense system and enlarging the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The subtext is: if, to achieve these goals, we must sometimes talk nice to the Russians, let's do so. The same pundits and politicians are equally blunt about consultations with American allies and partners: we can talk, but in the end we shall do what's good for us.
One would have to be very naive to think that such a strategy would not be resisted. If this attitude were to become United States policy, the Start 1 and Start 2 treaties would fall apart. Russia would put multiple warheads on its intercontinental missiles. A new round of the nuclear arms race and of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction would be inevitable.
Instead of jeopardizing global security, we must pursue policies and find solutions that are mutually acceptable. Such solutions cannot be found if security issues, important as they are, are the only item on the Russian-American agenda.
Perhaps the greatest failure during the 1990's was that Russia and the United States did not lay a groundwork for business and trade. Our relations are much the worse for it -- in contrast to those between the United States and China, for which economic ties act as a powerful stabilizer.
I am convinced that a breakthrough in Russian-American business relationships is possible in high technology, information and telecommunications, and science-based products. Of course, it is for the private business of the two countries to lead the way, but to get things off the ground, governments must act, and not necessarily through bureaucratic structures or commissions. The important thing is that our entrepreneurs should feel support, should see that obstacles are being removed.
Clearly, there must be major changes in the Russian economy: a favorable investment climate, stable and predictable taxation, a genuine effort to fight corruption. A start has been made. What's primarily needed from the United States is a signal from the Bush administration that doing business with Russia is in the national interest of the United States. I understand that, as agreed by the two presidents, a large delegation of American businessmen will soon be visiting Russia. 
In Ljubljana, Mr. Putin and Mr. Bush agreed on a mechanism for consultations on strategic stability. At their next summit, in Genoa, they should agree on how to give an impetus to trade and commerce between the United States and Russia.

HEADLINE: BILL ESTABLISHING PATIENTS' RIGHTS PASSES IN SENATE 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29 

 BODY:
Defying a veto threat from President Bush, the Senate tonight passed a bill that would establish a wide range of patients' rights for more than 200 million Americans with health insurance.
 The bill would, for the first time, set detailed federal standards for private health insurance and would allow patients to file suit, in federal or state court, to enforce their rights. 
 The vote was 59 to 36. Nine Republicans joined 50 Democrats in voting for the legislation. Thirty-five Republicans and the one independent, James M. Jeffords of Vermont, voted against it. 
The bill goes now to the House of Representatives, where Republican leaders hope to address Mr. Bush's concern about the possibility of a huge increase in lawsuits. 
But Democrats and some Republican champions of patients' rights, led by Representative Charlie Norwood of Georgia, said they would resist any changes that weaken protections for patients or the patients' right to sue health maintenance organizations for decisions that cause injury or death.
After the vote, President Bush said the Senate had made some improvements in the bill so it "more closely reflects my principles" than did the original version. But Mr. Bush said: "The Senate failed to address the danger that excessive, unlimited litigation in state courts would drive up premium costs and cause many American families to lose their health insurance. I could not in good conscience sign this bill because it puts the interests of trial lawyers before the interest of patients."
Today's vote was a big victory for the new Democratic majority in the Senate; for the majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, and for Bill Clinton, who as president started the push for patients' rights in 1997, after the failure of his earlier effort to guarantee health coverage for all Americans.
In his debut as majority leader, Mr. Daschle insisted that the Senate finish work on the patients' rights bill before going home for the Fourth of July, and in two weeks of debate, he kept up pressure on the Senate to achieve that goal.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, a sponsor of the bill passed tonight, said: "At long last, the Senate has acted to protect patients and doctors. This is a giant step forward in giving power to the powerless, the victims of exploitation by H.M.O.'s." 
Republicans said the bill did nothing to help the 43 million Americans who lack health insurance. Indeed, Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, said, "The bill will drive up health care costs and result in a lot of people losing their health insurance."
Public opinion polls have repeatedly shown support for tighter regulation of H.M.O.'s, and Mr. Bush embraced the concept in last year's presidential campaign. The standards being drafted by Congress represent a major expansion in federal authority over an industry that has been regulated by the states for more than a half-century.
Insurers have vehemently resisted federal regulation. But a tide of discontent with managed care evidently overwhelmed the arguments made by the industry, in a multimillion-dollar campaign of lobbying and advertising.
Senate Democrats beat back every significant Republican challenge to their bill, making compromises where necessary to win the votes of moderate Republicans.
The Republicans who supported the bill were Senators Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, Susan Collins of Maine, Mike DeWine of Ohio, Peter G. Fitzgerald of Illinois, John McCain of Arizona, Gordon H. Smith of Oregon, Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and John W. Warner of Virginia.
Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, asked today: "Why pass something just so the president can end up vetoing it? If this bill is sent to the president, he will veto it, and we'll end up with nothing." 
Mr. McCain of Arizona, the main Republican sponsor of the bill, said tonight: "We will do everything we can, within our power, to get a bill that the president will sign. Without betraying our principles, we can work with the White House, work with House members, and get a bill the president can sign." 
Mr. Daschle urged Mr. Bush to reconsider his veto threat. "We've made a lot of improvements, a lot of changes the president should find to his liking," Mr. Daschle said.
For example, Democrats said, the bill was amended to shield most employers from lawsuits and to require that most patients go through a process of administrative appeals, with an independent medical review of their claims, before filing suit against a health insurance plan. 
The Senate today also adopted a Republican amendment that limits class-action lawsuits. When Mr. Bush threatened to veto the original Senate bill last week, he said it provided "no effective limitations on frivolous class-action suits."
Today's vote was also a victory for the sponsors of the bill, the Bipartisan Patient Protection Act: Senators Kennedy, McCain and John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina.
In a tribute to the maverick Republican, Mr. Daschle said: "We could not have done this without John McCain. John was extremely helpful and remarkably courageous."
The two-week struggle over patients' rights vividly illustrates the difference made by the shift in control of the Senate from Republicans to Democrats earlier this month. Democrats used the power of the majority to set the Senate's agenda, to structure the debate and to keep up pressure for a final vote. 
The Senate passed patients' rights bills twice before, in July 1999 and in June 2000. This time, Democrats said, their majority status gave them a big tactical advantage: Democrats laid down their bill, and Republicans had to show what was wrong with it. In the past, Democrats had the burden of showing what was wrong with a bill written by Republicans.
President Bush and Republicans in Congress said repeatedly that the Senate bill would cause explosive growth in lawsuits against health plans, so that insurance premiums would rise and employers would drop coverage for their employees.
"It could result in a massive increase in the number of uninsured, which is the No. 1 problem in our country," said Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania. But the argument did not seem to resonate, Republicans said, or at least it did not appear to shift many votes.
Democrats said the Republicans did not have much credibility as guardians of the uninsured. For years, the Democrats said, Republicans resisted costly, ambitious schemes to expand coverage through new federal health programs. In recent years, Republicans have proposed new tax breaks to help people buy insurance and have enthusiastically supported the new Children's Health Insurance Program.
Democrats and Republicans in the Senate and the House agree on the core of the Senate bill: substantive guarantees intended to make sure that sick people with insurance receive the care ordered by their doctors, without interference by insurance company clerks.
Under the bill, patients could get emergency care at the nearest hospital, regardless of whether it was affiliated with their health plan. H.M.O.'s would have to give patients prompt access to medical specialists. Women could visit obstetricians and gynecologists without a referral or prior authorization. An H.M.O. would have to cover any hospital stay deemed necessary by a doctor caring for a woman after a mastectomy. Doctors would be free to discuss all treatment options with patients, regardless of whether the treatments were covered by a health plan.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that these provisions guaranteeing "access to care" would eventually increase insurance premiums by 2 percent. But sponsors of the bill said the guarantees would also improve the quality of care.
While senators of both parties endorsed these standards, they disagreed on questions of enforcement: Should the federal standards override existing state laws? When should patients be allowed to sue -- in what court, for what reasons, subject to what limits on damages? 
Democrats insisted, as Mr. Daschle said, that "a right without a remedy is no right at all."
By a vote of 98 to 0, the Senate today approved a proposal that generally requires patients to exhaust their administrative appeals before they can file suit against an H.M.O. 
However, under the proposal, offered by Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, a patient could go to court if an independent medical reviewer failed to rule on an appeal within 31 days.
Under the bill, patients could sue insurers in state court, for medical decisions, or in federal court, for administrative decisions on such questions as whether a part-time employee is eligible for coverage. 
In federal court, there would be no limit on damage awards for economic losses or pain and suffering, and plaintiffs could recover up to $5 million in "civil assessments" resembling punitive damages for flagrant violations of their rights. In state court, damages would be subject to the limits of state law, if any exist.
The Senate tonight rejected a proposal to set strict limits on damages, as President Bush has demanded. The proposal would have allowed new lawsuits only in federal court, with no punitive damages and with a $750,000 limit on payments for pain and suffering.
In its original form, the Senate bill would have provided protections to most Americans with private health insurance. Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader, said it was hypocritical for Congress to exclude federal health programs. The Senate today approved Mr. Nickles's proposal to include federal employees and people enrolled in Medicare and Medicaid, the programs for the elderly, the disabled and the poor.
Final numbers were not immediately available. But the Senate bill now appears to cover almost all of the 231 million Americans with health insurance coverage from any source. 
At first, most Republicans opposed any new right for patients to sue H.M.O.'s, but eventually many decided that patients should have a limited new right. Consumer groups and doctors said that H.M.O.'s should be held accountable in court, like doctors, because health plans were making medical decisions.
Democrats said the prospect of lawsuits would prompt health plans to approve many claims that they now deny.
"Nothing persuades an H.M.O. to do the right thing like the fear of liability if they do the wrong thing," Mr. Kennedy said.
